headline: Sri Lanka Soldiers Kill 10 Tamil Guerrillas C
abstract: Government security forces said today that they had killed 10 Tamil separatist guerrillas in a jungle battle in eastern Sri Lanka.

headline: ARREST OF CLERIC PROTESTED BY U.S.
abstract: The United States said today that it had formally protested to South Africa over the arrest of Dr. Allan Boesak, the anti-apartheid activist.   ''We believe that the detention of the Rev. Boesak and other leaders can only exacerbate the current cycle of polarization and tension,'' said Charles E. Redman, a State Department spokesman.   The protest, delivered to the South African Foreign Ministry, was meant to underscore the Administration's continuing irritation with the policies and tactics being followed by the Pretoria Government since it invoked emergency laws last month.

headline: Park to Purchase 2 Radio Stations
abstract: Capital Cities Communications Inc. said that it had agreed to sell WPAT-AM and WPAT-FM, which broadcast to the New York City area from Paterson, N.J., to Park Communications Inc. Terms were not disclosed.

headline: First Interstate
abstract: First Interstate Bancorp sold $100 million of five-year extendible notes. The notes, which carry a final maturity of Aug. 15, 2000, were won at competitive bid by Shearson Lehman Brothers. They were reoffered with a 9.70 percent coupon at a price of 99.583 to yield 9.80 percent. The offering has been rated A-minus by McCarthy, Crisanti & Maffei, AA-2 by Moody's and AA by S.& P.

headline: Prosecution in Aquino Trial Will Appeal a Ruling on Ver
abstract: Prosecutors in the Benigno S. Aquino Jr. assasination case said today that they would appeal to the Philippine Supreme Court to reverse the trial court's rejection of evidence against Gen. Fabian C. Ver, the suspended Philippine Chief of Staff, and seven others charged with a cover-up in the killing of the opposition leader.   The chief prosecutor, Bernardo Fernandez, said at a news conference at the end of the trial session today that the appeal was ''to the best interests of the public.''

headline: Advertising;   New York Air Moves Account to Levine
abstract: New York Air has ended its two-year relationship with the Bloom Agency Inc. and moved its account to Levine, Huntley, Schmidt & Beaver Inc. in New York. But, almost making up for that loss, the agency's Dallas office has won additional business from an existing client, Campbell Taggart Inc., the baked goods subsidiary of Anheuser-Busch Companies.   The agency, which already handles Campbell Taggart's Earth Grains line, has also been awarded its Rainbo, Colonial, Kilpatrick's, Roman Meal, Country Hearth, Family Recipes, Grant's Farm and Hollywood brands. They were previously handled by the St. Louis office of D'Arcy MacManus Masius.

headline: Filipinos Plan Protests; Army Goes on Full Alert
abstract: The Philippine Army was placed on full alert today as anti-Government activists called for strikes and a mock trial of President Ferdinand E. Marcos to mark the 13th anniversary Saturday of the declaration of martial law.   Military headquarters said Lieut. Gen. Fidel Ramos, the nation's military chief, also ordered regional commanders to adopt measures to prevent Communist rebels from using the demonstrations to promote violence.

headline: Hungarian, at the U.N., Meets With Israeli Foreign Minister
abstract: The Foreign Ministers of Israel and Hungary met today for the first time since 1967, when Hungary broke diplomatic relations after the Middle East war, an Israeli diplomat said today.   He said the 30-minute meeting at the United Nations between Yitzhak Shamir, the Foreign Minister of Israel, and Peter Varkonyi, the Foreign Minister of Hungary, was marked by a ''cordial'' atmosphere.   The Hungarian indicated his nation was willing to expand trade, sports and cultural contacts, the diplomat said.

headline: Southern Edison
abstract: The Southern California Edison Company denied charges by the California Public Utilities Commission that it overspent $762 million on the construction of two nuclear power plants.

headline: New UA Will Start As 'Shell Company'
abstract: Kirk Kerkorian is likely to continue his role in Hollywood motion picture production through United Artists after the rest of the MGM/UA Entertainment Company is sold to Turner Broadcasting Systems Inc. But how big a factor United Artists will be is not known.   An MGM/UA spokesman, Arthur E. Rockwell, said today that the new United Artists would have none of the personnel or production facilities now at MGM/UA.   ''United Artists will start as a shell company, with its film library and a half-interest in MGM/UA's distribution company,'' Mr. Rockwell said. ''A production schedule has not yet been determined.''

headline: ACAPULCO FELT MILD TREMOR
abstract: The earthquake that wrecked much of Mexico City rippled through this coastal resort with a mild tremor that the authorities said had caused no casualties and no damage.   Beyond Acapulco, however, in the surrounding state of Guerrero, there were scattered episodes of violent upheaval that the authorities said left two dead and 36 injured.

headline: The U.N. Today: Aug. 15, 1985
abstract: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Decolonization Committee - 3 P.M.

headline: Ex-Official Installed As Uganda's Premier
abstract: Paulo Muwanga, who was Vice President and Defense Minister under the ousted President, Milton Obote, was sworn in today as Prime Minister of the military Government that seized power in a coup five days ago.

headline: U.N. COUNCIL AGREES ON NEED TO IMPROVE
abstract: A special commemorative session of the Security Council, its first at the ministerial level in 15 years, approved a unanimous declaration today that recognizing the ''urgent need to enhance the effectiveness of the Security Council.''   The declaration was read by Sir Geoffrey Howe, the British Foreign Secretary, who was the Council President. It did not specify how the Security Council could be made more effective. But it resolved to continue to examine ''possibilities for further improvement of the functioning of the Security Council in carrying out its work in accordance with the Charter.''

headline: G.E. Aide To Police Contracts
abstract: John D. Peterson is the only person at the General Electric Company with his own ''800'' number to receive phone calls. And he is the only person at the company with an impersonal box number to get mail.   In May, G.E. admitted that its space systems division had overcharged the Air Force and the company was fined $1.04 million and ordered to pay back $800,000 that was falsely billed. After than, John Welch, G.E.'s chairman, instituted a number of new policies to try to foil future transgressions. One of his actions was to appoint a corporate ombudsman who could lend an ear to whistle blowers. John Peterson got the job.

headline: Article 107428 -- No Title
abstract: The Kaypro Corporation, citing inventory valuation changes, reported yesterday that it had a loss of $6.2 million in the third fiscal quarter of 1985 in contrast to earnings of $3.2 million, or 9 cents a share, in the corresponding three months a year earlier.   Sales shrank 48.1 percent, to $16.7 million, from $32.2 million.

headline: THE EXECUTIVE COMPUTER;  NUMBER CRUNCHING ON THE MACINTOSH
abstract: SOFTWARE is what sells hardware, except perhaps to the most dedicated of techies. The classic success story of the little software engine that could concerns Visicalc, the first computerized spreadsheet, or electronic worksheet, for number crunchers. Back in the early days of personal computing, Visicalc saved Apple from the fate of being just another pretty computer in the burgeoning hobby marketplace, and turned it into a machine that business executives across the country began scooping up.  Visicalc is history now, but in a sense its publisher, Visicorp, is a phoenix reborn. It has been merged into Paladin Software, which recently released the new spreadsheet Crunch ($295 for the Macintosh from the Paladin Software Corporation, San Jose, Calif., 95134, (408) 970-7300). Paladin, one assumes, hopes that its new product will come charging out of the West to become as popular with Macintosh users as Visicalc was with Apple II buyers.  Paladin is not alone in going after the Mac's potential spreadsheet market. In fact, this market niche is suddenly beginning to fill up, although much later than predicted, with Ensemble, Excel, Jazz and a number of other competitive packages dribbling into the stores at the same time. Crunch, however, is the program that adheres most closely to the standard so pretentiously dubbed the ''Macintosh philosophy.'' Anyone who likes icons is going to love Crunch.

headline: T.W.A. PILOTS IN PACT WITH ICAHN ON CONCESSIONS
abstract: The Air Line Pilots Association said yesterday that it had entered into an agreement with the New York investor Carl C. Icahn under which the union would give pay and benefit reductions of up to 20 percent if he acquired control of Trans World Airlines.   Robert J. Joedicke, the airline analyst for Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc., said in an interview that the agreement puts Mr. Icahn in a strong position to make an alternative offer for T.W.A. To escape an earlier attempt by Mr. Icahn to buy the airline for $18 a share, T.W.A. agreed on June 14 to be acquired by the Texas Air Corporation, parent of Continental Airlines and New York Air, in a cash-and-stock transaction valued at $925 million, or $23 a share.   ''This makes it attractive for Icahn to make another bid but it will have to be something better than the Texas Air bid,'' Mr. Joedicke added.

headline: Loss Widens At Pan Am
abstract: The Pan Am Corporation, parent company of Pan American World Airways, said yesterday that it lost $72 million in the second quarter, compared with a loss of $49.8 million in the 1984 period. Revenues were $868.1 million, down 5.7 percent from $917.5 million a year ago.

headline: Still in the F.D.I.C. Running
abstract: It has been 15 months since William M. Isaac's term as chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation expired. And it has been almost three months since the Reagan Administration began circulating the name of William Seidman, dean of the University of Arizona Business School, as Mr. Isaac's successor.

headline: JWT Profits Off
abstract: The JWT Group reported yesterday that its second-quarter net income was off 6.5 percent, to $5.8 million, or 62 cents a share, compared with $6.2 million, or 68 cents a share, a year earlier. Revenues were up 10.5 percent, to $141.5 million, from $128.1 million for the 1984 period.

headline: HALL & CO. STAKE
abstract: Martin Sosnoff and the Atalanta/ Sosnoff Capital Corporation told the Securities and Exchange Commission they had bought 885,700 shares, or 5.6 percent, of the stock of Frank B. Hall & Company between July 23 and Aug. 23. The stock was bought at prices ranging from $29.527 a share to $31.437 a share, for a total price of $27.2 million. The purchases were solely for investment purposes.

headline: STARTS OF HOUSING SHOW RISE OF 1.9%
abstract: Construction starts of single-family houses fell in June, but a surge in buildings with five or more units sent overall housing starts up by 1.9 percent, the Government said today.   The rise, to an annual rate of 1.7 million units, contrasted with a decline of nearly 14 percent the previous month.   Welcome as the overall increase was, some housing analysts were disappointed that lagging single-family starts held the figure down.

headline: Taiwan Seizes Magazines
abstract: The authorities have seized 81,000 copies of seven opposition magazines, officials said today. The officials said the magazines were seized in two raids Friday because they included articles that confused public opinion.

headline: Apple Review Of Chairman
abstract: Steven P. Jobs, chairman and co-founder of Apple Computer Inc., has recruited five Apple employees to join him in forming a new company, he told Apple last week. As a result, the Apple board is reviewing his status with the company, a spokesman said.

headline: U.S. in Steel Accord
abstract: The United States reached an agreement with the European Economic Community today on steel exports to this country.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: Debt Issues    * Ampad Corp. has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for $25 million of convertible subordinated debentures due 2010 through underwriters led by Kidder, Peabody.    * ARA Holding Co. is offering $150 million of 13 3/4 percent resettable subordinated notes due 1995 at a price of 100 through Goldman, Sachs as sole underwriter. Interest is payable semiannually until 1990 when it will be reset, unless the entire issue is redeemed by the company, to 4 1/2 percent above the 5-year Treasury note and subject to a minimum rate of 13 percent.

headline: A Guilty Plea in G.E. Case
abstract: The former manager of systems engineering for the General Electric Company's Re-entry division pleaded guilty today to two counts of making false statements to the Federal Government, just hours after three former colleagues pleaded not guilty to charges of fraud involving military contracts.   Richard S. Davis, 53 years old, of Springfield, Pa., nodded and said ''Yes, sir'' each time Federal District Judge Louis Bechtle asked him if he knew what he was doing in making his plea.

headline: U.S. HALTS FAIRCHILD PAYMENTS
abstract: The Air Force today suspended payments of about $4 million a month to the Fairchild Republic Company of Farmingdale, L.I., in a dispute over the company's work on several Government contracts.   The Air Force said it found ''numerous management and production deficiencies'' in a June inspection of the Farmingdale plant, where the company is producing a new training plane for the Air Force, along with pieces of three other airplanes.   William Fulwider, a spokesman for the company's parent, Fairchild Industries, said the company had made sweeping changes at the Long Island facility, including naming a new president of Fairchild Republic.

headline: A TEXAS AIR PROPOSAL ON T.W.A. FACES SNAG
abstract: A group of 24 United States and foreign airlines said yesterday that they would like to bid for the computer reservation system of Trans World Airlines if it is put up for sale. The move could complicate the Texas Air Corporation's efforts to prevent Carl C. Icahn from gaining control of T.W.A.   Texas Air has asked T.W.A. directors for the option to buy T.W.A.'s reservation system and its international routes and related facilities. Those steps would take away some of the most valuable assets of the airline, making it less attractive to Mr. Icahn, whose group now owns 45.54 percent of T.W.A.'s common stock outstanding.   T.W.A. and Texas Air advisers have been meeting for two days to see whether they can reach an agreement. Texas Air has also proposed that it get options on more T.W.A. stock to dilute Mr. Icahn's holdings. So far no agreement has been reached.

headline: U.S. WILL PROCEED WITH AN ARMS TEST ON SPACE TARGET
abstract: The White House announced today that, despite Soviet objections, the United States would proceed with the first American test of an anti-satellite weapon against an object in space.   Announcing the test, Larry Speakes, the White House spokesman, said the system was needed as a deterrent because the Soviet Union already has the world's only operational anti-satellite system. Mr. Speakes also said there was a growing threat from existing and planned Soviet satellites.   ''We have to test, and we have to test now,'' Mr. Speakes said. ''They have one, and they don't want us to have one.''      Keep Balance, McFarlane Says    In an interview, President Reagan's national security adviser, Robert C. McFarlane, said the test was needed to maintain the military balance between the United States and the Soviet Union.

headline: BOND PRICES PLUMMET, PERPLEXING ANALYSTS
abstract: In a tumultuous and puzzling trading session yesterday, the credit markets ignored fresh statistics showing a weak economy and low inflation and pushed short- and long-term interest rates up sharply.   As rates moved up, prices plummeted more than 2 points, or $20 per $1,000 face amount, for some long-term Treasury issues.   This performance was a sharp surprise to many market participants. They had expected higher prices and lower interest rates to follow the Commerce Department's announcement of a weaker-than-expected 1.7 percent growth rate for the gross national product during the second quarter, compared with the 3.1 percent estimated last month. The second quarter's 2.8 percent inflation rate was another reason traders had expected bond prices to remain steady or rise.

headline: Time to Test-Market Picture Week Magazine
abstract: Time Inc. management has given the ''go'' signal for an extended test-marketing planned for its latest entry, Picture Week magazine.   Starting with the Sept. 23 issue, the magazine will go on sale in 13 undisclosed markets that represent 10 percent of the national population, and the test will continue through the rest of the year.

headline: SOUTH AFRICANS AGAIN BATTLE NAMIBIAN REBELS IN ANGOLA
abstract: South African troops clashed again today with South-West African guerrillas in Angola, killing 16, the authorities here announced.   Gen. Constand Viljoen, commmander of South Africa's armed forces, said Saturday that the soldiers would leave Angola today.   Another military official, Gen. George Meiring, said the withdrawal had been delayed by renewed fighting and seizure of arms caches. The general issued the statement in Windhoek, capital of South-West Africa, a territory governed by South Africa and is widely known as Namibia. Rebels have been fighting to end white control of the territory for 19 years.

headline: Advertising;   General Foods Switches Tang Account to O.&M.
abstract: General Foods is switching the domestic account for its Tang breakfast drink to Ogilvy & Mather, which already handles the brand in some other countries.

headline: U.S. SHIP'S ARCTIC VOYAGE DRAWS HEAT IN CANADA
abstract: The planned voyage of a United States Coast Guard icebreaker through the Northwest Passage in August has set off ripples of complaints about threats to Canada's sovereignty and its environment.   The United States notified Canada in May that the heavy icebreaker Polar Sea would sail from Greenland to Alaska along the Arctic waterway that explorers once thought to be a way to Asia.   Washington considers the Northwest Passage an international strait open to shipping. Ottawa says the route, which passes among islands claimed by Canada, lies within its territory.

headline: BONN PACT IS SEEN OVER 'STAR WARS'
abstract: A West German parliamentary delegation told Congressional committees today that Bonn would sign an agreement setting terms for West German companies to take part in research on President Reagan's spaced-based missile defense program, American and West German officials said.   For the Reagan Administration, such an agreement would be an important symbol of European political endorsement of the program even if European commercial participation in the $26 billion, five-year research effort is only modest.   Since last spring, the Administration has been courting Western European governments with the prospect of attractive high-technology contracts for the strategic defense initiative, or ''Star Wars,'' as the program is known, as a counter to Soviet efforts at exploiting European anxieties about the program.   After months of technical talks with eight friendly industrial nations, Administration officials said today that both Britain and West Germany were moving toward agreements or memorandums of understanding that would set the terms for companies from those countries to compete for research contracts.

headline: Market Place;   Liz Claiborne's Many Fans
abstract: WHILE securities analysts are trimming earnings estimates for various apparel companies, they envisage another year of solid gains for Liz Claiborne Inc. Shares of this innovative designer of women's clothing have climbed from a low of 12 3/8 in February 1984 to a record high of 49 1/2 last month.   In over-the-counter trading yesterday, the stock rose 1 point, to 45. Its recent pullback, analysts said, basically reflects profit taking following the sharp and sustained rise.   Brenda J. Gall of Merrill Lynch estimates profits at between $2.60 and $2.65 a share this year and at $3.25 next year. These figures, she added, could prove conservative. In 1984, the company earned $1.98 a share. Miss Gall rates the stock ''O.K. to buy'' for the intermediate term and an outright ''buy'' for the long pull.

headline: RECOVERING DATA FROM DAMAGED DISKS
abstract: WHEN an early-morning fire swept through the MGM Grand Hotel in Las Vegas in 1980, technicians in the computer control room quickly unloaded two disk packs containing accounting records and the hotel's guest list and carried the disks as they ran down smoky corridors to the exit.   Though the hotel's computer hardware was destroyed by the fire that killed 85 people and injured 1,000, the disks seemed only slightly damaged. Hotel officials rushed them to another hotel and loaded them on a computer to find out the names of the guests trapped in the hotel. But the smoke damage to the disks made them unreadable.

headline: J. DAVID LAWYERS UNDER FIRE
abstract: The sentencing late last month of J. David Dominelli to 20 years in Federal prison for fraud and income tax evasion closed a chapter in one of the biggest investment frauds in United States history. But for the lawyers and accountants who offered professional advice to Mr. Dominelli's San Diego financial empire, J. David & Company, the tale is far from over.   That is because angry investors have filed more than 300 individual suits against the firm's outside law and accounting firms, among others, to recover more than $100 million actually lost as a result of the fraudulent Ponzi-like scheme Mr. Dominelli ran from mid-1979 to February 1984.   Many of Mr. Dominelli's victims lost tens of thousands of dollars. The plaintiffs are seeking an even greater amount for punitive damages.

headline: Mixed Fortunes for Steelmakers
abstract: Different companies are faring differently as the steel industry tries to cope with changing conditions. Here is a look at the major companies: United States Steel Corporation - Steel now accounts for only 35 percent of U.S. Steel's revenues. Most of its sales come from its Marathon Oil division, which it bought in 1982, and U.S. Steel is reported to be ready to make another big acquisition as a further counterweight to steel and oil. Analysts praise the company for the changes in its steel operations, which showed an operating profit of $85 million in the second quarter. The steel division has shrunk drastically, with 100,000 jobs eliminated and some 150 plants closed. The company lost $1.2 billion in 1983 and reported a profit last year of $493 million - helped by one-time gains from asset sales and accounting changes.   LTV Corporation - LTV became the country's second largest steel company, after U.S. Steel, with the acquisition last year of Republic Steel. LTV has the most troubled balance sheet of the major steel companies and is attempting to restructure its heavy debt. Among other moves, it put its specialty steel division on the block. The company's ace is its stake in aerospace, which is highly profitable. LTV posted a second quarter loss of $472.3 million, including a charge to permanently idle its big Aliquippa Works in Pennsylvania.

headline: WHEN ACCOUNTING GOES ELECTRONIC
abstract: Thorough pLanning and step-by-step Implementation will ease the tension For a small business, probably the most tantalizing promise made on behalf of the personal computer is automated accounting. Word procesing is fine, even necessary, in certain professions such as law that generate lots of words. Spreadsheets offer anyone involved in planning a visual panorama of future alternatives. Data bases handle mailing list maintenance and similar electronic filling tasks. All of these functions can be very useful.   But when it comes to deciding which of one's duties one would most like the computer to take over, accounting is susually the No. 1 selection. Unfortunately, the conversion to computerized accounting usually turns out to be a No. 1 headache.

headline: Cost for Air Force Fighter Tool Is Backed
abstract: Two major military contractors denied today that they had conspired to bilk the Air Force on a high-priced tool contract, and two Air Force generals agreed that the companies had followed proper procedures.   Executives of the contractors, the General Dynamics Corporation and the Westinghouse Electric Corporation, said they would not attempt to defend the Pentagon procedures that led to the high prices.

headline: Real Estate;   Big Lease Welcomed Downtown
abstract: THE World Trade Center, with its 10 million square feet of office space, is one of the linchpins of Manhattan's downtown office market. Conditions there can influence leasing all over the financial district. When the state decided in 1981 to vacate two million square feet of space in the center, the entire downtown market softened in anticipation. With new construction under way, the state's departure would mean additional space to be absorbed.   Much of the apprehension evaporated two weeks ago when Dean Witter Financial Services Inc. signed a lease for one million square feet on 24 of the 51 floors once occupied by the state. The 20-year lease has an estimated value of $700 million.

headline: Belgium May Seek Cut In Its NATO Tasks
abstract: Belgium's Defense Minister said today that his country might seek a further reduction in its defense tasks within the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.   At a news conference to present the first white paper on defense policy since 1977, the minister, Alfred Vreven, said he intended in the long term to repatriate as many as possible of the 30,000 Belgian troops stationed in West Germany and to reduce the number of warplanes committed to NATO, now 144.   Belgium has already reduced its contribution to NATO's air defense network in Germany by scrapping two of its six Nike ground-to-air missile units and refusing to buy the United States Patriot missile system to replace the remaining batteries.

headline: MILITARY REPORTEDLY OPPOSED USE OF U.S. MARINES IN BEIRUT
abstract: The Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff told a House committee investigating the 1983 truck-bombing of the Marine garrison at the Beirut airport that the military chiefs had unanimously advised President Reagan against deploying marines in Lebanon in the first place, according to a committee member.   A transcript of the classified hearings by the House Armed Services Committee was made public today, with most references to the Joint Chiefs' advice censored at Pentagon insistence.   But one member of the panel, Representative Larry J. Hopkins, Republican of Kentucky, filled in details of a censored exchange with General John W. Vessey Jr., Chairman of the Joint Chiefs, in which, according to Mr. Hopkins, the general said the Joint Chiefs had opposed the use of the Marines.

headline: AMERICAN AT THE HAGUE SITS IN JUDGEMENT ON U.S.
abstract: The prepared testimony was finished at this afternoon's session of the World Court.   The panel of 15 judges, seated in black robes under a row of stained-glass windows and glimmering chandeliers, had heard Nicaragua's Finance Minister, William Huper, catalogue millions of dollars worth of economic damage to his country due, he contended, to American support for the anti-Government forces known as the contras.   Then one judge - and only one judge - asked a series of polite but pointed questions. Among them was this: The Government of El Salvador claims that guerrillas in that country, which many contend are supported by Nicaragua, have caused disastrous economic losses. If Nicaragua is indeed supporting the insurgents in El Salvador, the judge asked, is it responsible for economic damage there?

headline: Hutton Agrees to Georgia Probation
abstract: E. F. Hutton & Company signed a consent decree yesterday with the State of Georgia that puts Hutton on probation for a year for its illegal check overdrafting practices, but allows its business there to continue unabated.   Georgia was one of many states investigating Hutton after the brokerage's guilty plea in May to 2,000 felony counts in a check overdrafting scheme. This was the first consent agreement to be signed.

headline: BAR GROUP ASSAILS PHILIPPINES AS ABUSING LAWYERS
abstract: The president of the American Bar Association expressed concern today over the treatment of human rights lawyers in the Philippines, saying they were arrested, harassed and sometimes killed in the last year.   As the bar association ended a weeklong convention here, John C. Shepherd, president of the association, listed for President Ferdinand E. Marcos of the Philippines the various abuses Mr. Shepherd said human rights lawyers in the Philippines had been subjected to.   Three members of the Free Legal Assistance Group, an association of volunteer human rights lawyers, have been killed since last September, Mr. Shepherd wrote. The most recent slaying occurred earlier this week.

headline: United Energy And Midcon Link
abstract: The Federal Trade Commission's challenge to the Midcon Corporation's proposed acquisition of United Energy Resources Inc. will not inhibit the merger of the two companies, Joseph Wells, vice chairman of Midcon, said today.

headline: LEUCADIA'S 3D INTERGROUP BID
abstract: In its third foray against National Intergroup, the Leucadia National Corporation yesterday offered to buy the company for $35 a share, or a total of $750 million.   Leucadia, an investment and insurance company based in New York, already owns 9 percent of National Intergroup, a Pittsburgh company that has steel, aluminum and financial operations. Leucadia has failed in two earlier proxy fights to get National Intergroup shareholders to adopt its plan to break up the company.

headline: Japanese Production
abstract: Production at Japan's factories and mines grew 5.8 percent in July from a year earlier, the Ministry of International Trade and Industry said today. The pace of growth was up slightly from June's 5.6 percent, but in recent months the rate exceeded 7 percent.

headline: INSTINET CHIEF TO ADD TITLE
abstract: The Instinet Corporation said yesterday that William A. Lupien, the chairman and chief executive, will assume the additional title of president on Nov. 1.   The appointment follows the announcement earlier this week that Frederic W. Rittereiser, who has been president of Instinet since July 1984, would leave the company at the end of October to become vice chairman of First Jersey Securities Inc.      Mr. Lupien joined Instinet in   August 1983 as president and chief executive and was named chairman in July 1984.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: Debt Issues    * Citicorp sold $50 million of 91-day commercial paper at an average rate of 7.735 percent, up from 7.716 percent last week, and $50 million of 182-day commercial paper at an average rate of 7.74 percent, down from 7.745 percent.    * Metropolis of Tokyo is issuing 100 million Swiss francs of 5 3/8 percent bonds at a price of 100 through underwriters led by Union Bank of Switzerland.

headline: BAXTER'S MERGER BID ACCEPTED
abstract: The American Hospital Supply Corporation and Baxter Travenol Laboratories, two of the nation's largest producers of medical supplies, agreed yesterday to merge in a transaction valued at about $3.8 billion.         The agreement ends a month of resistance by American Hospital Supply, which had vowed to go ahead with a previously agreed combination with the Hospital Corporation of America.

headline: Dividend Meetings
abstract: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of Aug. 12, 1985:                         MONDAY American Brodcstg Cos Meredith Corp First Mississippi     Minesots Mng & Mfg Fischbach Corp

headline: 'STAR WARS' TO BE SUMMIT FOCUS
abstract: A senior White House official said today that President Reagan planned to make his space-based defense program a central theme of his meeting in November with Mikhail S. Gorbachev.   The official said Mr. Reagan would seek to center the discussions on the proposed new type of defense, popularly known as ''Star Wars,'' rather than on nuclear offensive weapons.

headline: Laker Settlement
abstract: Sir Freddie Laker, a pioneer of cut-rate air travel, has lost his attempt in the high court to block an out-of-court settlement of Laker Airways' antitrust suit. High Court Judge Sir Nicholas Browne-Wilkinson, who had heard the case in private, today approved the $48 million deal, which 10 leading airlines had offered to the creditors of the bankrupt airline. Sir Freddie, who says the airlines conspired to drive him out of business in 1982, wanted the court to withhold approval from the settlement negotiated in the United States, saying it was ''pitifully inadequate.''

headline: Dow Slips by 0.67 in Slow Trading
abstract: The stock market continued its up-again, down-again pattern yesterday to close slightly lower in one its slowest days of the year.   The Dow Jones industrial average ended the day 0.67 lower, at 1,317.65. It was off as much as 5 points early in the morning and 3 points at noon, but managed to move fractionally ahead in early afternoon.

headline: WORKERS AT L.I. PLANT STILL HOPEFUL
abstract: Employees of the Fairchild Republic Company are taking in stride news that the Pentagon has proposed the cancellation of the $3.5 billion T-46A program, according to several workers interviewed during their lunch break at the company's plant here today.   A cancellation, industry analysts said, could result in the closing of the plant, which employs 3,600 people.   ''Every week it's the same thing,'' said Raymond L. Marshall, a data processor who has worked for the company for 10 years. ''They're going to cut, they're not going to cut; it's all you hear.''

headline: Atlantic and U.S. News Offering a Special Deal
abstract: Now that Atlantic magazine and U.S. News & World Report are both owned by the same party, Mortimer Zuckerman, certain advertising solicitation ploys can be employed.   It was announced last week that purchasing the equivalent of one full advertising page during the contract year in U.S. News will entitle an advertiser in Atlantic to a 5 percent discount on all purchases of six or more pages.

headline: U.S. TEAM ON MISSING PUTS OFF TRIP TO HANOI
abstract: A United States delegation scheduled to meet with Vietnamese officials to discuss the fate of missing American servicemen postponed its departure for Hanoi today after learning that Foreign Minister Nguyen Co Thach would not be present for the meetings next week.   The Vietnamese Government announced in July that it was prepared to resolve within two years the question of Americans missing in action, and wanted to hold high-level talks to discuss it.

headline: Pope Meets General Walters
abstract: Pope John Paul II met today with Lieut. Gen. Vernon A. Walters, the American representative at the United Nations, the Vatican announced. No details of the private audience, at the Pope's summer palace south of Rome, were made public.

headline: Detroit Area to Get Some Saturn Jobs
abstract: The headquarters and engineering operations of the Saturn Corporation will be located in the Detroit suburbs, although the Saturn manufacturing plant will be built, as expected, in Spring Hill, Tenn., the General Motors Corporation said today.   G.M. made the official announcement on the locations today, although Tennessee officials had announced last week that their state had won the bidding war for the Saturn plant.

headline: American Hospital To Consider Offer
abstract: The American Hospital Supply Corporation said its board would meet on July 12 to consider a revised buyout offer from Baxter Travenol Laboratories Inc. Meanwhile, American Hospital and the Hospital Corporation of America have delayed meetings at which their shareholders were to have voted on the proposed merger of the two companies.   American Hospital and Hospital Corporation announced plans to merge in April, but two weeks ago Baxter Travenol made a bid for American Hospital.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: * Archive Corp., Costa Mesa, Calif., which designs cartridge tape drives for computers, said J. Peter Wilson had been elected president and chief operating officer, succeeding D. Howard Lewis, who continues as chairman and chief executive.    * Barclays Bank of California, San Francisco, has appointed Richard J. King executive vice president of administration; Mick Spilsbury senior vice president and head of retail banking, and William E. Corcoran senior vice president and deputy head of retail banking.    * California Amplifier Inc., Camarillo, Calif., said chairman Donald W. Fuller had been named to the added posts of president and chief executive officer, replacing Jacob Inbar, who will continue to serve on the board.

headline: EXCERPTS FROM THE ENCYCLICAL ON SLAVIC NATIONS
abstract: Following, in official translation from the Polish, are excerpts from Pope John Paul II's encyclical ''Slavorum Apostoli'' (''The Apostles of the Slavs''), which was issued today:   In the present document I wish to make particular reference to the Epistle ''Grande Manus,'' by which Pope Leo XIII intended to remind the church and the world of the apostolic merits of both the brothers - not only of Methodius, who, according to tradition, ended his days at Velehrad in Greater Moravia in the year 885, but also of Cyril, whom death separated from his brother in 869, when he was in Rome, the city which received and which still preserves his relics with profound veneration in the Basilica of Saint Clement.   Together with the great respect for persons and a disinterested concern for their true good, the two holy brothers had the resources of energy, prudence, zeal and charity needed for bringing the light to the future believers, and at the same time for showing them what is good and offering concrete help for attaining it.   For this purpose they desired to become similar in every aspect to those to whom they were bringing the Gospel - they wished to become part of those peoples and to share their lot in everything.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: * Avalon Corp., a former real estate concern that is redeploying its assets in the energy business, and MSR Exploration Ltd. said they have reached agreement for Avalon to acquire a controlling interest in MSR Exploration.    * Belgium Standard Ltd., Waterloo, Ontario, said it was awarded a $25.3 million contract by a Canadian Government agency to manufacture 181 firefighting vehicles for the United States Army Troop Support Command.    * Coca-Cola Co. has reached an agreement with Nutri-Foods International Inc. and holders of 70 percent of Nutri-Foods stock to buy the company. The Atlanta-based soft-drink maker will pay $10 a share to holders of Nutri-Foods outstanding shares and $4 a share plus future earnings to holders of 70 percent of the company's stock.

headline: 6 BLACKS KILLED IN SOUTH AFRICA DURING A PROTEST
abstract: The South African police shot and killed six black protesters, detained at least 18 prominent political activists and rounded up 500 black schoolchildren today.   The police said the children were boycotting classes. On Thursday, 300 children were seized under similar circumtances in a police effort to force children to halt the boycotts.   Township residents said many of the children were under 13 years old.

headline: ARAB LEAGUE OPENS TALKS AMID DEEP SPLITS
abstract: An emergency Arab League meeting opened here today with King Hassan II of Morocco seeking to heal a rift that led five hard-line Arab Governments to boycott the conference.   King Hassan and Chadli Kleibi of Tunisia, Secretary General of the 21-member Arab League, delivered opening speeches expressing sorrow at the absence of Syria, Lebanon, Southern Yemen, Algeria and Libya from the meeting.   The conciliatory tone set by King Hassan was later dispersed by Yasir Arafat, chairman of the Palestine Liberation Organization, however.   In an unscheduled speech after King Hassan had formally closed the opening session, Mr. Arafat thanked those Arab countries present for '' responding to the Palestinian women's cry for help from the camps of Sabra and Shatila,'' an implicit attack on Syria.

headline: GAF Filing On Carbide
abstract: The GAF Corporation, in confirming yesterday that it had bought a 5.6 percent stake in the Union Carbide Corporation, described the purchases of shares as an ''investment position.'' GAF added that it was considering a number of options, ''including the possibility of a business combination'' between the companies, which are competitors in the chemical industry, In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, GAF said that it had not yet determined whether to pursue such an arrangement.

headline: Clashes Are Reported In Capital of Sudan
abstract: More than 10,000 Sudanese took to the streets today to call for more aggressive Government action against rebels in the south of the country.   Fighting broke out several times between opponents and supporters of Col. John Garang, leader of the main rebel movement, the Sudanese People's Liberation Army.

headline: Anti-Soviet March in Finland
abstract: About 400 emigres from Latvia, Lithuania and Estonia marched on the Soviet Embassy here today in the largest anti-Soviet demonstration in Finland since protests over the Soviet-led invasion of Czechoslovakia in 1968. Hundreds of police officers cordoned off the embassy during the march. The emigres said they were protesting Soviet human rights abuses and Soviet rule in the three Baltic states.

headline: Top Yield Is 9 1/4% On Illinois Bonds
abstract: The State of Illinois is offering $150 million of general obligation bonds with a maximum yield of 9 1/4 percent for bonds due in 2015, through underwriters led by the First Boston Corporation.   The financing also includes bonds with yields ranging from 5 percent in 1986 to 7.20 percent in 1990, 8.20 percent in 1995, 8.85 percent in 2000 and 9.15 percent in 2005. The bonds are rated Aaa by Moody's and AA+ by S.& P.

headline: E.E.C. Jobless Rate Up
abstract: The July unemployment rate in Common Market countries, excluding Greece, was an unadjusted 11 percent, up from a seasonally adjusted 10.8 percent in June and 10.6 percent in July 1984, officials said today. On July 31, 12.4 million people were unemployed, compared with 12.2 million in June and 12 million in July 1984, according to Eurostat, the Common Market's statistical service.

headline: WESTINGHOUSE RADAR PAYMENTS HALT
abstract: The Air Force has withheld more than $155 million in contract payments from the Westinghouse Electric Corporation and the Boeing Company because of defects in advanced new radar systems Westinghouse makes for F-16 fighter jets and B-1B bombers, Air Force officials said today.   The officials said the payments related primarily to manufacturing problems with the state-of-the-art circuit boards that are the nervous system of the radars used for navigation and targeting in the newest models of both aircraft.   More than $150 million has been held back from Westinghouse over the last two years because critical spare parts for the F-16 radar were delivered late or failed to meet specifications, according to Kari Fielder, a spokesman for the Air Force Contract Management division at Kirtland Air Force Base in New Mexico. The Air Force buys the radar for General Dynamics' F-16 directly from Westinghouse.

headline: Careers;   Improving Courses for M.B.A.'s
abstract: IN recent years deans and faculties of graduate schools of business administration have been re-evaluating ways to meet the needs of the future. One result has been the requirement of communications courses by Dartmouth, Columbia and others because so many M.B.A. students did not write or speak well. Courses in strategic planning have also been high on the agenda at some business schools, along with courses in small-business management.   Last week two prominent analysts of graduate schools of business were in New York and talked about the schools and their needs.

headline: CHIEF'S POST GIVEN UP BY GRAY
abstract: The United Technologies Corporation said yesterday that Harry J. Gray, its forceful, flamboyant chairman who has been one of the nation's most aggressive acquirers of other companies, would relinquish his additional post as chief executive officer on Jan. 1.   Succeeding Mr. Gray as chief executive will be Robert F. Daniell, the company's 51-year-old president and chief operating officer, United Technologies said.   Analysts said the announcement, which had been anticipated for months on Wall Street, makes Mr. Daniell the apparent successor to Mr. Gray whenever he steps down as chairman of the diversified high-technology company.      Without a Contract    Mr. Gray, 65 years old, is working without a contract. A year ago, he was asked by the United Technologies board to remain chairman until the end of 1985, but he has not stated publicly when he plans to retire.

headline: 2 Israelis Are Victims Of West Bank Attacks
abstract: Unidentified gunmen killed one Israeli and seriously wounded another today in separate attacks in Arab towns in the occupied West Bank, Israeli military sources said.   The slain Israeli appeared to have become the 12th to be killed in the last year in a series of attacks by individual Arabs against Jews in the West Bank and near Arab towns in Israel.

headline: Pepsi Welcomes Move
abstract: Dubbing the Coca-Cola Company's reformulated cola ''the Edsel of the 80's,'' Roger Enrico, president of Pepsi-Cola USA, said yesterday that his archrival's decision last April to change its flagship product represented a colossal marketing blunder.   He predicted that his competitor faced ''a very substantial competitive challenge'' in trying to market both the old and new Cokes.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Previous   Year

headline: A First Account
abstract: I. Goldberg & Partners, founded three weeks ago by the former co-creative director of Nadler & Larimer, has just picked up its first account, Nantucket Industries, which is licensed to manufacture Brut fashion underwear for men. Brut, the fragrance line, as all advertising fans know, was for years a Nadler & Larimer client.

headline: Stock Quotes Via Macintosh
abstract: Apple Computer Inc. will cooperate in marketing a new service to deliver stock and commodity quotes and other financial information to users of its Macintosh computer.   The service will be announced next week by Bonneville Telecommunications, a subsidiary of the Bonneville International Corporation, a radio and television station owner in Salt Lake City.

headline: HARTFORD TO GET HOUSING NEAR DOWNTOWN SECTION
abstract: Although long considered the insurance industry's capital city, until a few years ago there was no significant commercial development in Hartford, and its skyline went unchanged. Today the city is a boom town by anybody's standards. In the last three years it has seen more than three million square feet of office space rise in its central business district.   But until recently there was little new housing for the inner city's expanding work force and those who want to live close to their jobs. Last month, however, two new residential construction projects, to be built just beyond the central business district, were announced.

abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: SPAIN'S AUSTERITY PLAN HITS HARD AT YOUTHS
abstract: At the Government mint last month, 30 apprentices were in the 11th day of a classroom lock-in. The Government had said there was no money for them.   The apprentices, all teen-agers, had been told that they would not be hired because of the Government austerity program. It meant they would be added to the almost three million Spaniards who make up an official jobless rate of 22 percent, the highest in Western Europe.

headline: New Hiring Path Taken By Salomon
abstract: Although rival investment banks have often reached into the top echelons of the Federal Government to give their business a special cachet, Salomon Brothers has preferred to rely on home-grown talent. Yesterday, however, the giant securities firm broke with tradition when it announced that David A. Stockman would become its 88th managing director.   Mr. Stockman's intimate knowledge of the Federal bureaucracy - acquired as a Congressman from Michigan and as budget director for President Reagan - is expected to help the firm.   Salomon Brothers daily deals in financial markets that are shaped by Government borrowing. It is the largest dealer in government securities as well as the most active managing underwriter of corporate securities and one of the top three firms in municipal underwriting and stock trading.

headline: ACCORD REACHED ON INSTINET STAKE
abstract: Chicago Board Options Exchange Inc. acquired from the Instinet Corporation the right to acquire up to one million shares of Instinet's stock, or 18.5 percent of the total outstanding, the Chicago Board Options Exchange disclosed in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission. The Chicago Board said it reached an agreement with Instinet July 12 to buy up to 400,000 Instinet units, each consisting of one share of Instinet stock and a warrant to purchase, before October 1988, and an additional 1.5 shares at an exercise price of $20 a share.

headline: Uganda's New Rulers Reportedly Detain 1,000
abstract: The new military rulers of Uganda have detained more than 1,000 members of the ousted President's secret police and bodyguard in a maximum-security jail, prison administration sources said today.

headline: Israel Plans to Release Last Detainees Today
abstract: Israel said today that the last of the 1,200 prisoners seized in southern Lebanon are to be freed Tuesday.   The final group of 119 will empty the military prison at Atlit, south of Haifa, where they were held since their transfer from Lebanon on April 2.

headline: FEWER EPIC HOUSES FOUND
abstract: The Federal bankruptcy court judge presiding over the case of the ailing EPIC group of mortgage and real estate companies was told yesterday that there were 7,000 fewer houses in the company's bankrupt partnerships than had been previously believed. The court was also told that an EPIC affiliate paid a special $2 million dividend to its three owners just one month before EPIC halted all payments on its outstanding mortgages.   In another development, the negotiations to resolve EPIC's problems grew more complicated, with the formation of a committee of EPIC mortgage holders that will put together a second proposal for working out EPIC's problems.

headline: Nortek Chief Proves Acquisition-Minded
abstract: Ralph R. Papitto has often said his goal is to build Nortek Inc. into a billion-dollar-a-year company by 1986. As chairman and chief executive of the maker of construction supplies, metal products and electrical supplies, he has pursued numerous acquisitions - apparently with that end in mind.   Mr. Papitto's latest target is the Transway International Corporation, a transportation company he offered to buy last week for about $265 million. Transway officials rejected that offer, and Mr. Papitto has since sweetened his bid to $298 million and said his company will begin a tender offer for Transway this week.

headline: Chase Said To Hold Talks
abstract: The Chase Manhattan Corporation, is negotiating with Maryland officials to acquire a bankrupt savings and loan association in that state, according to banking sources.   Chase has told Maryland officials that it would acquire the institution, the Merritt Commercial Savings and Loan Association, and accept its deposit liabilities under certain conditions, including limits on Chase's potential losses, the sources said.

headline: Northern Israel Is Hit By Katyusha Rockets
abstract: Missiles fired from Lebanon struck northern Israel Monday night, causing slight property damage but no casualties, military sources said today.   They said the missiles were 122-millimeter Soviet-made Katyushas that hit four miles south of the Israeli border in the Galilee panhandle.

headline: French Paper Is Bombed
abstract: A bomb exploded early today outside the offices here of the regional newspaper Sud-Ouest, the police said. No one was hurt, and there was no immediate claim of responsibility.

headline: Courier Preparing For Battle
abstract: A WEEK before Federal Express begins its six-market European service July 15, DHL Worldwide Express, now the dominant service there, will start to run an expensive, distinctive and memorable commercial that will promote the company's service here and abroad.   According to Ally & Gargano, Federal's agency, their client, which domestically is Numero Uno, will not start advertising its international service until the fall.   By that time television viewers in DHL's best 19 domestic markets will be brainwashed to the fact that DHL delivers with equal ease to Canton, Ohio, and Canton, China, as well as to Venice, Calif., and Venice, Italy.   That information will be delivered via a $200,000 commercial that it took Pan Productions 16 weeks to complete in the shadow of the Brooklyn Bridge.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST: SATURDAY, SEPTEMBER 21, 1985
abstract: The Economy    The economy is growing at a 2.8 percent annual rate in the third quarter, according to the Government's ''flash'' G.N.P. estimate. That is a little faster than in the first half of the year but far below the Administration forecast of 5 percent growth for the second half. The report was also somewhat below the expectations of most private analysts. [Page 35.]  The G.N.P. figure was circulated widely in the financial community on Thursday, an incident that will be investigated by the F.B.I. [38.]    The Senate Finance Committee approved a price-support bill for tobacco and made permanent the 16-cent-a-pack tax. [32.]

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: Bell Canada Enterprises, Montreal, said its Bell Canada Management Corporation had agreed to buy the Campeau Corporation's 48.8 percent interest in Computer Innovations Distribution Inc. for $2.80 a share, or a total of $35.1 million.    * Charterhouse Group International Inc. said that it and the management of Wundies Inc. of Panex Industries had bought Wundies, which makes women's underwear and sleepwear, for $44.3 million in cash and stock.

headline: Retractable Blade For Disposable Razor
abstract: If you consider a retractable blade on a disposable razor a meaningful consumer benefit, then you will be overjoyed to learn that the Wilkinson Sword unit of Allegheny International has just that sort of a product and will be spending $23.5 million over the next two years to promote it.

headline: DESOTO INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: CONSUMER RATES
abstract: In percent

headline: NEW WAYS TO STOP A CORPORATE RAIDER
abstract: Corporate takeover defenses are becoming shrewder and more sophisticated by the day. First there was the ''poison pill,'' a tactic that corporate boards of directors adopted to make it prohibitively expensive for a would-be raider to acquire control. Lately , several corporations have cooked up another way to fend off hostile bidders - they offer existing shareholders a sweet deal but exclude the predators from the party.   The latest company to use what amounts to a new, improved poison pill is Revlon Inc., the cosmetics and health care giant that is fighting a $1.8 billion, or $47.50-a-share, hostile bid from Pantry Pride Inc. Early this week, Revlon adopted a strategy that would allow all shareholders except for a hostile bidder, such as Pantry Pride, to swap their shares for debt worth a substantial premium over the current stock price if a would-be acquirer purchased 20 percent of the shares.

headline: Trial Setback For Texaco
abstract: A state district judge granted a Pennzoil Company motion today to sever a Texaco Inc. counterclaim from Pennzoil's $14 billion damage suit against Texaco.   Texaco lawyers argued on the opening day of the trial that the counterclaim, charging harassment by Pennzoil, should be a part of the suit because it arose out of the same transaction, Texaco's acquisition of the Getty Oil Company last year.

headline: Sudan Bans Protests After Street Clashes
abstract: The Sudanese Government banned street demonstrations today after 2 people were killed and 45 were wounded in fighting Saturday.

headline: Offering Is Made For Texas Utility
abstract: The Matagorda Navigation District of Texas is offering $115 million of tax-exempt revenue bonds for the Central Power and Light Company, through underwriters led by Kidder, Peabody & Company.

headline: SOUTH AFRICAN CLERIC IS FREED ON BAIL
abstract: The Rev. Allan Boesak, a prominent anti-apartheid leader, was formally charged and freed on bail today after nearly a month in detention.   He was released after being charged with subversion under a section of this nation's vast body of security laws. The charges related to calls by Dr. Boesak for school and consumer boycotts and withdrawal of foreign investments.   He was also accused of involvement in illegal gatherings.

headline: Shops Remain Closed In Guadeloupe Protest
abstract: Separatists dismantled roadblocks today, but shops and businesses remained closed on the fourth day of a general strike on this French Caribbean island.   The atmosphere was tense, with few people on the streets and almost no traffic.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: Debt Issues    * Delta Air Lines said its bank credit facility has been raised to $1 billion, from $700 million.    * Homestead Mortgage Acceptance Corp., a wholly owned subsidiary of the Homestead Financial Corp., is offering $200 million of collateralized mortgage obligations in four parts with maturities ranging from 11 years to 30 years and coupons ranging from 10.90 percent to 11.45 percent.

headline: Money Fund Assets Up
abstract: Assets of the nation's money market mutual funds rose $876 million, to $211.65 billion, for the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday.

headline: PATENTS;  Pocket Terminal Used For Secured Banking
abstract: A pocket banking terminal and the method of its operation have been invented for the Atalla Corporation, a company in San Jose, Calif., specializing in electronic security. Patent 4,536,647 was granted this week to Martin M. Atalla, founder and chairman, and Ralph R. Bestock, a member of the engineering staff.

headline: SALLIE MAE SELLS FLOATING NOTES
abstract: The Student Loan Marketing Association, known as Sallie Mae, is offering $325 million of short-term floating-rate notes due Feb. 13, 1986, through various securities dealers. Sallie Mae sells such notes monthly.   Interest on the notes will be adjusted weekly at 20 one-hundredths of a percentage point above the average bond-equivalent yield set at each week's auction of new 91-day Treasury bills.

headline: Mexico Bars Chrysler Plan
abstract: The Mexican Government has turned down the Chrysler Corporation's proposal to set up a joint venture for building heavy-duty trucks. The decision, announced Thursday, was a setback to efforts by American companies to expand their investments in Mexico, where the Government tightly controls such projects.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: * Alco Health Services Corp., a full-service wholesale distributor of pharmaceutical products with headquarters in Valley Forge, Pa., said it had reached an agreement in principle to acquire Meyers & Co. of Tiffin, Ohio, from Hillman Securities Inc. for 1,110,000 shares of Alco Health Services common stock.    * Codenoll Technology Corp., Yonkers, a producer of proprietary fiber optic communications systems and components, said that Celanese Corp. had agreed to purchase 10 percent, or 400,000 shares, of Codenoll common stock for $5.25 million, , as well as up to 21 percent over the next five years.

headline: THOSE STRANGE MARKET TURNS
abstract: One day early this month in the midst of an otherwise lazy summer afternoon the stock market was grabbed by an undertow that pulled the Dow Jones industrial average down 21.73 points. And last week, stocks bounded up 11 points one day and down 11 on another for no apparent reason.   The mysterious force behind the moves, it turned out, was a relatively new phenomenon on Wall Street called program trading. The term refers to programs of orders from institutional investors and other professional traders to buy or sell shares in 100 or more large companies that are a surrogate for the broader Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks.   Such programs are often initiated by arbitrage opportunities when the current value of stocks reflected by the S.&P. 500 and the price of a stock index future on that index are out of line. An index future is a contract between two parties that allows an investor to bet on the general direction of the market over a short period of time.

headline: EXCERPTS FROM NOMINATING SPEECH
abstract: Following are excerpts from Mikhail S. Gorbachev's speech today nominating Andrei A. Gromyko as the Soviet President, as translated and distributed by the Soviet press agency Tass:   We are to elect a chairman of the Presidium of the Supreme Soviet of the U.S.S.R. The plenary meeting of the Central Committee of the Communist Party of the Soviet Union discussed the issue yesterday.   As you know, starting in 1977, the General Secretary of the Central Committee has also been holding the post of chairman of the Presidium of the Supreme Soviet.   One should say that it was justified in the conditions of that time to combine in one person the highest posts in the party and the state.   At the same time, the Central Committee took into account that the solution of the new tasks that are now emerging calls for adjustments both in the content and in the forms and methods of party and state activity, to the appointment of cadres both at the center and at the local level.

headline: SCM Deal Seen Under Study
abstract: Kohlberg, Kravis Roberts & Company, a New York investment firm that specializes in leveraged buyouts, is investigating the possibility of doing such a deal for the SCM Corporation, according to Wall Street sources. Earlier this week, sources disclosed that Merrill Lynch & Company, the brokerage firm, was also studying a leveraged buyout at the request of SCM's management.

headline: Taiwan Fleet's Growth
abstract: Taiwan's container fleet will become the world's third largest at the end of this year, behind West Germany and the United States, the Communications Ministry said Friday.

headline: DEVELOPING CANADA OIL SANDS
abstract: Unlike the United States, where Congress cut off funding for synthetic fuels development on July 31, Canada is pressing cautiously ahead with a number of efforts to develop its substantial oil-sands resources, potentially one of the largest synthetic fuel endeavors anywhere.   ''It is our ace in the hole,'' explained John Zaozirny, energy minister of Alberta, the province that has most of Canada's 1,000 billion barrels of oil in known oil-sands reserves. Some of the oil from those reserves is sold as is, but most that is extracted now is synthesized into a lighter, more conventional crude.   Mr. Zaozirny and industry officials say that even with today's eroding oil prices, many oil-sands developments, with their low cost and enormous resources, make economic sense -much more than coal gasification and oil-shale development make in the United States. With considerable governmental help still available on both the Federal and provincial level, they make even more.

headline: CERTAIN-TEED CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: New Toyota Plant
abstract: The Toyota Motor Corporation plans to build a $300 million auto plant somewhere in Canada that will be completed in 1988, according to the office of the Industry Minister, Sinclair Stevens.

headline: Advertising;   Commerce Department Is Moving to SSC&B
abstract: SSC&B, one of the Interpublic Group of Companies, is going to be working for the New York State Commerce Department in its noble attempts at bringing new businesses into our fair state.

headline: MORMONS IN ISRAEL ALARM ORTHODOX
abstract: They are the most unlikely antagonists.   On one side are black-robed extremely Orthodox Jews, with curling sidelocks hanging out from under their hats, carrying posters in front of City Hall that bear the messages: ''Mormons: Utah Isn't Big Enough?'' ''The Mormons Want to Convert Us To Christianity,'' and ''Close the Gates of Jerusalem to the Mormons.''   On the other side, brushing past the protesters on their way into Mayor Teddy Kollek's office, are officials of the Mormons' Brigham Young University. They wear business suits and carry briefcases stuffed with documents. And they say the papers prove they have no intention of turning the university's new center, now being built on Mount Scopus in Jerusalem, into a magnet to convert Jews.

headline: Natwest Seeks U.S. Brokerage
abstract: The National Westminster Bank P.L.C. of London said yesterday that it had applied to the Federal Reserve Board to set up a United States securities brokerage operation to function alongside its American banking unit.   Federal laws generally prohibit banking and securities brokerages from participating in each other's business.

headline: FILLING THE GAPS IN MEDICARE COVERAGE
abstract: MEDICARE, the Federal health insurance program for people over age 65, has gone a long way toward absorbing some of the health care costs of the elderly. But a major portion of those costs - close to 60 percent - are still borne by the patients themselves, either out-of-pocket or through extra insurance purchased privately.   Because the elderly use medical services far more frequently than the general population, choosing the best insurance to supplement Medicare - a so-called ''medigap'' policy - can have major financial implications for them and their relatives.   Shopping for a good medigap policy requires some knowledge of how Medicare itself works. The plan is available free to people over age 65 who are eligible for Social Security or Railroad Retirement benefits. Medicare's Part A is basically a hospitalization policy. The patient pays the first $400 in hospital charges; Medicare covers the full remaining cost of the patient's first 60 days of hospitalization. From the 61st through the 90th day, the patient contributes a co-payment of $100 a day; this rises to $200 for the 91st through the 150th day. After that, Medicare steps out and the patient is responsible.

headline: Goldsmith Stake Up to About 46%
abstract: Sir James Goldsmith, continuing his battle with management of the Crown Zellerbach Corporation, increased his stake in the paper-and forest products company to nearly 46 percent, a spokesman for the British financier said yesterday. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Sir James said he had raised his stake to 43.2 percent, but his spokesman said ''he's been buying up shares since then.''

headline: EXECUTIVES
abstract: * Amfac Inc., a San Francisco food and hotel company, has elected to its board Frederick W. Mielke Jr., chairman and chief executive of Pacific Gas and Electric.

headline: PLANE'S FINAL MINUTES: 'RAISE THE NOSE'
abstract: Tape-recorded conversations from the cockpit of the Japan Air Lines jumbo jet that crashed last week give no indication that the pilot was ever aware that much of the plane's vertical tail was missing.   According to transcripts of the tapes, made public tonight by the Japanese Transport Ministry, the pilot reported that the plane's hydraulic systems were ''gone,'' indicating there was no power to move wing flaps, rudders and other parts that control direction.   Other crew members reported a few minutes later that a luggage storage area had ''fallen down'' in the back of the Boeing 747 and that a rear right door was broken.   But if the crew recognized the extent of the damage, it was not clear from the transcripts made public tonight.

headline: Earnings Down 3.3% At BBDO International
abstract: Yesterday BBDO International, the first of the publicly held agencies to issue a second-quarter financial statement, reported that net income was down 3.3 percent, to $5.9 million, or 93 cents a share, from $6.1 million, or 96 cents a share, a year earlier.   Revenues were $83.7 million, up 6 percent from $78.9 million.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: * CIP Inc., a unit of Canadian Pacific Enterprises Ltd., said it plans to spend $44 million to upgrade its newsprint mill in Trois Rivieres, Quebec.    * Cox Communications, Atlanta, completed the previously announced acquisition of WFTV, an ABC affiliate in Orlando, Fla., from SFN Companies of Glenview, Ill., for $185 million.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: American Telephone and Telegraph Co. said it had been named primary contractor in a $29 million deal to modernize New York State's Capitol District Communications System.    * Cheezem Development Corp., a construction company in St. Petersburg, Fla., said its chairman, Charles K. Cheezem, had sold his family's majority stake in the company to 44-43 Corp. for $10 million.

headline: INDIA IS SAID TO DROP PROSECUTION OF A.P. REPORTER IN PUNJAB CASE
abstract: The Government has dropped legal procceedings against a reporter for The Associated Press, Brahma Chellaney, who was accused of inflammatory reporting about army operations in the Punjab last year, a senior official says.   Officials returned the reporter's passport last Thursday, having renewed it for five years. It was impounded more than eight months ago for what the Government called national security reasons.

headline: AVON TO SELL MALLINCKRODT UNIT
abstract: Avon Products Inc., the company that built the world's biggest beauty business by ringing doorbells, said yesterday that it was putting its large Mallinckrodt chemical and hospital products division on the block. It said it would use most of the money it collected to buy back 25 percent of its stock.   Avon had bought the company for $711 million only three years ago, in its efforts to diversify beyond the sagging beauty products business.   Hicks Waldron, chairman of Avon, yesterday called Mallinckrodt Inc. ''a great company'' but said ''it just doesn't fit with Avon's strategic direction.'' He said the divestiture is ''part of Avon's strategy to concentrate on consumer products and to continue to expand its health-care services business.''

headline: MEXICO THREATENED BY OIL PRICE CUTS
abstract: Mexico, which depends on the sale of crude oil to generate 75 percent of its export income and half of its government's revenues, is increasingly finding its economic back to the wall as the price of oil falls on the international market.   The country, which is the fourth-largest crude producer and the largest foreign supplier of oil to the United States, has twice reduced its oil prices this year and pressure on the international market may force yet another drop.   The troublesome question facing American bankers, to whom Mexico owes most of its $96 billion foreign debt, is how far oil prices can fall before Mexico finds itself in the midst of an economic crisis, unable to meet loan payments.   In February, as part of an economic recovery program, Mexico broke ranks with the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries for the first time and set a price of $27.75 a barrel for its Isthmus Light crude, 25 cents below the benchmark adopted by OPEC earlier in the year.

headline: MOSCOW CLEARS DECK FOR ANTI IMPERIALIST YOUTH
abstract: For many middle-aged Russians, the 1957 Moscow youth festival is a memory of unusual excitement and abandon, a time when the city welcomed its first mass influx of visitors from abroad since the closed days of Stalin.   The organizers, too, remember the 1957 festival, which many people believe planted the seeds of restlessness and a fascination with the West for succeeding generations of Russians.   In 1957, tens of thousands of foreigners flooded the city, which took on a fairground atmosphere as Russians rushed to clasp the visitors' hands and swap coins, pins and greeting cards. It was the first taste for many of them of blue jeans, ball-point pens and, simply, friendship with outsiders.

headline: ISRAEL AND CHINA QUIETLY FORM TRADE BONDS
abstract: While reports surfaced last week about secret exchanges between Israel and the Soviet Union, a far more intense and lucrative relationship has been quietly developing between Israel and China, according to Israeli officials.         The Chinese in the last seven months have shown an increasing appetite for Israeli skills in agriculture, solar energy, manufacturing, advanced technology, robotics, construction, road building and arms manufacturing, say Israeli officials familiar with the trade. Some deals have already been struck and many  others are pending at one stage or another, according to recent Israeli press accounts.

headline: Boeing Contract
abstract: The Boeing Company has been awarded a $405.8 million Air Force contract to build offensive weapons-control systems for 82 B-1B bombers.

headline: 8 SLAIN IN HOLDUPS IN 2 BRUSSELS STORES
abstract: Eight people were shot dead tonight when gunmen opened fire without warning during two holdups that were carried out about 15 minutes apart in suburban Brussels supermarkets, the police said.

headline: U.S. AFFIRMS SUPPORT FOR TUNISIA AS TENSIONS ON LIBYAN BORDER RISE
abstract: The United States today affirmed its support for Tunisia's security, amid a sharp rise in tension between that North African country and neighboring Libya.   Tunisia, which has longstanding ties to the United States, asserted on Sunday that Libyan fighter planes had violated its airspace and that Libya had massed forces along the Tunisian-Libyan frontier, after days of charges and counter-charges. Today, the State Department said Washington stood by a pledge made by President Reagan to President Habib Bourguiba of Tunisia on June 18 at the White House of American backing for Tunisia's security and territorial integrity.   The latest tensions between Libya and Tunisia arose two weeks ago when Libya suddenly ordered the expulsion of Tunisian workers, many of whom had been there for years. So far, about 23,000 Tunisians have been forced over the border into Tunisia, many of them without their property and documents.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: American Hospital Supply Corp., Evanston, Ill., said its American Critical Care division had agreed to distribute a line of injectable anti-cancer products manufactured by International Pharmaceutical Products Inc.    * American Motors Corp., Southfield, Mich., expanded its 7.5 percent financing program to apply to any loan of up to 48 months for certain 1985 model cars. Previously, the offer was for loans up to 36 months.    * BDM International Inc., McLean, Va., said it had received an Air Force contract worth up to $53.5 million to support the Air Force Operational Test and Evaluation Center at Kirtland Air Force Base, N.M.    * A. G. Edwards & Sons Inc., St. Louis, said it intends to repurchase up to 300,000 shares of its common stock in open-market transactions through Sept. 30, 1986.

headline: A Belfast Couple Are Slain as Informers
abstract: I.R.A. gunmen kidnapped a young Roman Catholic couple accused of being paid police informers, ''convicted'' them and put them to death, authorities said toaay.   The outlawed Irish Republican Army took responsibility for the slayings in West Belfast late Sunday night and issued a long indictment accusing the couple of having turned their apartment into an I.R.A. ''safe house'' to inform on the group in return for money and vacations.

headline: Top Lebanon Moslems Are Gathering in Syria
abstract: Senior Lebanese Moslem and Druse leaders have been converging on Damascus for Syrian-sponsored talks designed to end the breach among the various factions in Lebanon.   Those already in Damascus are Prime Minister Rashid Karami, a Sunni Moslem; the Parliament Speaker, Hussein al-Husseini, a Shiite Moslem; Justice Minister Nabih Berri, leader of the mainstream Shiite movement Amal, and Public Works Minister Walid Jumblat, leader of the mainly Druse Progressive Socialist Party. They are to be joined by other Sunni, Shiite and Druse figures at a conference scheduled to begin Monday.

headline: Merrill Drops Bid For SCM, for Now
abstract: The SCM Corporation and Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith Inc. said late yesterday that they had agreed to break off merger talks, but would continue exploring ''all possible alternatives.''   They said they had abandoned their plans for a leveraged buyout of SCM for $70 a share, or a total of $854 million, in view of a takeover bid from Hanson Trust P.L.C., the British conglomerate that has offered $72 a share, or $878 million, for SCM.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Previous   Year

headline: Canada Acts on Apartheid
abstract: Canada has tightened the rules for companies doing business with South Africa to reflect what officials say is a ''rising tide of revulsion'' against apartheid.   ''The fundamental changes in South Africa we had hoped for during the past quarter-century have not come about,'' External Affairs Minister Joe Clark told reporters Saturday after a meeting of Canada's inner Cabinet.

headline: JAPAN EXPANDS CAR SALES IN EUROPE
abstract: The Fiats and Renaults rotate on turntables, and the Mercedes-Benz limousines are spotlighted like movie stars. But out in hangar-like Hall 10 here at Europe's biggest automobile show, Japan's cars - Hondas, Nissans, Mazdas, Mitsubishis and others -are lined up as in a used-car lot.   The Japanese share of the 10-million-car European market, industry officials say, has doubled in five years, to more than 10 percent. But Europe's market is stagnant, and excess manufacturing capacity has spawned fierce price-cutting.

headline: WHAT VACATIONING EXECUTIVES ARE READING
abstract: It's summer - time for most people to settle back in a favorite easy chair or hammock with a good book. For those who head huge companies, the usual fare of reports, newspapers and trade journals must be read. But sandwiched between this required reading is some lighter fare: spy stories, autobiographies and a melange of fictional passions and intrigues.   A number of executives agreed to share their summer reading plans with The Times. (And nearly double that number declined, saying they did not have time to read).   At the Chrysler Corporation, a spokesman said that the books its chairman, Lee A. Iacocca, will be reading are classified as ''private information.'' But many of his peers in the business world were not so reticent and quite a few, in fact, have put ''Iacocca'' at the top of their reading lists. Donald Frey, chairman of Bell & Howell, said he is especially interested in the book because he worked under Mr. Iacocca in the 1950's and 1960's. ''I'm mentioned three times,'' notes Mr. Frey, ''if you want to use a body count.''

headline: EPIC UNIT TOLD TO OPEN ITS BOOKS TO TWO BANKS
