abstract: A Federal District judge today ordered EPIC Mortgage Inc., the troubled mortgage-banking company based in Falls Church, Va., to give a full accounting of its finances and to set aside in escrow any mortgage payments it receives until further determination by the court.   Judge Claude M. Hilton of the Eastern District of Virginia delayed a ruling on a request by two banks that he appoint a receiver to oversee the mortgage company's operations. That decision will await a trial.  Under his order, EPIC will have to open its books to the National Bank of Washington and the First National Bank of Maryland, which are trustees for certificate holders of $1 billion in EPIC-originated mortgages. The two banks have asserted that EPIC is in default on almost $15 million in mortgage payments to their certificate holders. Judge Hilton said that appeared to be so.

headline: Satellite Data Is Urged For Use by U.N. Staff
abstract: The United States and the Soviet Union should provide the United Nations with advance intelligence on potential trouble spots from their satellites and other monitoring devices, according to a report released here today.   The report, prepared by the United Nations Association of the United States, a nonpartisan, nonprofit organization, says the information could be provided on a ''need to know'' basis consistent with national security.

headline: Arco and Santa Fe Get China Pact
abstract: China will sign a $500 million deal with the Atlantic Richfield Company and the Santa Fe International Corporation to develop an offshore natural gas field in what would be the biggest single foreign investment in the country under Peking's seven-year-old open policy, industry sources said. The contract will be signed Saturday with the Government-run China National Offshore Oil Corporation.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: American Healthcare Management Inc., Dallas, promoted Mark L. Plaumann from vice president and chief accounting officer to senior vice president of finance and administration, and chief financial officer.    * Burroughs Corp., Detroit, has elected to its board William E. Lamothe, chairman and chief executive officer of Kellogg Co.

headline: WHAT'S NEW IN THE WEATHER BUSINESS
abstract: It was a matter of precision. Compu-weather Inc. meteorologists in Flushing, Queens, predicted that a ''monster snow storm'' would begin a little after noon, and that there would be 12 inches or more. Expect a blizzard, they said.   Not according to the National Weather Service, though. Only 4 to 8 inches, it predicted, starting later in the afternoon.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Previous   Year

headline: Chinese Deal Held Up
abstract: The United States is holding up a French company's sale to China of an advanced communications system that it fears could be used for military purposes, industry sources said today. The dispute centers on the sale of a sophisticated switching system for use in Peking and Shanghai.

headline: Dow Up 3.47 Points As Volume Eases
abstract: Stock prices closed slightly higher yesterday in a session that was hectic at the start and busy at the finish, but uneventful in between.   ''This is a market that is wrenching itself from one attitude and moving to another,'' said Monte Gordon, director of research for the Dreyfus Corporation. ''It's easing away from the safe harbor of interest-rate sensitive stocks'' and into shares that move with the economy, he said.   Mr. Gordon said that when such a shift occurs, the market often meanders.

headline: TWO TOP OFFICIALS OF HUTTON RESIGN IN BANKING SCHEME
abstract: Two high-level executives at the E. F. Hutton Group resigned today after the release of a report by Griffin B. Bell, the former Attorney General, on his investigation of a bank overdrafting scheme by the company's brokerage firm.   Hutton announced the resignation from their posts of Thomas P. Lynch, who was the vice chairman, chief financial officer and secretary, and Thomas Morley, the senior vice president and money manager. Mr. Bell's report assigned to them responsibility for management failures in overseeing the brokerage firm's cash management operations.   Mr. Lynch will remain as a Hutton director and will continue to receive his full salary.   Hutton also announced that its general counsel, Thomas W. Rae, would take early retirement. Mr. Rae was said by Mr. Bell to be responsible for his department's failure to respond fully to a Government subpoena of records pertaining to the overdrafting scheme.      Other Actions Recommended    Mr. Bell also cited 13 other Hutton executives and recommended disciplinary actions against 11 of them, including company-imposed fines of as much as $50,000. In addition, he called for a major restructuring of Hutton's top management and reorganization of the board to include a majority of outside directors.

headline: Ashland Oil to Sell Unit to Southmark
abstract: Ashland Oil Inc. said that it had agreed to sell the Integon Corporation, its insurance subsidiary, to the Southmark Corporation for about $157 million. The sale is part of a divestiture program announced by Ashland last year, and should not have any impact on current net income, the company said.         Ashland, based in Ashland, Ky., took a $271 million charge in its fourth quarter last year in connection with its plans to sell the insurance operations  and some of its technology units. Southmark, which is based in Dallas, said that it expected the acquisition to strengthen its ability to cross-market a variety of financial services. The companies said that they expected the transaction, which is subject to regulatory approval, to be completed in September.

headline: HUNDREDS OF EGYPTIANS GO HOME FROM LIBYA
abstract: The first of 100,000 Egyptian workers who have been expelled from Libya began arriving home today, further straining already poor relations between the Arab neighbors.   About 830 Egyptians arrived in the Mediterranean port of Alexandria to an official and popular welcome.

headline: BAR MORE RUSSIANS, WEINBERGER SAYS
abstract: Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger said today that the United States should reduce the number of Soviet citizens it allows to work and travel here in order to curtail their collection of American military technology.   The Defense Secretary, speaking at a news conference the day after his department released a study detailing a widespread Soviet quest for American military technology, said that the number of Russians in the United States was ''far out of proportion'' to the number of Americans in the Soviet Union and that ''a reduction in numbers would be a useful start.''   Mr. Weinberger asserted that ''the Soviets don't send people to countries like the United States unless they are fully equipped, fully trained, and either part of K.G.B., or might just as well be.''   Mr. Weinberger took several opportunities at today's wide-ranging news conference to reiterate his harsh view of Soviet behavior and intentions.

headline: FANNIE MAE TIGHTENS RULES FOR HOME BUYERS
abstract: Potential home buyers unable to make a 10 percent down payment will have a harder time qualifying for a conventional mortgage under guidelines announced today by the nation's main supplier of money for home loans.   But housing finance officials said the new standards are pretty much in line with what individual lending institutions are already doing and therefore should not prevent many people from buying homes.   The changes were announced by the Federal National Mortgage Association, known as Fannie Mae. It buys individual home loans from lenders and packages them for resale in the nation's money markets.

headline: Washington Watch;   Heated Textile Import Battle
abstract: The lobbying battle over the pending imported textile bill is not likely to cool any time soon, with the Senate expected to take up the textile bill sometime this week and the House waiting in the wings.

headline: GREENPEACE ATTACK: MEMO IN MARCH, DEATH IN JULY
abstract: In late May, six weeks before an environmentalist group's ship was sunk by an explosion in New Zealand, Gerard Andries, an agent of the French intelligence agency, was noticed in London by the British secret service.   Mr. Andries, according to accounts in the British and French press, was there to buy an inflatable dinghy that would be brought to New Zealand and used in the underwater demolition operation that on July 10 sank the Rainbow Warrior, the flagship of the environmentalist group Greenpeace.   The purchase may in retrospect have been a key point in the unraveling of a covert plan to sink the Rainbow Warrior, an operation that Le Monde asserted today was carried out by the French intelligence agency, apparently with the approval of senior French officials.   According to Le Monde's account, Mr. Andries purchased the inflatable dinghy in London so that it could not be traced to France, and he went several weeks later to New Zealand aboard a chartered yacht, the Ouvea. His detection in London by British intelligence apparently led to a search of the Ouvea by Australian and New Zealand customs officers on July 15, five days after the sinking of the Rainbow Warrior. And it was during that search that the New Zealand police first established a connection between the Ouvea and the sunken Greenpeace vessel.

headline: Advertising;   Motor Club Group Picks St. Louis Agency
abstract: Kerlick, Switzer & Johnson Advertising of St. Louis has been awarded the advertising for a AAA Motor Club co-op made up of 13 automobile clubs from 12 states, representing about 4 million members.   The agency won the account in competition with Dawson, Johns & Black of Chicago; W. B. Doner & Company, Southfield, Mich.; Caldwell/Van Riper, Indianapolis; Smith, Kaplan, Allen & Reynolds, Omaha, and Doremus & Company, a divison of BBDO in Chicago.

headline: TOYOTA PLANTS SET FOR U.S., CANADA
abstract: The Toyota Motor Corporation at last is joining its major Japanese rivals in building its own factory in the United States.   The company said today that it would build an assembly plant to produce 200,000 midsized cars annually beginning in 1988. It did not disclose the location, but most analysts expect the site to be in the Middle West.

headline: Warrnts Introduced For Currency Units
abstract: The growing use of European Currency Units by borrowers and lenders in the capital markets led Phibro-Salomon yesterday to issue the first put and call warrants for these units.   Each warrant is for 10,000 European Currency Units. The put warrants enable the holder to sell ECU's at a rate of 0.7765 for each American dollar, and the call warrants enable the holder to buy ECU's at 0.7865 to the dollar.

headline: HUSSEIN CALLS FOR ARAB WORKING GROUP ON MIDEAST
abstract: King Hussein of Jordan called on Arab governments today to form a working group to address critical problems confronting the region.   The King, saying efforts to convene an emergency meeting of Arab leaders appeared to have collapsed once again, said that formation of such ''a new constructive alliance'' was essential.   ''We simply can't go on like this,'' he said.   Last month, King Hassan II of Morocco proposed a meeting of Arab leaders to discuss attacks by Shiite Moslem militias on Palestinian settlements in Lebanon. King Hussein emerged as an ardent supporter of the idea.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Previous   Year

headline: MTV SALE PACT
abstract: The American Express Company has given its consent to an accelerated sale of MTV Networks Inc. to Viacom International. MTV Networks is partly owned by Warner Amex Cable Communications, a joint venture of American Express and Warner Communications.

headline: Pratt & Lambert
abstract: Pratt & Lambert Inc., a paint and chemical maker, said that its board had unanimously rejected the previously announced $60.8 million leveraged buyout proposal made by Carl Marks & Company.

headline: CONSUMER RATES
abstract: In percent

headline: Thai Trials Sought In Journalists' Deaths
abstract: An official of the National Broadcasting Company demanded today that Thailand identify and put on trial the crew of a rebel tank that killed two NBC News journalists as they filmed fighting during an attempted coup here Monday.   ''What we have is a pretty clear case that murder was done here,'' said Bruce McDonell, general manager in Asia for NBC News, of the deaths of Neil Davis, a cameraman, and William Latch, a sound technician. They were killed while they filmed rebel tanks firing at an army building in Bangkok.

headline: NEW THREAT MADE ON BEIRUT CAPTIVES
abstract: An anonymous caller who said he represented the Islamic Holy War organization said today that the group would hold a news conference at which it would produce some of the six Americans whom it is believed to be holding hostage.   The caller, who telephoned a Western news agency here, did not say when or where such a news conference would be held. But he hinted that after the conference the attitude of the kidnappers toward their hostages would be negative.

headline: Futures/Options;   3 Factors Influence Currencies
abstract: RARELY has a major trend in futures prices been so clearly determined by fundamental, technical and human factors as those in the foreign currency markets. Because these three are the major influences in all futures markets, it came as no surprise last week when all key foreign currencies futures posted strong gains.   The spot September British pound futures, for instance, jumped 6 cents last week, to $1.3795; West German marks, 1.37 cents, to 34.90; Swiss francs, 1.92 cents, to 42.03, and it took 240 Japanese yen, in currency unit terms, to buy a dollar, compared with 246.5 on July 5.   ''The chief fundamental factor in foreign exchange cash and futures markets was the decline in our short-term real interest rates,'' said Alan C. Leventen, president of Twenty-First Futures, a division of the Twenty-First Securities Corporation. ''And this factor has been telegraphed to the market daily for the past month.''

headline: Amax Officials Will Retire
abstract: Three executives of Amax Inc., including two of the company's top four officers, announced today that they will retire on Oct. 1.   The announcement came one day after the troubled mining, energy and chemical company announced plans to eliminate 12 percent of its 12,400-member work force and dispose of enough assets to reduce debt by $500 million by the end of 1986.

headline: Sharon Urges Israel to Strike P.L.O. Headquarters in Jordan
abstract: Ariel Sharon called today for Israeli military attacks against P.L.O. headquarters in Jordan in response to terrorist attacks in Israel.

headline: CITADEL HOLDING
abstract: The Citadel Holding Corporation said it had canceled its proposed $109 million takeover by the Great Western Financial Corporation, parent of the nation's third-largest thrift institution, the Great Western Savings and Loan Association. The takeover was agreed to May 20, but a Citadel shareholder group headed by an investor, Alfred Roven, soon opposed it. Mr. Roven emerged the victor in a board room struggle, and Citadel let the takeover plan languish.

headline: DECISION IS DUE ON EPIC UNIT
abstract: A Federal District Court judge in Virginia is scheduled to decide on Tuesday whether to appoint a receiver for the mortgage-banking unit of the EPIC group of companies, which is in default on more than $1 billion in mortgage securities.   In an affidavit filed with the court late last week, Robert N. Kemp Jr., president of EPIC Mortgage Inc., warned that the company could lose as much as $500 million if a receiver were placed in charge of its mortgage-servicing operations. He said the threat of such a loss would force EPIC Mortgage into bankruptcy.   At a court hearing Friday, the National Bank of Washington, the First National Bank of Maryland and the Federal National Mortgage Association, commonly known as Fannie Mae, petitioned Federal Judge Claude Hilton to grant a temporary restraining order against EPIC Mortgage. Fannie Mae holds more than $100 million in EPIC-originated mortgages. The two banks are trustees for holders of almost $1 billion in mortgage-backed securities sold by EPIC in the last three years. EPIC has missed more than $10 million in mortgage-related payments to the two banks.

headline: Toyota Weighs Plant in U.S.
abstract: Japan's largest car maker, the Toyota Motor Corporation, is considering a plan to build a plant to produce cars in the United States, the Kyodo news agency reported today.      Kyodo, quoting unnamed   Toyota officials, said that Toyota, now in a final stage of considering the plan, was expected to announce a final decision possibly as early as next month.

headline: ACTIONS TAKEN TO SPEED REAGAN'S TAX PROPOSAL
abstract: While most of official Washington has left town for the summer, tax specialists on Capitol Hill and at the Treasury Department have been laying the groundwork to speed legislative action on President Reagan's tax overhaul proposal when Congress returns from its recess.   The behind-the-scenes activity is aimed at insuring that the issue of tax revision is quickly thrust to the forefront of the Congressional and Administration agenda after Labor Day.   Although the prospects for House and Senate passage of sweeping tax overhaul legislation late this year or early next year are uncertain, the preparations that have taken place in the last two weeks - and that have been scheduled to take place in the next several weeks - are aimed at facilitating swift movement of the legislation through the House this fall while the President tries to build up public and Congressional support.   In the last two weeks, staff members of the House Ways and Means Committee, where tax bills originate, have drafted into statutory language substantial portions of the President's plan to prevent the lengthy drafting process from slowing movement of a bill through Congress. Members of the committee are set to begin work on the bill on Sept. 17.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: * Catalyst Energy Development Corp. said it had entered into a construction contract with Bechtel National Inc., Oak Ridge, Tenn., a unit of Bechtel Group, and the city of New Martinsville, W. Va., for the construction of a 34-megawatt hydroelectric generating facility for a total cost of $95 million.    * Chrysler Corp. said it would offer a $400 discount or the option of 8.8 percent financing on leftover 1984 and 1985 Dodge Aries and Plymouth Reliants.

headline: MARTIAL LAW IS LIFTED IN SOME PARTS OF TURKEY
abstract: T The authorities lifted martial law today in 6 of 24 provinces after six and a half years, but they showed no sign of ending it in the southeast of the country where Kurdish rebels skirmish almost daily with troops.

headline: Nestle to Close Libby Units
abstract: Nestle Holdings Inc., the United States subsidiary of Nestle S.A., the giant Swiss-based food company, said today that it would be closing the headquarters and food production facilities of its Libby, McNeill & Libby division within the next six to nine months. The closings will idle 655 employees.

headline: SOVIET SCHOOLS: IS SKEPTICISM STARTING TO SPROUT?
abstract: ''The United States is washed by the Atlantic Ocean in the east and by the Pacific Ocean in the west,'' begins a chapter in a seventh-grade Soviet English-language textbook.   ''Now the U.S. imperialists are claiming world supremacy,'' it says later. ''They are setting up military blocs and preparing for a new war.''   Facts in Soviet textbooks are treated much the same way as in the controlled press and in other books: they are presented in a way that will support the ideological bias that governs Soviet public life, and they are accompanied by the catch phrases of Soviet propaganda.

headline: PATENTS;  Way to Make Materials For Duplicating Teeth
abstract: Dr. Howard Cohen, a Long Island orthodontist, was granted a patent this week on materials for duplicating teeth. He believes this represents a major advancement in dentistry and thinks patent 4,543,063 will increase the effectiveness and quality in the construction of fixed bridges and crowns.  This week's patent, which is related to one he received in 1984, describes a method of using a photochemically cured elastomer as an implant, by exposing the area, applying the material, shaping it in the desired form and subsequently curing it under visible light sources.

headline: Eurobond Issue From Insurer
abstract: CMT International, a unit of the Connecticut Mutual Life Insurance Company, is issuing $343.7 million of Eurobonds backed by commercial mortgages, through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers International.   The bonds, which are similar to other issues arranged recently by mutual insurance companies in the Eurobond market, are secured by a pool of more than 100 seasoned commercial loans whose mortgage payments will be sufficient to pay interest and principal on the bonds.

headline: PATENTS;  Radar System Identifies Aircraft by Their Speed
abstract: A radar system for identifying aircraft by their speed has been invented for the Department of Transportation.

headline: Glemp Returns to Poland
abstract: Jozef Cardinal Glemp, head of the Roman Catholic Church in Poland, returned home today from what he called a ''very successful'' one-week trip to the United States.

headline: UNITED NATIONS CALENDAR
abstract: DAY NO. 5 - A King, a Prime Minister and a President are among those who are to address the General Assembly today. The assembly has already heard from 43 foreign delegations as it enters its fifth day of debate. King Hussein of Jordan is to begin the morning session and will be followed by the Polish leader, Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski, and the Foreign Ministers of East Germany, Madagascar and Afghanistan. President Julius K. Nyerere of Tanzania is to lead off in the afternoon. He will be followed by the Foreign Ministers of Ireland, Rumania, Saudi Arabia, Burma, Zaire and Sierra Leone.

headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE;Monsanto President Persistent on Searle
abstract: He says that he likes the necktie, but Richard J. Mahoney clearly had more than mere fashion on his mind when he went to work on Friday wearing a new purchase.         ''I like this tie a lot,'' said Mr. Mahoney, who is the president and chief executive officer of the Monsanto Company. ''It's blue with a horizontal stripe, and it has the Nutrasweet swirl logo on it. We like Nutrasweet a lot.''

headline: Spanish Chief Gets Apology After Iran Diverts His Plane
abstract: Prime Minister Felipe Gonzalez of Spain said today that Iran's Prime Minister has sent him a message of deep regret after Iran diverted his plane and made him late for a visit to China.   Mr. Gonzalez arrived in Peking for an official visit more than six hours late on Wednesday, because Teheran Air Defense abruptly banned all traffic in the area that his plane had previously received Iranian permission to cross.   At a news conference in Peking, Mr. Gonzalez said he had received a message from Prime Minister Mir Hussein Moussavi saying, ''The Iranian Prime Minister wishes to express his deep regret at this incident.''

headline: Trade Study Is Blocked
abstract: The White House Office of Management and Budget has scuttled a proposed study by the United States International Trade Commission into practices of semiconductor manufacturers, officials of both agencies said today. The move marks the first time the O.M.B. has blocked a proposed study by the trade commission, an independent agency.

headline: CONDOMINIUM CONVERSION IN HOBOKEN
abstract: In 1979 Robert S. Cohen was a composer struggling to earn a living in regional theater and university teaching. He had two music degrees and knew little about business, but he managed to get a marketing job at a computer services company. He figured that if he was going to learn the job he had better go to the company's top marketing representative and ask if he could accompany him on a call.   ''He was talking this financial stuff,'' Mr. Cohen recalled. ''I had never heard things like 'internal rate of return.' I was surprised people could communicate like this.''

headline: OPEC May Meet Oct. 3
abstract: Oil ministers of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries have tentatively scheduled a special conference for Oct. 3 to discuss production, an OPEC source confirmed today.

headline: DYNAMICS WILL CLOSE QUINCY SHIPYARD IN 1986
abstract: The General Dynamics Corporation, the nation's third-largest defense contractor, announced yesterday that it would close its shipyard at Quincy, Mass., following completion next year of a Navy ship construction program. The company blamed poor business conditions.   The yard, which employs 4,200 people, was opened 101 years ago and is one of the largest industrial facilities in the Boston area. It has built more than 600 ships.

headline: WHEN IT PAYS TO REFINANCE A MORTGAGE
abstract: WHEN Robert J. Grosso and his wife, Carolyn, bought their five-bedroom colonial in New Jersey two years ago, they financed the property with a 13 7/8 percent, variable-rate mortgage. They recently discovered that they owed almost $4,000 more than they had originally borrowed. The mortgage had a negative amortization feature, so when rates increased, the monthly payment remained the same and the difference was added to the principal. Dismayed, the couple decided to shop for a better deal.   Now that mortgage money is comparatively plentiful and rates are down, many property owners are taking out their calculators to figure out whether it is worthwhile to renegotiate their loans. Some are saddled with mortgages of 15 percent or more that they picked up when interest rates peaked a few years ago. Others face negative amortization, potentially unlimited rate increases or other unfavorable terms that they agreed to as a trade-off for lower initial rates. Still others want to cash in on the equity they have built up over years of rising home prices.

headline: PARLEY TO RECLAIM GLORY OF VERSAILLES
abstract: A week of scholarship and spectacle - bringing together academics, artists, socialites and politicians - opens on Sept. 29 in the palace of Versailles, once the center of cultural and political power in Western Europe. The visitors are expected to include Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader.   The event, the Versailles Colloquium, represents an attempt to reclaim, if only for a few days, the influence and importance its court once conveyed. There will be learned discourses on the architecture and horticulture and history of Versailles. There will be period operas performed for an elite audience. There will be cocktails in the chateau. Plans for the colloquium began three years ago with the relatively modest notion of two New Yorkers to hold a meeting of Versailles experts, a small and farflung fraternity indeed. The two men - Prof. Guy Walton of New York University and W. Howard Adams, an author and scholar on the French garden - admit to some shock at the dimensions their intellectual exercise achieved.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: * American Can Co., Greenwich, Conn., has appointed Walter A. Scott senior vice president and deputy sector executive of its financial services sector. He was also named senior executive vice president of Associated Madison Companies Inc., the holding company for all of American Can's financial services subsidiaries.    * Barton Brands Ltd., Chicago, has appointed John C. Negri executive vice president of marketing.

headline: TRW Unit Gets Contract
abstract: A unit of TRW Inc. has been selected to design a communications network for the Defense Department that would handle intelligence and command and control message traffic.

headline: U.S. CREATES AN OFFICE FOR ANTI-SANDINISTA AID
abstract: President Reagan announced today that he had set up a special office to distribute $27 million in ''humanitarian assistance'' to the rebels who are seeking to overthrow the Nicaraguan Government.   Mr. Reagan, in making the announcement, said the United States sought ''to support the democratic center against extremes of right and left'' in Nicaragua.   White House aides said the office would operate as a separate body within the State Department, similar to the Agency for International Development. Officials said the State Department would replace the Central Intelligence Agency as the vehicle for channeling American aid to the Nicaraguan rebels.

headline: BLOCK ON 'GOOD WILL' SOVIET TRIP
abstract: Agriculture Secretary John R. Block arrived in Moscow today and said he and a top-level team of American farm figures were seeking to expand agricultural trade with the Soviet Union during a weeklong ''good will'' trip.   Speaking at the airport after being met by the Soviet Agriculture Minister, Valentin K. Mesyats, Mr. Block said American-Soviet agricultural relations were productive but ''not entirely trouble-free.''

headline: AN ORE CARRIER'S TROUBLED ODYSSEY
abstract: IT is daybreak but a cold clammy fog blocks out the sun. Throughout the night, long steel arms, reaching out from the dock, have poured tens of thousands of tons of iron ore into the ship's 20 cargo hatches.   Finally, the Edwin H. Gott's huge holds are full, and it is time for Burt W. Winkel, the captain, and his 28-member crew, to begin the 1,000-mile voyage from Two Harbors, Minn., an aging iron ore port north of Duluth. For three full days, the Gott will carry the ore of Minnesota's Iron Range across the Great Lakes east and south to the steel mills of Indiana and Ohio. There is trouble at both ends of the voyage:   Closed mines and shuttered mills bear witness to rampant joblessness, to huge financial losses for hobbled industries and to foreclosed mortgages for thousands of families. But in the days at sea, such difficulties seem lightyears away.   As far as Captain Winkel is concerned, his is the best job in the withered steel industry. He navigates one of the most modern ships that ply the nation's vast inland waterways. The Gott is one of the grand 1,000-foot vessels of the Great Lakes, carrying four times the iron ore of the 600-foot ships that once ruled the inland waters.

headline: Pakistan Tells of Plan To End Martial Law
abstract: Prime Minister Mohammed Khan Junejo said today that martial law in Pakistan would be lifted after eight years and democracy completely restored within five months.

headline: AFGHAN DRIVE CALLED A FAILURE
abstract: Afghan rebels said today that one of the fiercest Soviet offensives in the six-year Afghan conflict had failed to cut guerrilla supply routes from Pakistan.   The monthlong offensive in Paktia Province, bordering Pakistan, appeared to end on Friday when Soviet and Afghan soldiers began retreating from a front south of the garrison town of Khost, said the Peshawar-based Moslem rebel sources.

headline: Two New Accounts For Tracy-Locke
abstract: Tracy-Locke/BBDO has been assigned two new accounts. The Dallas-based agency has been selected by Pepsico Inc. of Purchase, N.Y., to handle the advertising for its Pepsico Food Service Division, which markets Pepsi products to fountain customers.

headline: AT A HOLY CITY IN FRANCE, NO ROOM FOR A TAVERN?
abstract: The souvenir shops in this sainted city of pilgrims, shops that have names like Our Lady of Perpetual Aid, offer an array of flickering, plastic objects for sale that may fall short of high art. But the shops reflect the dominant tone of Lourdes, where some 45,000 of the faithful come every day to visit the holiest Roman Catholic site in France.   Every afternoon here, particularly in the busy August vacation season, a solemn and colorful procession of visitors - many of them disabled or sick, and wheeled on stretcher beds or pulled along by volunteers in blue canopied carriages - makes its way past the grotto, where the Virgin Mary is believed to have appeared to St. Bernadette in 1858. The procession goes on to the esplanade in front of the Basilica of the Immaculate Conception for the celebration of a multilingual mass.

headline: CHILD CARE
abstract: To the Editor:   The ''child-care specialists'' who say it's damaging to return to work after eight weeks are only telling half the story. It's around six months that the real difficulties begin.

headline: Purchaser of Tower Has Big Coast Holdings
abstract: The price, Walter H. Shorenstein acknowledged yesterday, was a full one: $660 million for 1.8 million square feet of office space. But Mr. Shorenstein, who on Friday agreed to pay that much for BankAmerica's 52-story world headquarters tower and two adjoining buildings in downtown San Francisco, said the buildings are worth the money.   ''BankAmerica is the premier property in San Francisco,'' Mr. Shorenstein said in a telephone interview, ''and when you look at this complex, it fits together with a lot of our other properties.''

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST: WEDNESDAY, AUGUST 28, 1985
abstract: International    South Africa halted trading on its stock and currency markets as its currency plunged to its lowest level ever. The suspension is in effect until Monday. The extreme step, which is rare in a country with an advanced economy, follows months of increasing capital flight. Since a state of emergency was declared in some areas in July, the rand has lost almost 25 percent of its value. [Page A1.]      The Economy    The Pentagon, after spending $1.8 billion, halted purchases of the Army's Sergeant York antiaircraft gun. Defense Secretary Weinberger said the weapon, made by Ford Motor, was ''not worth the cost.'' [A1.]  While some jobs are likely to be lost, the cancellation is not expected to have much impact on Ford. [A18.]

headline: DOG DAYS ON WALL ST.: THE DEALS MUST GO ON
abstract: On Wall Street, where succeeding in business means really trying, this week's steamy weather and attendant power disruptions have been just another opportunity for some of the deal makers to show what stern stuff they're made of.   Whatever the weather, said Eugene Matalene, vice president of the corporate finance department at Kidder, Peabody & Company, ''if someone wants to do a financing, the investment bankers will be there.''   Admittedly, the multibillion-dollar deals have largely dried up in the summer heat, and the Hamptons are said to be populated with superstars of the takeover fraternity. But the Street continues to churn out the dozens of lesser deals that are its staple. The generals may have captured the beaches, but the captains and lieutenants slog on.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: SATURDAY, SEPTEMBER 14, 1985        The Economy    Retail sales and industrial production rose in August, the Government reported.   But analysts, who noted that the output gain fell short of expectations and that the sales figures were inflated by financing incentives by auto makers, said the two reports were disappointing. [Page 31.]  The huge jump in auto sales pushed retail sales up 1.9 percent in August. [32.]  Producer prices fell three-tenths of 1 percent last month. [32.]

headline: PATENTS;  Dispenser of Liquids For Pets and Plants
abstract: John A. Paoluccio of Modesto, Calif., got a patent this week for a liquid-dispensing device that provides water for birds, small animals, plants and the like.

headline: SCHOOL COSTS MAY REQUIRE NEW TACTICS
abstract: THE Reagan tax proposals, if they become law, could make a big difference in how parents finance their children's education. Those who have used trusts, for example, must beware, said Warren S. Shine, a tax principal with the accounting firm of Ernst & Whinney, because the President ''proposes to slice these out of existence.'' Amid all the possible changes there appears to be but one certainty: Educational costs will continue to rise. So, planners say, parents would do well this fall to re-examine their full range of options.   Under current law, people with investment income may establish what are known as Clifford Trusts to shift some of their income to their children, whose tax brackets are lower. Clifford Trusts must extend for at least 10 years and a day, after which the assets held in trust revert to the person who established it.

headline: BEIRUT RETURNS TO NORMAL: SEVEN HOURS OF COMBAT
abstract: With the release of the 39 American hostages, Beirut returned to normal today.   Hours after the hostages from the hijacked airliner were driven to Damascus, Syria, after 17 days of captivity, Druse and Shiite Moslem militiamen clashed in West Beirut with automatic weapons and rocket-propelled grenades.   The police estimated that at least 7 people were killed and 20 wounded in seven hours of fighting.   It was the Shiite militia Amal, led by Nabih Berri, that had assumed custody of all but four of the hostages in Beirut; the automobile convoy that took the Americans to Syria had been escorted by gunmen from Amal as well as Druse militiamen.

headline: THE HOME OF ROLLS-ROYCE SLIDES INTO A RECESSION
abstract: They used to say that the East Midlands - the industrial area centered on Leicester and Derby and Coventry - was immune to recession.   But you don't hear that kind of talk anymore in Derby, a city whose prosperity was guaranteed for decades by big employers such as British Rail and Rolls-Royce. The rest of Britain may not have noticed because Derby's decline has not been as dramatic as Liverpool's or Newcastle's, but the city has slipped onto the debit side of Britain's divided society. It is a new recruit to The Other Britain - the one that shares little of the hustle and sheen of the southeast.   Unlike Port Talbot in Wales, Derby has escaped the grip of pervasive fatalism; people here still think things can get better. While Port Talbot represents places where once-thriving industries have crumbled, Derby is one of those places where once-labor-intensive industries have successfully automated, costing thousands of jobs. And even the optimists here do not expect enormous improvement soon.

headline: A Revamping at Moseley
abstract: Moseley, Hallgarten, Estabrook & Weeden Inc. said yesterday that it was reorganizing its government securities department, following large trading losses in the last 15 months.   Moseley will continue to be a dealer in government securities, but its activities will be reduced.

headline: F.T.C. Decision On Olin-FMC
abstract: The Olin Corporation may complete its $49.5 million acquisition of portions of the FMC Corporation, but must maintain the FMC assets as a separate operation pending a final Federal Trade Commission ruling on the purchase, the commission said today.

headline: REAGAN WEIGHING TRADE SANCTIONS, OFFICIALS REPORT
abstract: President Reagan is considering punitive actions against ''unfair'' trade practices, but has decided not to curb the volume of foreign shoes coming into the United States, Administration officials said today.   The two-pronged approach would represent an apparent answer by Mr. Reagan to strong protectionist feelings in Congress and his long-held opposition to such trade restrictions, the officials said.   The most likely target of Mr. Reagan's crackdown would be the flood of counterfeit products coming into the United States from Taiwan under infringements of American copyright laws, the officials said, including such things as blue jeans.      Broad Powers Available    The officials said that Mr. Reagan was considering imposing Section 301 of the 1974 Trade Act, which gives the President broad powers to deal with unfair trade practices. By using such an approach, the President could take advantage of existing laws, which would reinforce the Administration's contention that more stringent measures are not required.

headline: U.S. 'Ready' to Reopen Cuba Immigration Pact
abstract: Secretary of State George P. Shultz said today that the Reagan Administration was ''ready'' on ''short notice'' to reactivate an immigration agreement with Cuba that was terminated by Fidel Castro.   Mr. Shultz called on the Cuban leader to reverse his decision, made in response to the United States beginning Radio Marti broadcasts to Cuba last May. Mr. Shultz said the United States was ready to receive 1,800 former Cuban political prisoners.

headline: CAR BOMB KILLS 2 ON A U.S. AIR BASE IN WEST GERMANY
abstract: A car bomb exploded today outside the headquarters building at this United States military base, killing two Americans and wounding about 20 people, both Americans and West Germans.   Kurt Rebmann, the West German Prosecutor, said the attack bore ''the handwriting of the Red Army Faction,'' a terrorist group that appears to have succeeded the Baader-Meinhof Gang of the 1970's.   The incident at the air base, which is near Frankfurt, was the worst attack on an American installation in West Germany since the bombing of Ramstein Air Base in 1981, when 18 people were wounded. It was the latest of a series of assaults on military targets in Western Europe, apparently in response to the deployment of United States medium-range missiles.

headline: U.S. OFFICIAL REPORTING GAINS ON A CHINESE NUCLEAR ACCORD
abstract: A Reagan Administration official said today that the United States and China had made progress on a nuclear energy accord that has been held up for a year.   The official said the pact would be concluded in time for a visit by President Li Xiannian of China in two weeks. Other officials cautioned that technical details could delay completion.

headline: Japan Crash Insurance
abstract: At least $27.5 million in accident insurance, the largest amount for a single accident in Japan, will be paid to victims of the crash of a Japan Air Lines plane 11 days ago, the Marine and Fire Insurance Association of Japan said today.

headline: Egypt May Cut Oil Price
abstract: Egypt is considering an oil price cut, a senior oil ministry official, who declined to be identified, said today. Egypt's prices run from $26.75 a barrel to $25.

headline: 2 ISRAELI SOLDIERS AND 3 GUERRILLAS KILLED IN SOUTH LEBANON SHOOTOUT
abstract: Two Israeli soldiers and three Lebanese guerrillas were killed today in a shootout in south Lebanon, an Israeli Army spokesman announced.   The spokesman described the incident as the biggest shootout in the area since most of the Israeli Army was withdrawn last June.   The two slain Israelis were the first Israeli soldiers to die from wounds inflicted in Lebanon since April 24. That was by far the longest stretch of time for Israel to go without a death in Lebanon since the invasion of that country began on June 6, 1982. The total number of Israelis killed in action in Lebanon is now 656.

headline: VETERAN REUNION DRAWING PROTESTS
abstract: Veterans of an American infantry division and the German Waffen SS soldiers they battled in World War II more than 40 years ago have been exchanging visits for a decade and plan to meet again in a few weeks, according to members of the American group.   The organizer of this year's reunion said Friday that the recent disclosure of the meeting had drawn protests and a warning from a United States Army spokesman and that the veterans would therefore cancel their traditional get-together in a cemetery in France and meet instead in a small Bavarian spa.   ''We don't want to cause another Bitburg,'' said Floyd Freeman, a veteran of the 70th Infantry Division, alluding to President Reagan's divisive wreath-laying in May at a German military cemetery that has Waffen SS graves.   Mr. Freeman, who is a travel agent in South Gate, in the Los Angeles area, arranged this year's trip by 25 veterans and their wives. He said the exchange began after the brother of a 70th Division soldier who was killed in the war met the German veterans on a visit to West Germany in 1975. The next year, the Germans were invited to attend the American group's convention in Toledo, Ohio.

headline: STABLES OF DIVERSE COMPANIES
abstract: Machine tools, trucking, construction, lodging, retail stores. An enterprise with all of those businesses under the same roof could be an old-fashioned conglomerate.   Actually, the owner is Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company, a Wall Street investment firm that specializes in leveraged buyouts, the popular takeover strategy that results in a heavy debt load for the acquired company.   Kohlberg and several other concerns have completed so many buyouts in the past few years that they have quietly built up stables of diverse companies, just as the conglomerate builders did in the 1960's.

headline: SHORT INTEREST ON BIG BOARD OFF 1.7 MILLION SHARES
abstract: The New York Stock Exchange reported yesterday that short interest fell 1.7 million shares, or seven-tenths of 1 percent, in the month ended July 15, to 251.3 million shares. The record of 253 million shares was set last month. The short interest for the period a year earlier was 201.6 million shares.   In the same period, the short interest on the American Stock Exchange was down 792,761 shares, to about 16.7 million shares.   A short position can result from the sale of borrowed stock in the hope of buying the same issue at a later date and at a lower price to cover the sale.

headline: Dividend Meetings
abstract: Following is a partial list of dividend meeting for the week of July 29,1985:

headline: ELECTRONIC MAIL
abstract: To the Editor:   There are indeed serious problems within the electronic mail industry (''When Technology Outpaces Needs,'' June 9), at least some of them stemming from overly optimistic expectations among vendors regarding the pace at which electronic mail systems would grow. As Erik Sandberg-Diment avers, there are also problems in the lack of universal accessibility to electronic mail networks.

headline: NAIL-STUDDED CAR BOMB KILLS 12
abstract: A car packed with nail-studded TNT exploded in a fireball today outside an apartment complex in East Beirut, the Christian area of the city. At least 12 people were killed and 120 wounded.   The police estimated that more than 400 pounds of TNT had been packed into the car, a gray Mercedes sedan.

headline: Economic Calendar
abstract: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week.      Monday

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: Bell Atlantic Mobile Systems, a unit of Bell Atlantic Corp., Philadelphia, said it had entered a marketing partnership with Dollar Rent-a-Car to put Alex cellular mobile telephones in 100 Philadelphia-area Dollar cars by the end of the summer.    * Cox Cable Communications Inc., a subsidiary of Cox Communications Inc., Atlanta, and Storer Communications Inc. said they had completed the exchange of certain cable TV systems in California and Florida.

headline: REAGAN MAY SEEK TRUST LAW EASING
abstract: The Reagan Administration is considering asking Congress to relax the nation's antimonopoly laws because they might inhibit American industry's ability to compete abroad, Secretary of Commerce Malcolm Baldrige said today.   The Secretary, who has been advocating such changes for months, said that the President had been urged to cite the possibility in the trade-policy speech he is expected to make next week.   ''Other countries aren't impeded by the kinds of antitrust laws that we have,'' Mr. Baldrige said in an interview.   Among the changes Mr. Baldrige said the Administration would consider were his recommendation for repeal of Section 7 of the 1914 Clayton Act. That act, one of the pillars of antitrust law, prohibits mergers that would tend to diminish competiton.

headline: Chairman Is Named At Arthur Young
abstract: Arthur Young & Company, the international accounting and consulting firm, has named its managing partner, William L. Gladstone, to the additional post of chairman, effective Oct. 1.   Mr. Gladstone, 54 years old, succeeds William S. Kanaga, 60, who is retiring in accordance with the firm's policy requiring partners to step down at age 60. Mr. Kanaga will remain an adviser to the firm.   As managing partner since 1981, Mr. Gladstone has effectively been chief executive of Arthur Young, which has 2,400 partners in more than 350 cities worldwide. He is credited with leading an aggressive drive to expand the firm's business.

headline: Nominee Not Expected To Alter Antitrust Unit
abstract: Federal antitrust policy would not be substantially changed under Douglas H. Ginsburg, according to friends and associates of President Reagan's nominee to head the Justice Department's antitrust division.   Mr. Ginsburg, 39, a former Harvard Law School professor and a supporter of deregulation, would become an Assistant Attorney General, filling the vacancy created when J. Paul McGrath left the department last April to return to private law pratice.   Charles F. Rule, a Deputy Assistant Attorney General who has been acting head of the division since Mr. McGrath's resignation, will continue in that post until Mr. Ginsburg's confirmation by the Senate, a spokesman said.

headline: Guerrillas in Uganda Attack Army Garrison Near Capital
abstract: Rebel guerrillas attacked a Government army garrison less than 10 miles west of Kampala today and exchanged mortar and rocket fire with troops north of the capital, Western diplomats said.

headline: PHILLIPS FIGHTS SINKING OF SEABED OFF NORWAY
abstract: Last November, just before top executives at the Bartlesville, Okla., headquarters of the Phillips Petroleum Company became preoccupied with fighting off a takeover attempt led by T. Boone Pickens, they got some bad news from company officials responsible for operating the Ekofisk field in the North Sea southwest of here.   Ekofisk Center, the 250,000-ton concrete platform that is nearly twice as tall as the Statue of Liberty and is the operational heart of the field, seemed to be sinking. Further investigation confirmed that the seabed was subsiding as the reservoirs below it were drained, pulling the center and nearby platforms ever closer to the predictable reach of freak waves. Ever since, Phillips has been wrestling with a major challenge.

headline: American Can's Stake in Jefferies
abstract: The American Can Company said that it had agreed to increase its stake in the Jefferies Group Inc. to as much as 20 percent.

headline: Accounts
abstract: * Baltimore Sun Newspapers' Evening Sun, Sun classifieds and Sun trade advertising to W. B. Doner & Co., Baltimore.    * De Scenza Jewelers to Arnold & Co. and Arnold Public Relations, Boston.

headline: LAGGING SALARIES CAUSE SHORTAGES
abstract: TEN years ago, when the term was new, office automation conjured in many minds a futuristic vision of desks populated by electronic occupants with silicon souls - while the secretaries who once occupied those desks stood on the unemployment lines.   It has not happened that way at all. Bureau of Labor Statistics figures show that over the last decade the number of secretaries in the country has increased steadily, and will continue to rise through at least 1992. And even with that increase, there are more secretarial jobs than there are trained people to fill them.

headline: Upjohn Plant
abstract: The Upjohn Company said it was investing $23 million in a plant to make a drug that may cure baldness. The drug, minoxidil, is in the final stages of testing on human volunteers, and Upjohn hopes to ask the Food and Drug Administration this year for permission to market the product as a prescription medicine, said Peter Maas, a company spokesman. The drug has been prescribed for years to control high blood pressure under the trade name Loniten, but F.D.A. approval of its use to cure baldness may be several years away.

headline: Management Shifts For Union Carbide
abstract: The Union Carbide Corporation, in a top-level management restructuring, yesterday named Alec Flamm, its president and chief operating officer, to a newly created position of vice chairman. It also promoted two executive vice presidents to share the responsibities that have been held by Mr. Flamm.   The changes appeared to position Mr. Flamm, 58 years old, to succeed Warren M. Anderson, Carbide's 63-year-old chairman. Analysts said the changes also relieved Mr. Flamm of some of the intense, day-to-day responsibilities that he has taken on since the lethal gas leak at Carbide's pesticides plant in Bhopal, India, last December.

headline: Steinberg Gains at Brokerage
abstract: With a sweeping reorganization of its top management, Frank B. Hall & Company, the nation's third-largest publicly traded insurance brokerage, effectively placed control of the company yesterday in the hands of Saul P. Steinberg, its largest stockholder.   In a news release, the company said that Albert J. Tahmoush, who has run the company since 1977, had resigned. Two executive vice presidents were named to succeed Mr. Tahmoush, 64 years old, who had served as chairman, chief executive, president and chief operating officer.

headline: Magazine Campaign Is Planned
abstract: THE Magazine Publishers Association is starting a new advertising campaign next week (in magazines, of course) with the usual goal in mind: more advertising dollars for its members.   The message of the old campaign had to do with using magazines to reach people who apparently have become network TV dropouts, the ones accounting for so-called erosion.   The new effort, created by D'Arcy MacManus Masius, is out to attract marketing copycats - the advertiser companies that follow paths taken by the sophisticated giants.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Previous   Year

headline: UNITED NATIONS CALENDAR
abstract: SOVIET TURN TO SPEAK - The Soviet Union takes its turn at the podium today when Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze addresses the delegates. While Mr. Shevardnadze speaks, Avital Shcharansky, wife of Anatoly B. Shcharansky, a Soviet labor camp inmate, said she would hold what she calls a ''General Assembly of Truth'' from a symbolic prison cage outside the United Nations headquarters.   The cage will be placed near the base of the Shcharansky Steps, so named by the New York City Council several years ago, at 43d Street and First Avenue.

headline: Toyota Gesture
abstract: Toyota, Japan's largest car maker, said it planned to bring more foreign parts and materials into Japan this year at the Government's request. The company's vice president, Hiroyasu Ono, said Toyota planned to import $246 million worth of goods in 1985, compared with $193 million last year. The move is a gesture toward helping reduce the country's big trade surplus.

headline: Aide in Western India Resigns After Clashes
abstract: The Chief Minister of the west Indian state of Gujurat resigned today after failing to curb four months of violence, and the state's Interior Minister was chosen to replace him.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: Aetna Life and Casualty Co., Hartford, said it had signed an agreement with Banco Hispano Americano to acquire a significant minority interest in La Estrella, a multi-line insurance company with assets of more than $84 million.    * American Telephone and Telegraph Co. said it had reached an agreement with CNCP Telecommunications of Canada to provide private line communications services between that nation and the United States.    * Dow Chemical Co., Midland, Mich., said it would sell its plant in Plaqwuemine, La., which builds slurry-process high density polyethylene, as part of a consolidation move.

headline: July 14, 1985
abstract: THE ECONOMY

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: * Bloomingdale's has named Russel Stravitz executive vice president, stores merchandising, and Jeffrey Sherman executive vice president, finance and control and management information systems.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST: WEDNESDAY, AUGUST 7, 1985
abstract: Markets    Stock prices plunged on concern over the course of interest rates in light of the big Treasury financing that is under way. The Dow Jones industrial average lost 21.73 points, falling to 1,325.16, in its biggest decline since February 1984. Trading was moderate, at 104 million shares. Besides the bond market, analysts said, stocks were unsettled by general worries about the Federal deficit and the health of the economy. Transportation issues continued to post sharp declines. [Page D1.]    The Treasury sold $8.5 billion in three-year notes in the first leg of a three-part, $21.75 billion financing. Securities dealers had been watching investor demand with considerable interest, and one said the auction was ''modestly well received.'' The 9 1/2 percent issue sold at an average yield of 9.53 percent, the lowest for a three-year issue since May 1983. The domestic banking system was thought to have absorbed much of the issue, but banks are not expected to offer much help to the Treasury in its following two parts of the auction. Interest rates over all were little changed. [D13.]

headline: New York City Prices $350 Million of Bonds
abstract: New York City tentatively priced $350 million of general obligation bonds yesterday through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company.   The financing consists of serial bonds that were offered with yields ranging from 5 percent for bonds due in 1986 to 7 1/2 percent in 1990, 9 percent in 1998, 9 1/8 percent in 2002 and 9.30 percent in 2009.

headline: Recession Seen in '86
abstract: If the present economic upswing follows historic patterns, the United States will sink into a recession late next year and the Federal budget deficit will surge to more than $400 billion by 1989, according to a Congressional study issued today. Representative David R. Obey, a Wisconsin Democrat who is chairman of the Joint Economic Committee, released the report by the Congressional Research Service. He said that the report also indicated the United States would remain heavily dependent on foreign borrowing through 1990.

headline: Bank Group Head Named at Hanover
abstract: The Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company yesterday named C. William Schroth, a senior vice president and head of its United States merchant banking activities, to head its merchant banking group worldwide. He succeeds Stephen Antony Constance, 45 years old, who plans to leave the bank in September.   Mr. Schroth, 37, will be responsible for all merchant banking operations, including interest rate and currency swaps, private placements and mergers and acquisitions. He will report to Douglas E. Ebert, sector executive vice president for the bank's investment banking sector.

headline: PATENTS;  Sensitive Technique Aids Cancer Detection
abstract: A sensitive technique for detecting disease-causing substances, antigens and the antibodies produced in response to them was patented this week. The inventors are Yi-Her Jou and Richard B. Bankert, who did their research at the Roswell Park Memorial Institute in Buffalo and received patent 4,529,712.  The technique, which may permit early detection of cancer, the monitoring of tumor growth and the production of effective anti-tumor agents is being licensed by the Research Corporation, which has offices in Tucson, Ariz., and Port Washington, L.I. The rights are administered under an agreement with Health Research Inc., a unit of the New York State Health Department.

headline: WHAT'S NEW IN THE PET BUSINESS;  THE END OF THE MOM-AND-POP STORE
abstract: PET owners who push their shopping carts through the carpeted aisles of The Pet Department, a 7,800-square-foot pet products store in Los Angeles, can be overwhelmed with choices. The store stocks more than 5,000 items, from avocado-based dog food to honey-coated bird treats. Uniformed employees help customers choose among a dozen types of dog dishes and 500 different leashes while music plays softly in the background. ''It's a pet supermarket,'' said Larry Miller, a former NBC television executive whose three Los Angeles Pet Department stores will take in about $3 million this year.

headline: AROUND THE WORLD;Mozambican Rebels Accused of Killing 33
abstract: The official Mozambique radio said today that guerrillas killed 33 villagers  attending a funeral near this southeast African country's border with Malawi.         The radio, quoting military sources, said the attack took place Tuesday in a  cemetery in Intaque village in Tete province. No details were available.

headline: A ROUSING START BUT A SHAKY FUTRURE
abstract: LAST Monday, Alfred G. Roth pulled out of the driveway of his suburban home at 2:30 A.M. and was behind his desk at Chemical Bank long before dawn. That day, as the bank's chief foreign exchange trader, he was in the thick of the action that drove down the dollar by a hefty 5 percent against other foreign currencies.   By Friday, the tempo had softened. The dollar's value was still about where it had been on Monday, and the excitement generated by last Sunday's decision of the West's five major industrial nation's to reduce the dollar's value seemed to have worn off. Indeed, Hurricane Gloria was of much greater concern to Mr. Roth. By 10:30 A.M., trading in New York had all but halted and he quickly left his office for the drive to his Irvington, N.Y., home before the hurricane struck.

headline: New Ford Engines
abstract: The Ford Motor Company's British subsidiary said that it would invest $204 million to produce up to 200,000 new ''lean burn'' engines, with production starting in 1987.

headline: Truck and Bus Deregulation
abstract: THE Senate today begins its part of the final required annual Congressional assessment of reduced regulation of the motor carrier industry. A parade of witnesses is scheduled to testify before the Subcommittee on Surface Transportation of the Senate Committee on Commerce, Science and Transportation.

headline: Israeli Aide in New York
abstract: The Israeli Foreign Ministry announced today that its new consul general in New York City, Moshe Yegar, would assume his post Tuesday. He will replace Naphtali Lavie, who is leaving the Foreign Ministry. Mr. Yegar, 55 years old, was formerly the Foreign Ministry's Assistant Director General for Information. He served two previous tours in the United States, as consul in Los Angeles and consul general in Philadelphia.

headline: Portugal Train Toll At 54 Dead, 64 Missing
abstract: The official death toll in a train collision rose to 54 today, but the authorities said at least 64 people were still missing, their bodies believed buried in the charred wreckage.   Eleven foreigners, including 5 from Finland, 2 from Norway and 4 from Luxembourg, were among the missing.   A technician in the regional social security center in Viseu said 64 people known to have boarded the train did not appear on the lists of survivors or dead.

headline: Terrorists in Philippines Kill 25 in Movie House
abstract: Terrorists threw grenades into a crowded movie house in the southern Philippines today, killing at least 25 people and wounding more than 100, the authorities said.

headline: HUTTON: WHERE THINGS STAND
abstract: The Justice Department is beginning to say we told you so.   For almost three months, Congressional investigators have been digging into wrongdoing by E. F. Hutton & Company and into the Justice Department's decision to permit the big securities firm to plead guilty to defrauding more than 400 banks of millions of dollars without at the same time indicting a single Hutton executive. That decision aroused wide accusations of undue lenience.   The House Judiciary subcommittee on crime has subpoenaed tens of thousands of documents and conducted three days of hearings. It has uncovered new documents showing that top Hutton executives were clearly aware that the firm systematically overdrafted its bank accounts and applauded the practice. It is hardly a flattering portrait, a picture of Hutton managers exploiting its banks.

headline: Sanitary District Issue in Maryland
abstract: The Washington Suburban Sanitary District, a Maryland-based authority whose bonds are known to traders as ''washtubs,'' is offering $178.6 million of bonds through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers.

headline: Gains in Study Of Auto Fuel
abstract: THE ways in which gases ignite and burn inside an automobile's engine have long fascinated engineers, and studies have intensified in this decade, both because of new tools and because of the need for far better fuel economy and performance.   Lasers have allowed researchers to peer into the very heart of fire, and sophisticated devices such as mass spectrometers have let them analyze the exact chemistry of a flame. But until now, studies of the best way to distribute the gas molecules that fuel the flame have been almost impossibly difficult.   The technology that is changing all that - and that promises new designs in fuel injectors and spray nozzles - was developed by three engineers at the General Motors Research Laboratories in Warren, Mich. The tool is called computer-vision spray analysis, a process that allows rapid study of the shape and position of each microscopic droplet in a fuel spray.

headline: CHINESE CITY TAKES CAPITALIST ROAD A BIT TOO FAR
abstract: When reporters from Hong Kong were invited to buy Chinese babies in the free market here earlier this month, it was the latest in a series of shocks that have undermined the Shenzhen Special Economic Zone, principal showcase for Deng Xiaoping's ''open door'' economic policies.   The police cracked down swiftly on the practice after the reporters were approached by peasant mothers in Shenzhen's Dongmen market. An article in The South China Morning Post said a baby girl was offered by a woman for 1,200 Hong Kong dollars, equivalent to $154, and that others in the market had told the reporters that baby boys were going for 2,000 Hong Kong dollars, or $257.   The arrangement offered by sellers involved leaving the babies here until they could be smuggled by fishermen into Hong Kong, the British colony adjacent to Shenzhen.

headline: LTV Posts Huge Loss, Cites Shutdown of Mill
abstract: The LTV Corporation reported yesterday a second-quarter loss of $472.3million, which included a previously announced $400 million charge to indefinitely idle its big Aliquippa steel works near Pittsburgh.   LTV, which is based in Dallas, said its aerospace and military business continued to show strong growth, with operating earnings in the second quarter of $40.5 million, compared with $27.8 million in the 1984 quarter.

headline: India Seeking Oil Bids
abstract: India will ask foreign oil companies to submit new bids to explore oil in the country's offshore and onshore areas, Nawal Kishore Sharma, the petroleum minister, said today.

headline: NOW FREE, 39 LOOSEN LAST BONDS
abstract: This was the day when the 39 Americans who are still popularly called hostages actually broke free of the last of their physical confines: the high metal fences of an Air Force medical base here.   They had retreated to the United States Air Force Regional Medical Center after their dawn landing at a Frankfurt air base. But they remained sealed off from the world behind the medical center's fences for only a few hours.   Soon, a few television crews and selected reporters were allowed to slip through the gates to chat.

headline: D.D.B., Toyko Agency Buy Stake in Coast Shop
abstract: Doyle Dane Bernbach of New York and Dai-Ichi Kikaku of Tokyo, each of which has an equity position in the other ad agency, now have each acquired one-third ownership of Kresser-Craig, a recently formed Los Angeles agency with about $20 million in billings. The Los Angeles shop will continue to operate independently as Kresser, Craig/D.I.K., with Robert Kresser, chairman and chief executive, and Jean Craig as president and creative director. And if you wonder about the lack of a D.D.B. in the new name, perhaps it has something to do with an existing D.D.B. office in town.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: Debt Issues    * Central Sprinkler Corp. is offering $15 million of 8 percent convertible subordinated debentures due in 2010 at a price of 100 through William Blair & Co. as sole underwriter. The subordinated debentures may be converted at any time into the company's common stock at a price of $20.125 a share.    * The Council of Europe is issuing 600 million Luxembourg francs of an 8 7/8 percent bond due in 10 years at a price of 100 through underwriters led by Banque Internationale a Luxembourg S.A.    * Eli Lilly & Co. is issuing $150 million of 10 1/4 percent Eurobonds due in 1992 at a price of 99 7/8 through Morgan Stanley International.

headline: NEW ZEALAND SEEKING 3 IN GREENPEACE BOMBING
abstract: The police issued warrants today for three crew members of a French-registered yacht believed to be somewhere in the Pacific after having left Auckland the day before the Greenpeace flagship was bombed.

headline: MONSANTO TO ACQUIRE G. D. SEARLE
abstract: The Monsanto Company announced today that it would pay about $2.7 billion to acquire G.D. Searle & Company, the diversified drug company that makes aspartame, the artificial sweetener.   Searle, which is based in Skokie, Ill., accepted Monsanto's $65-a-share cash offer just four months after it had announced that it would remain independent.   Last fall, Searle officials said they were seeking to sell parts or all of the company, but the company's board decided last March that the company should remain independent after the bids it received were below what management had been seeking.   Monsanto, a St. Louis-based chemical company, has long said it was interested in acquiring Searle's drug business as a way for Monsanto to bring to market the drugs it is developing in its biotechnology laboratories.

headline: FARM ECONOMIES
abstract: To the Editor:   Neither ''The Third World: Back to the Farm'' and ''Starting Over in Mindanao'' (July 28) addressed the ways in which the bringers of development have ignored women's centrality to third world agriculture.

headline: PATENTS;  Eat Toxic Materials
abstract: A PROFESSOR at the University of Illinois, Ananda M. Chakrabarty, one of whose inventions led the Supreme Court to rule that forms of life can be patented, received another patent in that field this week. He and Scott T. Kellogg of San Diego, a microbiologist, were awarded patent 4,535,061 for microbes that can eat toxic materials in the environment.

headline: LOAN CURB TIED TO CREDIT RISKS IN SOUTH AFRICA
abstract: The South African Government's suspension Tuesday of currency trading followed the refusal by dozens of major international banks to renew loans to that country's large borrowers, bankers said yesterday.   Many banks also said that because of heightened concern about South Africa's political and economic prospects, they would continue to call in loans as they matured. That would increase the economic pressure on South Africa and could result in restrictions on capital flight and perhaps even a moratorium on repayments of debt owed to foreign lenders, bankers said.      Pleas to Bankers    To ease the country's predicament, the governor of South Africa's central bank, Dr. Gerhard de Kock, flew to Europe yesterday and was expected to try to persuade international banks to roll over some loans, bankers said. One banker said that Dr. de Kock might have some luck with Japanese, West German and Dutch bankers, but would be less likely to persuade American and British bankers to maintain credit to South Africa.

headline: Singapore Technology
abstract: Singapore's Economic Development Board said today that it would set up a $100 million fund (in Singapore dollars) to promote high technology. The money would be used to invest in joint ventures in microelectronics, telecommunications, robotics, biotechnology and laser optics in Singapore and abroad, a statement said. The fund, part of a plan to stimulate Singapore's sluggish economy, is intended to promote the transfer of technology and investments to Singapore.

headline: Bundesbank Cuts Rates
abstract: The Bundesbank, West Germany's central bank, lowered its leading interest rates today in an effort to bolster the country's economy and increase employment.

headline: SHEVARDNADZE EXPECTED TO OFFER SOVIET ARMS IDEAS TO REAGAN
abstract: Reagan Administration officials and members of Congress said today that they had been told that Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze of the Soviet Union was bringing serious proposals on arms control to his meeting with President Reagan this week.   Representative Les Aspin, Democrat of Wisconsin, who is chairman of the House Armed Services Committee, said:   ''My sources, my contacts tell me he is coming with some serious numbers, big reductions, serious reductions and a serious proposal.''   Mr. Aspin indicated that the information had come from Soviet sources.   Administration officials also expect significant moves from Mr. Shevardnadze. One official said:   ''We would hope that he does have in his kit bag the kind of serious icebreaker that would get us into a real negotiation. It depends on what the specific proposals are. Our hunch, based on our contacts and hints here and there, is that he will begin to peel away some of the layers of the onion.''

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: Debt Issues    * Abbey National Building Society is issuing $:150 million of 15-year floating-rate notes through Samuel Montagu & Co. as sole underwriter. Interest is set at 1/16 of a percentage point above the three-month London interbank offered rate, although the first coupon will be 1/16 of a percentage above the six-month Libor pending formal enactment of legislation allowing the payment of interest gross. The issue is callable after 7 years.

headline: STORM THREAT SHUTS FINANCIAL MARKETS AND MANY BUSINESSES
abstract: Commerce in the world's largest business center all but ceased yesterday as the threat of Hurricane Gloria led businesses in the metropolitan area to close almost en masse.   The stock market did not open at all, and most banks and major businesses opened briefly and closed early. The garment district was empty, and the Circle Line canceled its boat rides around Manhattan.

headline: NORTHROP-DYNAMICS FIGHTER TEST SET
abstract: The Pentagon has ordered the Air Force to arrange a one-time competition between Northrop's F-20 Tigershark and the General Dynamics F-16 Falcon for a role in defending the United States against bomber attack, Pentagon officials said today.   The decision guarantees Northrop a long-awaited chance to introduce its new fighter plane into the American military inventory, with the prospect of a substantial export market if it succeeds.   But the competition falls far short of what Northrop had been seeking, which was a running competition with General Dynamics for a variety of Air Force roles, with both companies guaranteed part of the market.   After news of the decision circulated on Wall Street, Northrop stock declined $2.25 today, to $51.50.

headline: MINERS STRIKE IN BOLIVIA OVER ECONOMIC PLAN
abstract: Bolivia's miners began a 48-hour strike today as labor unrest grew over measures to fight inflation.   ''Police forces have been put on a state of emergency,'' Interior Minister Fernando Barthelemy said. ''The Government will not allow disorder.''

headline: New DeLorean Effort
abstract: John Z. DeLorean, whose first try at building a revolutionary automobile ended in a sea of red ink and cocaine trafficking charges, said today he was back in business and would produce the world's fastest car at a plant to be built here. He declined to name his financial backers.

headline: Shining Path Guerrillas Said to Kill 14 in Peru
abstract: Maoist guerrillas attacked an Andean village with guns and explosives, killing 14 people and wounding 8, the police said today.   They said 60 members of the Shining Path geurrilla group, including women and children, attacked the town of Huayao before dawn Friday.

headline: U.S. JEWS INVITE PALESTINIANS' VIEWS
abstract: With an eye toward breaking down stereotypes and exploring new views, a small group of rabbis and American Jewish organizations are inviting Palestinians to be guest speakers in synagogues.   Their purpose, the rabbis say, is not to solve the Arab-Israeli conflict but to help break down the assumption that all Arabs are bent on destroying Israel, and to expose American Jews to views they rarely hear in synagogues.   No figures are available on the number of visits, and they are not part of any organized movement, although many of the rabbis know of each other's efforts. But some of the rabbis and leaders involved, most of whom are from the Reform branch of Judaism, estimate that two dozen synagogues across the country have taken part. And while many of the rabbis have been inviting Palestinians for more than 10 years with little public attention, most say they hope that current efforts to bring about Arab-Israeli talks in the Middle East will add weight to their efforts.

headline: Dollar Lowest in Year
abstract: Rumors about the President's health and BankAmerica's soundness pushed the dollar to its lowest levels since last July. Page D18.

headline: ANTI-SANDINISTA DENIES CHARGES
abstract: The military commander of the largest Nicaraguan rebel group said today that he knew of ''no evidence'' to support accusations that the rebels frightened young Nicaraguan men into joining them by killing Government officials and their sympathizers in towns and villages.   Edgar Chamorro, a former member of the political directorate of the group, the Nicaraguan Democratic Force, made the accusation in an affidavit made public this week.

headline: Bid by Taubman Seen; Refinancing Move Cited
abstract: A. Alfred Taubman, who yesterday announced a major refinancing of $2 billion worth of his real estate properties, may be preparing to make a large acquisition or other diversification move to add to his growing business, cultural and professional sports holdings, investment bankers said yesterday.   Among the acquisition possibilities mentioned by the bankers were the Allied Stores Corporation, Montgomery Ward & Company, a major auction house or another large retailer. The speculation was based on reports that Mr. Taubman had been seeking to raise $650 million and was fanned yesterday by news of his financing transaction.

headline: ECONOMIC INDEX FOR JULY SHOWS 0.4% ADVANCE
abstract: The Government index intended to predict the course of the economy rose four-tenths of 1 percent in July, the Commerce Department reported today. Analysts said this latest index of leading indicators, together with a substantial downward revision in the increase estimated for June, suggested continued listless economic growth over the next several months.   The Commerce Department also reported a large $2.9 billion narrowing of the nation's merchandise trade deficit last month, a development that inspired widely different interpretations. [Page 33.]  But most analysts said they thought nothing fundamental had occurred to lessen the nation's record trade deficits.

headline: Control Data Revises Results
abstract: The Control Data Corporation sharply revised downward yesterday its reported earnings for 1984's fourth quarter and for this year's second quarter, citing a variety of accounting changes and oversights.   The computer and financial services company, which is based in Minneapolis, said net income for 1984's fourth quarter had been reduced to $4.5 million, or 11 cents a share, from the $31 million, or 80 cents a share, originally reported.

headline: C.I.A. ROLE IN REBEL AID IS BARRED
abstract: Two House-Senate conferences overrode Administration objections today and agreed to bar the Central Intelligence Agency from distributing $27 million in nonmilitary aid to Nicaraguan rebels.
