The Reagan Administration had been pressing the negotiators to allow some role for the intelligence agency, but House members stood firm.   ''When we got down to the end, they had to face the facts of life,'' said Representative Dante B. Fascell, Democrat of Florida. ''There was no way the House could change its position.''

headline: METROPOLITAN LIFE TO BUY CENTURY 21 REAL ESTATE
abstract: The Metropolitan Life Insurance Company said yesterday that it had agreed to buy the Century 21 Real Estate Corporation, the nation's largest real estate sales organization, from the Transworld Corporation.   Executives of both companies and the First Boston Corporation, Transworld's investment adviser, declined to disclose the sales price. However, sources in the financial community said the amount was significantly above the $200 million minimum that Transworld set when it put Century 21 up for sale in May.

headline: U.N. SPEAKERS ALL DENOUNCE APARTHEID
abstract: Foreign leaders of countries as diverse as Cuba, Britain, and Mozambique condemned South Africa's system of apartheid in speeches before the General Assembly today.   The criticisms were made by the 11 foreign dignitaries who spoke today, and they followed similar criticisms by virtually all of the diplomats who have addressed the Assembly since debate at the 40th session began Monday.   ''We call upon the South African Government urgently to move beyond mere words to actions which are long overdue, to end apartheid and to establish a system of government acceptable to the people of South Africa as a whole,'' said Sir Geoffrey Howe, the British Foreign Secretary.   ''Britain is united with other countries in its determination to see fundamental changes made,'' Sir Geoffrey said. His comments were made on the day the British Government said it had adopted a series of measures approved recently by its partners in the Common Market that are intended to increase the pressure on South Africa to end its policy of racial separation.

headline: PENTAGON ACTS ON DYNAMICS DIRECTOR
abstract: The Defense Department said today that it had begun proceedings to revoke the top-secret security clearance of Lester Crown, the biggest shareholder and an influential board member of the General Dynamics Corporation, because of his involvement in a 1972 bribery case.   If the move is successful, Pentagon officials said, General Dynamics would be responsible for denying Mr. Crown access to any classified information. If the company failed to do so, its own security clearance could be jeopardized.   ''It means he can't deal with us on any classified material,'' said Glenn Flood, Pentagon spokesman. ''You can't say it would force him off the board. It's up to General Dynamics how to handle it.''

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: * Alimak Inc., Bridgeport, Conn., which makes freight elevators, tower cranes and underground hoisting equipment, has promoted Ulf Lundell to president.    * Belleek Ireland Inc., which makes china giftware, has appointed Bernard C. O'Rourke executive vice president of its United States operations, based in Pine Brook, N.J.    * Bunge Corp., an agribusiness company, has named John E. Klein president and chief executive officer.    * Chase Manhattan Trust Co. of Florida, a subsidiary of the Chase Manhattan Corp., has appointed J. Bradford Greer president.

headline: United Technologies
abstract: William F. Paul, the 49-year-old president of United Technologies' Sikorsky Aircraft division, has been named senior vice president, defense and space systems, of the parent company, United Technologies said today. Two other promotions were also announced. Robert Zincone, Sikorsky's executive vice president, will become president of the division, and Eugene Buckley becomes executive vice president for operations.

headline: Argentina Debt Accord
abstract: The Government of Argentina will sign agreements to restructure much of its foreign debt on Aug. 27 in New York, Citibank announced yesterday.   The agreement, which would stretch out payments of about $10 billion in public sector debt, was reached last fall.

headline: SHULTZ SUGGESTS MORE SOVIET TALKS ARE A POSSIBILITY
abstract: Secretary of State George P. Shultz said today that President Reagan and Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader, might hold a rotating series of meetings in each other's capitals if their first session in Geneva next November turns out well.   Mr. Shultz said the two leaders had exchanged messages expressing the hope that ''a more constructive relationship'' would emerge from the November meeting, but he cautioned that major differences persisted.   Meanwhile, the Soviet Union announced today that Mr. Gorbachev would travel to France in October before holding the meeting with President Reagan. The announcement of the trips, coming after the replacement of Andrei A. Gromyko as Foreign Minister on Tuesday, flouted the common belief that Mr. Gorbachev would set foreign relations aside as he wrestled with domestic issues. [Page A4.]  Coming Months to Tell Administration officials said today that the nearly five months leading up to the Reagan-Gorbachev meeting should indicate if the decision to hold the first Soviet-American summit meeting in six years presaged a significant improvement in relations or would only underscore the persisting differences.

headline: Don Tennant Company Names a New Chief
abstract: Elizabeth D. Harrington, 42, who joined the Don Tennant Company in Chicago last year as president, last week was given the big title, chief executive. Mr. Tennant remains chairman and chief creative officer.   Miss Harrington previously worked for Quaker Oats, where she was president of Adcom, its in-house agency; for J. Walter Thompson, and for Procter & Gamble, where she began in 1966 after graduating magna cum laude from Cornell.

headline: AXEL SPRINGER, GERMAN PUBLISHER, IS DEAD AT 73
abstract: Axel Springer, the builder of West Germany's largest publishing empire and a prominent conservative voice for three decades, died last night in West Berlin. He was 73 years old.   A spokesman for his publishing company said Mr. Springer died of a heart attack after a brief illness, Reuters reported.   Mr. Springer created, owned and managed the Axel Springer Publishing Group, whose publications include the tabloid Bild Zeitung, Europe's best-selling daily newspaper; Die Welt, an influential daily in Bonn; and the Sunday newspapers Bild am Sonntag and Welt am Sonntag.

headline: Management Shifts Set at First Jersey
abstract: First Jersey Securities, the ambitious independent broker-dealer, announced a number of management changes yesterday that it said would help further the firm's expansion.   Robert E. Brennan, who founded the firm in 1974, said that John E. Dell, 37 years old, an executive vice president, had been named president. In addition, Frederic W. Rittereiser, 48, now president and chief operating officer of the Instinet Corporation, is to become vice chairman in early November.

headline: BEATRICE SHAKE-UP SEEN AS HELPFUL
abstract: The forced resignation of James L. Dutt as chairman of the Beatrice Companies is a step in the right direction for the food and consumer products giant, industry analysts said today. They remain unconvinced, however, that Beatrice has put its troubles behind it.   The company's directors, at a Saturday meeting, accepted the resignation of Mr. Dutt and elected William W. Granger Jr. to replace him. Mr. Granger, 66 years old, is a former Beatrice vice chairman who had retired.

headline: Lebanese Opposition Group Calls for Closer Ties to Syria
abstract: About 100 Moslem, Druse and moderate Christian leaders announced today that they were forming a National Unity Front, calling for political and social change and closer ties with Syria to end Lebanon's civil war.   After a day-long meeting in Shtaura, east of Beirut, the group pledged commitment to a united Lebanon but demanded changes to lessen the power of Lebanon's Maronite Christians.

headline: U.S. Seeking GATT Talks
abstract: The United States, frustrated by the failure of the 90-member council of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade to set a date for a new round of anti-protectionist trade talks, today called for a meeting of senior officials in September.

headline: THE JAPANESE SURGE IN U.S.
abstract: This week's announcement by the Toyota Motor Corporation of Japan that it would build an automobile factory in the United States marks the development of an important new phase in the often turbulent economic relations between the two countries, according to Japanese officials and economists here.   In a little more than a year, Japan has risen to the front rank of foreign owners of American industry, along with Britain, Canada, West Germany and the Netherlands. With the surge in investment, a country that has been most conspicuous, and often berated, for the goods it ships to the United States is now becoming conspicuous as well for the goods it makes in this country.      Rise in Direct Investment    Last year, according to the Commerce Department, Japanese companies and their affiliates in the United States poured $1.7 billion into American businesses in so-called direct investment, more than three times the average of $490 million annually that the country had spent over the preceding five years. Direct investment includes outright ownership of American factories or the ownership of 10 percent or more of an American enterprise.

headline: Brewery Venture
abstract: The Adolph Coors Company said that it and two other family-controlled breweries, Molson Breweries of Canada and Kaltenberg Castle Brewery of West Germany, have formed the Masters Brewing Company. It said that the new company is not a merger of the three but will operate independently. It said that Masters would compete against the three companies in various markets.

headline: TRW in Bid For Intelogic
abstract: TRW Inc., seeking to expand its hold on the third-party computer service business, said yesterday that it had bid $177 million to acquire Intelogic Trace Inc., a recently created company that formerly was the domestic customer service division of the Datapoint Corporation.   Asher B. Edelman, chairman of Intelogic Trace, said in a telephone interview that he was surprised by the offer.

headline: U.S. EXPORT FINANCING AIMED AT FRANCE, JAPAN
abstract: France and Japan are the main targets of a new policy the United States is preparing to fight what it is calling predatory export practices of foreign governments, Administration officials said today.   Discussing how the policy might be applied, one official offered the example of a French-speaking African country that decides to build a bridge or a power station and is looking for industrial country suppliers.   Because of their linguistic and cultural ties, French exporters traditionally get the lion's share of such business. But now the United States Government will reach into its pockets to offer such easy credit terms, if an American supplier is selected, that the African Government would have a hard time refusing.

headline: A.T.& T. AND FORD PLAN HUGE JOB CUTS
abstract: A.T.&T.'s huge cutbacks in its Information Systems unit are being forced by the increased competition that resulted from divestiture, analysts say. A.T.&T. is planning to eliminate 24,000 jobs, about 7,000 in management, although no one yet knows how many workers will actually be laid off. The company eliminated 15,000 jobs in the unit after the breakup, but demand for business communications products has fallen, and analysts said the unit was losing as much as $1 billion a year.   Ford is eliminating 10,000 management jobs - 20 percent of its white-collar force - over the next five years. The company is trying to keep production costs low, but layoffs are difficult in the highly unionized blue-collar work force. Analysts also said Ford has made its management more efficient with new technology.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: Debt Issues    * Burroughs Corp. has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for $150 million of convertible subordinated debentures due 2010 through underwriters led by Drexel Burnham Lambert.    * Chrysler Finance Corp. is issuing 75 million European Currency Units of 9 percent Eurobonds due 1992 through Banque Paribas Capital Markets.    * Comalco Ltd. is arranging a $480 million refinancing facility through Morgan Guaranty Ltd. consisting of a $300 million global-note facility and a $180 million floating-rate note guarantee facility.

headline: PRICES CUT MODESTLY BY OPEC
abstract: OPEC ministers wound up their four-day meeting here by agreeing today to a slight cut in some oil prices. But analysts said the move merely underscores the organization's lack of unity and waning influence. The agreement still leaves OPEC's prices higher than those in today's free market.   By a vote of 10 to 3, the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries approved Saudi Arabia's demand for a 50-cent cut in the price of heavy crude, to $26 a barrel, and a 20-cent cut in the price of medium crude, to $27.20 a barrel.

headline: Federated Stores
abstract: One of the nation's largest department store chains has agreed to tell consumers when their credit applications are rejected because of information obtained from a credit reporting agency, the Federal Trade Commission said today. The agreement covers Federated Department Stores Inc., based in Cincinnati, which operates more than 590 stores under a variety of names, including Bloomingdale's, Filene's, Foley's, I. Magnin, Burdines, Abraham & Straus, Bullock's and Sanger Harris.

headline: LEADERS AIR DIFFERENCES AT CHINESE PARTY MEETING
abstract: The Communist Party ended a national conference here today with an unusual airing of policy differences that have created tension between Deng Xiaoping, the reform-minded veteran who is China's pre-eminent leader, and more doctrinaire figures in the party hierarchy.   The conference had been summoned by Mr. Deng to entrench his open-door economic policies in the new five-year plan for 1986-90, and to replace dozens of aging leaders with middle-aged loyalists on the party's top bodies. But the session ended on a discordant note as Chen Yun, an orthodox Marxist, made a brusque speech that challenged the Deng line on agriculture, the play given to market forces in the economy, and the downgrading of ideological indoctrination.   Some Western analysts said they interpreted one section of Mr. Chen's speech as implying that the 81-year-old Mr. Deng had been too autocratic in imposing his pragmatic, profit-oriented ideas on the party, but the context for this was less clear.

headline: Brazil Names Bank Chief
abstract: Dilson Funaro, who was sworn in as Brazil's Finance Minister today, named Fernao Bracher, vice president of the Bradesco Group, as the new central bank president.

headline: Pasta Accord Is Approved
abstract: European Community agriculture ministers today approved a plan to reduce subsidies on pasta exports to the United States in an effort to defuse a trans-Atlantic trade dispute.   Officials said the ministers authorized the community's executive branch to vary pasta export subsidies by country of destination, without specifically mentioning the United States.

headline: Rome Blames the Mafia For Murder of 2 Officers
abstract: Gunmen opened fire with automatic weapons in Palermo, Sicily, today and killed a top police official who had been investigating the Mafia.   The policeman, Antonino Cassara, 38 years old, the deputy chief of Palermo's mobile police squad, was killed instantly as he was leaving his home.

headline: United Nations Calendar
abstract: 40th GENERAL ASSEMBLY -The 15-day general debate of the 40th annual General Assembly opens today and will feature 12 speakers. President Jose Sarney of Brazil and President Alan Garcia Perez of Peru will lead off the morning and afternoon sessions, respectively, with speeches expected to focus on the Latin American debt crisis and regional stability.   Secretary of State George P. Shultz follows Mr. Sarney, with a speech that American officials say will offer a broad overview of the world situation and the United Nations role in preventing conflict. Other speakers include these foreign ministers: Basile Laetare Guissou of Burkina Faso, Suppiah Dhanabalan of Singapore, Augusto Ramirez Ocampo of Colombia, Svenn Stray of Norway, Dante Caputo of Argentina, Jaime Gama of Portugal, Koffi Amega of Togo, Laurent Nzeyimana of Burundi and A. C. S. Hameed of Sri Lanka.

headline: GATT EFFORT BY U.S. GAINS
abstract: A majority of the 90-member General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade has endorsed an American effort to advance the pace of discussions among world trading nations of a new trade round this fall, according to GATT officials.   A spokesman for the Geneva-based trade body said Thursday that 52 nations had voted in favor of the American proposal.

headline: Iran Rebels Deny Bombing
abstract: A spokesman for a group that supports the People's Mujahedeen, an Iranian rebel organization, said today that it was not responsible for a car bombing in Teheran on Sunday as charged by the Iranian Government press agency. The spokesman, Ali Safavi, said in Washington that the rebels condemned the bombing, in which 30 people were reported wounded.

headline: ISRAEL HOLDS AN AMERICAN IN FERRYING OF GUERILLA
abstract: Israel said today that it was holding an American and an Australian who it said were captured last Saturday on a yacht with six Palestinian guerrillas.   Officials said the Palestinians had been planning an attack on Israel.   Israeli officials said the American and the Australian, whose names have not been made public, were co-owners of the yacht, which the Israeli Navy intercepted late Saturday night while it was sailing between Cyprus and the Lebanese port of Sidon.   The Israeli Navy towed the boat into Haifa after apprehending its crew. Israeli officials said the yacht, the ''Kasilradi,'' was carrying six Palestinian guerrillas who were members of Al Fatah, the guerrilla organization heaaded by Yasir Arafat, chairman of the Palestine Liberation Organization.

headline: Outlook For Jobs in Retailing
abstract: MAJOR retailers have been reducing their middle management staffs to cut costs and make operations more efficient. Although that means fewer jobs and slower promotions for middle managers, store executives say retailing still offers good opportunties for new college graduates.   ''There are fewer staff jobs in retailing these days, but there are good openings for line jobs,'' said Howard Falberg, vice president-personnel for the Associated Dry Goods Corporation. One of the nation 's largest retail chains, it operates such units as Lord & Taylor in New York, J. W. Robinson in California and Joseph Horne in Pennsylvania.

headline: Utility Issues Tumble on Rate Fears
abstract: In a dramatic reversal, the stock market yesterday went from a major gain at midday to a sizable loss at the close as investors dumped interest-sensitive utility and telephone issues.   The Dow utility index, often considered a good indicator of future market action, suffered its worst single-day loss in 23 years.   Anthony Woodruff, market analyst with Kidder, Peabody & Company, said investors in large numbers seemed to change their focus, as rising interest rates made capital-intensive businesses like utilities less attractive.   The Dow Jones industrial average, down 1.90 points on Monday when investors decided to take profits earned last week, fell another 5.83 points yesterday to finish at 1,351.81. The blue-chip index of 30 stocks was up nearly 10 points in the early afternoon, propelled mainly by an early surge in high-technology issues.

headline: South Korean Leader Picks 2 Hard-Liners
abstract: President Chun Doo Hwan named hard-liners today to two important posts of his governing party, apparently in expectation of a clash in the Assembly this fall with opposition parties seeking greater democracy.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: BankAmerica Corp., San Francisco, said its Bank of America unit had won a one-year contract to provide an electronic funds-transfer system for retailers who will be selling California state lottery tickets beginning Oct. 3. Terms were not disclosed.    * Banc One Corp., Columbus, Ohio, said it had signed a definitive agreement with Purdue National Corp., Lafayette, Ind., to acquire Purdue National in an exchange of shares valued at about $32.1 million.

headline: Blast at Italian Post Office
abstract: A powerful bomb damaged a post office in the southern outskirts of Florence early today, but no one was wounded, the police said. No group immediately took responsibility, the police said, and there was no indication of a motive.

headline: Brazil Trade Surplus
abstract: Brazil's trade surplus in August narrowed to $1.08 billion, from $1.39 billion a year ago, the Government said today. Exports were $2.13 billion, down 16 percent from $2.54 billion a year earlier. Imports were $1.06 billion, off 7.8 percent from $1.14 billion.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST: TUESDAY, AUGUST 20, 1985
abstract: Companies    Pantry Pride bid for Revlon, which took defensive steps. Revlon said it planned a ''special dividend'' to shareholders - a so-called poison pill - that could add $750 million to the cost of buying the company. It also said it would buy up to five million of its shares in the open market. Pantry Pride offered $47.50 a share, or a total of $1.81 billion, for the cosmetics company. [Page D1.]    T.W.A. shareholders other than Texas Air and Carl Icahn would decide which offer for the airline to accept under a proposal going to T.W.A.'s board today, a Wall Street source said. The proposal, worked out by T.W.A. and Texas Air advisers, is intended to leave the decision to ''impartial'' shareholders, the source said. [D1.]

headline: Burroughs Unit
abstract: The Memorex Corporation, a unit of the Burroughs Corporation, said that it and the Control Data Corporation had agreed to dissolve Disk Media Inc., a jointly owned concern with about 200 employees. They also agreed that Magnetic Peripherals Inc., principally owned by Control Data, would buy Memorex's share in Peripheral Components Inc., a second venture.

headline: Times Mirror Unit Is Selling 6 Mills
abstract: The Times Mirror Company said that the Publishers Paper Company, its newsprint and forest-products subsidiary, is seeking a buyer for four sawmills and two particleboard mills in Oregon. The company, which broke off discussions with the Boise Cascade Corporation for the sale of its newsprint and forest-products facilities in March, is also considering the sale of its 272,000 acres of timberland in Washington and Oregon.

headline: CANADA DECLINES TO JOIN U.S. SPACE-ARMS EFFORT
abstract: Canada will not formally take part in the research phase of President Reagan's space-based missile defense plan, but does not oppose it, Prime Minister Brian Mulroney said today.   He said that while the Government was rejecting the American invitation, private Canadian companies would be free to bid on research contracts in the plan, officially designated the Strategic Defense Initiative and popularly known as ''Star Wars.''   ''After careful and detailed consideration, the Government of Canada has concluded that Canada's own policies and priorities do not warrant a government-to-government effort in support of S.D.I. research,'' Mr. Mulroney told reporters. He spoke with them after a daylong meeting of legislators of his Progressive Conservative Party.

headline: Cluett Rejects Takeover Offer
abstract: Cluett, Peabody & Company rejected a $336 million takeover bid, but the two California investors who made the bid said they would ''vigorously pursue'' their efforts to acquire the New York apparel company and would consider making an all-cash tender offer to shareholders. The investors, Paul Bilzerian and William Brodovsky, hold a 9.9 percent stake in Cluett and last week offered to buy the company, whose brands include Arrow shirts, for $40 a share, half in cash and half in debt securities.

headline: KUWAIT AGAIN RULES OUT PRISONER-HOSTAGE TRADE
abstract: Kuwaiti officials reiterated today that they had no intention of releasing 17 convicted terrorists in exchange for the freedom of 6 remaining Americans believed to be held hostage in Lebanon.   A seventh American, the Rev. Benjamin Weir, was freed last week after 16 months in captivity. He said his captors told him that the price of freedom for the other Americans was the release of the 17 prisoners in Kuwait. Mr. Weir said the kidnappers told him that if the prisoners in Kuwait were not released, the captors might kidnap more Americans or kill their hostages.   This rich but tiny emirate on the northern end of the Persian Gulf occupies a precarious position between three powerful neighbors - Iran, Iraq and Saudi Arabia. According to Kuwaitis and Western diplomats here, the Government believes that any capitulation to terrorist threats, any appearance of weakness, will only make the country vulnerable to new attacks.

headline: THE U.S. QUANDRY
abstract: The Reagan Administration found itself in a quandary today as it sought to open the door for negotiations with Lebanese kidnappers on the release of the remaining American hostages, even though it was reasserting that the captors' demands were unacceptable.   ''We are in a difficult bind,'' a White House official said, after a news conference by the Rev. Benjamin Weir, who announced that he had been freed by his kidnappers in Lebanon to take back with him a fresh demand that the United States obtain the release of 17 Shiite Moslems convicted in Kuwait for terrorist activity.   Mr. Weir said the kidnappers were threatening to seize more Americans and to execute the remaining six American hostages if the prisoners in Kuwait were not released soon.   The problem for the Administration, the official said, was how to persuade the kidnappers to agree to terms for freeing the Americans without compromising the Reagan Administration's often stated refusal to yield to terrorists' demands.

headline: NEW-HOME SALES RISE
abstract: Sales of new homes posted their biggest increase in eight months in May, the Government reported today. The Reagan Administration called the 9.7 percent gain evidence of a ''strong resumption of steady growth'' in the economy.   The May increase put sales of new single-family homes at a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 676,000.

headline: DEATHS IN FRENCH TRAIN WRECH RISE TO 49
abstract: The death toll rose to 49 today in a train derailment and collision in central France. Nearly 100 people were reported injured, 10 of them critically, when a passenger train derailed and was struck by a mail train.   The engineer of the passenger train, which offiicials said appeared to have been exceeding a safe speed, was taken into custody by the police pending further investigation.

headline: Thais Settle Cambodians In Camp Near the Border
abstract: The Thai Government announced this week that it had finished moving about 55,000 displaced Cambodians to a new site on the Cambodian border.   The Cambodians, civilian followers of the non-Communist Khmer People's National Liberation Front were driven from Rithisen, a base inside Cambodia, last Dec. 25 in a Vietnamese offensive against guerrilla camps.

headline: HONECKER IN PLEA ON CHEMICAL ARMS
abstract: East Germany has begun a campaign to persuade the West German Government of Chancellor Helmut Kohl to back an accord banning chemical weapons from central Europe.   The East German campaign, according to several Western diplomats and academic analysts, appears aimed at stimulating the efforts of the Social Democratic Party, West Germany's main opposition group, to make chemical weapons an issue in the West German elections in early 1987. The accord for which East Germany is seeking support was negotiated between its Government and the Social Democrats.

headline: EX-WHITE HOUSE LAWYER TO HELP GREENHOUSE
abstract: A former White House counsel, Lloyd N. Cutler, will represent the antinuclear and environmental group Greenpeace in its legal battle with the French Government over the sinking of the ship Rainbow Warrior, Greenpeace announced today.   The group said Mr. Cutler, counsel to President Carter from 1979 to 1981, would help Greenpeace seek compensation for the bombing last month in New Zealand that sank the ship and killed one crew member, Fernando Pereira, a photographer.   ''We are a peaceful, nonviolent organization,'' David McTaggart, the Greenpeace chairman, said at a news conference, ''but that does not mean we will stand by and let ourselves be hit.''   Greenpeace said Mr. Cutler, a partner in the Washington law firm of Wilmer, Cutler & Pickering, had offered his services without charge.

headline: PHILIPPINE CAPITALIST LOOKS OVERSEAS
abstract: Enrique Zobel, one of the richest men in the Philippines and perhaps its most prominent business executive, is characteristically blunt about the investment outlook in his country these days.   ''If you had money to invest in Southeast Asia, the Philippines is the last place I would tell you to put it now,'' he said.   To many people here, it appears that Mr. Zobel is following his own advice. Last March the burly 58-year-old executive stepped down as chairman of the Bank of the Philippine Islands, the nation's largest financial institution.

headline: Champion Sale Of Units Set
abstract: The Champion International Corporation, in a move to reduce the debt it incurred from its acquisition of the St. Regis Corporation last year, said yesterday that it had agreed to sell several of its building products operations to current management in a leveraged buyout. Industry analysts placed the value of the transaction between $155 million and $175 million.

headline: IN SOVIET, EAGER BEAVER'S LEGEND WORKS OVERTIME
abstract: Fifty years ago tonight, a Ukrainian miner named Aleksei G. Stakhanov hewed 102 tons of coal in a single shift, 14 times more than his norm, setting a Soviet record.   His achievement was duly noted the next day in a paragraph in Pravda, and almost immediately Stakhanov became a national symbol.   Within three months, on Nov. 22, 1935, Stalin was addressing the First All-Union Conference of Stakhanovites in Moscow, hailing the movement as conclusive evidence that Communism would triumph over capitalism.   The Stakhanovite movement, Stalin declared, represented ''a model of that high productivity of labor that only socialism can produce and that capitalism cannot produce.''

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: * Adams Drug Co., Pawtucket, R.I., said James Salmanson had been appointed president and chief executive, succeeding Donald Salmanson, who has retired.    * Alexander & Alexander Services Inc., the insurance brokerage, has elected Dr. Robert H. Moore senior vice president.    * American Express Bank Ltd., the banking arm of the American Express Co., has elected Gary L. Johns and Robert J. Simmons senior vice presidents.

headline: Montedison Purchase
abstract: Montedison, Italy's largest chemical concern, confirmed today that it had gained control of a sizable stake in one of the country's most powerful finance groups, Bi-Invest. A Montedison spokesman said the company chairman, Mario Schimberni, had informed the Italian stock exchange authority, Consob, that it now held 36.8 million shares, or 37 percent, of Bi-Invest, a group with interests in insurance, property and industry.

headline: THE SURGE IN HOTEL BUILDING
abstract: The maids and bellhops at the Adolphus Hotel in Dallas, as at most downtown hotels in that city, have time on their hands because their opulently refurbished grand hotel is only 60 percent full. Throughout downtown and in the suburbs, however, yet 16 more hotels are being built to provide the area with another 2,000 rooms.   A coming hotel glut? Or smart planning? Whatever the case, the Dallas lodging scene is a reflection of the apparent paradox in the nation's hotel industry today: Despite worrisome conditions in some key cities and little or no growth expected in overall occupancy rates this year, the industry is building or planning new hotels and motels at a faster clip than at anytime since the late 1950's.   Plans call for the addition by 1992 of 400,000 rooms to the current 2.7 million, according to Albert J. Gomes, a senior partner at Pannell Kerr Forster, a consulting firm to the hotel industry.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Previous   Year

headline: LEADING INDICATORS CLIMB 1%
abstract: The Government's main economic forecasting gauge jumped 1 percent in June, aided by a surge in new businesses, the Commerce Department reported today.   This was the strongest gain in the index of leading indicators since January, and it inspired the White House, which this week predicted the economy would expand at a robust 5 percent rate during the second half of the year, to call it ''ringing economic news.'' In the first half of 1985 the economy grew at a 1 percent rate, far less than the Administration forecast.   Private analysts, however, regarded the latest index reading with considerably more restraint, noting that it is a volatile statistical series that has shown mixed results - seven increases and five declines - in the past 12 months. They also pointed to a fairly sharp downward revision in the index for May, which the department now says rose only one-tenth of 1 percent instead of the seven-tenths of 1 percent initially reported.

headline: IN QUOTES
abstract: ''We have reached a situation in which either we conquered inflation or inflation conquered us.''      Shimon Peres   Prime Minister of Israel, on the imposition of strict austerity measures.

headline: CLUES SOUGHT FOR SAFER CONSTRUCTION
abstract: To specialists in earthquake-resistant construction, the heavy damage inflicted upon Mexico City in the disaster Thursday will provide the most valuable demonstration they have ever had of what design features in a modern city are most resistant to such an onslaught, particularly when structures are built on a deep accumulation of sediment.   It has long been known that the central part of Mexico City, resting on a prehistoric lake bed, is particularly vulnerable to shaking. David Harlow of the United States Geological Survey, a specialist in the geology of that region, said yesterday that in previous, less violent earthquakes the city center had been shaken ''much more than surrounding areas.''   The sediment accumulation on which the city was built is believed to be from 500 to 1,000 feet deep and such material, in an earthquake, ''would shake like crazy,'' Mr. Harlow said yesterday in a telephone interview from Menlo Park, Calif.

headline: DEBT LIMIT MAY DELAY U.S. AUCTIONS
abstract: The Treasury's financing schedule is a source of uncertainty in the bond markets as traders and investors wonder when Congress will approve an increase in the Federal debt ceiling.   This week, the Treasury will proceed with its regular weekly sale of new bills today, followed on Wednesday by the regular monthly auction of two-year notes. Late last Friday, the outstanding three-month bills were bid at 7.23 percent while the six-month issue was at 7.37 percent. Government securities dealers offered the two-year notes on a when-issued basis with a yield of 9.05 percent.

headline: Uganda Bans Rallies But Vows to Free 1,400
abstract: Uganda's new military Government banned political gatherings today but pledged to free 1,400 prisoners jailed by the previous Government.   Meanwhile, the Uganda radio appealed for soldiers loyal to Milton Obote, the former President, to lay down their arms, and the Government announced ''no fundamental change'' in its foreign policy of nonalignment.

headline: PRETORIA'S FORCES ASSESSED: ABLE AND, IF TESTED, RUTHLESS
abstract: South Africa's security forces are reasonably well trained, professional and ably led and can be expected to be ruthless in trying to quell black disorders or attempts at insurrection, according to American experts.   If the combined force of army troops, reserves and police have any weakness, these experts say, it may be a diminishing flow of reliable intelligence from black informants in the segregated African townships during the state of emergency declared nine days ago. This was once a notable strength of the security forces.   At any given moment in peacetime, the number of armed services personnel on active duty totals about 82,000, according to Kenneth Grundy, a professor at Case Western Reserve University in Cleveland, who closely follows South African military affairs and is preparing a book on the subject.

headline: Bus Crashes in England
abstract: A double-decker bus overturned in northeast England today, killing a woman and injuring 50 other passengers, at least 8 seriously, the police said. A rescue worker said the driver might have swerved to avoid a sheep. The bus was traveling from Newcastle-upon-Tyne to London.

headline: U.S.-KOREA CHIP TIES GROW
abstract: American electronics companies are increasingly selling or licensing computer chip technology to Korean electronic companies, helping those companies rapidly advance in the semiconductor industry, executives and analysts say.   The growing number of ties is seen as part of a new alliance of American and Korean companies against Japanese ones, which already dominate certain parts of the business of supplying the integrated circuits used in computers and other electronic equipment.   But there is also a growing concern that the transfer of technology to the Koreans will create another competitor that could one day hurt the American industry. The Japanese, analysts point out, also made major strides by licensing United States technology.      'Trading Away Our Future'   ''There are people who view it as trading away our future,'' said Lane Mason, a semiconductor industry analyst at Dataquest, a market research concern in San Jose, Calif.

headline: BOLIVIAN IN AN ENCORE: VICTOR PAZ ESTENSSORO
abstract: When his opponent announced victory the day after Bolivia's presidential elections, Victor Paz Estenssoro waited patiently for the official tally to be completed. In the end, he lost the general election by 2 percent, but won in Congress, becoming the first civilian to take the presidency without a majority of the popular vote.   It is such patience and knowledge of the Bolivian political scene that has characterized Mr. Paz Estenssoro's success in winning the presidency four times.   His present term as President is likely to be one of the most difficult. After being sworn in today, he called on all Bolivians to help the country emerge from its economic crisis. ''If we don't immediately apply a package of pragmatic, realistic and concrete measures to arrest the crisis, we run the risk of bankruptcy,'' Mr. Paz Estenssoro said.

headline: Scott & Fetzer Deal in Limbo
abstract: A $440 million leveraged buyout of the Scott & Fetzer Company seemed in doubt yesterday. Directors said they could not approve a $25 million contribution to its employee stock ownership plan because there was no assurance that the buyout would be completed promptly or on a satisfactory basis.

headline: Thomson Plan With Olivetti
abstract: Thomson S.A. of France and Ing. C. Olivetti & Company of Italy, two of Europe's major electronics concerns, have joined Acorn Computer Group P.L.C., Olivetti's British home computer subsidiary, in an effort to create standards that could be used to develop small computers for sale throughout Europe.   The companies hope that the cooperative effort will produce a European alternative to the design standards of the American computer makers and the MSX standard adopted by Japanese manufacturers.

headline: Treasury Post Nominee
abstract: President Reagan today nominated Charles O. Sethness, a Harvard Business School associate dean, to be Assistant Secretary of the Treasury for Domestic Finance. Mr. Sethness, 44 years old, would succeed Thomas J. Healey.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST: SATURDAY, JULY 6, 1985
abstract: The Economy The unemployment rate remained at 7.2 percent in June for the fifth straight month, the Labor Department reported. But analysts were disappointed by a decline in factory employment and slow growth in nonfarm payrolls. When taken with other recent figures - on car sales, trade, inventories and the ''flash'' G.N.P. - the report suggests that the economy is soft enough for the Federal Reserve to ease monetary policy further. There was, however, a small gain in the length of the factory workweek. [Page 1.]  Employment rose in the New York metropolitan area, but job growth is slowing. [7.]  Markets The basic money supply jumped $2.6 billion in the week ended June 24, far more than the market had expected. The news dimmed a bond market rally brought on by weakness in the unemployment report. Still, bond prices closed a point and a half higher than Wednesday, the previous day of trading. While economic weakness could encourage lower interest rates, the Fed is also concerned that rapid increases in the money supply would cause inflation. [27.]  Stock prices marched higher in very light activity. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 8.06 points, to 1,334.45, just shy of the record on Monday of 1,337.14. Broader measures did set records. Trading was the slowest of the year, at 62.5 million shares. [31.]  The dollar fell in light trading although a late upturn brought it above the day's lows. Gold edged higher overseas, gaining $1 an ounce, to $311.50, in London.

headline: TBWA Advertising
abstract: TBWA Advertising has been appointed the agency for Chock Full o'Nuts coffee.

headline: IN FEARFUL COSTA RICA, THE YANQUIS ARE WELCOME
abstract: As the United States gradually increases its military aid to Costa Rica, one thing seems missing in this country without an army: popular protest.   To a remarkable degree, Costa Ricans are united by the belief that they face a threat from neighboring Nicaragua. They perceive the small but growing American military presence here as necessary to guard against that threat.   ''We are not preparing an army,'' said President Luis Alberto Monge in May after the arrival of the first contingent of American Green Berets, who are training a new unit of the Costa Rican civil guard, but he added, in a clear reference to Nicaragua, that Costa Ricans should be prepared ''to defend ourselves against terrorism, subversion and the possibility of foreign invasion.''

headline: UGANDAN GUERRILLAS CAPTURE NILE BRIDGE, AND THEN GIVE IT UP
abstract: Ugandan Government troops today retook a strategic Nile River bridge that rebel forces had seized earlier in the day, according to travelers arriving in the capital.   Many of landlocked Uganda's imports and exports must cross the span, the Owens Falls Bridge at Jinja, some 50 miles east of the capital. A hydroelectric power complex that supplies nearly all of Uganda's electricity is also at Jinja.

headline: DURABLE GOODS ORDERS INCREASED 1.8% IN JUNE
abstract: Orders for durable goods, buoyed by continued demand for military equipment, rose 1.8 percent in June, the third consecutive monthly increase, the Government reported today.   The gain, which had not been generally expected, gave rise to cautious optimism about the economy in coming months after a year of sluggish activity in the industrial sector.   The Commerce Department said orders for durable goods, items expected to last three or more years, rose to $104.9 billion in June following advances of 3.3 percent in May and two-tenths of 1 percent in April.

headline: Sri Lanka Police Report Plot Against President
abstract: The police said today that they had thwarted a bomb plot by Tamil terrorists to kill President J. R. Jayewardene.

headline: Sanyo to Produce Recorders in U.S.
abstract: The Sanyo Electric Company, a major Japanese electric and electronic appliance company, said today that it planned to build a factory to produce videotape recorders in the United States as early as 1986.

headline: PATENTS;  A Low-Calorie Cake
abstract: Inventors for the General Foods Corporation of White Plains recognized that for centuries people have been weight-conscious and have sought to control their diets.

headline: WEINBERGER'S NEW ROLE: A SUMMIT SENTINEL
abstract: In the political stagecraft preceding the November summit meeting in Geneva, Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger appears to have assigned himself the job of dashing what he regards as exaggerated expectations.   Lest the audience or the other players forget, Mr. Weinberger has filled the theater of diplomacy with reminders that he considers the Soviet Union the villain of world affairs.   He has revealed what he says are new details of Soviet efforts to buy or steal American military technology. He has urged cutbacks in the number of Soviet citizens allowed in the United States, saying they are all intelligence agents ''or might just as well be.''

headline: Foote, Cone Loses Account
abstract: Foote, Cone & Belding, Chicago, announced yesterday that it had resigned the $5 million Nutri/System Inc. national account, because of strong differences of opinion between the agency and new client management. According to the client, F.C.& B. was handling the national trust fund account, which is going to be suspended in favor of local and regional advertising programs that will not require the services of a national agency.

headline: Stocks Stage Broad Technical Rally
abstract: The stock market yesterday staged a broad-based technical rally in which secondary stocks greatly outpaced the blue chips.   Analysts said the upturn was overdue, especially after the recent sharp selloff suffered by the market. ''You have to treat this still as a technical rebound,'' said Harvey Deutsch of Purcell, Graham & Company.

headline: THE SIKH UNREST: THREE YEARS OF TURMOIL
abstract: The agreement between Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi of India and Sikh political leaders yesterday follows years of Sikh unrest. Here are some of the main developments in the last three years.      August 1982 - The main Sikh political party, the Akali   Dal, led by Harchand Singh Longowal, begins a mass movement of civil disobedience calling for greater autonomy for the Punjab and the declaration of Amritsar as a holy city. February 1983 - Mr. Longowal, who follows the peaceful tactics of strikes and marches used by Mohandas K. Gandhi, is joined in the campaign by a militant cleric, Jarnail Singh Bhindranwale, whose radical followers resort to violence, killing police officers and others. October 1983 - The central Government takes over the civil administration of the Punjab in response to the protests and violence. April 1984 - The militants, said to number fewer than 1,000, engage in a campaign of terror, shooting politicians and even moderate Sikhs and killing Hindus at random; police and paramilitary forces get orders to shoot on sight.

headline: $325 Million Offering Made in North Carolina
abstract: The North Carolina Eastern Municipal Power Agency is offering $325 million of electric power system revenue bonds with a maximum yield of 10.13 percent for bonds due in 2017, according to tentative prices announced yesterday by the lead underwriter, Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company.   The financing also includes bonds yielding from 7.80 percent in 1991 to 8.80 percent in 1995, 9.40 percent in 1998 and 9.70 percent in 2000.

headline: Seabrook Share Acquisition Talks
abstract: The Central Maine Power Company, which has been told by state regulators to sell its 6 percent share in the Seabrook nuclear project, is talking to a potential buyer.   Central Maine and Eastern Utilities Associates, a Boston-based utility holding company, announced jointly yesterday that they were engaged in discussions about the sale of Central Maine's interest in the New Hampshire project to Eastern Utilities.

headline: REPAYMENT PLAN FILED BY BALDWIN
abstract: The Baldwin-United Corporation and a subsidiary, the D.H. Baldwin Company, filed a joint reorganization plan today in United States Bankruptcy Court under which Baldwin-United estimates that it will ultimately pay unsecured creditors as much as $140 million in cash.   The plan is subject to approval by United States Bankruptcy Judge Randall Newsome of Cincinnati, who is overseeing Baldwin-United's reorganization under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Act.   Baldwin-United officials said they could not project precisely how much cash would be available for creditors, because the officials are still trying to resolve an array of claims lodged against the company since it filed for protection from its creditors in September 1983.

headline: OFFICIAL DEFENDS SPACE-WEAPON TEST
abstract: A senior Government official, defending a decision to proceed with a test of an anti-satellite weapon, insisted today that the Reagan Administration had complied with a Congressional order that it delay any testing until it had made a ''good faith'' effort to negotiate limitations on the weapons.   The official, Kenneth L. Adelman, the director of the Arms Control and Disarmament Agency, said the decision to proceed was based on the Administration's conclusion that it could not foresee any possible agreement to limit anti-satellite weapons that would be in the national interest.   Mr. Adelman said, ''We are therefore acting in conformity'' with the Congressional mandate.

headline: BIG BUILDERS LEARN TO THINK SMALL
abstract: A FEW miles from its futuristic headquarters in Irvine, Calif., the Fluor Corporation is building an $18 million sewage treatment plant for a planned community near Mission Viejo.   About an hour's drive from its headquarters in San Francisco, the Bechtel Group is constructing the $75 million Sacramento County Jail.   Fluor, Bechtel and other giants of construction -Parsons and Morrison-Knudsen, for example - were nothing less than 20th century pyramid-builders just a few years ago. They would barely consider projects with price tags below a billion dollars. Marshaling armies of men and machines, they erected refineries, petrochemical plants and huge nuclear power facilities in the United States. Overseas, they built entire industrial cities and vast copper mines.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Previous   Year

headline: APPLE COMPUTER ENTREPRENEUR'S RISE AND FALL
abstract: In his years of guiding Apple Computer Inc., Steven P. Jobs had become the epitome of the American entrepreneur, a symbol of the wealth and power that can arise almost overnight in California's Silicon Valley.   Even President Reagan, in a recent address, urged the nation's youth to ''follow in the footsteps of those two college students who launched one of America's great computer firms from the garage behind their house.''   The tale of Mr. Jobs's visionary leadership at Apple came to a bitter end on Tuesday when he resigned as the company's chairman after disclosure of his plans to start a new company.      A Prominent Salesman   Mr. Jobs has been the most prominent salesman of the personal computer revolution, preaching that the new technology would change everyone's lives. And just as Mr. Jobs is falling, the revolution he foretold is stalling: Consumers and businesses are slowing their purchases of computers and questioning how much they really need the machines.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Previous   Year

headline: TRADE GAP 22% LESS FOR JULY
abstract: The nation's trade deficit narrowed to $10.5 billion in July, the smallest since January, the Government said today.   The big improvement reflected a 19.3 percent decline in oil imports and a 16.7 percent drop in imports of cars. A brief teamsters' strike, now resolved, kept the cars from being hauled from American ports.   The Commerce Department said the merchandise trade deficit, the difference between what the country exports and what it imports, was 22 percent less than the $13.4 billion June deficit.

headline: BONN SOCIAL DEMOCRAT WARMLY RECEIVED IN SOVIET
abstract: Mikhail S. Gorbachev gave a pointedly warm reception today to Johannes Rau, the fast-rising star in West Germany's opposition Social Democratic Party.   At a Kremlin reception that the Government press agency Tass said was ''marked by an atmosphere of mutual understanding and constructive spirit,'' Mr. Gorbachev endorsed a proposal the Social Democrats had worked out with East Germany for a zone free of chemical weapons.   The endorsement reflected the Soviet Union's close ties with the Social Democrats, whose leader, Willy Brandt, worked out West Germany's reconciliation with the Soviet Union when he was Chancellor in the 1970's. Last May, Mr. Gorbachev received Mr. Brandt at a luncheon and in a four-hour meeting.

headline: U.S. Reports Defection Of High Czech Envoy
abstract: Reagan Administration officials said today that the second-ranking Czechoslovak diplomat here had defected to the United States.

headline: I.R.S. Ruling To Help Banks
abstract: In a ruling that could help bank holding companies comply with Government capital requirements, the Internal Revenue Service said yesterday that interest paid on equity-contract loans could be deducted from income.   Equity contracts are 12-year loans that must be redeemed with newly issued stock if the issuing banking company has not issued enough stock during the life of the loan to cover the amount borrowed.

headline: POWERBOAT SINKS JUST HOURS FROM BREAKING ATLANTIC SPEED RECORD
abstract: The Virgin Atlantic Challenger, a powerboat trying to beat the trans-Atlantic speed record of the liner United States, filled with water and sank just below the surface in stormy weather today only hours from the British lighthouse that marked the end of her 2,850-mile course.   Her crew of nine, including a yachtsman who had rowed the Atlantic and a millionaire sponsor whose experience was limited to a canal boat, were rescued unhurt by a British banana boat, the Geestbay, that lumbered along in answer to their calls of Mayday.   The $2.1 million Atlantic Challenger, a 65-foot-long twin-hulled vessel with two 2,000-horsepower engines, was reported still floating, submerged and bow-up, 138 miles from the finish line at the Bishop Rock Lighthouse in the Isles of Scilly, where champagne and the relatives of the crew were waiting.   Ted Toleman, Atlantic Challenger's skipper, who with other crew members was whisked off the banana boat by a Royal Air Force helicopter just as they were about to sit down to dinner, reported that his vessel met disaster when it hit a solid object beneath the surface.

headline: CONGRESS IS URGED TO PUT SANCTIONS ON SOUTH AFRICA
abstract: Senator Richard G. Lugar, chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, said today that he favored moving rapidly on legislation imposing economic sanctions against South Africa, and that he expected President Reagan to go along.   Alluding to the two separate measures already voted on in the two houses of Congress, the Indiana Republican said through an aide:   ''I want a bill, I want the House to agree to the Senate bill if the House wants something done quickly, and I think I can get the President to sign it.''      Senate Voted a Milder Version    The Senate bill provides for a milder set of sanctions than the House bill does. House and Senate conferees are to meet Wednesday to iron out the differences.

headline: Suave Shoe Lays Off 400
abstract: The Suave Shoe Corporation, the largest shoe manufacturer in Florida, has laid off 400 of its 1,400 workers because of competition from low-cost imports,  company officials said. ''We have no immediate plans to recall any of them,'' Pedro Mirones, secretary and assistant general manager, said Friday. Some of the laid-off workers have been employed by Suave for 20 years.

headline: E.E.C. Head Criticizes U. S.
abstract: The Commissioner of the European Economic Community, Claude Cheysson, accused the United States Friday of betraying the free market ideal and spoke of the ''total despair'' of debt-burdened Latin American countries.   Mr. Cheysson, at the end of a two-day visit to Tunisia to discuss the effects of the entry of Spain and Portugal into the Common Market next year, said it was essential to give debt-burdened countries the possibility to develop.

headline: Drexel, in Revamping, Sets 2 Vice Chairmen
abstract: In response to rapid growth in the last five years, Drexel Burnham Lambert announced yesterday that it had named two vice chairmen and was realigning various operations.   The firm said that James Balog and Edwin Kantor, senior executive vice presidents, had been named vice chairmen.   At the same time, Drexel said that a number of operating departments had been consolidated into three major business segments: investment banking, an individual investor group and a professional investor group.

headline: ON GUATEMALAN CAMPUS, THE FIRST TEST IS SURVIVAL
abstract: The rector of the University of San Carlos here is out to set an unusual record. He would like to be the first head of the school to finish a term in office since 1978.   But the rector, Dr. Eduardo Meyer Maldonado, is aware that it may not be an easy task. Overseeing Guatemala's national university has proved to be a high-risk occupation of late, as political violence, much of it Government-directed, has swept the country.

headline: Markets Closed
abstract: All stock and commodity markets in the United States are closed today in observance of Labor Day. Government offices, banks and many businesses also are closed.

headline: G.M. to Modernize Ohio Metal Plant
abstract: The General Motors Corporation said today that it would spend up to $600 million to modernize its metal fabrication plant near Mansfield, Ohio. The project is part of G.M.'s continuing product development and investment program, which will total more than $9 billion this year.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: Debt Issues    American Express Credit Corp. is offering 25 billion yen of 8 percent, 10-year senior Euronotes at a price of 100 1/2 through underwriters led by Shearson Lehman Brothers International.    * Barclays Australia Finance Ltd. is issuing $50 million (Australian) of 12 5/8 percent Eurobonds due 1990, at a price of 100 1/4, through Barclays Merchant Bank Ltd.    * Great Northern Nekoosa Corp. has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for up to $150 million of debt securities.

headline: Advanced Micro
abstract: The United States Philips Corporation, a subsidiary of the United States Philips Trust, said it had filed a patent infringement suit against Advanced Micro Devices Inc. of Sunnyvale, Calif. U.S. Philips said the suit, filed in a Federal District Court in California, charges infringement of three patents covering technology for local oxidation of silicon, a process in the manufacture of semiconductors.

headline: Fidelcor to Buy IVB Financial
abstract: Fidelcor Inc., the parent company of Fidelity Bank, said it would acquire the IVB Financial Corporation, parent of Industrial Valley Bank and Trust Company, for $168 million.

headline: BELL'S FEARED HUTTON INQUIRY
abstract: Executives, past and present, at E. F. Hutton & Company are awaiting Sept. 5 with more than a little trepidation. That is the day former Attorney General Griffin B. Bell plans to release the findings of his internal investigation into the brokerage firm's bank overdrafting scheme and who was responsible.   After 10 weeks of inquiry, scores of interviews, thousands of hours of studying financial records by a staff of 14 lawyers and 5 paralegals, Mr. Bell says he is ready to tell the public what he has learned about the illegal activities.   But while Mr. Bell will be handing down what amounts to a verdict, it is his own handling of the investigation and the extent of his findings that will be under scrutiny as well. As the investigator hand-picked by Hutton's senior management, Mr. Bell's own reputation is at stake, especially if subsequent Congressional inquiries disclose that Hutton top executives masterminded an illegal scheme.

headline: AUTO GROUP FIGHTS ANTI-THEFT PLAN
abstract: A proposed Transportation Department regulation designed to reduce automobile theft is being fought by a group of foreign-car importers who say their business could be crippled by the terms of the ruling. The importers, who make up much of the so-called gray market in luxury cars, are supported by the Justice Department.   The debate over the terms of the anti-theft rule as it applies to gray market autos is the most recent battle between franchised foreign distributors and companies that sell the same items at a lower price by bypassing traditional channels for purchasing automobiles.   The anti-theft rule, expected to be issued by the Transportation Department next month, would require manufacturers to place identification marks on up to 14 parts - such as fenders, hood, doors, bumpers, engine and transmission - of cars that have a high frequency of theft.

headline: IRAN SEALS SOME BORDER AREAS TO COMBAT DRUG SMUGGLING
abstract: Iran said today that it had sealed off some border areas to stem the flow of narcotics into the country.

headline: IRAQ REPORTS RAIDING KHARG ISLAND AND 'LARGE NAVAL TARGET'
abstract: Iraq said today that its warplanes raided the Iranian oil terminal at Kharg Island twice in the last 24 hours and hit a ''large naval target'' in the Persian Gulf. Iraq generally uses the term to refer to an oil tanker or merchant ship.   Military spokesman said Iraqi jets attacked the northern Gulf oil terminal Friday night and again today, dropping four tons of explosives in each raid.

headline: MORE BLIMPS GO TO MARKETING
abstract: As Goodyear's giant blue and silver blimp drifts serenely and confidently above Manhattan, a red and silver challenger, sporting McDonald's ubiquitous golden arches, suddenly darts into sight and playfully dogs its tail.   The game of tag is a sign that Goodyear has lost its monopoly in the skies. Indeed, the Goodyear airship these days is just as likely to cross paths with a green and white Fuji rival or a red and white contender from Resorts International.   The skies are hardly crowded with blimps yet, but there is no doubt that in New York and elsewhere companies are suddenly turning to this unusual marketing medium. They like its visibility, the free publicity it sometimes garners at televised sporting events, and even its price tag. And some see other business tie-ins.

headline: Cost-Cutting Plan At Boise Cascade
abstract: The Boise Cascade Corporation announced a cost-cutting plan that includes layoffs and a freeze on hiring and salary increases, citing the intense competition for business in the depressed market for forest products. A spokesman, Doug Bartels, said wage concessions also might be sought from some workers as the company strives to cut its payroll costs by at least 3 percent.   The company's chairman, John B. Fery, said the continued reduction in the work force, begun several years ago, would be made primarily through attrition, ''but there will also be selective reductions in employment levels throughout the company.'' Mr. Bartels declined to say exactly how many jobs would be cut.

headline: Tests Start On New Magazine
abstract: TIME INC. goes into supermarkets in 13 markets today to begin the 17-week test of its latest magazine entry, Picture Week.   According to Kelso Sutton, executive vice president for the magazine group, by the time the corporation makes its ''go'' or ''no-go'' decision in December, this publication for the masses will have been pretested more than any other new magazine in the history of publishing.   Just two years ago Time folded TV-Cable Week after a $100 million drain and the knowledge that much of the failure was due to the reliance on a third party - the cable system operators - for marketing.

headline: ALOIS CARIGIET, SWISS PAINTER KNOWN FOR CHILDREN'S BOOKS
abstract: Alois Carigiet, the Swiss painter and graphic artist best known for illustrating children's books, died Thursday in his native Trun after a long illness, his family said today. He was 82 years old.

headline: ALEXANDER'S MOVE OUTSIDE THE FAMILY
abstract: Alexander's Inc., the New York retailer that was founded by George Farkas and run by his family for 66 years, has reached outside the family for the first time and has turned over daily control of the company to Roger A. Barrer and Louis Powell, who are expected to be formally named co-presidents shortly.   Although both are longtime veterans of Alexander's, their appointment will open a new chapter in a company long dominated by a merchant entrepreneur and his four sons. The dynasty, now represented only by two of Mr. Farkas's sons, steered the stores in a direction that set them apart.   Alexander's became a seller of copies of the newest international fashions at bargain-basement prices. In addition, it accumulated valuable real estate, and led its competition into suburbia.

headline: A Merger Quandary For Richardson Kin
abstract: He is only 38 years old, but Stuart S. Richardson, chairman of Richardson-Vicks Inc., already must know a bit about loyalty, both to his family and to his company.   When Mr. Richardson took over as chairman of the company earlier this summer, he became the fifth member of the Richardson family to serve in that role since 1907, when his great-grandfather, Lunsford Richardson, a North Carolina chemist, started a concern called the Vicks Family Remedies Company in Greensboro.   Stuart, who joined the company in 1971, assumed the chairmanship from his father, Smith Richardson Jr., and father and son, along with four other family members, currently sit on the company's 18-member board. Through trusts and other holdings, the 200-or-so members of the Richardson family own more than 25 percent of Richardson-Vicks's 24.5 million outstanding shares.

headline: Nigeria Ends Curfew And Reopens Seaports
abstract: Nigeria's new military authorities lifted a dusk-to-dawn curfew today that it had imposed on major cities after the coup Tuesday. It also reopened all seaports.

headline: India and Afghanistan Sign a Cultural Accord
abstract: India signed a two-year cultural agreement today with the Afghan Government of Babrak Karmal, which is supported by the Soviet Union.

headline: Central Soya Set To Sell Foods Unit
abstract: The Central Soya Company said in a letter to its employees that it would sell its branded foods units, which include Fred's Frozen Foods and J.H. Filbert Inc. Last month, Central Soya's shareholders approved the acquisition of the company by a partnership led by California-based Shamrock Holdings Inc. Shamrock, which has interests in real estate and broadcasting and is owned by the Roy E. Disney family, had said that it will dispose of branded foods to concentrate on Central Soya's agribusiness operations.   Central Soya, based in Fort Wayne, Ind., is a leading soybean miller and food processor, with sales of $1.73 billion in its most recent fiscal year.

headline: U.S. BEGINS PROCEEDINGS TO DEPORT AN EX-NICARAGUA REBEL LEADER
abstract: The Immigration and Naturalization Service has started proceedings that could lead to the deportation of a former Nicaraguan rebel leader who has been critical of Reagan Administration policies, an immigration official said yesterday.   The official, Perry A. Rivkind, who is the I.N.S. district director in Miami, said he had reviewed the file of Edgar Chamorro, a former director of the Nicaraguan Democratic Force, the major guerrilla group fighting the Sandinista Government, after reading an article written by Mr. Chamorro last week that was critical of United States activities in Nicaragua.   Mr. Rivkind denied that there was any connection between the exclusionary order issued to Mr. Chamorro and the critical statements made by him.

headline: A.T.&T. Plans Computer Unit
abstract: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company said today that it would establish a new business unit to sell computer systems that could respond to limited spoken requests and dispense information with an electronic voice.   Both speech recognition and speech response systems have been in use for several years, but A.T.&T. says it is the first to put both technologies together in a system for use over the telephone.

headline: Trade Deficit Up in Britain
abstract: Britain suffered its biggest trade deficit in a decade last year, with shortfalls in every commodity but oil, the Government said today.

headline: IN NEW ACCOUNT, AGCA TELLS OF A 4TH TURK AT SHOOTING OF JOHN PAUL
abstract: Mehmet Ali Agca reversed himself today and agreed to answer more questions in the trial of himself and seven other men on charges of conspiring to assassinate Pope John Paul II.   Once on the witness stand, Mr. Acga also changed his story again. This time, he said there was a fourth Turkish conspirator in St. Peter's Square when he shot the Pope on May 13, 1981.   Mr. Agca, a 27-year-old Turk who is the star witness against three Bulgarians and four Turks charged with complicity in the shooting, said last week during his 12th day of testimony that he would not answer any more questions.

headline: OPEC FAILS AGAIN IN EFFORT TO UNITE TO KEEP PRICES UP
abstract: Oil ministers of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries failed again today to agree on measures to bolster world oil prices, despite a warning by Mexico that it might cut its oil prices next week.   It would be Mexico's second price cut in a month in response to declining demand for its oil. Analysts say a price cut by Mexico, which is not an OPEC member, would almost certainly lead to a renewed decline in world oil prices, rendering the cartel's price structure increasingly unrealistic and fragile.   After two days of apparently fruitless talks here, Indonesia's Oil Minister, Subroto, who is presiding over the meeting, told reporters he had asked ministers to return on Sunday to suggest ''immediate steps'' to defend the cartel's price structure and its share of the world market.

headline: U.S. NOTES SELL WELL AT AUCTION
abstract: Strong demand at yesterday's auction of new 10-year Treasury notes led to a modest afternoon rally that raised prices and reduced yields for all outstanding Treasury issues.   By all accounts, the $6.75 billion auction of 10-year notes attracted good demand from investors, which helped to spark more aggressive buying by securities dealers and other speculators. By late afternoon, when the Treasury announced that the 10 1/2 percent notes sold with an average yield of 10.60 percent, prices had already improved enough so that the 10-year issue was trading with a yield of 10.54 percent.   Prices continued to rise late in the day, so that the new notes were offered to yield 10.53 percent, well below the 10.7 percent that was estimated by some analysts a day earlier. Although the yield on 10-year notes is still higher than the 9.93 percent level of July 5, it remains well below the 11.30 percent set at the previous 10-year note auction in May.

headline: People
abstract: Stephen D. Bowers has resigned as president of LeAnce/Herbert/Bower Public Relations and Advertising, Newport Beach, Calif.

headline: CONSUMER PRICES UP BY 0.2%
abstract: Consumer prices rose two-tenths of 1 percent in August, the Labor Department said today, meaning that inflation for the first three quarters of 1985 is running at an annual rate of 3.3 percent, the lowest in almost two decades.   August was the fourth consecutive month in which the Labor Department's Consumer Price Index rose at that pace.   The slack inflation prompted some analysts to suggest that the Federal Reserve Board was being too timid in stimulating the economy. Roger Brinner of Data Resources, in Lexington, Mass., said, ''If 0.2 is the current core, then that means we have had enough benefit from weak oil prices and weak farm prices that the Fed has overdone it again.''

headline: Trade Deficit Record Likely
abstract: The United States trade representative, Clayton K. Yeutter, said today that the United States trade deficit could reach a record $150 billion this year.         ''The numbers for 1985 are probably going to be the worst that we have ever had,'' Mr. Yeutter said in a televised interview on NBC. He said the deficit with Japan alone is likely to reach $50 billion this year.

headline: NEW ARMY SLAYINGS IN GUATEMALA REPORTED BY VILLAGERS AND CHURCH
abstract: At least 60 Indian peasants living in and around this small town have been killed or have ''disappeared'' in the last seven months, almost all of them victims of the Guatemalan Army, according to local residents and the Archbishop of Guatemala.   More than 40 of the attacks have been carried out since March, according to a Roman Catholic Church report that has been sent to Pope John Paul II. Guatemalans and diplomats who have visited the town have also confirmed the killings.   According to the church report, the Government-directed violence, apparently intended to eliminate anyone suspected of even sympathizing with leftist rebels, has left at least 146 orphans and 45 widows in this village alone.   ''The army kills many people, up to children,'' the Archbishop of Guatemala, Prospero Penados del Barrio, said in an interview. ''There are many dead.''

headline: PATENTS;  High-Temperature, Gas-Cooled Reactor
abstract: A gas-cooled, high-temperature nuclear reactor has been patented for a West German company. Patent 4,543,232 was granted this week to Claus Elter and four co-inventors, who assigned it to Hochtemperatur-Reaktorbau of Cologne.  The reactor is described as having a pressure vessel, a reactor core, a roof-shielded reflector and suspension bolts that are hollow and permit the flow of gas.

headline: Nicholas Eden, Earl of Avon And Former Aide to Thatcher
abstract: Nicholas Eden, the Earl of Avon and a former under secretary in Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's Cabinet, died Saturday after a long illness, it was reported today. He was 54 years old.

headline: Business Digest: MONDAY, JULY 8, 1985
abstract: International OPEC oil ministers failed to agree to any changes in pricing or production after three days of meetings in Vienna. Oil industry analysts, oil company executives and some oil ministers said the lack of a clear solution to the group's problems could lead to a further decline in oil prices. However, the 13-member organization will meet again July 22 in Geneva, where some of the suggestions made over the weekend may be discussed again. [Page A1.]  Competition for international long-distance calls is heating up as A.T.& T.'s rivals fight to cut into the telephone giant's 97 percent share of the $5 billion overseas market. [D1.]  Sinking oil platforms may threaten European gas production from the Ekofisk field in the North Sea. [D1.]  High-technology investments by foreign companies in Malaysia have disappointed officials there, who had hoped for greater stimulus to local development. [D4.]  Canada's grain farmers are facing a quiet crisis as pests threaten crops and worldwide oversupply hurts prices. [D4.]  The Economy Economic activity among manufacturers continued to sag last month, the nation's purchasing managers reported. They said overall activity last month fell to its lowest level since December 1982 -a finding that was in sharp contrast to other recent reports that suggest the economy may be regaining lost momentum. [D1.]  Companies Six huge airlines could result from industry consolidation, according to analysts and airline executives, who said the giant carriers would have the power to control fares and routes.

headline: Peru Chief Continues State of Emergency
abstract: Peru's new Government extended a state of emergency in six states today in reaction to rebel attacks, including a car-bombing Wednesday outside police headquarters that seriously wounded five people.

headline: Giant TV Campaign Set For Beneficial Corp.
abstract: Yesterday, Dancer Fitzgerald Sample began to prove that you do not have to be jolly and green to be a good giant.

headline: Fireman's Fund Leader
abstract: The American Express Company, as expected, named John J. Byrne today as chairman and chief executive of the Fireman's Fund Corporation, the holding company for its insurance operations. Mr. Byrne used to be chairman of the Geico Corporation.

headline: Norfolk Is Backed In Bid for Conrail
abstract: The Federal share of Conrail should be sold to the Norfolk Southern Corporation, the state Transportation Department said today. In return for the endorsement, the department said the company had agreed, among other things, to give the state the West Side line in Manhattan so trains from Albany and the north could go into Pennsylvania Station and to pay the $20 million estimated cost of the planned Harlem River freight yard.

headline: ISRAEL SEEMS IN NO RUSH ON DETAINEES
abstract: The Israeli Cabinet today discussed the release of the American airliner hostages, but made no decision on when to free 735 Lebanese and Palestinian detainees whose freedom was the principal demand of the hostage-takers, the Cabinet secretary said.   Cabinet sources said the United States had put no pressure whatsoever on Israel to release the 735 detainees on any particular schedule now that the hijackers had freed their 39 American captives. Some of the detainees, mainly Shiites from southern Lebanon and the Beirut area, have been in custody for nearly two years for purported involvement in attacks on Israeli forces. They have never been charged under Israeli or Lebanese law.

headline: Hybritech Agrees To Bid by Eli Lilly
abstract: Eli Lilly & Company said yesterday that it had signed a definitive agreement to buy Hybritech Inc., a San Diego-based medical research company, for about $300 million.   Richard D. Wood, Lilly's chairman, said the acquisition would provide the company ''immediate entry into the diagnostics market'' and would enhance Lilly's research on monoclonal antibodies for the treatment of certain types of cancer.   ''Hybritech's emerging leadership in diagnostic products for hospital, laboratory and physician offices complements our own experience with therapeutic products in these same markets,'' Mr. Wood said.

headline: Philip Morris Issues Magazine for Smokers
abstract: Some cigarette companies may be curtailing the amount of money they are sinking into magazine advertising, but Philip Morris is not only increasing its spending but also bringing out a magazine of its own.   A quarterly, called simply Philip Morris Magazine, is a project of the corporate affairs department of the domestic company and is intended for distribution among smokers.

headline: KIN IN U.S. WORRYING ABOUT FATE OF RELATIVES
abstract: The devastating earthquake that struck Mexico City yesterday morning left Mexican-Americans across the country wondering about the fate of friends and relatives south of the border, with no way to obtain any reliable information.   Employees of the Mexican Embassy in Washington and other Mexican Government agencies or businesses in the United States were also scrambling to find out what was happening back home. But they too were frustrated by the breakdown of communications with the Mexican capital.

headline: Faberge Picks President With Sales Background
abstract: Faberge Inc., the perfume and hair care company, has named Steven Manenti, a former sales representative for the company's products, to the posts of president and chief operating officer.
