His appointment was effective Monday.   Mr. Manenti, 50, fills jobs that have been vacant since Faberge was acquired by the McGregor Corporation for $180 million last year. George Barrie, former president, left at the time of the acquisition.

headline: Head of Asia Division Named by Doyle Dane
abstract: Doyle Dane Bernbach Group has announced that its Asia division, which it said has been ''suffering from benign neglect,'' will be headed by Alan R. Pilkington, the executive vice president and director of business development at D'Arcy MacManus Masius Worldwide.   Mr. Pilkington, a 42-year-old Australian, will be based in Sydney and will have responsibility for the agency's operations in Asia and the Pacific.

headline: Sudan Reports Arrests After Attempted Coup
abstract: A Sudanese Government newspaper said today that 163 military men and civilians were arrested after an unsuccessful coup was reported last week.

headline: BOND PRICES END DAY MIXED
abstract: Interest rates edged higher yesterday as bond prices finished the day mixed in light trading.   Following the bond market's advances in the two previous sessions, traders became less enthusiastic yesterday when the Federal Reserve failed to stem an early rise in short-term rates.   The rate on Federal funds, excess reserves that banks lend each other overnight, surged to the 9 percent level, where it remained most of the day. On Friday, Fed funds closed at 7.71 percent.

headline: Golden West Deal
abstract: The Golden West Financial Corporation said it had acquired the offices and insured deposits of Bell Savings Banc of Texas under the auspices of the Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corporation. The company said its purchase of Bell's liabilities is being offset by payment of an undisclosed sum by the F.S.L.I.C. Golden West, parent of the World Savings and Loan Association, said the units will become its first in Texas. The thrift institution already operates in Kansas and Colorado, in additon to California.

headline: MASS PRODUCTION
abstract: To the Editor:   In ''Break the Habits of Mass Production'' (Forum, Aug. 25), Wickham Skinner has stated the situation superbly. But people need to know what their new ''habits'' should be.

headline: Australian Union Protesters
abstract: The police arrested more than 100 people today during union demonstrations against tough anti-strike laws passed by the conservative Queensland state government. The police moved in after more than 2,000 people gathered outside the state parliament buildings at the start of a new parliamentary session. Queensland unions have been in dispute with the state government since laws were enacted in February imposing constraints on union activities.

headline: Evening News
abstract: Two television producers have agreed temporarily to stop soliciting Evening News Association stock from Michigan residents in a hostile $453 million takeover bid for the newspaper and broadcasting company, lawyers said. The agreement by Norman Lear and A. Jerrold Perenchio will remain in effect until a Federal appeals court decides whether Michigan law applies to the takeover fight, said Theodore Souris, a lawyer representing the producers. Arguments are scheduled for next Tuesday in Cincinnati.

headline: BEHIND THE NEW BASEBALL PACT, COMPROMISES
abstract: Neither representatives of the major league baseball teams nor the players claimed victory yesterday as a result of the two-day baseball strike, and there was disagreement over the role played by Commissioner Peter Ueberroth in reaching a settlement.   But representatives of the owners and the players said negotiators for both sides moved quickly to end the dispute because they feared another long strike if they did not reach agreement in the first few days of a strike. They said the players and the owners each conceded ground to the other.   For example, even though the players agreed to reduce from 33 percent to 18 percent their share of the national television revenue for their benefit plan, the players won a hefty pension: At age 62, a player with 10 years of major league experience will receive a pension of nearly $91,000. Under the previous plan, a 20-year major leaguer, at age 65, would have gotten about $57,000 a year.

headline: Bunker Ramo
abstract: Bunker Ramo, a subsidiary of the Allied Corporation, introduced a new information network that it described as ''an aggressive repositioning for the company.'' The new network, called Supernet, provides an array of financial information on either special terminals or conventional personal computers. Bunker Ramo, which supplies information to investors, said the new system was being tested and would be operating in five brokerages by the end of the year.

headline: MIDDLE CLASS
abstract: To the Editor:   Robert Z. Lawrence tries to reassure us that ''The Middle Class Is Alive and Well'' (Forum, June 23) in the face of all the reported declines in high-paid jobs in the manufacturing sector. His approach is too aggregative to be true.

headline: SOUTH AFRICAN POLICE START BRUTALITY INQUIRY
abstract: The police in Cape Town said today that they were investigating allegations of police brutality after complaints by mixed-race citizens of unprovoked attacks.   The police activity was condemned by the opposition party and, in an unusual move, questioned by the National Party newspaper in Cape Town.   The inquiry was ordered by Brigadier C. A. Swart, the new police commander in Western Cape Province, and comes in the wake of the deaths of two people in police action Wednesday in the Cape Town area. One of those slain was a 10-year-old boy who was reportedly shot once in the head and twice in the back when policemen fired on a group of fleeing children.

headline: Accounts
abstract: * Logicsoft Inc., Farmingdale, L.I., which markets personal computer software, hardware and systems, to Greenstone & Rabasca Advertising, Melville, L.I.  ADVERTISING

headline: RCA and MCA Met on Friday
abstract: Top executives of the RCA Corporation and MCA Inc. met Friday to continue discussions about a possible merger between the new companies, according to sources close to the situation. These talks followed talks last spring between top management of both entertainment conglomerates.

headline: SYRIA AND IRAN ARE NURTURING A WARY, AMBIGUOUS ALLIANCE
abstract: Women and children, the relatives of ''martyrs'' from the recent struggles of Iran, dismount from buses at a mosque on the southern edge of this city and, amid the pilgrims from Saudi Arabia and Kuwait, pray before the tomb of a granddaughter of Mohammed.   Many of them are in this country courtesy of the Iranian Government, whose official Martyrs Foundation pays their expenses for the pilgrimage and provides them with some spending money.   Near the tomb, a casual bazaar extends along a badly littered stream running beneath a row of dusty trees, where the women from Iran buy quartz watches and Instamatic cameras. On a wall of the Sitt Zainab Mosque, the holiest Shiite shrine in Syria, is a rare sight in this rather secular country: a large portrait of the Iranian leader Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini.   The busy scene at the mosque, a glittering structure of silver mirrored arches and whirring ceiling fans, is one aspect of the complex relationship that has existed between the two hard-line, bitterly anti-Israeli nations of Syria and Iran, particularly since the Iranian revolution and the outbreak of the Iran-Iraq war nearly five years ago.

headline: B.A.T to Divest Packaging Unit
abstract: B.A.T Industries said today that it had agreed to a $246 million leveraged buyout of its Mardon Packaging International Ltd. subsidiary by Mardon executives and Canadian and British investors.

headline: FUND CITED
abstract: The Exxon Corporation, the world's largest industrial company, yesterday reported a 44.8 percent drop in second-quarter profits, primarily because it set up a $545 million contingency fund after a court's recent ruling that the company had overcharged oil customers.   Elsewhere, the Atlantic Richfield Corporation, the nation's fifth-largest oil company, reported a $1.1 billion loss, one of the highest quarterly deficits in American corporate history. The company is going through a broad reorganization.   Two other oil companies that are being restructured, Phillips Petroleum and Diamond Shamrock, also reported weak results. Phillips had a sharp drop in profits, while Diamond Shamrock reported a loss.

headline: TURNER ADVISED ON CBS BID
abstract: Ted Turner is considering several plans that would add as much as $2.6 billion in cash to his offer for 67 percent of CBS Inc., an official of Turner Broadcasting System Inc. testified today, but he sought to minimize the possibility that the offer would be revised.   The testimony came during a hearing in Federal District Court here on a request by Turner Broadcasting for an injunction to block CBS from buying back 20 percent of its stock. The CBS buyback, particularly because of its restrictive covenants, would render the Turner offer ''unworkable,'' William C. Bevins Jr., vice president and chief financial officer of Turner Broadcasting, testified.   Under questioning by CBS attorneys, Mr. Bevins said E. F. Hutton & Company, which is advising Turner Broadcasting, had recommended at least five plans to add some cash to the bid, which now offers stock and debt securities but no cash. But he emphasized that Turner had no plans to change its offer.

headline: Gulf Canada Assets Sale
abstract: Gulf Canada Ltd. and Petro-Canada Inc. said Gulf, as expected, will sell its refining, distribution and marketing assets west of Quebec to Government-owned Petro-Canada, effective Sept. 30, for $446 million (United States). The companies said the transaction involves a refinery/lubricant plant at Clarkson, Ontario; an asphalt plant at Moose Jaw, Saskatchewan; Gulf's interests in a refinery at Port Moody, British Columbia, and various product pipelines and about 1,800 Gulf retail outlets.

headline: British 737 Is Landed After Engine Overheats
abstract: British Airways Boeing 737 with 80 people aboard made an emergency landing at Heathrow Airport today after a signal light indicated that one of its two engines had overheated, officials said.   They said the plane landed safely with only one engine working after the pilot shut down the port engine.

headline: U.S. SPYING HELD UNHURT BY WEST GERMAN BREACH
abstract: Reagan Administration officials have concluded that recent disclosures of West Germans spying for East Germany are very costly to West German intelligence operations but will not seriously hurt American intelligence activities.   At the same time, the officials acknowledged that the exposures gave an accurate and unsettling look into the amount of Soviet espionage in Western Europe and raised embarrassing questions about sharing information with allies, questions the Administration would sooner not have to answer.   The officials said the Central Intelligence Agency had always assumed that West Germany, more so than other Western European countries, was significantly infiltrated by East German and Soviet agents.   Accordingly, the officials maintained that American intelligence shared with Bonn was given in pieces that did not include information about American agents and their sources and methods.

headline: MEDICAL TRAINING FOR REBELS PLANNED
abstract: The first systematic medical training program for Afghan rebels will soon be organized at Thal, a refugee camp in Pakistan near the Afghan border, according to the director of a private medical relief group based in Hawaii.   The program is intended to give Afghan rebels medical training that they can take back to Afghanistan, according to Gay-LeClerk Brenner, director of the group, called Freedom Medicine.   She said the group planned to start classes in November and to prepare the first group of medics to work in the spring and summer, after the lull in winter fighting.   Freedom Medicine is affiliated with the Afghanistan Relief Committee in New York, a private American group that helps Afghan refugees. Freedom Medicine is closely cooperating with other refugee and relief groups, including the International Rescue Committee, Direct Relief, the International Medical Corps and the French group Doctors Without Borders, Mrs. Brenner said.

headline: FINDING THE RIGHT CAR DEAL
abstract: BUYING an automobile can be enormously complicated. Not only is it the second largest purchase most people make (after a house), but there is usually financing to arrange, a used car to dispose of and insurance and options to consider.   Nevertheless, by taking the process one step at a time and examining options at each stage, an individual can make a good deal. Car buyers have more room to bargain than ever today, because more auto producers are vying for consumer dollars -though more choices, for some, can mean more confusion.

headline: Peru Ousts 2 Generals After Peasant Massacre
abstract: The Joint Armed Forces Command said today that soldiers massacred about 40 Andean peasants last month.

headline: Rumrill-Hoyt, at Last, Heralds New Accounts
abstract: Russ Berrie & Company of Oakland, N.J., which makes mugs, stuffed animals and other impulse gift items, after about a month with its first agency, Warwick Advertising, has switched the business to Rumrill-Hoyt. Billings are supposed to be $5 million.

headline: A SOUTH AFRICAN FUNERAL, A MOTHER'S SPECIAL PAIN
abstract: Eight years ago, the woman said, she attended the funeral of the black nationalist Steve Biko and was troubled by the problem of whether or not to take children to such events - to shelter them, that is, or to expose them to the harshnesses of this land.   At the time, said the woman, Nyameka Goniwe, she did not think that one day, she would face the same ordeal and decision herself: whether or not to take her son, Nyaniso, now 3 years old, to watch his father being buried. But that decision, she said, she will have to make before Saturday, when her husband, Matthew Goniwe, and three other men are buried here.   The body of Mr. Goniwe, a bespectacled schoolteacher and civic leader in his 30's, was found early this month, near those of his three associates. The burned and mutilated bodies were found amid the dunes of the Indian Ocean coastline 125 miles south of here. The four left a political meeting in Port Elizabeth June 27, their associates say, and planned to drive north to Cradock. That was the last time they were seen alive.

headline: Baxter Travenol Names Chairman
abstract: In an apparent gesture of conciliation, Baxter Travenol Laboratories, which is acquiring the American Hospital Supply Corporation, announced yesterday that Karl D. Bays, American's chairman and chief executive officer, would become chairman of Baxter's board and the board's executive committee.   At the same time, Vernon R. Loucks Jr., the man who masterminded the acquisition, would remain president and chief executive officer of Baxter Travenol, which is based in Deerfield, Ill., a Chicago suburb.   Since the merger was announced last month, officials at American Hospital, which is based in Evanston, Ill., have declined to say whether Mr. Bays would join the merged company. Many analysts said there was some tension between employees of the two competing companies, especially after Baxter had outmaneuvered American, the nation's largest hospital supply company, and prevented its plans to merge with the Hospital Corporation of America.

headline: NICARAGUAN REBELS SAID TO OPEN MAJOR DRIVE WITH NEW WEAPONS
abstract: Substantial shipments of weapons in recent months have permitted Nicaraguan guerrillas to open a new anti-Government drive inside Nicaragua, according to rebel officials, Western diplomats and Hondurans familiar with the rebels' operations.   The new offensive, officials here say, appears to have caught the Nicaraguan Government by surprise.   Rebel units said to number up to 10,000 guerrillas seem to have sidestepped Sandinista troops along the Honduran border to launch attacks in the last week in the departments of Esteli and Chontales, where they are reported to have killed as many as 95 Nicaraguan soldiers and militiamen in a series of ambushes. Esteli is near the Honduran border, but Chontales is deep inside Nicaragua.

headline: SUDAN REJECTED JOINT WAR GAMES, U.S. SAYS
abstract: Pentagon officials said today that the Sudanese Government had declined to participate in Middle East military exercises with American forces next month.   A Pentagon official said the decision was made in late April, less than a month after a military coup in which President Gaafar al-Nimeiry was ousted. The official said the decision appeared to stem both from confusion within the new regime and a desire not to seem too close to the United States.   The Pentagon and the State Department have been closely watching for signs of trouble in what has been a cordial military relationship between the United States and the Sudan, especially since the Sudan announced this month that it had signed a military agreement with Libya.

headline: CRIME WAVE
abstract: To the Editor:   Ralph Nader's ''America's Crime Without Criminals'' (Forum, May 19) touches only briefly on the most effective deterrent to white collar crime: forfeiture of licenses or company charters.

headline: Greek Opposition Chief Quits Party Presidency
abstract: The head of the major opposition party, Constantine Mitsotakis, resigned today after party squabbling over the date of a party congress.   Mr. Mitsotakis, leader of the New Democracy Party, said in a statement, ''It was obvious that the disagreement over the date for holding the party's congress conceals doubts over the party's leadership.''

headline: $115 Million Bonds From New Mexico
abstract: A $115 million New Mexico offering of severance-tax bonds was priced yesterday, through underwriters led by Prudential-Bache Securities Inc.   The financing consists of bonds with yields ranging from 5.40 percent for securities due in 1986 to 6 1/2 percent in 1988, 7.35 percent in 1990 and 8 1/2 percent in 1995.   The bonds are backed by the full faith and credit of the state and secured by a severance tax. They are rated Aaa by Moody's and AA+ by S.&P.

headline: PERES SEES BETTER EGYPT TIES
abstract: Prime Minister Shimon Peres has told Israeli officials that there has recently been a marked improvement in relations between Israel and Egypt, according to a source close to the discussions. [Egyptian officials, reached by telephone, denied that there had been any change in Egypt's policy toward Israel.]  The source said Mr. Peres had made the statement Tuesday in a review before the parliamentary committee on foreign affairs and security.

headline: Money Fund Assets Up
abstract: Assets of the nation's money market mutual funds rose $649.1 million, to $210.08 billion, for the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday.

headline: People
abstract: Neal Martineau has joined Tucker Wayne & Co., Atlanta, as senior vice president and executive creative director.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: * Cray Research Inc., Minneapolis, said British Petroleum Co. had awarded it a contract for the installation of a computer valued at $7.5 million.    * Digital Equipment Corp., Weston, Mass., said it had filed suit in United States District Court in New Hampshire against Emulex Corp., charging patent infringements and seeking an injunction against further production and distribution of Emulex Disk Controllers.

headline: Japan Denial of Capital Curb
abstract: The Japanese Finance Ministry and the Bank of Japan today denied a press report that Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone has told them to study ways of curbing capital outflows from Japan.   A Bank of Japan spokesman, who said he checked with the bank's governor, Satoshi Sumita, said the bank has been given no such instruction.   A Finance Ministry spokesman said the Ministry has not received any directives from Mr. Nakasone.

headline: MURDOCH WILL BUY OUT DAVIS'S HOLDINGS IN FOX
abstract: Marvin Davis, the wealthy Denver oilman, officially bid farewell to the entertainment industry today by agreeing to sell his 50 percent stake in the 20th Century-Fox Film Corporation to Rupert Murdoch for $325 million in cash.   The transaction will give Mr. Murdoch, whose News America Corporation publishes The New York Post and other newspapers and magazines, sole control of one of Hollywood's major film and television production studios within months of his acquisition of six independent television stations from Metromedia Inc.   With this latest purchase, Mr. Murdoch's News Corporation Ltd., with assets of more than $2 billion at the end of 1984, will have spent $1.6 billion in the last 12 months to acquire 12 trade publications from Ziff-Davis, total ownership of Fox and the six Metromedia stations.   A Wall Street source close to the Australian-born Mr. Murdoch, who asked not to be named, said News Corporation would finance the purchase of Mr. Davis's share of Fox through bank credit lines and cash generated by existing operations.

headline: Lebanese Chiefs Reach An Accord on Airport
abstract: Moslem and Druse leaders announced agreement today on a plan to tighten security in West Beirut and the international airport, and they invited Syrian observers to take part in putting the plan into effect.   The announcement, which came after 13 hours of talks in Damascus by political and religious figures from the Shiite, Sunni and Druse sects, also criticized the Reagan Administration's efforts to organize an international boycott of the Beirut airport over the recent ordeal of 39 American passengers taken hostage on a Trans World Airlines plane.

headline: POLISH CHIEF IS CAUGHT UP IN THE WHIRL
abstract: On his first full day in New York today, Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski surveyed the city from the roof of Rockefeller Center. Turning to his host, David Rockefeller, at a private lunch, the Polish leader remarked that for such a big city, it was wonderfully clear, with little pollution.   ''It is fair enough to say that he was impressed,'' said Maj. Wieslaw Gornicki, his aide. ''Certainly, from that elevation the city is positively not repulsive.''

headline: ZIMBABWE AFTER VOTE
abstract: At its congress last August, the ruling party adopted a plan calling for transforming this Western-modeled democracy into a socialist, one-party state ''in the fullness of time'' and in accordance with the nation's British-drafted Constitution.   The tone seemed moderate, sending a signal to the world and to the nation's economically powerful whites that change was not immediately at hand.   But, at least for now, that moderate tone appears as passe as white rule in this southern African nation that was once called Rhodesia.   On Saturday, after his party's landslide victory in Zimbabwe's first general election since independence in 1980, Prime Minister Robert Mugabe gave strong indications that he would change elements of the Constitution that stood in the way of the aims of his party, the Zimbabwe African National Union-Patriotic Front.

headline: SUDAN SAYS IT FOILED A COUP BID
abstract: The Sudanese Government said today that it had foiled an attempted coup by southern Sudanese who had foreign support.   The police imposed a 10 P.M.-to-5 A.M. curfew in Khartoum, the capital, after Prime Minister al-Gazouly Dafallah announced the purported coup attempt on the Sudanese radio.

headline: DROPPING OF BBC PROGRAM STIRS PROTEST
abstract: A political storm erupted today over a decision by the BBC to cancel the scheduled broadcast of a television documentary featuring a purported Irish Republican Army guerrilla leader.   The cancellation, which had been had been formally requested by the Home Secretary, Leon Brittan, at the direction of Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, sparked a staff rebellion at the British Broadcasting Corporation today and searching questions in Parliament and elsewhere about the BBC's independence from Government control.   The Prime Minister, who told The Sunday Times of London last week that she would ''utterly condemn'' the BBC for showing such a program, said she was ''very pleased'' by the BBC's decision, which was announced Tuesday night by the BBC board of governors.   ''I do not believe that any great body like the BBC should do anything which might be construed as furthering the objectives of terrorists,'' she said. ''I feel extremely strongly about it.''

headline: ARTHRITIS: BUILDING AN INDUSTRY ON PAIN
abstract: ARTHRITIS entered Ann DeGrout's life when she was 28. She was walking down the stairs of her home one day when her knees inexplicably gave out. She felt a stinging pain. The symptoms worsened and it became clear that she had rheumatoid arthritis. Thirty years later, the disease is still with her.   Arthritis has been an expensive companion. Mrs. DeGrout, a prim woman with quick eyes who lives in Clifton, N.J., buys about $200 worth of medication a year. She swallows eight to ten tablets a day of Ecotrin, a coated aspirin. Each morning, she takes 5 milligrams of Prednisone, a steroid that must be prescribed by a doctor. At least once a month, she must see her physician, which typically costs her $20 to $50. Lately, she has been showing up weekly.   She has found it necessary to acquire a range of equipment to help her through the routines of daily life. She has a padded bathtub seat that cost her about $130. She spent $35 for a walker, $25 for a set of canes. She owns a reacher ($15) that she uses to scoop up things.

headline: ADMINISTRATION DEBATES ATTITUDES TOWARD SYRIA
abstract: Reagan Administration officials say that as long as Syria may be helpful in gaining the return of seven Americans still missing in Lebanon, President Reagan is ready to be restrained toward the Damascus Government.   But beneath the surface, two Administration debates are reported under way.   A tactical debate centers on whether, as a price for Syrian help on the hostages, the United States should ignore and deny what it has described until recently as a Syrian role in terrorism.   This issue was joined this week when Mr. Reagan omitted Syria from a list of nations purportedly sponsoring terrorism and the State Department sidestepped the question of possible Syrian involvement in two suicide car bombings in southern Lebanon.

headline: Black & Decker Officer
abstract: The Black & Decker Corporation said yesterday that Nolan D. Archibald, a senior vice president of the Beatrice Companies, had been elected president and chief operating officer of the maker of power tools. He will take the jobs on Sept. 9, succeeding Laurence J. Farley, who will become chairman, filling a vacancy. Mr. Archibald, 42 years old, has worked for eight years at Beatrice, where there has been substantial management turnover lately. But he said said ''I'm leaving because of an outstanding opportunity at Black & Decker.''

headline: WHAT'S NEW IN DENTISTRY
abstract: TEN years ago, Terry McDonald, an orthodontist in Salem, Ore., had a waiting list for his services. Now that list has evaporated, a casualty, Dr. McDonald says, of a declining teen-age population and a sluggish local economy. So Dr. McDonald and Salem's seven other othodontists have done something they never thought they would do: advertise in the local paper, with such slogans as ''When you dress for success, don't forget your smile.''

headline: Marietta Contract
abstract: The Martin Marietta Corporation's aerospace unit is being awarded a $260 million contract for work on the MX missile program, the Air Force said.

headline: First Boston Offers Four Separate Issues
abstract: The First Boston Corporation yesterday startled the debt markets with a simultaneous offering of four separate issues of collateralized mortgage obligations totaling $801 million.   ''All four deals look, taste and smell just about the same, so we decided to eliminate some confusion by offering them all at the same time,'' said Laurence D. Fink, a managing director at First Boston.   The largest issue was $350 million by the Collateralized Mortgage Securities Corporation, a special purpose company created by First Boston. Another $200 million of securities were issued by the ISFA Mortgage Funding Corporation, a conduit program allowing savings and loan associations to convert mortgage pass-through securities into collateralized mortgage obligations. The American Southwest Financial Corporation, a financing company for home builders, issued nearly $101.4 million of obligations, while the Guaranteed Mortgage Corporation II, a subsidiary of Pulte Home, issued $150 million.

headline: Swiss Storms Cause Floods
abstract: The first heavy thunderstorms in western and central Switzerland this summer caused flooding, knocked out power and telephone services and washed out roads and rail links. Hardest hit by the storm Thursday evening was the village of Schwarzenburg, where the waters pushed into basements and forced the evacuation of a shopping center. The rail link between Bern and Schwarzenburg, 13 miles away, was shut down.

headline: MCI Seeks Court Costs
abstract: The MCI Communications Corporation is asking a Federal court to order the American Telephone and Telegraph Company to pay $27.6 million in fees and costs incurred by MCI in its long-running antitrust lawsuit against the communications giant.   The petition, filed Monday, includes $10.3 million in attorneys' fees; a $10 million contingency fee for its law firm, Jenner & Block, and other expenses - all stemming from a long court battle that resulted in a $113 million antitrust award to MCI.

headline: LATIN DEBT CRISIS SEEN INTENSIFYING
abstract: Senior Latin American officials said today that Peru's decision to limit foreign debt payments to 10 percent of export earnings adds a new element of urgency to the regional debt crisis.   The officials, including several ministers from the most indebted nations of the area, said Sunday's announcement by Peru's new Government was evidence that events were beginning to overtake efforts to resolve the three-year-old crisis.   ''This is the first time some government has tried to change the rules,'' said one minister who asked not to be named. ''The banks have the problem now. The ball is in their court.''

headline: NIPPON TELEGRAPH IN PACT WITH I.B.M.
abstract: The International Business Machines Corporation and Nippon Telegraph and Telephone said yesterday that they would enter a joint venture to build a complex computer network in Japan, marking the Japanese telecommunications giant's first major cooperative agreement with an American multinational corporation.   The announcement, which has been expected since the companies acknowledged in June that they were in negotiations, came in the midst of debate over a number of protectionist trade bills in Congress, many fueled by contentions that Japan's telecommunications markets have been closed to American companies.   Analysts doubted that the timing of the announcement was coincidental. The agreement was signed Sept. 12, but Hisashi Shinto, the president of Nippon Telegraph, is currently visiting the United States, arguing to both politicians and business executives that American companies that understand Japanese telecommunications needs will have little difficulty in selling goods there. Disagreement in U.S.American telecommunications experts disagree. In several recent speeches Clayton K. Yeutter, the United States trade representative, has charged that Nippon Telegraph has not lived up to a 1981 agreement calling for the purchase of more American telecommunications equipment. Such purchases, he and others maintain, actually leveled off or declined in 1984, and Mr. Yeutter has suggested that the agreement may have to be ''re-evaluated.''

headline: Productivity Up at 1% Rate
abstract: Nonfarm business productivity rose at an annual rate of 1 percent in the second quarter of 1985, the Labor Department said today. Gains were especially strong in the manufacturing sector because of competitive pressure from imports.

headline: The U.N. Today: July 25, 1985
abstract: SECURITY COUNCIL Meets at 3:30 P.M. on situation in South Africa.

headline: $200 Million Issue For Houston Light
abstract: The Brazos River Authority, Texas, is offering $200 million of pollution control revenue bonds on behalf of the Houston Light and Power Company, through underwriters led by the First Boston Corporation.   The financing is divided between $120 million of term bonds yielding 9 3/4 percent in 2005 and 9.926 percent in 2015, and $80 million of 7 3/4 percent bonds due in 2015 which may be put, or redeemed at a price of par, on Aug. 1, 1988, and every three years thereafter. The bonds are rated A-3 by Moody's and A by S.&P.

headline: Security Set to Buy Arizona Bancwest
abstract: The Security Pacific Corporation, the nation's seventh-largest bank holding company, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy the Arizona Bancwest Corporation for about $480 million.   The acquisition would be the bank's first move into full-service interstate banking.

headline: OLYMPIA, CHEVRON IN NEW PACT
abstract: Olympia & York Ltd., the Canadian real estate company, yesterday bought control of Gulf Canada Ltd., just two weeks after breaking off a purchase agreement and forfeiting a $25 million deposit.   Olympia agreed to pay up to $2.8 billion (Canadian) if it acquires the full 60.2 percent stake held by Chevron Inc. Its earlier agreement with Chevron called for it to buy the same percentage of stock for $3 billion.   But analysts said the Canadian dollar has recently strengthened, so that the payment to Chevron after conversion into United States dollars would be about the same as in the previous arrangement.   At the same time, Gulf Canada agreed to buy 84 percent of Abitibi-Price Inc., the world's largest manufacturer of newsprint, for $1.1 billion. Olympia owns 93 percent of Abitibi.  The deals were officially separate, but analysts said they were linked so that Olympia's profit on the Abitibi deal would more than offset its $25 million forfeiture in the aborted agreement with Chevron. Analysts said the deal would also have some favorable tax consequences for Olympia.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: Debt Issues    * Astrex Inc. is offering $15 million of 9 1/2 percent convertible subordinated debentures due 2000 at a price of 100 to yield 9 1/2 percent through Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc.    * Bank of Greece is issuing $:75 million in 10 3/4 percent bonds due 2010 at a price of 91.443 to yield 11.827 percent to maturity through Morgan Grenfell & Company.    * Chrysler Financial Corp. is offering $250 million of 10.60 percent senior notes due in 1990 at a price of 100 through Salomon Brothers. The notes are rated Baa-2 by Moody's and BBB-by Standard & Poor's.

headline: 9 KILLED IN KUWAIT BOMBINGS
abstract: Bombs exploded in two popular cafes here today, killing 9 people and wounding 56, the police said. There was no immediate assertion of responsibility.

headline: Port Authority Names Maritime Unit Director
abstract: James J. Kirk, a 33-year employee of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, has been named director of the agency's port department.   The appointment, which was announced by Peter Goldmark Jr., executive director of the Port Authority, is effective Aug. 19.   For the past six years, Mr. Kirk, 59, has served as deputy director of the Authority's rail transportation department. In that position, he has been responsible for the operation and capital improvement of PATH, the commuter railroad linking New Jersey and New York.

headline: Mickelberry Net Falls
abstract: The Mickelberry Corporation, holding company of ad agencies, announced Friday that its second-quarter earnings were down 59.3 percent, to $187,000, or 3 cents a share, from $460,000, or 8 cents a share, in the similar quarter last year. Revenues were up 13.3 percent, to $35 million, from $30.9 million.

headline: HIGH TECH BLOSSOMS ALONG THE POTOMAC
abstract: IT was called a High Tech Career Faire, the Old English spelling lending a touch of Dixie whimsy. The place was the conference hall of the Westpark-Best Western Motel at Tyson's Corner, Va., about 10 miles from downtown Washington.   Dark suits were pressed and shoes polished to a high luster as more than 200 software engineers, systems programmers, electronic data processors and other high-tech job-seekers distributed resumes to smiling personnel officers manning booths labeled IBM, TRW, Rockwell, Advanced Technology Systems and Planning Research Corporation.   This sort of fair is becoming a regular occurence in the Washington suburbs, particularly on the Virginia side of the Potomac, as dozens of high-tech companies, some of them newly located near the nation's capital, vie for skilled electronics workers in a city whose work force has been dominated by Government employees, lobbyists and consultants.   ''It's as if you were being auctioned off like so much meat,'' said R. Hawkins Dale, a recent Harvard graduate who has trained himself in ''C'' language, the hottest of the computer languages, and is planning to transfer to Washington from Charlottesville, Va. ''They were actually making money offers, and asking when you could start,'' he said.

headline: Change Set At National Distillers
abstract: The National Distillers and Chemical Corporation yesterday named John Hoyt Stookey, president, to succeed Drummond C. Bell as chairman and chief executive when Mr. Bell retires in April.   Mr. Bell will continue as a director and will become chairman of the board's executive committee.

headline: German Study Of 'Star Wars'
abstract: A delegation of West German Government officials, business executives and scientists began a 10-day study of the American space weapons market today with briefings at the Pentagon.      The group, led by Horst   Teltschik, an adviser to Chancellor Helmut Kohl on foreign and security issues, is expected to seek a framework for joining the Reagan Administration's proposed Strategic Defense Initiative, dubbed the ''Star Wars'' effort, to build a shield against missiles.

headline: Solvency Test For Lloyd's
abstract: A record number of ''names'' - the wealthy individuals who underwrite Lloyd's of London - have failed a solvency test, the insurance market said today. Lloyd's chief executive, Ian Hay Davison, said that 517 ''names'' had not shown ready realizable assets of $134,000.

headline: Pact Reported For Iran Plant
abstract: Technipetrol of Italy and Kinetics Technology International, a Dutch company, have jointly contracted to build part of a new petrochemical plant in central Iran, industry sources said today.   The sources said the contract is worth some $20 million for engineering, service, supplies and furnaces for an ethylene plant in the complex.

headline: Blast at Arms Depot Kills 9 Near Havana
abstract: Nine workers died today in an explosion, apparently caused by a fire, at an arms storage installation about 15 miles outside Havana, civil defense officials said.

headline: Sperry Computer
abstract: The Sperry Corporation has introduced a personal computer that is compatible with the International Business Machines Corporation's PC-AT computer. Sperry said its computer works 45 percent faster than the top I.B.M. Personal Computer and includes twice the expandable memory capacity and double the mass storage capacity. Sperry said its machine, the PC/IT, priced at $4,340, also supports three times as many users.

headline: TOURISTS ARE ENCOURAGED NOT TO CANCEL TRIPS
abstract: A Mexican official said in New York yesterday that, despite cancellations by tourists in the aftermath of the earthquakes in Mexico, he would still encourage those concerned for their relatives and friends to travel there and ''find out for themselves.''   ''They can fly, take trains or use the highways to get to Mexico,'' said Antonio Enriquez Savignac, Mexico's Secretary of Tourism. ''Travel through the country is unrestricted.''

headline: Advertising;   Generic Drugs and Agencies
abstract: NOW we have all heard about the plight faced by the makers of highly profitable prescription drugs as their patents run out and the makers of generic brands prepare to leap in and challenge their lock on the market.   But what about their advertising agencies?   After all, if sales go down, ad budgets go down and agency income goes down.   The answer yesterday at William Douglas McAdams Inc., a leading health-care advertising specialist, came from William M. Wolf, an executive vice president, who said, ''Agencies will have to come up with strategies to delay the incursion of generics.''

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: SATURDAY, AUGUST 31, 1985        The Economy    Leading economic indicators rose four-tenths of 1 percent in July, the Commerce Department said. Analysts said the latest data, including a substantial downward revision in the increase previously estimated for June, suggest continued listless economic growth over the next several months. [Page 1.]    The nation's trade deficit in July narrowed by 22 percent from June, to $10.5 billion. A drop in imports of oil and cars accounted for the change. Economists are unsure if the tide has turned. [33.]

headline: Dow Falls 6.50 in a Broad Decline
abstract: Snags in the Federal budget reduction talks and concern over poor corporate earnings trimmed stock prices on Wall Street yesterday, but some companies with overseas operations rallied on the recent weakness of the dollar.   As has happened several times in the last few months, concern over profits at the International Business Machines Corporation infected the entire technology group and created a drag on the market as a whole.   I.B.M., one of 30 components of the Dow Jones industrial average, fell 2 3/8, to 121 1/8, on a volume of nearly 1.2 million shares, the third heaviest of the session on the New York Stock Exchange.   The Dow fell 6.50 points, to 1,321.91, its second consecutive drop and fourth loss in the last five sessions.

headline: SOUTH AFRICA BANS MASS FUNERALS FOR THE VICTIMS OF BLACK UNREST
abstract: The South African authorities, invoking 11-day-old emergency powers, announced sweeping restrictions today on funerals for victims of civil unrest in black townships.   The funerals represent one of the few lawful forms of assembly for the black majority in South Africa, and the restrictions were interpreted by the Government's critics as a hazardous stifling of political expression.   In the tradition that has arisen in South Africa in recent months, funerals have become an opportunity for mass rallies addressed by a multitude of speakers and attended by thousands of black activists carrying anti-apartheid banners and chanting the songs and slogans of dissent. The funerals have been preceded by mass gatherings in open-air sports stadiums. #500 Killed Since September Such funerals are frequent. More than 500 people have been killed in township violence since September.

headline: MOVIE ADS
abstract: To the Editor:   ''Now Playing on the Big Screen'' (Sept. 1) quotes Bruce R. Watson, Kodak's marketing communications director, as saying his company ''found little adverse reaction'' to commercials in movie theaters.   Prices at some Broadway houses have risen to $6.

headline: U.S. AND 4 ALLIES PLAN MOVE TO CUT VALUE OF DOLLAR
abstract: Finding the high value of the dollar unwarranted, the top economic officials of the United States and four other major industrial countries said yesterday that they were prepared to work in concert to drive the dollar down.   The countries - Britain, West Germany, France and Japan, along with the United States - did not say specifically that they would sell their treasuries' vast holdings of dollars to try to force the decline and thus make other currencies rise. But the threat to do so was clear if the marketplace does not.   The commitments the countries made yesterday could be of some economic and political significance. Not once since 1973, when the world's currencies were left to ''float'' in the foreign-exchange markets to seek their own value, have countries contracted to try to alter their currencies' values.

headline: $85 Million Issue Set By California
abstract: An $85 million issue of California general obligation bonds was offered yesterday through underwriters led by Chase Manhattan Bank with yields ranging from 4.75 percent for bonds due in 1986 to 6.50 percent in 1990, 7.70 percent in 1995, 8.50 percent in 2002 and 8.70 percent in 2005.   The bonds are rated Aa by Moody's and AA+ by S.&P.

headline: PERSONAL SPENDING SOARS 1.2%
abstract: Americans went on a buying spree in August, increasing their personal spending by the largest amount since April. But they financed the purchases by pushing their savings level to a record low, the Government reported today.   The Commerce Department said personal consumption spending soared 1.2 percent last month as Americans rushed to take advantage of cut-rate financing incentives being offered by auto makers before the start of the new model year.   The August spending gain was three times the July advance of four-tenths of 1 percent and was the biggest increase since a 1.3 percent rise in April.

headline: HOSTAGES' NEWS CONFERENCE IN SYRIA: 'THEY'VE ALL KEPT VERY COOL HEADS'
abstract: Following is a transcript of the news conference held yesterday in Damascus, Syria, by the former American hostages, as recorded by The Associated Press:   ALLYN B. CONWELL: We haven't really had the opportunity to discuss what was going to be said, but without any doubt at all in my mind we can say we're most happy to be in Damascus with you people.   We do indeed wish to take this opportunity to thank President Assad and all of the people of Syria in the part they played in gaining our freedom. We are sure, without their assistance, without their help, without their concern over our welfare, we would undoubtedly still be in Beirut with an uncertain future. So for them I give a hand.   We're well aware that the negotiations involved in securing our freedom were indeed one of a very complex nature involving many, many people. We certainly wish to have the opportunity to thank all of these people because we do have a heartfelt sense of gratitude that we wish to convey to them. So, for anyone and everyone who has prayed for us, talked for us, waited for us, hoped for us, we thank you all from the bottom of our heart. That's to you we applaud.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: Debt Issues    * Banque Nationale de Paris is issuing, under its own lead management, 75 million European Currency Units of 8 7/8 percent, 10-year Eurobonds at a price of 100.    * Dillard Investment Co. has filed for a shelf offering of $100 million of debt securities through underwriters that may include Goldman, Sachs & Co.

headline: Advertising;   Generating Publicity For Fight
abstract: ''NOBODY here is sophisticated in the advertising business.   We've got no huge advertising budget,'' said Bob Arum, Harvard law graduate turned fight promoter and now president of Top Rank.   His comments came toward the end of an interview during which he proved pretty sophisticated about advertising and extremely sophisticated about public relations.   What he is interested in promoting at the moment is the Marvelous Marvin Hagler-John (The Beast) Mugabi middleweight boxing contest, a multimillion-dollar entertainment, which will harvest most of its bucks from about 400 closed-circuit television outlets.

headline: TIKHONOV RETIRES AS SOVIET PREMIER
abstract: Prime Minister Nikolai A. Tikhonov, at 80 the oldest member of the Soviet leadership, retired today and was replaced by Nikolai I. Ryzhkov, one of the new younger generation of Soviet leaders.   The official announcement said Mr. Tikhonov had asked to be relieved of his duties because his health had ''considerably deteriorated.'' His attendance had been reported at only one official function since early July, and there were unconfirmed reports that he had become partly paralyzed.   Mr. Tikhonov's replacement by Mr. Ryzhkov, who turns 56 on Saturday, had been widely anticipated here, although the timing came as something of a surprise to diplomats. Most had not expected the shift before the next session of the Supreme Soviet, the nominal Parliament, at the earliest.

headline: Stocks Fall Again; Dow Declines 7.05
abstract: Wall Street stock prices fell moderately yesterday, with the market battered for the third consecutive day by a wave of technical selling related to index options contracts. The closely watched Dow Jones industrial index slipped to its lowest level in almost three months.   The big sellers yesterday, according to traders, were Salomon Brothers and Goldman, Sachs & Company, and Kidder, Peabody & Company was also said to be unloading equities.   The result was a 7.05-point drop in the Dow, to 1,312.39. It was the lowest close in the index of 30 blue-chip stocks since it finished at 1,299.73 on June 20.

headline: Treasury Rates Off Slightly
abstract: Interest rates declined modestly yesterday for short- and long-term Treasury securities, as demand for government debt was increased by reports that the Farm Credit System is seeking Federal Government assistance.   The reports were carried in a front-page article in The Wall Street Journal.   By late in the day, rates on Treasury bills were lower by about seven-hundredths of a percentage point, with the six-month issue bid at 7.21 percent, down from 7.30 percent at Tuesday's auction but up from the low of about 7.13 percent set early in the day. The preference for Treasury debt was also evident in the note and bond market, where prices rose as much as 3/8 point, and the 10 5/8 percent bonds due in 2015 were offered at 102 3/32, up 3/8 point, to yield 10.40 percent.

headline: THE DISHEARTENING HOUSING SLOWDOWN
abstract: To understand why economists are becoming more pessimistic about the economy, it helps to know that Charles H. Sanford is giving out free curtains.   Mr. Sanford builds homes around the country, but recently some have not been selling well. So he decided Friday to lower home prices in a development in north Dallas by about $2,000 and to throw in free curtains with each purchase.   The Dallas market may be worse than most, largely because of the Texas oil business slowdown, but Mr. Sanford is not alone. Almost everywhere across the country, builders are finding that new homes are not selling well, so they are slowing construction of both houses and apartments. The housing market is stagnant, and a boom that seemed to be materializing early this year as mortgage rates dropped has dissipated.

headline: The U.N. Today; Aug. 9, 1985
abstract: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Decolonization Committee - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.   Preparatory Committee for the International Conference on the Relationship Between Disarmament and Development - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.   Special Committee Against Apartheid - International Day of Solidarity With the Struggle of Women in South Africa and Namibia - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

headline: INVESTING;  CHASING OPTION AND DIVIDEND INCOME
abstract: THE use of stock options - once exclusively considered ''racy'' speculative investments -to hedge portfolios and increase total return is now accepted Wall Street practice. But Edward A. Greene, the founder of E. G. Capital Management Inc., is one investment manager who has turned such option strategies into a veritable science.  The 38-year-old Mr. Greene is not alone in his high-tech approach - the big wire houses have option departments that specialize in esoteric plays similar to his - but his firm has attracted the attention of some large American and foreign investors, thanks mainly to the 20 percent returns his portfolios produced in 1983 and 1984. He warns clients not to expect returns of more than 14 to 16 percent on an annual basis. This year, in a generally bullish market, his accounts are lagging behind the indexes and are up 11 percent. Indeed, in surging markets, strategies such as Mr. Greene's will almost always underperform market indexes.  His two-year-old Stamford, Conn.-based firm manages about $100 million of client funds. One of his most successful strategies involves the sale of options against high-dividend stocks.

headline: Georgia Power's Preferred Stock
abstract: The Georgia Power Company is offering 2 million shares of $25 adjustable-rate preferred stock with an initial dividend yield of 9.53 percent through underwriters led by Morgan Stanley & Company.   The dividend on the perpetual stock will be adjusted quarterly at 1.25 percentage points below the higher of the bond equivalent yield of 90-day Treasury bills, 10-year Treasury notes or 20-year Treasury bonds. The dividend yield on the preferred stock is subject to a maximum of 12 3/4 percent and a minimum of 6 1/4 percent.

headline: I.B.M. AND N.Y.U. JOIN TO PRODUCE COMPUTER
abstract: The International Business Machines Corporation said yesterday that it had begun work with New York University on a new experimental supercomputer to try to resolve the debate in the data-processing community over whether several processors inside a computer are better than one.   I.B.M. said that over the next two years its Thomas J. Watson Research Center in Yorktown Heights, N.Y., would work with N.Y.U. to produce a computer containing 512 processors that could achieve high speeds in such applications as computer-aided design, artificial intelligence and reading images off a printed page. The machine will be called the Research Parallel Processor, or RP3. Until now, most computers had worked with only one processor.

headline: TRAPPED 4 DAYS IN MOUND OF RUBBLE,A DAZED MEDICAL STUDENT IS RESCUED
abstract: Last Saturday night, three days after the earthquake struck, someone heard a muffled cry in the mound of rubble that had been the Juarez Hospital.   A French disaster team started probing the wreckage and 35 hours later, in the chill moments before dawn this morning, they dragged a dazed medical student to safety through a serpentine tunnel that was caving in as they made their way out.   As some members of the team had tunnelled toward the medical student, others, working with specially trained dogs and electronic sensors, rescued a 27-year-old resident physician and a female patient, whose legs had to be amputated in order to free her from the wreckage.   The rescue of the medical sudent, Juan Jose Hernandez Cruz, who had been trapped standing up in an air pocket beneath tons of broken concrete and twisted iron rods, was one of the most dramatic in the earthquake disaster that has killed and maimed thousands and left the city dotted with destroyed buildings. #600 Buried in Hospital Wreckage It probably was also among the last as hope faded quickly for any more survivors, even as foreign rescue teams and equipment continued to arrive. One hospital administrator estimated this morning that perhaps as many as 600 people were still buried in the hospital wreckage and presumed dead.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: * Albany Savings Bank has elected Herbert G. Chorbajian president, chief operating officer and a trustee.    * Associated Dry Goods Corp., which operates department and apparel stores, has appointed John A. Toler president and chief executive officer of its Robinson's of Florida division, based in St. Petersburg.

headline: BRAZILIANS TAKE 'LAND REFORM' AS FIGHTING WORDS
abstract: A jeep pulled up outside the local landowners' society and a stout figure climbed out, shifting the two pistols in his belt.   ''Who's ever heard of a peaceful land reform?'' he said in a tone not open to argument. ''If the politicians stick to this mad idea, a lot of blood is going to flow.''   Inside the colonial building, in this city on Brazil's north coast, men who run cattle ranches and rice and soybean farms nervously cast around for information, solidarity, fuel for their rage. In lowered voices, some talked of a war in the making, of people arming themselves.

headline: New Shekel Approved
abstract: The Israeli Government voted today to introduce a new shekel worth 1,000 times more than the present currency, which has been legal tender for the past five years. The long-expected revision followed the erosion of the currency from 6 shekels per dollar when the shekel replaced the Israeli pound in 1980, to 1,487.40 per dollar today.

headline: RISE IN AFRICA DEBT WORRYING BANKS
abstract: Sub-Saharan African countries, faced with mounting foreign debts and rapidly rising debt service, are finding it increasingly difficult to repay their loans, raising concerns within the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund as well as among commercial bankers.   According to I.M.F. estimates, by the end of last year total debt to foreign creditors owed by all African countries, excluding Libya and South Africa, was $104.3 billion. Some private economists, however, place the debt of the sub-Saharan African countries alone at between $130 billion and $135 billion, a figure these economists say is more realistic than the I.M.F. numbers.   The sub-Saharan region comprises all African nations except Algeria, Egypt, Libya, Morocco and Tunisia. In addition, South Africa is not treated as part of Africa in economic discussions.

headline: Shearson Lehman Unit Adds ACLI
abstract: Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc. said its London-based affiliate, Shearson Lehman Brothers Ltd., has acquired ACLI Metals Ltd., an indirect subsidiary of Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Inc. Shearson Lehman said ACLI was sold at book value, but would not disclose the actual amount.

headline: JET'S 'BLACK BOX' IS RAISED FROM THE SEA
abstract: The voice recorder from the Air-India jumbo jet lost off the Irish coast last month with 329 people aboard was brought to the surface today, raising hopes that the mystery of the crash could be solved.   The unit, one of two so-called black boxes, was recovered by a robot submarine from a depth of 6,700 feet.   The device should contain recordings of the final 30 minutes of conversation in the cockpit of the doomed Boeing 747, along with public-address announcements and perhaps ambient sounds such as a whoosh of decompression. A whoosh would indicate that there had been an explosion aboard the Boeing 747, which was en route from Canada to India, via London's Heathrow Airport.

headline: Scovill Offering Debt Securities
abstract: Scovill Inc., a diversified manufacturer of housing and industrial products, is offering $200 million of debt securities in a two-part financing through Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. as sole underwriter.   A $125 million issue of 14 1/2 percent senior notes due 1995 and a $75 million issue of 16 percent subordinated debentures due 1999 are both offered at a price of par. Both issues carry speculative grade ratings of B-2 by Moody's and CCC by S.&P.   Proceeds from the sale will be used in part to repay $135.9 million borrowed from the company's parent, First City Industries, and for working capital.

headline: Money Fund Assets Off
abstract: Assets of the nation's money market mutual funds declined $516.0 million, to $208 billion, for the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday.

headline: Reorganization Plan by Lionel
abstract: The Lionel Corporation said yesterday that the United States Bankruptcy Court for the Southern District of New York had approved a new reorganization plan.

headline: Ford Spending
abstract: The Ford Motor Company expects its worldwide capital spending will exceed $3.5 billion in 1985, the company's chairman, Donald E. Petersen, said today. He told a University of Michigan seminar that much of the money will go for upgrading the company's manufacturing technology as well as for new products. Last year, Ford's capital spending was $3.52 billion, compared with $2.33 billion in 1983.

headline: HUSSEIN, AT U.N., URGES TALKS ON MIDEAST BY SUPERPOWERS
abstract: King Hussein of Jordan said today that any consultation on the Middle East between the United States and the Soviet Union was ''both necessary and positive.''   The King, addressing the General Assembly, reiterated that he was ready to negotiate with Israel under the auspices of an international conference sponsored by the United Nations Secretary General.   Today's speech indicated that the King had not changed his position on the need for an international conference on the Middle East, an approach that has been rejected by the Reagan Administration as too time-consuming and as allowing the Russians into the peace process. This weekend the King is to travel to Washington where he will meet with President Reagan on Monday and with Congressional leaders on Tuesday.

headline: Coldwell Banker Head Announces Retirement
abstract: Sears, Roebuck & Company said yesterday that C. Wesley Poulson would retire as chairman and chief executive of its Coldwell Banker Real Estate Group at the end of the month.   Sears said a replacement for Mr. Poulson, who is 55, would be named at a later date. He has held his current positions since January 1982, following Sears's purchase of Coldwell Banker, one of the nation's leading real estate brokerage companies.

headline: Real Estate;  The Office Growth in Great Neck
abstract: WHEN Paul P. Schmergel asked New York City banks in 1962 for financing to put up a small office building on Northern Boulevard in Great Neck, L.I., he was turned away. The banks told him the suburban community just over the city line from Queens was not ready for office development.  Mr. Schmergel, a 76-year-old Hungarian immigrant who came to New York in 1939 as part of the contingent working at his nation's World's Fair exhibit, went ahead with his plans anyway. He arranged financing through a local bank and constructed a 15,000-square-foot building at 417 Northern Boulevard.

headline: Banks to Combine
abstract: The Bank of Virginia Company said that it would acquire the Union Trust Bancorp of Baltimore in a transaction valued at $302.4 million. If completed, the combination would be the first between a Virginia and a Maryland bank since regional interstate banking laws took effect in both states on July 1. Bank of Virginia will exchange 4.1 of its common shares for each of Union Trust's 2.5 million shares outstanding.

headline: Advertising;   Old Song Is Revived For Toyota
abstract: GEORGE E. BORST, the corporate marketing manager of Toyota Motor Sales, U.S.A., considers the six-year-old ''Oh! What a feeling'' campaign warm and humorous - and a nice way to keep his company's name in front of consumers when it is already selling all the vehicles it can import.   However, there are great changes in the wind in the auto industry and, given the opportunity, as he was yesterday at his agency, Dancer Fitzgerald Sample, he can list all of them. What they add up to is a more competitive environment and, for Toyota, a more aggressive advertising message.

headline: Laker Agrees To Settlement
abstract: Sir Freddie Laker, who pioneered discount trans-Atlantic flights, today abandoned his battle to prove that the world's airlines plotted to bankrupt him and accepted a settlement he earlier called ''pitifully inadequate.''   The deal, ending a legal battle that lasted three years, was announced by British Airways and confirmed by Sir Freddie, who said he was very pleased with the agreement.

headline: PATENTS;  Impurities Removed From Interferon Items
abstract: Genentech Inc. of San Francisco, a leading biotechnology company, received a patent this week on the removal of impurities from human leukocyte interferon preparations.

headline: Consumer Prices Rose 0.2% in July
abstract: Consumer prices rose a moderate two-tenths of 1 percent in July for the third consecutive month, the Government said today. The increase means the Consumer Price Index has risen at an annual rate of just 3.5 percent for the first seven months of 1985, compared with 4 percent for all of 1984, the Labor Department said.   Shelter costs, which include renter and homeowner expenses, accounted for nearly three-fourths of the increase in July. Food costs edged up slightly - largely because of higher fresh vegetable prices - while prices for gasoline, clothes and household furnishings were down.

headline: Accounts
abstract: Floral Glass and Mirror Inc., Hauppauge, L.I., to Mad. Ave. East of Melville, L.I.    * Primetime Entertainment Inc., a television production and syndication company, to CCI Communications.

headline: Two-Way Trading Seen
abstract: The Securities and Exchange Commission is expected to approve a pilot program Thursday to create a two-way link between the American Stock Exchange and the Toronto Stock Exchange.

headline: ONE REBEL GROUP IN PERU ANNOUNCES A TRUCE
abstract: Members of the Tupac Amaru Revolutionary Movement, took over six radio stations here tonight and announced a truce.   Tupac Amaru, one of three leftist rebel groups in this troubled South American nation, said it was halting its attacks to give the newly elected president, Alan Garcia, an opportunity to run the Government for the benefit of the poor.

headline: Sukemasa Irie Is Dead at 80; Hirohito's Grand Chamberlain
abstract: Emperor Hirohito's closest aide, Grand Chamberlain Sukemasa Irie, died of a heart attack at a Tokyo hospital today, two days before his retirement, the Imperial Household Agency reported. He was 80 years old.

headline: 3 Companies Approved As Intelsat Competitors
abstract: The Federal Communications Commission today authorized three American companies to offer limited competition to Intelsat, the nonprofit group of 109 countries that operates the only worldwide satellite communications system.   The three are International Satellite Inc., the PanAmerican Satellite Corporation and RCA American Communications Inc.   It could be three years, however, before any of the companies has a system in the air and operating, commission officials said, although one of the three predicted a launching by next summer. Still, today's decision effectively ends American recognition of Intelsat's 20-year monopoly over international satellite communications.

headline: Advertising;   Thoughts From a Reasearcher
abstract: ALTHOUGH only a teen-ager when he left his native Hungary, George S. Fabian already had a burning desire to know what makes some products successful and what makes consumers tick.   That, of course, is called marketing research. But, Mr. Fabian said, there was no such phrase in Hungarian, a handicap he easily overcame.   He was only 17 years old then. Now he's 55 and has worked in every facet of the business. So it is with some authority that he says, ''Risk reduction, that's the name of the game.''

headline: ESTIMATES REDUCED ON 2D-HALF GROWTH
abstract: After saying for months that the nation's economy would rebound vigorously in the second half of 1985, many business economists now are downgrading their estimates of that rebound, or pushing it further back.   Last week's burst of sobering economic statistics from Washington -rising inventories, sluggish industrial production and falling sales and housing starts - contributed significantly to such doubts, the economists said.   ''We're all rethinking our positions,'' said Michael W. Keran, chief economist at the Prudential Insurance Company of America. ''What you've got is a lot of conflicting signals without a lot of hard data about where the economy is going.''

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: Aetna Life and Casualty Co., Hartford, was selected to hedge about $1.2 billion of Caterpillar Tractor Co.'s pension plan assets using stock index and bond index futures.    * Allied Products Corp., Chicago, said it had tentatively agreed to acquire the assets of two corporations, Xonics Photochemical Inc. and Cooper Manufacturing Corp., for a total of about $14.7 million.

headline: GLOBAL MARINE DEBT REVAMPING
abstract: Global Marine Inc., which is in default under the terms of its loan agreements and publicly traded debentures, said it was critical that an agreement on a debt restructuring with its secured lenders be reached within the next two weeks. The company said discussions on a restructuring were continuing, but ''several important issues remain to be resolved.''

headline: TUTU'S SON ARRESTED IN SOWETO COURT
abstract: The son of Bishop Desmond M. Tutu, winner of the 1984 Nobel Peace Prize, was detained today under this nation's sweeping emergency powers after he purportedly made insulting remarks to authorities.   Trevor Tutu, 29 years old, was arrested at a magistrate court in Soweto during legal proceedings involving scores of schoolchildren who were rounded up by security forces in the sprawling black township last week for boycotting classes.   He was reportedly taken to Diepkloof Prison in the township. Bishop Tutu, the Anglican leader, who helped mediate the release from detention of about 800 Soweto schoolchildren last Friday, said this evening that he was ''proud of'' his son and that his detention would help underscore the near-absolute powers of the police.

headline: MEXICO SEEN OUT OF COMPLIANCE WITH I.M.F. PLAN
abstract: Mexico has fallen out of compliance with an austerity program established by the International Monetary Fund, probably costing it more than $900 million in I.M.F. assistance and substantially complicating its relations with creditor banks around the world, financial sources said last night.   The fall from compliance - coupled with the economic demands of reconstruction after yesterday's earthquake - is a major blow to Mexico's efforts to emerge from the burden of its $96 billion foreign debt. If these difficulties discourage foreign banks from making new loans to Mexico, putting the country in a severe cash squeeze, then the Government might demand easier terms of repayment to the banks or even curtail payments.   The dual blows of the probable loss of I.M.F. money and the earthquake come at a difficult time for Mexico, as falling world oil prices have cut sharply into its export earnings. Mexican officials, including President Miguel de la Madrid, already had taken a tougher line on the debt issue in recent weeks in public speeches, asserting that new ways would have to be found to address the third world's debt problems.

headline: I.C.C. to Consider Streamlining
abstract: The beleaguered Interstate Commerce Commission will meet Wednesday to consider yet another plan for streamlining its operations in the face of continued Congressional criticism.   Several divisions are to be consolidated and about 100 jobs eliminated under the tentative plan revealed last month.

headline: Dow Jumps 10.08 as Volume Surges
abstract: Pushing further into record territory, the stock market yesterday registered its second consecutive big gain as investors cheered the Federal Reserve's decision to raise its targets for money supply growth.   The Fed's action, announced after the market closed on Tuesday, allayed fears that recent increases in the money supply might cause a tightening of credit conditions.   With institutions scrambling to participate, volume soared yesterday to 159.9 million shares, the fourth-busiest session of 1985 and the heaviest since 170 million shares traded on Jan. 30.   Scoring a double-digit gain for the second consecutive day, the Dow Jones industrial average jumped 10.08 points, to 1,357.97. The index of 30 high-capitalization stocks had gained 12.43 points on Tuesday.

headline: REAGAN ASSAILS CUOMO'S OBJECTIONS TO TAX PLAN
abstract: President Reagan today assailed Governor Cuomo's criticism of the Administration's tax-overhaul proposals as ''balderdash'' and said they would save New York State taxpayers $588 million a year.   Pressing his efforts for the Administration's tax-revision plan - which would reduce tax rates significantly and abolish many existing tax deductions and credits - Mr. Reagan told a crowd of mostly retired and elderly Floridians that the present system is full of loopholes, swollen with ''useless tax dodges'' and ''too complicated and utterly unfair.''   Mr. Reagan's speech today was part of his continuing campaign, marked by a trip each week, to spark support for his tax revision efforts among workers, farmers, students, the elderly and others. Privately, White House aides are concerned about the prospects of enacting a tax bill this year, partly because public opinion for it has seemed marginal and partly because a Senate vote by Dec. 31 remains uncertain.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST: THURSDAY, AUGUST 1, 1985
abstract: The Economy    The index of leading indicators rose 1 percent in June, its strongest gain since January. The White House called this ''ringing economic news,'' but private analysts were more cautious, citing the index's up-and-down pattern of recent months. [Page D1.]  Orders for manufactured goods, buoyed by demand for military hardware, rose a healthy 1.9 percent in June, after climbing 2.1 percent in May. [D5.]  Prices that farmers get for raw products dropped 0.8 percent in July, for their fifth consecutive decline. [D5.]    Some budget progress was reported by Congressional leaders, but differences remain that could thwart a compromise. [A1.]

headline: HOW TAX PACKAGE MAY SHAPE UP
abstract: President Reagan's chief tax-policy advisers and the members of Congress most closely involved in writing tax legislation agree that the House of Representatives will quite likely pass legislation this fall embracing the main principles of the President's plan to redesign the Federal income tax system.   The measure, they are confident, would reduce tax rates for individuals and corporations, increase the personal exemption allowed taxpayers and their dependents, abolish many deductions and credits and, based on the best available estimates, raise neither more nor less revenue than the present tax law.   Beyond that, there is no consensus among the more than a dozen key players interviewed last week on what will happen. Some people think the particular elements of the House bill - the rate structure and the specific deductions to be retained and repealed, for example - will closely resemble the President's proposals. Others think the bill will be vastly different from what Mr. Reagan recommended.

headline: Auditor to Submit Papers on Hutton
abstract: Arthur Young & Company was instructed yesterday by E. F. Hutton & Company's law firm, Cahill Gordon & Reindel, to provide the Securities and Exchange Commission with most of its reports and work papers on Hutton's cash management system, which the commission is investigating.

headline: Dividend Meetings
abstract: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of July 1, 1985:

headline: Security Pacific Forms A Friendly Partnership
abstract: When the Security Pacific Corporation announced this week that it would make its first move into full-service interstate banking by buying the Arizona Bancwest Corporation for $480 million, the deal was not a quick association of two companies with little knowledge of one other.   Richard J. Flamson 3d, Security Pacific's chairman, and Don B. Tostenrud, his counterpart at Arizona Bancwest, go back a long way.   ''We have been well acquainted with their management for a number of years, and we believe that their style and our style are very much the same,'' Mr. Flamson, 56, said in a telephone interview.

headline: Peabody Holding
abstract: The Miami investor Victor Posner said he intends to increase his stake in the Peabody International Corporation from 34.3 percent to more than 50 percent of the company's shares outstanding.

headline: Craxi Backed on Lira
abstract: Prime Minister Bettino Craxi's Government won a confidence vote tonight, easing political tension caused when the Treasury Minister and central bank governor offered their resignations because of the recent collapse of the lira. Both men have now decided to stay in the Government.

headline: KOREAN FAMILIES VISIT AFTER BORDER IS OPENED
abstract: For the first time since the end of the Korean war 32 years ago, North and South Koreans met and embraced long-separated relatives living on the other side of the fortified Korean border.   Tearful reunions, at times intensely emotional, were held in a large hotel room in eastern Seoul as 15 North Koreans met brothers, sisters, cousins and uncles they had not seen for decades.   Several learned for the first time that their parents had died. Most of them, like a 51-year-old North Korean man named Lee Yun Koo, sobbed hard.

headline: FRANK B. WALKER
abstract: Frank B. Walker, former editor in chief of The Montreal Star, died of a heart attack Tuesday.

headline: AUG. 1-10 CAR SALES FELL 10.1%
abstract: New-car sales fell 10.1 percent in the August 1-10 period, the major American automobile manufacturers said here today. At the same time, light truck sales increased by 11.2 percent, compared with the same period in 1984.   Industry officials and Wall Street analysts said the results were distorted by the impact of a strike by car haulers, represented by the International Brotherhood of Teamsters. The walkout began July 26 and a tentative settlement was reached today, although the agreement has to be approved by the union's 21,000 members.

headline: U.S. Team Arrives in Soviet To Check on Tracking Dust
abstract: A team of United States experts arrived here today to inspect Americans' work areas, cars and homes for a chemical powder that the State Department says the Russians have been using to track the movements of Americans.   The team, which is to brief Americans here on Thursday, is headed by Dr. Ernest McConnell, acting director of the toxicology research testing program for the National Institute of Environmental Health Sciences, a branch of the National Institutes of Health.   The other members are Edwin Tinsworth, deputy director of the office of toxic substances in the Environmental Protection Agency; Karen Hammerstrom, an E.P.A. environmental protection specialist, and Jeff Lybarger of the Center for Disease Control.

headline: Wheat Sale Complaints
abstract: Australian wheat growers condemned the United States today for the subsidized sale of 500,000 tons of wheat to Egypt, Australia's main customer. The sale was ''economic lunacy,'' the chairman of the Australian Wheat Board, Sir Leslie Price, said in a statement. The deal, Washington's first under its export enhancement program, was $20 a metric ton below current commercial prices.

headline: INDEX OPTIONS
abstract: To the Editor:   I wish to set the record straight concerning our entry into the index option and futures markets (''Banks Betting on Indexes?'' Prospects, June 16). Chase Lincoln First Bank is the first bank in both New York State and, we believe, the country to receive permission to trade index options and futures in common trust funds.

headline: BBC IS CAUGHT UP IN NEW FUROR
abstract: For the second time in a month, the British Broadcasting Corporation has become ensnarled in a controversy that calls into question its cherished image of political independence.   On Sunday, The Observer, a leading weekly newspaper, charged that M.I.5, the British security service, ''secretly controls the hiring and firing'' of BBC staff members. It cited a number of instances in which the careers of journalists, directors and others had purportedly been blighted by blacklisting.

headline: ECONOMY CALLED KEY FOR DOLLAR
