abstract: After an unbroken two-month stretch of stability, the calm in the foreign-exchange market has been shaken, with the dollar's value declining sharply and the markets suddenly turning volatile over the past two weeks. The dollar is at its lowest level in about 10 months.   Economists and currency traders say the dollar's drop is the result of an erosion of a principal factor behind its rise to record highs earlier this year: confidence in the Reagan Administration and its handling of the American economy.   Undercutting the dollar are the increasing number of signs showing economic weakness and concern that the Government may not have ready solutions for the economy's problems, the analysts said. They added that these factors could provide the combination needed to sustain a decline in the dollar, finally breaking a five-year run.

headline: BEAR, STEARNS SECRETS ARE OUT
abstract: Among Wall Street's privately owned brokerage partnerships, profitability has always been a jealously guarded secret. But Bear, Stearns & Company disclosed all yesterday in announcing the terms of its plans for an initial public offering of stock - and at the same time confirmed its reputation as a savvy trader able to reap profits even in bad times.   In recent years, when heated competition and volatile markets depressed the results of many publicly owned firms, Bear, Stearns produced returns of better than 50 percent on its partners' capital. It had net income before taxes of $163.8 million on revenue of $1.3 billion in the fiscal year that ended April 30, 1984, and net income of $168.7 million on revenue of $1.8 billion in the most recent year. For its most recent quarter, ended in July, Bear, Stearns earned $69 million on revenues of $565 million.

headline: SHARP FALL SHOWN BY CARBIE STOCK
abstract: News of Sunday's accident at the Union Carbide Corporation's Institute, W.Va., pesticide plant sent the company's stock down sharply today.   Analysts were also quick to react, saying that the accident, coming nine months after the devastating gas leak at Bhopal, India, could not have occurred at a worse time for the company.   ''People were beginning to give Carbide the benefit of the doubt,'' said Anantha Raman, a chemical industry analyst and president of Anantha Raman & Company. ''Of course, that has changed.''

headline: United Energy's Stock Up Sharply
abstract: The price of United Energy Resources Inc.'s stock rose sharply yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange as speculation continued that the company would soon disclose a takeover bid from the Midcon Corporation.

headline: RIVALS PURSUE IMPEACHMENT
abstract: President Ferdinand E. Marcos, saying that the Philippines was at a crucial turning point, appealed today to his countrymen to support the Government's efforts to achieve an economic recovery and to quell the Communist insurgency.   Mr. Marcos spoke to the National Assembly on the eve of a scheduled presentation there of a resolution calling for his impeachment. The resolution, signed by 35 of the 59 opposition members of the 180-seat Assembly, will be the first impeachment effort against him since he won the presidency in 1965.

headline: STEPSON OF SAKHAROV BEGINS A HUNGER STRIKE
abstract: The stepson of Andrei D. Sakharov, the Soviet physicist and human rights advocate, has begun a hunger strike to protest what he says has been Reagan Administration inaction in winning freedom for his father.   Alexsey Semyonov, the son from a previous marriage of Yelena G. Bonner, Dr. Sakharov's wife, began the hunger strike on Friday near the Soviet Embassy here.   He asserted today that the ''Reagan Administration is only paying lip service to human rights abuses in the Soviet Union'' and that it had not tried hard enough to win Dr. Sakharov's release.

headline: Digital to Set Up Plant in Scotland
abstract: The Digital Equipment Corporation, the world's second-largest computer maker, said today that it would invest $116 million to set up a semiconductor plant in Scotland.

headline: PARTI QUEBECOIS ELECTS A MODERATE TO SUCCEED LEVESQUE AS PREMIER
abstract: Pierre Marc Johnson, a political moderate who favors independence for Quebec only as a last resort, was elected today as the leader of the Parti Quebecois. He succeeded Premier Rene Levesque, who has stepped down.   Under Canada's parliamentary system, Mr. Johnson, as leader of the majority party, will also succeed Mr. Levesque as the Premier of Quebec. He will be sworn in later this week.

headline: McDonnell Order
abstract: The McDonnell Douglas Corporation is being awarded four Navy contracts totaling $498.3 million, the Defense Department said.

headline: SOUTH AFRICA'S NEW FEAR
abstract: Helen Suzman, a longtime campaigner against apartheid, was musing the other day on the call by some in the United States for disinvestment in South Africa - a course of action she opposes.   Soon, she said, there would be no need to make such calls because foreign confidence in this nation would ebb so far that investors would not want to touch South Africa anyhow.   By a coincidence a few days later that seemed to prove her point, South Africa's currency nosedived, the authorities suspended foreign exchange and stock market dealings and the unthinkable had happened: South Africa, long able to boast a high credit rating in a continent plagued by economic disaster, had been disowned by some of those same outsiders who had helped, with investment and economic faith, to build the reputation of economic robustness.      Gas Bombs and Nervous Bankers    It was as if the nation's township violence, flaring and sputtering now for a year and with no end in sight, had come home to haunt a white elite long sheltered from it by geographic separation and personal inclination. That white elite was now confronted with the impact of the turbulence, expressed not by rocks and gasoline bombs but by nervous foreign bankers who were seemingly more worried from afar about township violence than were the whites of South Africa themselves.

headline: Consumer Debt Rises
abstract: Americans took on $9 billion more in installment debt than they paid off in May, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.         The May increase followed an $8.3 billion rise in April.

headline: Rescuers Search for Missing After Japan Landslide Kills 5
abstract: Rescue workers searched through tons of earth and rubble today for 21 people from a home for the aged who were believed buried by a landslide in which at least five other people died in a town north of Tokyo, the police said.   The landslide, which occurred Friday, sent mud and rubble thundering through the city of Nagano, about 135 miles north of the capital. The police said 21 people were injured.

headline: PANTRY PRIDE RAISES REVLON BID TO $50
abstract: Pantry Pride Inc. raised its acquisition offer for Revlon Inc. by $8 a share yesterday, to $50, and repeated that it was interested in negotiating a friendly merger.   The higher bid comes after months of sparring between Pantry Pride, a Florida-based investment and retail company that is controlled by MacAndrews & Forbes, and Revlon, a New York cosmetics concern. Revlon is fighting its second unwanted takeover bid in two years.   The $50 offer is apparently intended to breathe new life into Pantry Pride's acquisition hopes as well as to force Revlon to the bargaining table, something that Revlon's president, Michel C. Bergerac, has flatly refused to do.

headline: FINAL HOUSE TAX ACTION BY OCT. 31 A POSSIBILITY
abstract: The House Ways and Means Committee today announced a legislative schedule that could lead to House passage of a tax bill by the end of October.   Senate Republican leaders said that probably would not leave enough time for the Senate to complete action on the measure before next year.   The House tax-writing committee plans to hold a brief meeting next Wednesday and begin intensive sessions to draft legislation Sept. 26, a committee spokesman said.

headline: PROPOSED: TAX STAND-STILL ACT OF 1985
abstract: ADVOCATES of tax reform use a simple but beguiling logic: We have a lousy tax system; let's fix it. I am now convinced that we should follow a less obvious logic: We have a lousy tax system; let's leave it alone or it will get worse.   Tax reform is a political impossibility in our country. The choice of words is important. Reform is an impossibility, not just a formidable task. That's why I am proposing the Tax Stand-Still Act of 1985 and Beyond, which would assure that no new provisions or language would be added to the Tax Code - ever.

headline: Lebanese Militias Duel In Beirut and Mountains
abstract: Christian, Moslem and Druse militias fought machine-gun and artillery battles until early today in Beirut's center and in the nearby Shuf Mountains.   Mortar and rocket explosions and the sound of automatic weapons fire echoed through the city.

headline: MAINTENANCE REVIEWED AT AMERICAN AIRLINES
abstract: The Federal Aviation Administration is in the final stages of a special investigation into maintenance practices at American Airlines, the nation's second largest passenger carrier, an F.A.A. offical said today.   The official, Roger G. Knight, manager of the agency's flight standards division at the regional office in Fort Worth, said the surveillance began in June and should be completed in about a month.

headline: DOLLAR PACT HELPS DOW SOAR 18.37
abstract: Stock prices surged yesterday in response to the weekend agreement by the United States and four other industrial nations to try to lower the value of the dollar.   The Dow Jones industrial average of 30 blue-chip stocks soared 18.37 points, to close at 1,316.31.   The reaction to Sunday's accord was sharp, broad and immediate. The closely watched Dow average was up 18 points in the first 20 minutes of trading. The market gave up a small part of the gain at midday, when the Dow was up 14 points, and then started higher again. By day's end, the Dow average had registered its best gain since it climbed 24.75 points on June 21.

headline: DOVES AND GORBACHEV OPEN SOVIET FESTIVAL
abstract: As children sang, crowds chanted political slogans and hundreds of doves swirled through the Lenin Stadium, Mikhail S. Gorbachev opened the 12th international festival of youth and students.   Mr. Gorbachev and 10 other members of the ruling Politburo remained in their seats for the entire four-hour ceremony, which began an eight-day festival at which 30,000 or more delegates and guests were to attend concerts and political lectures.   Groups from what organizers say were more than 100 nations paraded into the stadium, many of them in national costumes and many performing regional dances as they went.   The Cubans, hosts of the last of the festivals, which gather young people from Soviet allies and mostly left-leaning groups, led the parade wearing khaki uniforms and holding up what appeared to be machetes.

headline: U.S. ASSERTS ITS PROTEST IS NOT AIMED AT TALKS
abstract: The United States said today that its protest over the Soviet Union's purported use of a possibly hazardous chemical to track the movements of Americans in Moscow was not intended to ''sabotage'' the summit meeting scheduled in November between President Reagan and Mikhail S. Gorbachev.   When they made the accusation on Wednesday, United States officials said there is a possibility that the chemical could cause cancer. The substance is nitrophenylpentadienal, a little-known substance also referred to as NPPD.   Reagan Administration officials asserted today that the accusation about the yellow powder was not deliberately timed to coincide with the announcement this week of American plans to test an anti-satellite weapon.

headline: Rostenkowski Meets Executives on Taxes
abstract: A group of the nation's elite corporate leaders, including the heads of I.B.M., General Motors and R. J. Reynolds, flew to the Chicago area today to meet with Dan Rostenkowski, chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, to discuss the status of tax revision and to convey their views.   After the hourlong meeting held at the headquarters of Dart & Kraft, Mr. Rostenkowsi said the most ''sensitive'' issue discussed was the taxation of fringe benefits.   ''The thread that runs through all the material that we've discussed is that we'd like to see the business community make decisions based on good business as opposed to how they can shelter dollars to avoid paying taxes,'' Mr. Rostenkowski said.

headline: PRESIDENT OF CHINA ASSAILS U.S. MOVE ON BIRTH CONTROL
abstract: China's President, leaving for a tour of the United States and Canada, responded angrily today to a vote in the United States House of Representatives that condemned Peking's one-child-per-family policy.   Speaking to reporters at Peking Airport, President Li Xiannian described as ''a fabrication and distortion'' a measure, approved Wednesday, that accused China of using forced abortion and sterilization. The legislation, an amendment to the foreign aid bill, described such population-control methods as ''crimes against humanity'' and barred the use of American funds for any nation with a policy of coerced abortion.   Mr. Li, visibly agitated, added his remarks on the amendment to a prepared statement in which he spoke of the ''positive results'' he hoped for from his tour.

headline: Swiss Expel Soviet Diplomat
abstract: A senior Soviet diplomat accredited to the United Nations in Geneva has been expelled from Switzerland on charges of spying, the Federal Prosecutor's office said today. The diplomat, it said, had been engaged ''for a long period'' in espionage against Switzerland and ''third countries.'' It did not identify the diplomat or the other countries.

headline: Insider Reports
abstract: The New York and American stock exchanges issued yesterday their latest reports of changes in the shareholdings of officers, directors and large stockholders in companies whose shares are listed on the exchanges. The reports of changes follow: NEW YORK EXCHANGE BRISTOL-MYERS COMPANY-William Robert Miller, vice chairman of the board, bought and exercised options of 17,591 shares giving him directly a balance of 46,753 shares.

headline: SPAIN LAW ALLOWING SOME ABORTIONS TAKES EFFECT
abstract: Abortion became legal in Spain today over the bitter objections of many doctors and a statement by the Spanish Roman Catholic Church that anyone ''who cooperates physically or morally'' in the operation will be ''automatically excommunicated.''   The regulations enacting the new law, signed July 5 by the Socialist Government of Prime Minister Felipe Gonzalez after nearly two years of court battles, were published Friday in the official state bulletin and went into effect today.   The law limits abortions to cases of rape, a malformed fetus or danger to the mother, but all abortions were illegal before. The operation is free of charge in public clinics.

headline: Futures/Options;Concern Over Safety of Funds
abstract: HOW safe are the funds that futures traders entrust to their brokers? The question arose again last week when the Commodity Exchange in New York, the largest metals futures exchange, approved a plan to compensate customers of a now-defunct member concern, the Volume Investors Corporation.         It will be raised again next Monday when the Federal Commodity Futures Trading Commission examines the unusual events that caused the collapse of the member concern on March 20.

headline: A MEMOIR: WHEN THE U.N. WAS YOUNG
abstract: They were strange, those first years of the United Nations, so far back in the mid-40's and 50's, and sometimes quite wonderful.   Everybody knew that one pillar of the United Nations concept had collapsed before the first speech was made, the first resolution passed.   The way it was supposed to work was that the great Allies of World War II, the Big Five - the United States, the Soviet Union, China, Britain, France - were to continue great and allied forever.   They were to guide the United Nations with strength and wisdom. So unthinkable was it that they would ever be anything but strong and wise, that anything could be done against their will, that each of them was ennobled with veto power in the United Nations Security Council, where resolutions were supposed to be transformed into action.

headline: ARMS TALKS WITH SAUDIS
abstract: The Reagan Administration has long been trying to sell new F-15's and other advanced military equipment to Saudi Arabia but it has met resistance in Congress from supporters of Israel.   About 9 months ago, the Saudis submitted a formal application to the Reagan Administration to buy about 40 more McDonnell Douglas F-15's to augment the 60 they bought in the 1970's. In addition, they are seeking Stinger shoulder-fired antiaircraft missiles, and advanced Sidewinder air-to-air missiles.

headline: Transway Urges Nortek Rejection
abstract: The Transway International Corporation said that it was urging shareholders to reject a $45-a-share takeover offer from Nortek Inc. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Transway's board said that it would seek other transactions that ''would provide stockholders with more value for their shares than the Nortek offer.''   Transway declined to specify what alternatives it might be exploring, but analysts speculated that it was seeking a higher offer from Nortek, a friendly merger partner or a leveraged buyout.

headline: New Plant Closings At Hewlett-Packard
abstract: The Hewlett-Packard Company, extending a series of plant closings because of a sharp downturn in the computer industry, said yesterday that it would close all of its non-sales facilities during the Thanksgiving and Christmas holiday weeks, affecting 45,000 employees.   In a statement explaining the move, Dean O. Morton, the company's chief operating officer, said: ''We may be seeing the beginning of an upturn in the United States, but international orders remain quite weak.''

headline: Dan River Aide to Shift To Britain as Consultant
abstract: William M. Fine has always had a soft spot for Britain and Ireland. He bought an Irish home near Galway years ago, and quite recently a farm outside London. So on Dec. 1, Mr. Fine, the 59-year old president of the consumer products division of Dan River Inc., will make the big leap, moving with his family to London to resume a career as a corporate consultant for multinational companies expanding in the United States, as well as for American companies.

headline: CLASHES AND LOOTING REPORTED IN SOUTH AFRICA
abstract: Arson, looting and stonethrowing continued across South Africa today, the police said.

headline: BANKERS SAY CREDIT RATING WILL SUFFER
abstract: South Africa's freeze on repayments of foreign debt was a necessary move but will harm the country's credit rating and discourage new lending there in the future, bankers said yesterday.   ''Anybody is going to work like a bandit to get out of this situation,'' an economist at a major United States bank that has loans to South Africa said.   For United States banks already mired in the debt problems of Latin American and Eastern European countries, the announcement last night of a four-month freeze on repayments of principal on foreign debt represented another blow to their portfolios from a country that had prided itself on always paying its obligations promptly. But bankers said they expected to be repaid eventually, and had more confidence in South Africa's economic prospects than those of some Latin debtors.

headline: Carnation Unit Is Sold
abstract: The Carnation Company said it had sold its genetics division, which deals with bovine artificial insemination, to a new company controlled by Clark A. Nelson, a senior vice president of Carnation. Terms of the transaction were not announced.

headline: Easco to Sell Unit
abstract: The Easco Corporation has agreed to sell its hand tool division for $105 million to $110 million, and said it would take a one-time pretax write-off of $30 million to $35 million. Easco said the buyer was a new company, Peter W. Smith & Company of Chicago, in conjunction with several current hand tool managers and outside investors. The new owners, who should acquire the company in October, have agreed to assume the division's debt.

headline: U.N PENSION FUND DIVESTS ITSELF OF HOLDINGS TIED TO SOUTH AFRICA
abstract: The $4 billion United Nations pension fund has rid itself of all holdings in companies that do business in South Africa, it was announced today.   Joe Sills, a United Nations spokesman, told reporters that the fund ''has no remaining interests with companies which invest in South Africa.''   A week ago, the pension fund still had $100 million invested in 14 companies that do business in South Africa, despite an 11-year policy mandated by the General Assembly to divest. That figure was down significantly from the end of May, when $250 million of the fund's holdings were in shares of 30 companies with operations in South Africa, including I.B.M.

headline: DEVALUATION IS WEIGHED
abstract: Citing uncontrollable trading, the Italian Government suspended foreign exchange trading today after the lira plunged in heavy selling.   The Italian currency lost more than 20 percent of its value against the dollar. Before the halt, the price of the dollar on the Milan currency exchange had risen to 2,200 lira, from about 1,800 lira at the close of trading on Thursday.   At a news conference, Finance Minister Giovanni Goria said the Government would try to arrange a devaluation at a weekend meeting with its partners in the European Monetary System. He promised that trading would resume on Monday.

headline: Report on Conrail Sale Expected
abstract: The United States Railway Association, the agency responsible for monitoring Conrail and Amtrak, is expected to release this week a study critical of all the major players in the Administration-backed plan to sell the Consolidated Rail Corporation to the Norfolk Southern Corporation.   The report finds that the Department of Transportation and Norfolk Southern have underestimated the negative impact on competition that would result from this combination.

headline: WEST BANK STABBING KILLS ISRAEL SOLDIER
abstract: An Israeli soldier was stabbed to death and another seriously wounded today as they stood guard at an apartment in the West Bank, the Israeli Army spokesman announced.   Israeli military sources said the stabbings had been carried out by one or two ''local residents,'' which they said ''obviously means Arabs.''   The apartment, in the old marketplace of Hebron, was recently occupied by three Israeli members of Parliament who sought to demonstrate that Jews were free to live anywhere in the Israeli-occupied West Bank.   A third Israeli soldier guarding the building opened fire on the crowded street after the attack, wounding a young Arab woman and an Arab man who were apparently not involved in the incident, military sources said.

headline: Rights Group Faults U.S. On Guatemala Situation
abstract: A human-rights monitoring group has asserted that the Reagan Administration has refused to acknowledge major human-rights abuses in Guatemala under three successive Governments there.   The group, Americas Watch, said in a report that was made public last week that by failing to criticize the present military Government, headed by Gen. Oscar Mejia Victores, Washington had wasted a chance to improve the human-rights situation there.

headline: New Caledonia Militants End Blockade of Mine
abstract: Militants demanding independence for France's South Pacific territory of New Caledonia ended a five-day blockade of the Thio nickel mine today after the Government agreed to reduce the police presence in the area.   The lifting of barricades blocking the entrance to the mine ended a tense confrontation between Melanesian militants of the Kanak Socialist National Liberation Front and 600 riot police officers.

headline: The U.N. Today: July 1, 1985
abstract: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Ad Hoc Committee on the Indian Ocean - 3 P.M.

headline: PANTRY BID IS OPPOSED BY REVLON
abstract: A takeover battle between Revlon Inc. and Pantry Pride Inc. burst into the open yesterday as Revlon announced a series of defensive steps and Pantry Pride made a formal tender offer.   Revlon said it planned a ''special dividend'' to shareholders - a so-called poison pill - that could add $750 million to the cost of buying the company. It also said it would buy back up to five million of its shares in the open market.   For its part, Pantry Pride formally offered stockholders $47.50 a share for any and all of Revlon's 38.2 million shares, or a total of $1.81 billion. It said its offer was conditional on getting about $750 million in additional financing.

headline: KHMER REBELS SAY POL POT IS RETIRING
abstract: The Khmer Rouge rebel movement in Cambodia announced today that its leader, Pol Pot, was retiring from command of the organization.   The announcement on the Khmer Rouge radio said that Mr. Pol Pot, who ruled Cambodia for four years until Vietnam invaded the country in 1979, would assume a vaguely defined military advisory role.   Diplomats and experts on the Khmer Rouge, whose rule of Cambodia was marked by a reign of terror and policies that left as many as two million people dead, reacted to the report with caution. They said it was unclear whether the announced change in leadership would be substantive.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST: THURSDAY, SEPTEMBER 5, 1985
abstract: The Economy    Congress could adopt trade curbs in defiance of a veto threat because of a growing public alarm over jobs lost to imports, Congressional leaders from both parties warned. Returning lawmakers said Congress seemed headed for a confrontation with the White House on a number of other critical issues, too, ranging from tax revision to military spending to farm prices. [Page A1.]    The Farm Credit Adminitration may ask to be rescued, officials of the agency said. The White House has opposed such assistance, which could run in the billions, but defaults are so widespread that some sort of intervention may be recommended to President Reagan, a White House official said. The Farm Credit Administration, which oversees the nation's farmer-owned banking system, is suffering its first losses in decades. [A1.]  International

headline: FAST-RISING ECONOMIST FOR A TOP KREMLIN POST
abstract: Nikolai I. Ryzhkov, who was appointed Soviet Prime Minister today, is an engineer and industrial manager by training, not a Communist Party official.   In his new job as head of the Soviet Government, or chairman of the Council of Ministers, he will have the main responsibility for instituting the economic changes outlined by the man thought to be his mentor, Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader.   Mr. Ryzhkov, who will turn 56 on Saturday, represents the new generation of well-educated, professionally trained managers who began to climb when Yuri V. Andropov was Soviet leader, and have been promoted to top positions by Mr. Gorbachev.

headline: Allnet's Merger Set For December
abstract: Allnet Communications Services Inc. and the Lexitel Corporation said that they would merge by December, forming a new company yet to be named. Each will receive half of the new company's stock, according to Steve Ingish, an Allnet spokesman.

headline: Teamwork In a Proper Setting
abstract: EARLY Friday morning, an hour before McCann-Erickson would make its presentation for more than $15 million of Union Carbide billings, Jay McNamara, its chairman for North America, was already in his office and as cool as one would expect a former Marine Corps officer to be.   And he seemed totally unconcerned that in the competition for the assignment - which is for Prestone, STP and Simoniz - he would be up against Young & Rubicam, the world's largest agency and until exactly six months ago his employer of 22 years. He had been the domestic president there and probably agreed to join Robert L. James, chairman of McCann Worldwide, because of greater opportunities to enlarge the scope of his responsibilities.   In the meantime, he seems to be making McCann, the largest unit within the Interpublic Group of Companies, more like the agency he left behind.

headline: NICARAGUA REBELS OPEN A NEW FRONT
abstract: Anti-Government rebels appear to have opened a new battlefront in the central part of Nicaragua, where eight months ago the war was something local residents only read about in newspapers.   Residents of the region, Boaco and Chontales Provinces, said Sandinista helicopters periodically bombard rebel positions in the rugged hills around their villages.   They said squads of the United States-supported insurgents, known as contras, had descended on several villages, where they killed or kidnapped local Sandinista leaders and military recruiters and convened political meetings for residents.   ''Nobody really knows where the contras are,'' said a shopkeeper in La Libertad, where the Sandinista Army maintains a sizable force backed by armor and heavy artillery. ''But I think we're surrounded.''

headline: Cooke F.C.C. Filing Due On Multimedia
abstract: Jack Kent Cooke intends to file an application with the Federal Communications Commission, seeking its consent for his proposed takeover of Multimedia Inc., according to a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission. Mr. Cooke, a Washington investor, holds 9.75 percent of the common shares of Multimedia, a South Carolina-based telecommunications concern. The S.E.C. filing did not specify when Mr. Cooke would file with the F.C.C. Mr. Cooke's proposal for a merger with Multimedia at more than $65 a share was turned down by Multimedia's board in May.   Eugene J. McCarthy, the former Senator from Minnesota and Presidential candidate, will act as Mr. Cooke's trustee in the event he takes over Multimedia while his F.C.C. application is still pending.

headline: Ontario Arrests 4 Protesters
abstract: The police arrested four Greenpeace protesters today when they climbed down from a bridge connecting Ontario and Michigan after an overnight protest against purported chemical dumping, officials said. The four were charged with trespassing and released.

headline: BONN SPY CASE: 'HOPELESS PERSONAL SITUATION'
abstract: A note apparently written by Hans Joachim Tiedge, a West German counterespionage officer, says he defected to East Germany because he was in ''a hopeless personal situation,'' a well-informed Bonn official said today.   The two-sentence handwritten note, which the official said was dated Aug. 24 and appeared to be genuine, was delivered on Thursday by Wolfgang Vogel, an East Berlin lawyer, to Ludwig Rehlinger, a Bonn official. Written on a blank piece of paper and signed, the note said Mr. Tiedge defected of his ''own free will'' on Aug. 19.

headline: KOCH BIDS BANKS CUT PRETORIA TIE
abstract: Mayor Koch sent out a letter to the presidents of 12 banks Friday, urging them ''to immediately suspend all banking activities in South Africa, to call in all your loans and to refuse to roll over maturing debts until the state of emergency is rescinded and apartheid is ended.''   Such an action, the Mayor said in his letter, would ''send a clear message to the South African Government that continued economic viability cannot go hand in hand with oppression.''

headline: Turk Denies Any Role In Attempt to Kill Pope
abstract: A Turk accused of being the link between Soviet bloc intelligence services and a right-wing Turkish terrorist who shot Pope John Paul II in 1981 today denied having any part in a purported plot to kill the Pope.   The 50-year-old Turkish businessman, Bekir Celenk, who Mehmet Ali Agca, the Pope's convicted assailant, says acted as an intermediary for a Soviet diplomat in Bulgaria and offered Mr. Agca $1.2 million to assassinate the Pope, appeared before a military tribunal investigating the killing in 1979 of a Turkish newspaper editor, Abdi Ipekci.

headline: Buyout Talk And Rorer
abstract: WHEN the Rorer Group adopted anti-takeover measures earlier this year, the Fort Washington, Pa., drug and medical product manufacturer probably thought the buyout rumors that had dogged it for years would ease. It was wrong.   In fact, in the last week the name Rorer, whose most recognizable product is Maalox antacid, has probably been whispered by more takeover speculators than at any time in the last few months.   The results of these rumors has been to put some additional zip into Rorer's stock, making it severely overpriced on a fundamental basis and creating what some believe may be one of the riskiest investments now on Wall Street. That is true, of course, only if speculation about Pfizer Inc.'s or the Beecham Group's wanting to acquire Rorer is unfounded.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST: WEDNESDAY, SEPTEMBER 4, 1985
abstract: Companies    The Pentagon proposed canceling a Fairchild Republic plane made at a plant on Long Island, Pentagon and industry sources said. They said the Air Force proposed ending the $3.5 billion program as part of a budget-cutting move. Industry analysts said the cancellation plan, which could be reversed, would be a severe blow to the plant in Farmingdale, which has 3,600 employees. [Page A1.]    CBS is going to offer early retirement to 2,000 employees, or about 7 percent of its work force, as a way to pay for its costly takeover fight with Ted Turner earlier this summer. [A1.]

headline: 100 More Are Freed By Israelis From Atlit
abstract: Israel today released 100 prisoners captured in Lebanon, sending them by bus across the border where they will be handed over to the International Committee of the Red Cross, the military command here said today.

headline: Peru Misses U.S. Payment
abstract: Peru has failed to repay some $200,000 to the United States for military equipment it bought on credit and is now automatically cut off from new aid consideration, State Department officials said today.

headline: SCM RISES ON BUYOUT SPECULATION
abstract: The stock of the SCM Corporation rose sharply again yesterday in heavy trading on the New York Stock Exchange on speculation that the company's management, possibly with the help of Merrill Lynch & Company, may be moving ahead with plans for a leveraged buyout.   Meanwhile, there was also conjecture that Hanson Trust P.L.C. of London might be willing to raise its $60-a-share tender offer for the chemicals and business-products manufacturer if the leveraged-buyout plan progresses or if another bidder emerges.   Wall Street sources said the possible inclusion of Merrill Lynch, the giant brokerage house, in SCM's corner might be the most important development yet in the not-yet-week-old struggle for the maker of Smith-Corona typewriters.

headline: U.S. HOSTAGE TOOK PHOTOS IN BEIRUT
abstract: One of the 39 Americans held hostage in Beirut after their plane was hijacked in June hid a camera from his Moslem captors and secretly took three dozen color pictures of his companions, the building in which they were confined and the surrounding landscape. He later gave the pictures to American authorities.   The former hostage, Peter W. Hill, a travel agent and tour guide from the Chicago area, said today that his Canon 35-millimeter camera had been packed in his suitcase, which was confiscated by the hijackers of Trans World Airlines Flight 847. Later, for reasons still unknown to him, the bag was delivered to him in custody, with the camera apparently untouched.

headline: Taking Funds Out of an I.R.A.
abstract: THE basic rules for putting money into an individual retirement account are generally known to workers who have been using this long-term savings vehicle. But the requirements and restrictions for taking money out of an I.R.A. at retirement are, in most cases, less understood by the public.   On the pay-in side of the ledger, there are two essential points to remember: tax-deductible contributions of up to $2,000 of earned income can be made annually by anyone under the age of 70 1/2. And an individual with a nonworking spouse can establish two I.R.A.'s, with their total contributions amounting to $2,250 a year.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Previous   Year

headline: Transway Stake To Goldman, Sachs
abstract: Goldman, Sachs & Company said today that it had bought a 5 percent stake in the Transway International Corporporation. Its filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission indicated that the New York investment firm was apparently hoping to benefit from increased bidding for the transportation company, which is based in White Plains.

headline: Mary Kay Buyout
abstract: Mary Kay Cosmetics Inc.'s board approved a sweetened leveraged buyout proposal that it valued at $19.25 a share, or a total of $404 million. The company said that it had entered into a definitive agreement with an investor group that includes Mary Kay Ash, the company's founder and chairman.

headline: STARTING OVER IN MINDANAO
abstract: HE crouches a bit, gropes into the green leafy foliage and plucks an oblong-shaped woody fruit with rumpled reddish-orange skin - a cocoa pod. ''This,'' says Carlos Villa-Abrille, gesturing toward the dense thicket of 10-foot-high cocoa bushes around him ''is the future.''   Mr. Villa-Abrille, the 39-year-old president of the Philippine Cocoa Estates Corporation, was speaking mainly of the state-of-the-art cultivation technology that allows for unusually dense planting of cocoa bushes and dramatic increases in yields. But more generally, the big cocoa orchard here on the southern island of Mindanao is one of the most striking examples of the Philippines's new focus on agriculture as the key to economic development.   ''Agribusiness'' is suddenly the subject of choice in the restaurants and bars where Manila's business elite gather. Impassioned remarks and knowing glances are exchanged over such topics as hybrid corn, black pepper, irrigated rice, mangoes, mong beans, peanuts, coffee and oranges -some of the crops being planned for and planted with increasing frequency in recent months. Aquaculture, too, is included in the new-found penchant for agriculture.

headline: Gabon Plotter Is Doomed
abstract: A court martial in Gabon has sentenced an air force captain to death for plotting to overthrow President Omar Bongo, court sources said today. The sources said that they did not know when the captain, Alexandre Mandja Ngoukouta, was to be executed, but that the verdict was announced on Thursday.

headline: Oil Project Loan Set
abstract: The Synthetic Fuels Corporation today awarded $60 million in subsidies for an oil project in Texas despite a supposed understanding with the White House that no grants would be approved until President Reagan decides whether he wants the agency abolished.

headline: Iraqi Planes Damage Turkish Tanker in Gulf
abstract: Iraqi warplanes crippled a Turkish supertanker today, setting its stern section on fire with a missile strike, Persian Gulf shipping sources said.

headline: HOME BUILDING OFF BY 2.4% IN JULY
abstract: Construction of new housing, an important gauge of future economic activity, fell a surprising 2.4 percent in July, the Commerce Department reported yesterday.   The drop in what are known as housing starts - the beginning of construction on new single or multifamily dwellings - was the latest in a series of indicators showing that the economy is not rebounding from the disappointing first six months of the year. Building permits, an indicator of future activity, fell nine-tenths of 1 percent in July following a 3.7 percent decline in June.   And in another indication that the economy is failing to regain momentum, the Government reported yesterday that factory operating rates were unchanged in July for the fourth consecutive month. [Page 36.]  1.65 Million Annual Rate The Commerce Department reported that, in July, new housing was started at a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 1.65 million units.

headline: ARMS ISSUE IMPERILS U.S.-NEW ZEALAND PACT
abstract: Though neither side wants it to, a 33-year-old defense treaty that links the United States and New Zealand appears to be unraveling over this country's insistence on barring nuclear-armed or nuclear-powered ships from its ports.   The dispute is forcing New Zealanders to choose between two of their main foreign-policy priorities: their alliance with the United States and Australia under the pact, known as Anzus, and their opposition to nuclear arms.   Opinion polls show that at least two-thirds of New Zealanders support both policies, but realities indicate that the two are becoming mutually exclusive.   By the conclusion last weekend of a visit to Washington by Deputy Prime Minister Geoffrey Palmer, commentators here said it had become clear that both nations had reached the point where, for the moment at least, their positions were irreconcilable.

headline: Ameritech Seeks Waiver
abstract: The American Information Technologies Corporation said today that it had asked the Justice Department for permission to make telecommunications and computer equipment overseas.   Ameritech is asking the Government to waive guidelines set down in the breakup of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company that bar Bell operating companies from making telecommunications equipment, either in the United States or in foreign countries.

headline: Ghana Bus Kills 26 in Crowd
abstract: A bus raced into a crowd celebrating a minor chief's assumption of office in central Ghana, killing 26 people, the Ghana news agency reported today. The accident occurred Saturday in Ekumfi-Ekotsi, 73 miles north of here.

headline: Xerox Reports Profit Increase
abstract: The Xerox Corporation said today that its second-quarter earnings rose to a total of $221 million, or $2.17 a share, from $96 million, or 87 cents a share, a year earlier.

headline: WHAT'S NEW IN DENTISTRY
abstract: AMERICANS' dental health is improving all the time, but many of the nation's dental practices are ailing.  Rapid advances in preventing tooth decay, improved equipment and materials that reduce treatment time, the smaller number of teen-agers - among the most frequent users of dental services - in the general population, all have combined to leave many of the profession's 127,000 members less busy than they have ever been. The American Dental Association makes no bones about it -the supply of dentists, it says, has outstripped demand for their services.

headline: Converting A Police Station
abstract: FOR two generations its cells held Wall Street's bomb throwers, stock swindlers and confidence men as well as the sweepings of the nearby piers along Water and South Streets.   But now what had been for 60 years the Old Slip station house of the First Police Precinct is looking for a new tenant. This time, however, it is hoping to attract a different type of clientele, perhaps a brokerage house or a bank.   The Neo-Italianate Renaissance building, which has been declared a landmark by the city's Landmarks Preservation Commission, has four floors, plus a mezzanine and a penthouse. Its address is 48 Old Slip, on the southeastern tip of Manhattan at the foot of William Street.

headline: I.B.M.-Japan Patent Details
abstract: The International Business Machines Corporation will receive a number of advanced technology patents in its agreement with the Japanese Government, the company said today.

headline: New York Agency Hospital Offering
abstract: The New York State Dormitory Authority is offering $64 million of hospital revenue bonds for Rochester General Hospital through a group of underwriters led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets.   The financing consists of 7.60 percent bonds due in 1995 and 8 1/2 percent bonds due in 2005, both at par, as well as 8 3/4 percent bonds due in 2025 offered at 99 1/2 to yield 8.80 percent.   Rated Aa by Moody's Investors Service and AA by the Standard & Poor's Corporation, the bonds are backed by a mortgage that is insured by the Federal Housing Administration.

headline: Cuts at Timken
abstract: The Timken Company said nearly 70 percent of the 340 salaried workers who were offered early retirement as part of a budget-cutting move had accepted the offer. Timken has said it wants to reduce the number of salaried positions by 500.

headline: IN BEIRUT, HOODED MEN TELL OF CAPTIVES' RELEASE
abstract: Two men who said they were the hijackers of the Trans World Airlines jet said today that they had committed the act to show the world ''the ability of the oppressed to confront America.''   Hoods over their heads and automatic pistols jammed in their pants, the men met reporters at the Beirut airport at almost the same moment that the 39 Americans were beginning their journey to Syria and freedom after 17 days in captivity.   ''America is the great Satan,'' one of the men said in an angry tone as he read a 10-minute statement in Arabic. His head was covered by what appeared to be a pillowcase with eyeholes cut into it.

headline: Another Executive Resigns at Wang
abstract: Jon F. Kropper, an executive vice president and one of four top officials at Wang Laboratories Inc., resigned yesterday, less than two months after John F. Cunningham resigned as president of the troubled computer maker.   Mr. Kropper's resignation is effective Oct. 1, when he will become president and chief operating officer of the Hadco Corporation, a much smaller company in Salem, N.H., that makes electronic circuit boards used in computers and other products. Wang did not name a successor.

headline: New Shekel For Israel
abstract: Israel's Parliament today unanimously approved introduction of a new shekel valued at 1,000 existing shekels, in a currency change aimed at keeping pace with inflation.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: * American Savings Bank said its board has approved conversion to a Federal capital stock savings bank, from a mutual savings bank.    * Applied Materials Inc., Santa Clara, Calif., said it has reduced its workforce by 190 people, or 13 percent of the total, to adjust for the current slowdown in the semicondcutor industry.

headline: Washington Post's Net Up
abstract: The Washington Post Company said today that its second-quarter net income totaled $34.1 million, or $2.61 a share, for the second quarter of 1985, up 25.4 percent over $27.2 million, or $1.94, a year earlier.   Revenue for the second quarter of 1985 was $284.3 million, a gain of 11 percent over revenue of $256.1 million a year ago.

headline: COLECO SMITTEN BY 'RAMBO'
abstract: Coleco Industries, the company whose cuddly Cabbage Patch Kids became a national craze, said yesterday that it would market a line of dolls and accessories based on Rambo, the muscle-bound movie hero portrayed by Sylvester Stallone.   Mr. Stallone plays a gun-slinging ex-Green Beret on a one-man mission to retrieve Americans missing in action in Vietnam, and the character has already become something of an American phenomenon. Johnny Carson has parodied him on television and President Reagan, in off-the-record remarks before a speech, said that after seeing the film he would know how to handle terrorists.      Quick to Criticize    But while some toy experts predicted Coleco could well have another hit, others were quick to criticize it for introducing a toy based on a character featured in R-rated movies, ''Rambo: First Blood Part II,'' and its predecessor, ''First Blood,'' that some critics have said glorify violence. The rating prohibits people under 17 from attending unless accompanied by an adult.

headline: The U.N. Today: Sept. 12, 1985
abstract: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Committee to Review International Development Strategy - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.   International Conference for Just Cause of Namibian People - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

headline: TRYING TO SPOT WIND SHEAR
abstract: NO sooner had wind shear been identified as the probable cause of the Delta Air Lines L-1011 crash that killed 133 people last week than a bevy of Government and industry experts asserted that the accident was probably avoidable.   They said existing technology, in the form of Doppler radar equipment, could track movements of the deadly ''microbursts'' of air capable of thrusting a low-flying plane to the ground. But budgetary politics and bad planning, they said, have delayed installation of the system.   When pressed, however, both the manufacturers of Doppler radar systems and some meteorologists concede that significant refinements of the technology are needed before airport systems can go into production, even though a research version was successfully tested at Denver last summer.

headline: Iraq Reports New Raid On Iranian Oil Depot
abstract: Iraq said its jets carried out a ''devastating raid'' on the Iranian oil terminal at Kharg island today, but Iran said it thwarted the attempt and a surface-to-air missile downed one of two Iraqi warplanes that violated Iranian airspace.   The attack on Kharg, Iran's main center for oil exports, was the ninth reported by Iraq on the Persian Gulf terminal since Aug. 15.

headline: RESORTS GETS 8.8% STAKE IN PAN AM
abstract: Resorts International Inc. disclosed yesterday that it owns an 8.8 percent stake in the Pan Am Corporation, the parent company of Pan American World Airways.   Resorts, the hotel and gambling concern, said in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission that it purchased the stock as an investment, and that it does not expect to increase its stake in the troubled airline to more than 10 percent.   Yesterday's announcement came two months after Resorts made a bid to acquire Trans World Airlines for $22 a share, or a total of $759 million, according to Wall Street sources. That bid was rejected by T.W.A. in favor of a higher offer from the Texas Air Corporation.

headline: N. Carolina Hub For American Air
abstract: American Airlines said that it would open a new hub at Raleigh-Durham, N.C., beginning in mid-1987 with 40 to 45 daily flights to 25 cities. The airline now offers four flights a day from the airport and employs about 15 people.

headline: West German Woman Is Freed in Honduras
abstract: The Honduran Army today turned over to West German diplomats a West German woman captured June 14 by Indian rebels in Nicaragua.   The woman, Eva Regine Schemann, an ecologist working for the Nicaraguan Government, was captured by a unit of the Misura guerrilla group near the isolated Caribbean town of Puerto Cabezas, about 180 miles northeast of Managua near the Honduran border.   Miss Schemann was released on the Honduran-Nicaraguan border to Honduran Army troops, who then turned her over to West German diplomats at the main Honduran air base outside the capital of Tegucigalpa, the army announced.

headline: Market Place;   Airline Stocks And Oil Prices
abstract: AIRLINE stocks are basking in investor enthusiasm these days, following Saudi Arabia's assertion that it plans to use every bit of its oil production quota from the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, thereby doubling its current output.   Analysts say that if Saudi Arabia, one of the biggest oil-producing nations, follows through on its threat, it could undermine the modest price decrease that OPEC announced last week.   And, if the price of oil is depressed further, it could be a boon for the airline industry. The second-largest cost component of airlines is fuel, topped only by employee salaries and benefits.

headline: Advertising;   TV Campaign Against Crime
abstract: The Department of Justice will begin its first national television campaign on Sept. 2. The public service commercials were designed to encourage citizens to assist law enforcement officials by coming forward to ''Report. Identify. Testify.''

headline: 28 First Bank Units for Sale
abstract: First Bank System Inc., the Minneapolis-based bank holding company, said today that it planned to sell 28 of its regional banks in Minnesota, Montana and North and South Dakota. First Bank, the nation's 14th-largest banking concern, owns 78 banks and trust companies.

headline: Rubber Bullets: Riot Weapon
abstract: Rubber bullets are used by South African authorities extensively in confrontations with crowds. The bullet is an inch and a half in diameter and three inches long and weighs about three ounces.

headline: Former Officers Form Pooled Fund Venture
abstract: In his years as chief lending officer of the Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Company, George R. Baker had ample exposure to the financial problems of the bank's corporate borrowers. And, Gerald C. Meyers faced corporate financial and management problems of his own when he was chief executive of the American Motors Corporation.   Now the two have teamed up with two others to form Barrington Limited Partners, a pooled venture that will invest in troubled companies, with the goal of turning them around through a combination of financial backing and management advice.

headline: LONGER DAYS AT THE BIG BOARD
abstract: Chester Pado can sleep late this week. But it will be the last week that the Los Angeles stockbroker can stay in bed until the ripe hour of 5 A.M. Starting next Monday, he and thousands of others nationwide will be rising even earlier to accommodate the New York Stock Exchange's decision to squeeze an extra 30 minutes of trading into the front part of the day.   For the Big Board, the decision to begin trading at 9:30 A.M. New York time instead of 10 is aimed at generating more business, and it may even start the clock ticking toward 24-hour trading markets.   By raising the curtain one half-hour earlier, the Big Board will catch more afternoon trading from Europe, where investors have shown larger and larger appetites for United States stocks. Studies in the securities industry had already predicted that, even without the extra trading time, foreign trading in United States stocks would grow to $167 billion by 1988, compared with $134 billion in 1983.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: Chesapeake and Potomac Telephone Co., a unit of Bell Atlantic Corp., tentatively priced $110 million of 11 1/4 percent, 30-year debentures at 99 to yield 11.364 percent through underwriters led by Morgan Stanley & Co.    * Old Kent Financial Corp. is issuing $40 million of 8 percent convertible subordinated debentures due 2010 through Merrill Lynch Capital Markets. The debentures may be converted into Old Kent Financial common shares at a conversion price of $38 a share.

headline: SECURITY UNDERWRITERS BUSIER IN 2D QUARTER
abstract: The second quarter produced a heavy level of securities offerings for underwriters as a blizzard of offerings were made in the generally favorable market.   Along with the heavy volume of securities, there was some competitive jostling among the ranks of underwriters during the second quarter, with shifts in their rankings.   Analysts cited the continuing decline in interest rates as the principal factor behind the enormous supply of securities sent to the market. This led to a huge level of debt securities offerings but a modest amount of common stock offerings, according to IDD Information Services.

headline: Manville Closing
abstract: The Manville Corporation said today that it would close its plant in the central New Jersey town that took its name from the company.

headline: PROSECUTORS IN AQUINO CASE SPURN NEW DATA FROM U.S.
abstract: Prosecutors in the trial of 26 people accused in the assassination in 1983 of Benigno S. Aquino Jr. today rejected evidence supplied by the United States that described what appeared to be unusual activity by the Philippine Air Force on the day the opposition leader was slain.   The Government ombudsman, Bernardo P. Fernandez, who is in charge of the prosecution in the trial, made public a memorandum saying statements by six American servicemen were ''irrelevant and immaterial'' as well as legally flawed.   Sources here said the affidavits, which have not been made public, describe an apparently unsuccessful attempt by two air force F-5 fighter planes to intercept the China Air Lines commercial airliner that was bringing Mr. Aquino from Taipei to Manila.

headline: The U.N. Today; July 19, 1985
abstract: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Ad Hoc Committee on the World Disarmament Conference - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Previous   Year

headline: AROUND THE WORLD;Thailand Reports Firing Across Mekong River
abstract: Thai military authorities said today that Vietnamese and Laotian forces had been firing across the Mekong River at Thai positions for three days. The Thais  were reported to have returned the fire.         The mortar and gunfire exchanges were reported near the Thai river town of Nong Khai. A Thai policeman was reportedly killed.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: Debt Issues    * Chase Manhattan Corp. has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for a shelf offering of up to $500 million in debt securities.    * Chrysler Financial Corp. is issuing $75 million of seven-year floating rate notes through underwriters led by Morgan Guaranty Ltd.

headline: Hispanic Supplement
abstract: Beginning Sept. 8, The Dallas Morning News will distribute a 16-page, four-color national newspaper supplement for Hispanic readers. Called Vista, the magazine will be included in the Sunday editions of the paper. It will be written in English and will feature Hispanic personalities and activities.

headline: POLL FINDS TAX PLAN SKEPTICISM
abstract: The Reagan Administration's campaign to sell its tax revision plan as a boon to middle-income Americans has not taken root in the minds of the public, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll.   When he submitted his tax proposals to Congress in May, the President said they would ''reduce the tax burdens on the working people of this country,'' and he emphasized that theme in speeches around the country last month.   The Times/CBS News Poll indicates, however, that only 13 percent of Americans believe their taxes would be reduced by the President's proposals. Two Americans in five believe their taxes would be raised, and another another two-fifths believe their taxes would remain about the same as they are now.

headline: Market Place;Cautious View On Oil Stocks
abstract: MANY oil companies are expected to report higher second-quarter earnings, but a generally cautious view toward the group prevails on Wall Street. The main uncertainty, analysts agree, concerns the extent to which crude oil prices may decline.         ''At present, we are not recommending for purchase any of the major domestic  oil companies,'' said Eugene L. Nowak of Dean Witter Reynolds.

headline: Denial Issued By Hutton
abstract: E.F. Hutton & Company yesterday denied reports published in The Los Angeles Times that its senior officials were aware of and encouraged illegal overdrafting of its bank accounts, to which it pleaded guilty in May.   Hutton released a statement saying: ''On their face, the documents in question do not indicate that anyone associated with them was necessarily aware of any illegal activity.''   The company also denied assertions that one of its branch managers had destroyed documents relevant to the Justice Department's fraud case against Hutton.

headline: First Union Deal
abstract: The First Union Corporation of Charlotte, N.C., said that it would acquire the Central Florida Bank Corporation for about $25 million in stock. First Union has already agreed to acquire the Atlantic Bancorporation of Jacksonville, Fla., and said it now plans to merge the two Florida banks when the acquisitions are completed later this year or early in 1986. First Union has assets of $8.2 billion, while Atlantic has assets of $3.8 billion and Central Florida Bank has $180 million.

headline: ISRAEL'S PERES: VOTERS TURN TO HIM, IF NOT TO HIS PARTY
abstract: After almost a year as the head of Israel's national unity Government, Prime Minister Shimon Peres has established himself as the dominant figure in Israeli politics today, according to Israeli political experts.   Mr. Peres, they say, has been far more successful at dealing with Israel's economic problems and ending the country's involvement in Lebanon than many people had predicted when he took office last Sept. 13. It is his success in these areas that appears to have led to his new popularity.   The pollsters, consultants and other political experts say, however, that Mr. Peres has been less successful in extending to his party the personal popularity that he has gained.   They say that within his party, Labor, he has failed to bring forward the kind of new faces and new approaches that would attract more of Israel's increasingly populous Sephardic Jews.

headline: A SEAL TO PREVENT PIPE JOINT LEAKAGE
abstract: A flange arrangement that meets Environmental Protection Agency regulations on the handling of hazardous materials was patented this week.

headline: A.M.C. Jeep Shift
abstract: The American Motors Corporation said today that it was shifting production of its four-wheel-drive Jeep CJ model to a Canadian plant at Brampton, Ontario.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST: SATURDAY, SEPTEMBER 7, 1985
abstract: The Economy    The unemployment rate fell 0.3 percentage points in August, to 6.9 percent, the lowest level since President Reagan took office. The sharp drop followed six straight months in which the jobless rate registered 7.2 percent. The labor data showed strength in nearly every major category, with particularly big improvements for workers between 16 and 24 years old. [Page 1.]  Unemployment in New York City, however, rose by almost a percentage point, to 7.7 percent, which was still the lowest August jobless rate since 1974. The rate in New York State inched up 0.2 percentage points, to 6.1 percent, but the rate in New Jersey dropped 1.5 percentage points, to 4.4 percent. [29.]    The White House took a dim view of extending Federal aid to the Farm Credit System, and two officials of the system said the severity of the lenders' mounting losses had been exaggerated. [31.]

headline: Woman's Day Account Moves to Leber Katz
abstract: After three years with Calvillo, Shevack & Partners, Woman's Day magazine has moved its advertising account to Leber Katz Partners, which will handle both trade media and consumer circulation promotion.   ''It was for business reasons,'' said Anne Sutherland Fuchs, publisher of Woman's Day.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Previous   Year

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Previous   Year

headline: U.S. AND SOUTH AFRICA AIDES MEET IN VIENNA OVER 'SERIOUS SITUATION'
abstract: Senior American and South African officials met today at the United States Embassy in Vienna at Pretoria's request to discuss the situation in South Africa, the White House and the State Department said.   The meeting, the first high-level contact between the two Governments since March, included Robert C. McFarlane, the White House national security adviser; Roelof F. Botha, the South African Foreign Minister; Chester A. Crocker, the Assistant Secretary of State for African Affairs, and Herman W. Nickel, the United States Ambassador to South Africa.   Officials said the South African Government had indicated that it wished to discuss possible reform measures Pretoria might announce within the next week or so. South Africa is governed by whites who exclude the black majority from any political power.

headline: Well Completions Fall
abstract: Petroleum companies completed a total of 41,318 oil and natural gas wells in the United States during the first six months of 1985, down by a slim 120 wells from a year earlier, the Petroleum Information Corporation reported today.

headline: 2 Newspaper Sales By Capital Cities
abstract: Capital Cities Communications has agreed to sell The Daily Register of Red Bank, N.J., a 28,000-circulation newspaper serving Monmouth County, and the 100,000-circulation semi-weekly Ocean County Reporter of Toms River, N.J., to Price Communications for $7.5 million.

headline: Crown Zellerbach Files to Restructure
abstract: The Crown Zellerbach Corporation filed a plan yesterday with the Securities and Exchange Commission to carry out its previously announced restructuring into three parts, but added that Sir James Goldsmith, who has been its takeover nemesis, did not approve.   The filing also disclosed that on July 1, during negotiations over the restructuring, Sir James rejected a management proposal that he acquire Crown at $50 a share.   Sir James, who owns slightly more than 25 percent of the stock, reached an accord in May with the company to cooperate in the restructuring, which is intended to increase the value of Crown's shares. He was made a board member at the time.

headline: SOVIET SAID TO HINT AT NEW ARMS OFFER
abstract: The Soviet side in the Geneva arms talks has raised the possibility of offering to make a 30 percent cutback in strategic nuclear missiles and bombers along with a related reduction in nuclear bombs and warheads, Administration officials said today.   Last Friday, earlier public hints from Moscow in a similar vein were dismissed by the Reagan White House as ''really propaganda,'' on the ground that they were not part of the Geneva arms negotiations.   The significance of the latest disclosure is that American officials now say that in Geneva, the Soviet side has raised the possibility of a cutback in nuclear warheads and bombs, something the Administration has sought for three years along with a cutback in strategic missiles and bombers. The development came late in the round of talks that ended July 16, officials said.

headline: PERU'S NEW CHIEF TO LIMIT PAYMENTS ON FOREIGN DEBT
abstract: In the boldest move yet by a Latin American debtor nation, Peru's new President, Alan Garcia Perez, announced today that his Government would limit payments on the country's foreign debt to a percentage of its export earnings.   In his inaugural address, the 36-year-old Social Democrat said Peru would dedicate no more than 10 percent of its export earnings to debt payments over the next 12 months while it seeks to renegotiate its $14 billion foreign debt.   He also said Peru planned to deal directly with its creditors without the involvement of the International Monetary Fund, which he described as ''an accomplice'' in the country's acute economic troubles.      Will Seek Unity    ''We will look to make payments under the best conditions, working with other countries,'' he said. ''But while we seek a united Latin America, we will talk with our creditors without the involvement of the I.M.F.''

headline: MEXICO CUTS PRICES OF ITS OIL
abstract: Mexico reduced the average price of its crude oil today by as much as $1.24 a barrel and announced a new pricing system that differentiates among geographical areas.   An announcement by the Department of Energy, Mines and Parastate Industries said the action was taken because of a sagging world market in which the 13 members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries have been undercutting each other in their pricing.   Mexico is not a member of OPEC, but had been following its pricing policies until some months ago.

headline: A.M.C. Proposal
abstract: The American Motors Corporation may seek as much as $500 million to $600 million in state grants to build a new auto plant or refurbish its current facilities in Kenosha, a company vice president, Jerry L. Sloan, said. Without the state aid, the auto maker ''would be forced to locate elsewhere,'' Mr. Sloan said, adding that if the state made such concessions, ''we would be building a new small car in Kenosha.''

headline: Women Advance in Agriculture
abstract: MORE women are studying for jobs in agriculture, in areas ranging from animal production and agricultural business management to horticulture and other specialties.   Dr. Gene Love, associate dean for resident education at Pennsylvania State University's college of agriculture, observes that agriculture is much more than a matter of ''cows and plows.'' Farm production training represents only a small percentage of the activity in schools of agriculture, and these days women are majoring in a variety of areas of agriculture, not just nutrition and food science.   ''There is no question that this is a national trend,'' Dr. Love said, pointing out that 37 percent, or almost 470 students, in the school of agriculture are women these days, highly visible in all except one of 19 specialty areas, such as agronomy, animal science, bioscience and environmental resource management. The big exception is forest science, in which women do not major often.

headline: CHARTING A DIFFERENT KIND OF OUPUT
abstract: PLOTTERS are peripherals unknown to most personal computer users. While tens of millions of printers have been sold since microcomputers started invading the business world, only several hundred thousand plotters - essentially printers for presenting pictorial data - have made their way off the manufacturers' shipping docks. Yet, as overlooked as they might be, plotters have a very definite place in the world of personal computing.   The reason plotters have not become as popular is that word processing, spreadsheet development and data base management still dominate the business use of personal computers. And the input and output for those activities primarily take the form of alphanumeric characters - letters and numbers. To get a hardcopy of the data, the user needs only a fairly traditional printer.

headline: Urban Chinese to Get Raises for Hard Work
abstract: As promised by the Communist Party last October, urban Chinese will get pay increases this month in changes intended to reward hard work and talent.   The official New China News Agency said today that nearly 20 million state workers would receive raises under a new ''structural wage system'' based on four parts.

headline: ISRAELIS FREE 100 MORE DETAINEES FROM LEBANON
abstract: A total of 100 Lebanese and Palestinian prisoners were driven to the Lebanese border and freed today, leaving about 300 others still in Israeli custody, a military spokesman announced.   The detainees were part of a group of more than 700 prisoners, most of them Shiite Moslems, whose release was demanded by the Shiite gunmen who hijacked a Trans World Airlines jetliner last month. The hijackers held 39 Americans hostage for 17 days and murdered a United States Navy diver.   At the time, Israel refused to give in to the hijackers' demands to free the prisoners immediately. Since the T.W.A. hostages were released on June 30, Israel has been taking its time in freeing the remaining detainees in order to emphasize that it was not party to any deal with the hijackers.

headline: TV STATIONS' LURE FOR BUYERS
abstract: Financial data on three television stations being auctioned by ABC and Capital Cities Communications on July 12 provide an unusual insight into why television prices have soared in recent years.   The data, which are being provided by Goldman, Sachs & Company, the investment banker, to potential buyers, include the revenue and cost structure of several Capital Cities' properties as well as the Detroit television station that ABC has decided to sell before the merger.   At three television stations being sold - WTNH in Hartford-New Haven, WXYZ in Detroit and WKBW in Buffalo - the data show consistently high operating margins. Two of those stations - WTNH and WKBW - indicate exceptionally high margins.   ''In the media business, television stations are still the most attractive properties,'' said Martin Pompadur, the managing general partner at Television Station Partners Inc., a company that operates four television stations. ''A buyer knows he is guaranteed steady cash flow to pay off his debt.''

headline: Turner Requests F.C.C To Stop CBS Buyback
abstract: Ted Turner appealed yesterday to the Federal Communications Commission to stop CBS Inc.'s plan to buy nearly $1 billion of its stock.   CBS, which has been fighting a takeover proposed by Turner Broadcasting System, said on Wednesday that it would buy 21 percent of its own stock for $955 million. The purchase would incur substantial debt, increasing the cost of a takeover. Equally important, both the notes and preferred stock that CBS is offering carry limits on the amount of debt the CBS can assume in a merger.

headline: CASTRO, MARKING REVOLUTION, TALKS OF DEBTS
abstract: In a strikingly mild address here tonight marking the 32d anniversary of the beginning of the Cuban revolution, Fidel Castro focused on the Latin American debt crisis and domestic affairs. He referred only obliquely to his old enemy, the United States, and never mentioned it by name.   Of the debt crisis, which has become his main preoccupation in recent months, the Cuban leader said, ''This is a battle for the new economic order in Latin America, a battle for the economic integration of Latin America.''   He has repeatedly said that the way to solve the crisis, in which the Latin American nations owe foreign lenders $360 billion, is for those nations to band together and simply refuse to pay the debt.

headline: MARRIOTT STAKES OUT NEW TERRITORY
abstract: FOR the last decade, things were good for the Marriott Corporation. Few sizable companies in any business can grow at 20 percent year after year, but the aggressive company from the suburbs of the nation's capital made fast growth its credo. Marriott's business hotels sprouted in choice suburban, airport and downtown locations and the company - and its industry - seemed to be on a never-ending growth spiral. But times have changed. The hotel market has become overbuilt and business has slackened. And feisty Marriott, which anticipated many of these changes, is now switching gears within the industry and taking its name where it has never been before.   Next month the doors officially open on the New York Marriott Marquis, a glittering $400 million atrium hotel plunked down in tawdry Times Square. Marriott is going into the convention business in a big way and will spend over $1 billion in a coast-to-coast effort to take on the heavyweight in conventions, the Hilton Hotels Corporation. The first try has not been easy: The Times Square location is not prime territory, and a new convention center nearby, which Marriott was betting on to feed guests into its 1,877-room hotel, is still in construction and far behind schedule. Marriott executives insist that the goliath New York hotel will eventually succeed, but they concede that profits are several years away.

headline: Sybron Board To Study Bid
abstract: Directors of the Sybron Corporation are to meet today to consider a leveraged buyout offer from an investor group that includes top executives of the Rochester-based maker of medical and dental equipment.

headline: INDIA'S SIKHS LOSE A SOURCE OF STABILITY
abstract: The assassination of Harchand Singh Longowal removes a moderating force of stability at a time when it appeared that, thanks in large part to his efforts, a long-festering conflict in the Punjab was finally nearing a solution.   His removal from the scene as head of the Sikh's Akali Dal Party leaves a power vacuum, with no successor in sight and important elections coming up that had promised to consolidate the accord he had reached with Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi only last month.   Sikhism, founded in northern India about 500 years ago, today claims some 15 million believers. About 13 million of them live in India, where they make up 2 percent of the population but exert a far greater influence over India's economy and politics than sheer numbers would suggest.

headline: New Creative Director Is Named by McCann
abstract: Curvin O'Rielly, ace of admen, is returning to the Big Apple to be executive vice president, creative director of McCann-Erickson, New York. He will replace Bruce Nelson, 33 years old, and Ira Madris, 45, already executive vice presidents, who become creative directors of McCann's domestic operation.   Mr. O'Rielly, who is 43, had worked at Young & Rubicam, New York, starting in 1969 and then joined Batten, Barton, Durstine & Osborn before going west to Ogilvy & Mather, where he has been senior vice president and executive creative director.

headline: Iraq Is Buying 45 U.S.-Made Copters
abstract: A White House spokesman confirmed today that Iraq was buying 45 American-made 20-seat helicopters once destined for Iran and said the purchase has been designated a commercial transaction.

headline: Daily Express Bid Wins Clearance
abstract: A takeover bid for the Daily Express newspaper empire built by Lord Beaverbrook has received Government clearance.

headline: Fiber Optic System Halted by Sponsors
abstract: One of the largest and most ambitious attempts to build a nationwide fiber optic communications system was suspended yesterday after the sponsors concluded they had too few customers to begin construction. It was not clear whether the project would be resumed.

headline: LEBANESE SHIITES SEE SYRIAN LEADERS
abstract: Syria's official press agency said today that President Hafez al-Assad had conferred in Damascus with four senior leaders of Lebanon's Shiite fundamentalist group, the Party of God. The report came amid speculation here that the Syrian leader was engaged in new efforts to obtain the release of seven Americans, four Frenchmen and a Briton kidnapped in Moslem West Beirut over the last year and a half.   Mr. Assad's intervention is widely believed to have been a key factor in the release of 39 Americans held hostage on a Trans World Airlines plane that was hijacked to Beirut by Shiite gunmen in June.

headline: JAPANESE SCHOOLS
abstract: To the Editor:   ''Business Schools, Japanese Style'' (Aug. 4) errs in attributing the basis for this nouveau cuisine of management training. After Japan's defeat, the Civil Communications Section (C.C.S.) of General MacArthur's headquarters had the job of re-establishing the electronics industry.

headline: Top China Propagandist Loses His Position
abstract: The Chinese Communist Party's top propagandist, Deng Liqun, who was widely seen as a leading opponent of liberal changes in China, has lost his post, the Foreign Ministry announced today.   The ministry said in a statement that ''Comrade Deng Liqun is no longer the head of the Propaganda Department'' of the Communist Party's Central Committee.

headline: A GAMBLE FOR GANDHI
abstract: Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi, stepping up his efforts to end the turbulence and bloodshed in the Punjab, has begun what associates say might be his most dangerous political gamble since he took office 10 months ago.   Brushing aside warnings from both critics and friends, Mr. Gandhi decided Thursday to proceed with early elections in the Punjab and run the risk of further violence by Sikh terrorists.   Several political leaders had advised him to postpone the vote after the assassination Tuesday of Harchand Singh Longowal, president of the main Sikh political party, the Akali Dal. He was killed less than a month after signing an accord with Mr. Gandhi to end the three years of political strife in the Punjab.

headline: EVENING NEWS EASES STANCE ON SALE
abstract: The Evening News Association, one of the nation's largest communications companies, has permitted its investment bankers to circulate financial data among ''8 to 10'' prospective investors, a source with direct knowledge of the situation said yesterday. The move is regarded by analysts as a significant step toward the sale of the company.
