Salomon Brothers Inc. is circulating a brochure about the private Detroit-based company to a group of major communications companies that are regarded as ''friendly, good managers and good people,'' according to the source, who asked not to be identified.   Communications companies have been hot acquisition properties recently, with prices at record levels. This puts great pressure to sell on companies such as Evening News, whose stock is widely dispersed among several generations of family owners. The company's holdings, which have been valued at between $500 million and $1 billion, include its flagship newspaper, The Detroit News; television stations in Washington, Oklahoma City, Austin, Tex., Mobile, Ala., and Tucson, Ariz.; two Detroit radio stations, and small newspapers in California and New Jersey.

headline: Trying to View Market Future
abstract: WHENEVER the Dow Jones industrial average passes through a round number like 1,300, investors take notice even though market professionals tend to regard such moves as more psychological than meaningful.   Nonetheless, when the Dow fell nearly 11 points on Tuesday, closing at 1,298.16, it underscored the lowered expectations for equities that gradually have been pervading Wall Street. Gone are those forecasts made early this year of a Dow climbing to between 1,400 and 1,500 by December.   Yesterday the industrials edged ahead 2.24, to 1,300.40.

headline: 2 Killed by French Train
abstract: A freight train crashed into a car at a crossing near the central city of Tours today, killing two people and injuring three others, all members of the same family, officials said. The accident occurred at a crossing 140 miles southwest of Paris, after the car was trapped by the automatic crossing gate, the police said.

headline: Globus-Gateway
abstract: Van Brunt & Company may have missed out on Newsday but it did land a new travel account with billings of about $1.5 million.

headline: JAPAN'S MARKET-OPENING PLAN BEGINS
abstract: The Japanese Government today announced a series of measures to counter criticism of its trade practices.   The provisions are intended to relax import procedures, simplify product standards and promote Japanese buying of foreign goods.   At a morning news conference, Japanese officials said the package, to take effect over three years, would make the Japanese market as open as - if not more open than - any other market in the world.   American officials here are not so optimistic, however. One of them, after reviewing a draft of the measures, said they would have no immediate impact on the trade gap. Few of the measures, he added, exceed commitments previously made by Tokyo.

headline: Ex-Broker In Settlement
abstract: A former stockbroker has agreed to forfeit about $160,000 he made from trading securities based on advance information about Wall Street Journal columns, the Securities and Exchange Commission said yesterday.   The settlement was part of a consent agreement under which Kenneth P. Felis neither admitted nor denied charges in an S.E.C. civil complaint brought against him, R. Foster Winans, a former Journal reporter, and others.

headline: Afghan Rebels Report Air Strike by Soviet
abstract: Guerrillas said today that Soviet air strikes in Afghanistan this month killed 23 civilians.

headline: MANVILLE PLAN SEEKS SLASH IN COSTS
abstract: The Manville Corporation, which recently offered to pay $2.5 billion to settle asbestos health claims against the company, is in the midst of a program  to sell or close some operations and slash costs.         Manville filed for reorganization under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy  Act in August 1982 not because of insolvency but in order to deal with mounting  claims against it by workers who said that they had suffered from exposure to asbestos.

headline: Warning on Textiles
abstract: A visiting American Congressman said today that the United States wanted to expand trade with India but might have to cut textile imports because of a slump in the industry in the United States. Representative Sam M. Gibbons, Democrat of Florida, said the United States might be forced to cut textile imports from India by 15 percent next year. He is the head of a nine-member delegation visiting India to discuss trade ties.

headline: 'Jam War' Proclaimed By Sorrell Ridge
abstract: Yesterday morning the Crystal Suite of the Plaza - thanks to the Mayor's water-saving no-pre-10 A.M. air-conditioning ruling - had atmospheric conditions that are probably typical in Southeast Asia. So the four young women wearing brief camouflage fatigues and carrying submachine guns did not look out of place, although Jan Leighton, an actor done up like Gen. George Patton, did.

headline: Portuguese Governor Who Yielded Goa Dies
abstract: Gen. Manuel Antonio Vassalo e Silva, the colonial Governor who defied his Government and surrendered Portuguese India in 1961, died Sunday after a long illness, his family said. He was 86 years old.

headline: CANADA TRIES OIL DECONTROL
abstract: Less than three months after Canada decided to phase out 11 years of control over the oil industry, the effects are beginning to show in lower prices and increased production and exports.   Before June 1, the federal and provincial governments controlled prices, buyers and export levels. The so-called Western Accord between the federal Government and the oil-producing provinces of British Columbia, Alberta and Saskatchewan has put all those functions in the hands of the companies. The agreement, designed to provide oil companies with more cash for exploration and development, deregulated oil prices and began to phase out stiff taxes, among other things.

headline: Berkey's Holders Back Sale of Unit
abstract: Berkey Photo Inc. said shareholders had approved the sale of its film processing group to the Colorcraft Corporation, a unit of Fuqua Industries, for $40 million.

headline: PATENTS;  Sealed Joints Pierced And Greased by Device
abstract: Sealed joints such as those on cars can be pierced and greased by apparatus patented this week by Eldon E. Larson, who lives in Kitsap County, Wash.

headline: Move in Japan On Imports
abstract: A Government panel today instructed Japanese ministries to prepare measures by the end of the month to stimulate demand for foreign goods in an effort to reduce trade surpluses, an official said.   The Japanese have expressed concern that Congress might pass protectionist legislation this month aimed at curbing Japanese exports to the United States.

headline: USING SOVIET GAS TO KEEP OPEC REELING
abstract: TWELVE years ago, OPEC jolted the world economy by curtailing production, raising prices and ushering in the era of limits and high energy prices. Inevitably, consumers curtailed demand. Today, OPEC is producing at less than half of capacity, and Saudi Arabia, OPEC's stoic hero, has reduced its production to a bare quarter of capacity.  The Saudis now threaten to punish their sometime friends by raising production and letting the prices fall where they will. Will the Saudi ploy bring discipline to the unruly oil producer ranks? Or will the Saudis' game of ''oil chicken'' lead to a cascade of price cuts?

headline: TINY LIECHTENSTEIN BASKS IN POPE'S BIG SPOTLIGHT
abstract: This tiny Alpine country, which thrives on anonymity and has reason to believe that small is beautiful, briefly loomed large today because of a visit by Pope John Paul II.   For nearly 10 hours, the Pope made his way across the country's green valleys and spoke in the shadow of craggy mountainsides.   He watched parades of Liechtensteiners in traditional costumes and visited the Vaduz castle, which still dominates this city - there are no skyscrapers - and received the devout homage of the royal family.   He visited a monastery where for 300 years, the faithful could receive a plenary indulgence, a kind of guarantee of safe passage to heaven, by praying on their knees on a Saturday as the bells rang.

headline: Second Mexico Quake Described by Tourists
abstract: Air passengers arriving here from Mexico City today said the second earthquake that hit the capital caused already weakened buildings to collapse and sent people running into the streets for safety.   ''We were completely caught by surprise by the second one,'' said Genie Davis, who said she had volunteered to help Red Cross relief station workers after the second big quake hit the city late Friday.

headline: MUBARAK IN TALKS WITH U.S. OFFICIAL
abstract: The Assistant Secretary of State for Near Eastern and South Asian Affairs, Richard W. Murphy, held what he termed ''useful'' and ''productive'' discussions today with President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt on American efforts to spur Arab-Israeli peace talks.   Mr. Murphy, maintaining a practice he has followed on forays into the Middle East, refused to disclose details of his discussions, either here or in previous meetings on this tour. His first talks were held with King Hussein of Jordan. A day later, he met with Prime Minister Shimon Peres of Israel and other senior Israeli officials.

headline: MURDER OF INDIA M.P. HEATS UP DEBATE OVER SIKHS
abstract: The murder of a popular young Member of Parliament and his wife has jolted the Government of Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi and stirred concern that other politicians might be on a ''hit list'' compiled by Sikh extremists.   The killing has also prompted new recriminations over the role played by well-known politicians in the anti-Sikh rioting that erupted after the assassination of Prime Minister Indira Gandhi last Oct. 31.   The murder occurred Wednesday morning when Lalit Maken, a 34-year-old Member of Parliament, was shot and killed at his home in a middle-class area in western New Delhi. Witnesses said two young gunmen fired at him and then chased him inside the house.

headline: Advertising;   Addenda
abstract: * The Star will increase its circulation rate base 9.4 percent, to 3.5 million, and advertising rates the same percentage, as of the Jan. 7 issue.

headline: 22 RARE DEER ARE RETURNED TO NATIVE GROUND IN CHINA
abstract: More than 120 years after an intrepid French missionary peered into an imperial hunting park here and discovered a breed of deer unknown in the West, a joint enterprise by a British aristocrat and American benefactors has brought the animal back to China.   The Pere David deer - named after Father Armand David, a Lazarist missionary and naturalist who toured China in the 19th century - has been extinct in China since at least 1900. But an Air France plane that arrived here Saturday from Paris brought 22 of the animals back to their native habitat.   The animals were immediately driven to the location 15 miles southwest of Peking where Father David first saw them in 1865. It was then the imperial hunting park of the Manchu emperors, and any unauthorized person killing one of the animals was subject to execution. Now it is farmland worked by peasants, part of it recently enclosed to provide a breeding ground for the deer.

headline: August Imports Fell in Japan
abstract: Japan posted a $3.53 billion trade surplus in August, as its exports continued to increase and its imports kept declining, the Finance Ministry said today.   The surplus was down from Japan's record monthly surplus of $5.02 billion in June and $4.6 billion in July.

headline: Jordanian Diplomat Is Slain in Turkey
abstract: A Jordanian diplomat, Ziad Sati, was shot dead today as he drove to work at the Jordanian Embassy.

headline: China Reminds Tibet Of Takeover in 1965
abstract: China today marked the 20th anniversary of Tibet's designation as an autonomous Chinese region by reiterating Peking's sovereignty and promising prosperity for Tibetans.

headline: CONSUMER RATES
abstract: In percent

headline: POPE IS IN KENYA FOR CHURCH TALKS
abstract: Pope John Paul II arrived here today for a visit that is expected to highlight the controversy over his strong opposition to contraception and sterilization.   In Kenya, the Roman Catholic Church and the country's political leaders have clashed over Government plans to encourage birth control. The Government argues that its 4 percent annual population growth rate, the highest rate in the world, is potentially catastrophic for a country with limited farmland.

headline: CHEAPER LINES BY DESIGNERS
abstract: As Douglas and Jeanne Johns of Baltimore wandered through the Anne Klein II section on the third floor of Lord & Taylor in Manhattan, a black and tan blazer displayed above the racks caught their attention. The price tag said $248. ''Not bad,'' Mr. Johns said to his wife.   In the Anne Klein designer section a few feet away, however, they spotted another jacket of similar design, but in silk rather than wool. There was another difference, too: the $600 price tag. Moreover, to purchase the rest of the designer ensemble, a skirt and blouse complementing the jacket's subtle shading, added more to the cost. ''It would take $2,000 to look right in the jacket,'' said Mrs. Johns.

headline: Georgia Bank's Interstate Deal
abstract: The Citizens and Southern Georgia Corporation said it had signed a definitive agreement to acquire the Citizens and Southern Corporation of South Carolina for about $400 million, or $55 a share.   The Georgia bank had assets of $12.3 billion as of June 30; the South Carolina bank had assets of about $2.5 billion.

headline: CAMBODIA TAKING LARGER WAR ROLE
abstract: Pressed by the Vietnamese to take a more active role in defending their country against attacks from three guerrilla armies, Cambodians are building ''strategic fences,'' planting mines and training ''suicide commandos'' for service on the Thai border, according to officials here.   Civilians, apparently in substantial numbers, are being drafted into border labor groups to supplement the country's 30,000-man army, officials acknowledge. The three guerrilla forces are thought to total more than double that number - the war against them has been waged mostly by about 160,000 Vietnamese troops.   A Cambodian Communist Party official told reporters this week that it was now the ''duty'' of citizens of Phnom Penh, a city of 500,000, to go to the border to aid in the clearing of land and the construction of trenches, bamboo fences and other defensive barriers.

headline: Mormon Team Goes To O.&M.
abstract: IN this town, the capital of world advertising, an agency changing its creative director is a fairly routine happening. But what has happened at Ogilvy & Mather Partners under the recently established leadership of Jeffrey W. Woll, managing director, has all the earmarks of a truly unusual event.   He has not only hired Gordon S. Bowen, 35 years old, to be executive creative director, but he has also hired four Bowen associates. A package deal.

headline: Lord, Geller, Federico Promoting Health Plan
abstract: Lord, Geller, Federico, Einstein is one of the few New York agencies blessed with a Boca Raton, Fla., office.

headline: SMITHSONIAN VOTES AGAINST DIVESTING
abstract: A sharply divided board of regents of the Smithsonian Institution declined today to sell the institution's stock in companies that do business in South Africa.   The stock is worth $34 million, about a quarter of the institution's portfolio, but the action was closely watched because of the makeup of the regents board. It includes the Chief Justice and Vice President of the United States, three members of the Senate, three members of the House, the president of Princeton University, a former United States Ambassador to Britain and corporate and civic leaders.   At a briefing for reporters after the meeting, the secretary of the Smithsonian, Robert McC. Adams, said all of the regents had expressed abhorrence at apartheid, the South African policy of racial separation, but offered widely differing suggestions about what the Smithsonian ought to do to express that opposition.

headline: Harvard Investment
abstract: Harvard University is considering selling its $5 million investment in the Philip Morris Companies because of concerns that product-liability suits against cigarette companies could lower the stock's value, a school official said. The university has sold stock in other tobacco companies, including American Brands, Brown & Williamson and R. J. Reynolds. The review is ''not being conducted from the standpoint that tobacco stocks are immoral or wrong,'' said Walter Cabot, president of the Harvard Management Company, which oversees the university's $3 billion endowment.

headline: DEMOCRACY IN TURKEY: SOME PROGRESS IS MADE, BUT BARRIERS REMAIN
abstract: Five years after a military coup, the Turkish Government has reinstated important aspects of parliamentary democracy, but serious restrictions on civil rights continue to make the country lag behind its Western allies.   Opposition politicians, both in and out of Parliament, openly express vigorous opposition toward the policies of Prime Minister Turgut Ozal. Mr. Ozal himself was elected two years ago even though President Kenan Evren, a general who led the coup on Sept. 12, 1980, favored another candidate.   Former Prime Ministers Suleiman Demirel on the center-right and Bulent Ecevit on the center-left, Turkey's most respected political leaders, are active behind the scenes, even though they are barred from political roles.   And the press, according to editors of the most outspoken newspapers and periodicals, feels increasingly free to express criticism. Many Turks say they have begun to take pleasure again in the spirit of their newspapers after years of uniform, uncritical blandness.

headline: Saatchi Begins Link With Istanbul Firm
abstract: Saatchi & Saatchi Compton Worldwide announced that, effective Sept. 1, it will enter into an exclusive associate arrangement with a major advertising agency in Turkey, Guzel Sanatlar.

headline: BRITISH SOLDIERS HURT IN BLAST
abstract: Six British soldiers were wounded in an explosion during a military exercise at Schwarmstedt, 25 miles southwest of Verden, last night, a British army spokesman said today.

headline: SOUTH AFRICAN BLACKS BOYCOTTING WHITES' STORES
abstract: For a fourth successive day, thousands of blacks boycotted white-run shops in the restive Eastern Cape today, in a rare spillage of black protest into white areas.   In black townships near this Indian Ocean port today, streets were blocked and littered with garbage and debris, put there as roadblocks by young vigilantes enforcing the boycott by searching home-bound cars and destroying any clothes or groceries bought in white shops.   White civic officials called the impact of the boycott, which is set to last for two months, ''desperately urgent'' while its black organizers - one of whom was reportedly detained briefly by the police today - said the action had resulted in a total suspension of black trade in shops owned or operated by whites.   Elsewhere, the police used tear gas in Soweto, southwest of Johannesburg, to disperse 1,000 high school students demonstrating in sympathy with victims of recent unrest east of the city, while thousands of workers in Pietermaritzburg, in Natal, were reported staying away from work to protest dismissals.

headline: Haiti Says 99.9% Backed President in Referendum
abstract: At least 99.9 percent of the electorate approved President Jean-Claude Duvalier's life term in office in a referendum this week, the Government said Friday.

headline: Business and Health;   Profit Squeeze In Home Care
abstract: HOME health care seems to be an idea whose time has come, at least for health planners and hundreds of thousands of patients. But for many of the thousands of health agencies and companies crowding the marketplace, business has been disappointing.   Home care is the fastest-growing slice of the nation's $400 billion health sector. The money and the customers are there and growing. Yet profit margins are squeezed by powerful forces, starting with the main payer, the Federal Government. Medicare expects to spend $2.3 billion for home health care this year, up 14.7 percent from 1984. But it is turning the screws to limit what will be paid for.

headline: Iraq Says Its Troops Killed 478 Iranians
abstract: Iraq said its forces killed 478 Iranian soldiers and wounded many others today in a dawn commando attack on a mountain on the northern war front.

headline: Times Mirror
abstract: The Times Mirror Company said that about 22.9 million shares had already been tendered under its offer to repurchase 7.5 million shares, or 10.9 percent of its common stock outstanding, for $60 each.

headline: Bailout Plan for EPIC Gets Mixed Reactions
abstract: The reactions yesterday to the Ticor Mortgage Insurance Company's bailout plan for the ailing EPIC group of real estate and mortgage companies were mixed. While saying the plan made a good start, some of the participants, who asked not to be named, said that any ''work out'' will require more cash payments by Ticor and the other private mortgage insurers involved with EPIC's $1.4 billion in mortgages.   But the participants generally agreed that, since the mortgages are likely to be in default soon, time is of the essence. ''If a work out is not arrived at very soon, then you will probably lose the opportunity for an orderly solution,'' said a lawyer representing one of the financial institutions involved in the complex case.

headline: SPY REPORTEDLY FLED AFTER SOVIET CALL
abstract: A summons to return to Moscow for consultation prompted the head of the K.G.B. in Britain to seek asylum in a ''safe house'' in the south of England in July, according to a senior British official.   The official said the K.G.B. man, Oleg A. Gordiyevsky, feared that after more than 15 years as a double agent for Britain and the K.G.B., the Soviet intelligence agency, his superiors had learned about his role and that on his return to Moscow he would face interrogation, probably under torture, and inevitably execution.   The official compared the Gordiyevsky case to that of Arkady Shevchenko, a senior Russian bureaucrat at the United Nations who says he supplied intelligence to the Central Intelligence Agency for 32 months. Mr. Shevchenko was also called home for consultation, and, suspecting that his espionage had been discovered, defected to the United States.   On Thursday, when Mr. Gordiyevsky's defection was announced, the British Government ordered 25 Soviet diplomats, journalists and others to leave the country, saying they had engaged in activities incompatible with their status and jobs - diplomatic parlance for spying. The Soviet Government responded Saturday by ordering 25 British diplomats, businessmen, journalists and others to leave the Soviet Union, accusing them of ''impermissible activity.''

headline: Honeywell Net Off 29%
abstract: Honeywell Inc. announced today that net income for the second quarter was $52.5 million, or $1.14 a share, down 29 percent from the $74.3 million, or $1.59 a share, earned in the same period a year ago. The company attributed the decline to the downturn in the computer industry and a weakness in the capital spending markets. Revenue was $1.55 billion, up from $1.47 billion.

headline: OFFICIALS SAY F.B.I. INSISTED PRESSER PAY 'GHOST WORKERS'
abstract: After authorizing Jackie Presser to put people who did no work on the teamsters' union payroll, agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation several times rejected his requests for permission to dismiss them, law-enforcement officials said today.   The disclosure by the officials, who asked not to be identified, is the first time authorities have acknowledged the extent of the F.B.I.'s participation in practices that were later the focus of a lengthy criminal investigation by the Labor Department.      Case Dropped Last Month    Last month, the Justice Department dropped the case against Mr. Presser, the president of the teamsters, after officials learned that F.B.I. agents had permitted him to commit the labor law violations with which he had been charged. Investigators at the Justice Department and in Congress are trying to determine why prosecutors did not learn the details of the F.B.I.'s relationship with Mr. Presser until several years after the investigation of the union leader had begun.

headline: Dunes Subsidiary
abstract: Dunes Hotels and Casinos Inc. said that its subsidiary, M & R Investments Inc., had not made a $527,000 monthly interest payment on a $68.6 million loan from Valley Bank of Nevada.

headline: TREASURY REPLIES
abstract: To the Editor:   Congressman Al Swift's article (''Fed, Not Treasury, Should Take the Lead,'' Forum, Aug. 4) seriously misrepresents the position of the United States Treasury on the question of legislation to regulate the government securities market.   Mr. Swift suggests that the Treasury is opposed to further regulation of that market. In fact, in my June 20 statement before his subcommittee, I presented Treasury's specific proposal for expanded regulation and stated that, after completion of its studies, Treasury is prepared to request any needed legislation to implement its proposal. On July 26, Secretary Baker stated in letters to Senators Garn and D'Amato, that the Treasury is preparing legislation for submission to Congress soon and that the Administration is ''firmly committed'' to this proposal.

headline: Semiconductor Shipments Up
abstract: Semiconductor shipments increased slightly during August, while there was a small drop in orders, the Semiconductor Industry Association said yesterday.   A key indicator of the beleaguered industry's health, the book-to-bill ratio, was 0.74, up from 0.72 in July.

headline: PATENTS;  Microwave Scalpel Aids Instant Blood-Clotting
abstract: A surgical scalpel that uses microwave energy to produce instant blood-clotting was patented this week by Leonard S. Taylor, an electrical engineer at the University of Maryland.

headline: GOLDSMITH LIFTS CROWN STAKE
abstract: Sir James Goldsmith, continuing his takeover battle with management of the Crown Zellerbach Corporation, increased his interest in the San Francisco-based forest-products company yesterday to more than 40 percent.   Analysts said that the financier was now in a position to forestall a company restructuring proposal he opposes. Ownership of 40 percent gives him the right to call a special stockholder meeting in his attempt to stop the restructuring.

headline: Dow Off by 7.05 In Profit Taking
abstract: News of weaker than expected economic growth in the second quarter touched off a bout of profit taking yesterday on Wall Street, pushing stock prices down after two consecutive big gains.   The Dow Jones industrial average retreated 7.05 points, to 1,350.92. The Dow had closed at new highs two times this week and had risen a total of 22.5 points in the previous two sessions.

headline: IN TUNISIA, NO. 2 IS CHAMPING AT THE BIT TO BE NO. 1
abstract: He has been at the epicenter of Tunisia's continuing tensions with Libya, standing up to Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, meeting with Arab leaders abroad, moving against unions at home.   He is pictured daily on the front pages, and his writings seem to sprout in bookshop windows, though careful never to outnumber those by the ''Supreme Combatant,'' Tunisia's President for Life, Habib Bourguiba.   This second man is Mr. Bourguiba's designated successor, Prime Minister Mohammed Mzali. And while no one is accusing him of fabricating the more than 30,000 Tunisians who have been evicted from Libya in recent weeks, even the Prime Minister's associates breezily admit he has used the crisis to consolidate his position.

headline: Hill, Holliday, Connors Gets Newsday Account
abstract: Newsday, long a Long Island newspaper, has retained an ad agency for the first time and that agency is the New York office of Hill, Holliday, Connors, Cosmopolus.

headline: MARYLAND THRIFT UNIT CLOSING FOR TWO DAYS
abstract: The troubled Community Savings and Loan Association of Bethesda, Md., closed its nine offices yesterday for what it said would be two days of a cooling-off period after a three-day run by depositors.   The temporary closing, which came at the insistence of Community Savings' executives, followed Monday's order by Maryland's Gov. Harry R. Hughes for a 20-day moratorium on withdrawals from the thrift institution. The run was precipitated by reports of financial trouble at a Community Savings subsidiary that arranges real estate syndications. The institution's officials said they were concerned that not all depositors would have heard about the moratorium.

headline: UGANDA LEADER REPORTEDLY OUT IN ARMY COUP
abstract: President Milton Obote of Uganda was overthrown today in a bloodless military coup, according to radio reports from the Ugandan capital and other sources in that East African country.   A second lieutenant in the 14,000-member army, who identified himself as Walter Lacuru, said in a broadcast monitored here that the takeover had been led by Brig. Basilio Olara Okello.   Brigadier Okello commands the army brigade in the country's northern region, where a rebellion by soldiers Friday dramatically underscored a tribal split within the army.      Obote Said to Flee to Kenya    Diplomatic sources in Nairobi said Mr. Obote had crossed the border into neighboring Kenya today. His wife, Miria, who had been attending the United Nations women's conference here, left today in a three-car convoy to Kakamega, in Kenya's Western Province near the Ugandan border, where she reportedly met her husband.

headline: Carlsberg Bought
abstract: The Carlsberg Corporation, a real estate financial management service, said it had agreed to merge with the Southmark Corporation for about $55 million in cash and preferred stock. Southmark, a real estate investment concern in Dallas, said each Carlsberg share would be exchanged for $5.50 in cash and $5.50 in market value of adjustable-rate preferred stock. Carlsberg said the Dallas concern would issue about 575,000 shares of the preferred stock and pay about $28 million in cash.

headline: 24 Are Reported Dead In Philippine Battles
abstract: At least 24 people were killed and 35 wounded in separate battles involving Communist guerrillas in the southern Philippines in the last two days, military spokesmen said today.

headline: Oklahoma Power Agency
abstract: The Oklahoma Municipal Power Authority yesterday made its debut in the public bond market, with a $167.7 million offering of electric revenue bonds through underwriters led by Prudential-Bache Securities Inc.   The financing included 9 5/8 percent bonds due in 2023 tentatively priced at 99 1/2 to yield 9.673 percent.

headline: FRANCE DENOUNCES U.S. AMBASSADOR
abstract: The French Foreign Ministry today protested what it called the ''unacceptable character'' of comments on French politics made to a newspaper by the departing United States Ambassador, Evan Galbraith.   The protest, which was made to the American charge d'affairs, John Maresca, followed the publication today in the rightist daily Figaro of an interview given by Mr. Galbraith on July 8.   Mr. Galbraith, who left Monday, was quoted as having said that the governing Socialists were likely to lose their parliamentary majority in the elections next year and that the Communist Party was ''sort of outside the law'' and should not be allowed to participate in the Government, as it did from 1981 to 1984.

headline: Scientists Started in '67 On Squibb's Prize Drug
abstract: The heroes at the Squibb Corporation these days are the two men who invented a drug that promises to become one of the leading medications for treating high blood pressure. But Miguel A. Ondetti, vice president for preclinical cardiovascular research at Squibb, and David W. Cushman, assistant director of the company's department of pharmacology, are trying not to let their celebrity status go to their heads.   ''In a couple of days, people will ask us what we're going to do next,'' joked Dr. Ondetti in a telephone interview from Squibb's headquarters in Princeton, N.J.   The drug that the two men invented, captopril, was long in the making. Introduced four years ago, the medicine, which sells under the brand name Capoten, could be used in the United States only to treat people with severe hypertension and severe congestive heart failure and those who did not respond to other remedies.

headline: REALIST HERO: THE RUSSIANS MOURN A POET
abstract: They gathered at the cemetery again last week in the rain, thousands of Russians carrying bouquets, sheaves of poems and tape recorders from which a gruff, urgent voice sang of the ironies and hardships of their lives.   People who had never met him or heard him sing during his lifetime exchanged fond stories about this hard-living, hard-drinking man and scribbled down the lyrics of his songs.   It was the fifth anniversary of the death of the actor and bard Vladimir Vysotsky, a man whose songs were barely tolerated by authorities during his lifetime and who has become, since his death at the age of 42, probably the most idolized figure in the Soviet Union today.   As it has each year, the line at the Vagankovskoye Cemetery stretched along the graveyard's yellow plaster wall, around the corner on 1905 Street and toward a railway overpass.

headline: Orders Up in Germany
abstract: The West German economy is growing briskly, despite nagging unemployment, the Government said today. Orders to the nation's factories rose 4.5 percent in July from June. The unemployment rate dipped to 8.9 percent in August from 9 percent in July.

headline: A MACHINE-TOOL DYNASTY
abstract: In this small rural town in central Japan lies the plant of one of the largest machine-tool manufacturers in the world, Okuma Machinery Works Ltd. The company started up 87 years ago when its founder invented a simple lathe, and its rise tells a great deal about how Japan grew to dominate this industry.   The company's president, Takeo Okuma - a blunt and earthy patriarch at 75 years of age - credits his company's ascent to advanced technological prowess and old-fashioned family-style labor relations. In the fiscal year ended March 31, 1985, the family-run company recorded a net income of $14 million on sales of $394.5 million. Although other machine-tool companies listed on the Tokyo Stock Exchange are more profitable, Okuma leads in sales, analysts say.

headline: Texas Steps Up Pace Of Tax-Exempt Issues
abstract: Local governments in Texas are accounting for an unusually large portion of the record amount of new tax-exempt bonds being issued by local governments across the country.   Officials in Texas, like those elsewhere, are eager to refund their outstanding bonds on more advantageous terms before Congress approves revisions to Federal tax law that would sharply restrict such financings in the future.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: * Bausch & Lomb Inc., Rochester, said it reached an agreement with Canon USA, a subsidiary of Canon Inc., to be the exclusive North American distributor of Canon manufactured autorefractors and autokerameters. Terms of the agreement were not disclosed.

headline: Market Place;   Gains Foreseen In Fiber Optics
abstract: DESPITE last week's announcement that construction of Fibertrak, one of the largest fiber-optics communications networks in America, was being put on hold, Wall Street analysts remain bullish about the companies that make optical fiber and related equipment.   ''You have an industry that today is capacity constrained and that will stay that way for at least the next year,'' said Frederick D. Ziegel, an analyst at Salomon Brothers Inc.   Jay W. Killea of Montgomery Securities Inc. added, ''I'm still very optimistic about that side of the business. The outlook for the fiber-optics suppliers is real bright.''

headline: $246 Million Issue Of Texas Bonds
abstract: A $246 million issue of San Antonio general obligation bonds was tentatively offered yesterday with a maximum yield of 9.02 percent for 8 3/4 percent bonds due in 2010, which underwriters led by Dillon, Read priced at 97 1/4.   Among shorter maturities, the bonds were tentatively priced with yields ranging from 4.75 percent in 1986 to 8.70 percent in 2000.

headline: The U.N. Today: July 3, 1985
abstract: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Ad Hoc Committee on the Indian Ocean - 10:30 A.M.

headline: Penn Central in Deal With Holden
abstract: The Penn Central Corporation said it had combined certain energy-related subsidiaries and assets valued at about $130 million with the closely held Holden Corporation. The assets are Penn Central's exploration and production subsidiary, its four onshore drilling units and certain receivables held by the drilling units.   In exchange, Penn Central has received 70 percent of Holden's common stock, $22.5 million in preferred stock of a new Holden energy unit and four-year warrants to buy an additional 4 percent of the Holden unit's common stock.

headline: Bonn Reported to Face 'Serious' Spy Scandal
abstract: A West German Cabinet minister's aide who disappeared early this month was a spy planted in the mid-1950's by the East German secret service, the D.P.A. news agency reported today.   The news agency, which reported last Friday that suspicion of espionage had hardened against the aide, quoted sources today as saying the aide had access to state secrets and that Bonn faces ''a serious espionage scandal.''

headline: COMPRESSION LABS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: AUDITOR QUALIFIES REPORT ON PLAYBOY
abstract: Playboy Enterprises Inc., publisher of Playboy magazine, said yesterday that its auditor, Price Waterhouse & Company, would not give Playboy's annual report its full blessing because of uncertainties over Playboy's ability to collect on a $37.9 million note.   The note is the balance due on the sale of Playboy's 45.7 percent interest last year in an Atlantic City casino, renamed the Atlantis.   Explaining Price Waterhouse's qualified opinion of its fiscal year ended June 30, 1985, Playboy said that it had sold its interest to the Elsinore Corporation, controlled by the Pritzker family of Chicago, for $7.6 million in cash, six annual notes amounting to $45.3 million and $5.6 million in management fees due by 1990. Playboy said it received its first note last April and that the next was not due until next April.

headline: CITY'S RETAIL SALES UP 3.9%
abstract: New York City retail sales rose 3.9 percent in August from a year earlier, and sales in the metropolitan area were up 7 percent, according to a spot-check of seven large retailers.   The city results, while not sharply better than 1984, represented the best trend since February, while the suburban stores had their biggest average gain in a year.   The improvement was not evident at all the reporting retailers. Two registered declines from the year before in both the city and the area, and two others in the city had gains slightly below the average. However, three companies had year-to-year rises well above the average in both city stores and suburban branches.

headline: BRITISH-SOVIET OUSTERS
abstract: As the dust settled on the six-day diplomatic shootout between Britain and the Soviet Union over charges of espionage, the most striking aspect was Moscow's resolute and unexpectedly sharp reaction.   The initial appraisal among Western diplomats was that Mikhail S. Gorbachev had no choice but to respond with toughness to the British announcement last Thursday that the top Soviet spy in London had defected and had exposed a large number of agents among Russians posted there.   Britain's Ambassador here, Sir Bryan Cartledge, said that the 31 Britons ultimately ordered to leave the Soviet Union were ''innocent victims of retaliation'' against Britain's expulsion of ''31 incontrovertibly identified Soviet intelligence agents.''   In the past, when Soviet agents abroad were exposed and sent home, the Soviet Union usually reacted quietly, evidently finding it more expedient to avoid a crisis and to return to business-as-usual as soon as possible.

headline: President Chosen In ITT Reshuffling
abstract: The ITT Corporation, the subject of merger and takeover rumors in recent months, said yesterday that Edmund M. Carpenter had been elected president and chief operating officer. Mr. Carpenter, who is 43 years old, joined ITT as an executive vice president in 1981.   The appointment was one of several announced by Rand V. Araskog, ITT's chairman and chief executive.   DeRoy C. Thomas, 59, senior executive in charge of the company's services operations, and M. Cabell Woodward Jr., 56, chief financial officer, were named vice chairmen.

headline: President Named At Home Loan Unit
abstract: The Federal Home Loan Bank of New York said yesterday that Brian D. Dittenhafer had been named president and chief operating officer, an appointment that was confirmed by the Federal Home Loan Bank Board in Washington.   Mr. Dittenhafer, who is 43 years old, has served as acting president since July 2, following the death of Bryce Curry. Mr. Curry had been president of the bank, which has $9.5 billion in assets, for the last 22 years.   In addition to his posts at the bank, Mr. Dittenhafer was named principal supervisory agent for the Federal Home Loan Bank Board. In that post, he will be responsible for the examination, supervision and enforcement of Federal regulations governing all federally chartered thrift institutions in the Second Federal Home Loan Bank District, an area that encompasses New York, New Jersey, Puerto Rico and the United States Virgin Islands.

headline: No Headline
abstract: Companies Carl C. Icahn won control of T.W.A. The New York investor told the S.E.C. he has 50.3 percent of the company's shares, putting him in charge of the nation's fourth-largest airline. In addition, sources close to the situation said that Texas Air, Mr. Icahn's rival for T.W.A., had withdrawn its merger proposal, removing the largest potential block to his smooth assumption of control. Labor unions, which had feared a takeover by Texas Air, played an important role in the two-month-long struggle over the airline. [Page 31.]  Union Carbide officials accepted full blame for a gas leak two weeks ago at an Institute, W.Va., plant. The company said there were violations of plant procedures by workers. [A1.]  Unocal plans to refinance the $4.1 billion in debt that it took on in fighting off the takeover attempt by T. Boone Pickens. The company will buy back the notes it issued to shareholders, transferring the debt to banks and other investors at a lower interest rate. [31.]  Forstmann Little and Warner Communications ended their MTV talks. Forstmann had twice extended the deadline on its $470 million offer for Warner's share of the music video service. Talks with other bidders are expected, with Viacom being mentioned most prominently. [31.]  Manville can sue the Government to recover some asbestos damages the company paid, a Federal judge ruled. The ruling in the case of an injured naval shipyard worker may be an important step in Manville's efforts to get the Government to help pay the huge asbestos claims it faces.

headline: Spain's Ambassador Is Killed in Zimbabwe
abstract: Spain's Ambassador to Zimbabwe was beaten to death and left nearly naked on a road outside Harare, authorities and diplomats said today.   Zimbabwe's Foreign Ministry said the circumstances of the death of the Ambassador, Jose Luis Blanco Briones, were unclear, but he pledged to bring the killers to justice.   Officials said that Mr. Briones, a 50-year-old career diplomat, attended a dinner for Spanish residents in the northwestern Harare area of Mount Pleasant on Sunday night and that his body was found at about 6 A.M. today.

headline: FREE TRADE
abstract: To the Editor:   In spite of Mr. Culbertson's remarks that manufacturing processes are about the same all over the world, this is not so. It is conceded that the steel and automobile industries here, for example, are obsolete and inefficient as compared to foreign producers, and their labor is the highest priced in the world and over twice the average in America.

headline: City Employees of Liverpool Strike Over Spending Curbs
abstract: A one-day strike today by employees of this near-bankrupt city to protest spending curbs imposed by the Government shut down City Hall, kept thousands of children out of school and curtailed other services.

headline: GUADELOUPE FARE: GOOD FOOD, FINE WINE, BOMBS
abstract: The handful of revolutionaries on this French island, who feel that Guadeloupe should become independent like most other Caribbean islands, have got their work cut out for them.   The per capita income here is $5,000 a year - two or three times times higher than on most neighboring islands, five times higher than on some. There is free and compulsory French education and excellent, subsidized medical care. The housing is substantial and the roads are well maintained. The people eat well and, according to Government officials, they are among the highest consumers of champagne in the world.

headline: Ulster Protestants March In a Catholic District
abstract: More than 1,000 soldiers and policemen sealed the route of a Protestant parade through a Roman Catholic neighborhood of this market town today.

headline: SOVIET AND CHINA SIN FIVE-YEAR TRADE PACT
abstract: The Soviet Union and China agreed today to almost double trade over the next five years, a move that diplomats assessed as a notable step in the revival of relations.   The Tass press agency said that Yao Yilin, a Chinese Deputy Prime Minister, and Ivan V. Arkhipov, a Soviet First Deputy Prime Minister, had signed an accord under which the volume of trade is projected to reach $3.5 billion by 1990. It is expected to be $1.8 billion in the current year.   In 1982, before relations began to improve, exchanges between the two countries were down to $300 million.

headline: BILL PROPOSE 25% DUTY AGAINST JAPAN, 3 OTHERS
abstract: Legislation that would impose a 25 percent duty on goods from Japan and three other countries was introduced today in both houses of Congress by three senior Democrats. It drew an oblique veto threat from the Administration.   The bills, aimed at reducing this nation's growing trade deficit, would penalize major exporters to the United States that are deemed to maintain unfair trade barriers. The target countries, at least initially, are Japan, Brazil, South Korea and Taiwan, all of which run substantial trade surpluses with the United States.

headline: FOREIGN BANKS EAGER FOR DEBT TALKS WITH PERU
abstract: Western banks seem eager to start debt talks with Peru's new Government despite its decision to turn its back on the International Monetary Fund and limit debt payments over the next year to just 10 percent of export earnings.   Foreign bankers said a 12-bank advisory committee had been encouraged by the Government's initial moves to control Peru's chaotic economic situation and was now awaiting the appointment of a debt negotiator so that a time and place for the talks can be set.   The bankers, who asked not to be identified, said they were taking a ''wait-and-see'' attitude, but some financial experts believe their very willingness to discuss Peru's conditions for restructuring its $14 billion foreign debt suggested a readiness to be flexible.   ''The reaction of the banks has been prudent and intelligent,'' President Alan Garcia Perez noted in a recent interview. ''They're giving Peru the benefit of the doubt and are not condemning us a priori. We have made a practical suggestion that can be handled practically.''

headline: FREE TRADE
abstract: To the Editor:   In ''Free Trade Is Impoverishing the West'' (July 28), John Culbertson asserts that lower foreign wage rates do not offer a ''comparative advantage'' or improved efficiency.   To dismiss any portion of a national industry's cost structure is ludicrous. To dismiss wages as a legitimate cost element is absurd. Economists who think the acceptance of a lower standard of living via lower wages doesn't offer at least an interim competitive advantage are removed from the real world. R. BRUECKNER Bridgewater, N.J., Aug. 4

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: Armstrong World Industries, Lancaster, Pa., said it had reached a preliminary agreement to buy Dixie Yarns Inc.'s Chatsworth, Ga., yarn spinning plant for use in producing tufted carpet. Terms were not disclosed.

headline: WHAT'S NEW IN ECONOMIC HISTORY
abstract: TO an economist, defining ''money'' these days is a challenge, given the near-daily creation of new financial instruments. But imagine the situation back in colonial America: Until 1738 Massachusetts accepted corn, beef and hemp in payment of income taxes. Figuring out the size of the money supply - when was food just food, and when was it money? - and estimating its impact on inflation during that period make interpreting M-1 or M-2 look like child's play.

headline: Scott & Fetzer, Kelso Deal Off
abstract: The Scott & Fetzer Company said yesterday that it had ended an agreement with Kelso & Company, the New York investment firm that had unsuccessfully tried to organize a $440 million leveraged buyout.   Ralph Schey, chief executive of Scott & Fetzer, said the termination of the agreement would release the company from restrictions preventing solicitation of new proposals and that other possible transactions would be considered.

headline: Advertising;   More Than Yuppies in Baby Boom
abstract: SO you know all you want to know about yuppies, but what about so-called workers, elite workers and would be's who make up the rest of the 21-to-39 age group bulge known as the baby boomers.   They are all part of a recently completed study of the national population by J. Walter Thompson U.S.A., entitled ''The New American Consumer.'' It covers the entire scene of spenders, from teens through 59-year-olds and up, but ignores the poor, who advertisers do not consider of interest as a target audience.   The results of the study come from already existing data as well as from original consumer research conducted by the agency. It will help the agency and its clients to better fashion advertising messages and better select the media to carry them.

headline: Tom Williams Is Dead at 99; Was World War I Flying Ace
abstract: Tom Williams, a World War I flying ace who was a founding member of the Royal Canadian Air Force, died in a hospital here today. He was 99 years old.

headline: Ladbroke Buys Rodeway Inns
abstract: The Ladbroke Group P.L.C., a British-based hotel, realty and racing concern, said that it had acquired Rodeway Inns International, which runs a chain of 138 franchised hotels in the United States, for $13 million.   Ladbroke said that $7 million of the purchase price would be deferred without interest for three years and that additional payments of 12.5 percent of adjusted profits will be made for the next five years. Ladbroke said it intended to expand Rodeway's franchise system rapidly.

headline: PATENTS;  Hepatitis Virus Isolated, Raising Vaccine Hopes
abstract: The Department of Health and Human Services received a patent this week that indicates progress has been made toward the development of a hepatitis vaccine. Hepatitis is a serious public health problem.

headline: Patents;  Controlling A Craft on Autopilot
abstract: AN invention that enables a pilot to control a helicopter or other aircraft whose flight is being regulated by a mechanical autopilot was patented this week for the Rockwell International Corporation of El Segundo, Calif.

headline: A QUIET ACQUISITOR IS CAUGHT IN A CROSS FIRE
abstract: AS Mohamed al-Fayed talks of his family's prized possessions, such as Harrods, this city's legendary department store, or the Ritz Hotel in Paris, he is an effusive and joyous man. But when a visitor to his elegant Mayfair penthouse residence overlooking Hyde Park turns the discussion to his friends, his family background and the scope of the family fortune, affability fades from the face of the 53-year-old Egyptian patriarch. He rustles impatiently in the deep cushions of his chair and, although the politeness is unfailing, he becomes tense. Such questions have become the bane of Mr. al-Fayed's existence.   Last March, Mr. al-Fayed and his two younger brothers, Ali and Salah, made news when they mounted a management-supported bid for control of the House of Fraser P.L.C., acquiring the retailing empire, including its jewel, Harrods, for $842 million. This was a dream come true for the family, which built its fortune in real estate, shipping, construction and banking - first in the oil-rich countries of the Persian Gulf, then in Europe and, more recently, the United States.   Unlike many high-flying deal makers, however, Mr. al-Fayed treasures his privacy and tries to keep his family from the limelight. To the general public, the Fayeds were known, if at all, for their lavish restoration of the Ritz Hotel since acquiring it in 1979, and a major role in financing the Oscar-winning film, ''Chariots of Fire.''

headline: Levi Strauss
abstract: Levi Strauss & Company said that the HHF Corporation and a group of 10 banks headed by Wells Fargo Bank N.A. had entered into a $1.45 billion credit agreement for the financing of a leveraged buyout of the San Francisco-based apparel manufacturer. The agreement is part of a previously announced offer by Robert D. Haas, president and chief executive, and other members of the company's founding family to take the company private.

headline: Mass Transit
abstract: To the Editor:   In ''Can Entrepreneurs Save Mass Transit?'' (Forum, May 26), Ralph Stanley missed the point: Except for pipelines and some of the rail freight comnpanies, private unsubsidized transportation does not exist in America. How can private enterprise compete against the tremendous hidden subsidies that are lavished on the airlines and motor vehicle users?

headline: THE OTHER TAX PLAN IS UNVEILED AT LAST
abstract: Dan Rostenkowski countered President Reagan's tax proposal with one that would be more favorable to low- and middle-income taxpayers. The long-awaited proposal from Mr. Rostenkowski, the Illinois Democrat who is chairman of the House Ways and Means panel, followed the outline of the President's proposal, but included a higher corporate tax rate and permits partial deduction of state and local taxes where the President would allow none. Mr. Rostenkowski's plan was called more realistic than the President's by several legislators, but many say it will face some of the same hurdles.   The dollar took a dive in frantic trading after the financial ministers of the five major industrial nations said they would put pressure on the currency. But as the week progressed, some traders became skeptical that the Group of Five's actions would be significant, and the dollar regained some of its value. The Group of Five's agreement apparently was directed particularly at raising the value of the Japanese yen.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: * Atlantic Richfield Co., Los Angeles, said it had completed the sale of its 27 percent interest in Alumina Partners of Jamaica, an refinery in southwest Jamaica, to Kaiser Aluminum and Chemical Corp. and Reynolds Metals Co. Terms were not disclosed.

headline: PERU DEBT-PAYMENT CAP IS AN IMPORTANT SYMBOL
abstract: Peru has thrown down the gauntlet, challenging its creditors by becoming the first major country to take unilateral action to cap its debt payments to foreign banks.      The move, which President Alan   Garcia Perez announced in his inaugural address on Sunday, is important mostly as a symbol and a precedent. For international banks, the worry is not so much that Peru might not pay its debts - it already is months in arrears - but that other, bigger debtors like Brazil or Mexico might get ideas.   No one thinks that other countries will follow Peru's lead very soon, limiting payments on foreign debt to a percentage of export earnings. But it is a fashionable idea in some Latin circles that countries should bargain harder with the banks and not accept cuts in living standards so that New York banks can report higher earnings. Mr. Garcia's statements reinforced this view.

headline: G.E. BAN IS LIFTED
abstract: The Air Force said it had lifted a suspension on awarding contracts to the General Electric Company's missile re-entry systems operation. The Air Force said the ban had been lifted because of G.E.'s cooperation with the Government on weeding out and reporting past violations of Government procurement regulations. G.E. was suspended from doing business with the Government in March after a Federal grand jury in Philadelphia indicted the company on charges of defrauding the Government. The suspension was narrowed to the re-entry division in July.

headline: ETHIOPIA RETAKES TOWN FROM ERITREAN REBELS
abstract: A strategic town held by Eritrean rebels for two months has been recaptured by the Ethiopian Army, according to both the rebels and the Ethiopian Government.   But the two sides both claimed victories in the operations centering on the town of Barentu, the major urban center of western Eritrea.

headline: Advertising;   Scali, McCabe to Open Los Angeles Office
abstract: Richard Kelly, 38 years old, and Charles Silverman, 42, a pair of agency executives with impressive West Coast experience, have been rounded up by Scali, McCabe, Sloves to run a Los Angeles office. It opens tomorrow.

headline: McCaw President Grew With Cable Company
abstract: Craig O. McCaw began his commmunications career in high school, selling subscriptions for his family's fledgling cable television company during summer vacation. Now, his closely held McCaw Communications Companies is a $100 million-a-year business, and still growing.   Earlier this week, McCaw agreed in principle to buy the MCI Communications Corporation's celluar mobile telephone and paging operations for $120 million.

headline: Cuban Aide Dropped, Continuing a Shake-Up
abstract: A senior Cuban minister was dismissed today in a continuing Government shakeup that is eventually expected to lead to a more prominent role for Fidel Castro's younger brother, Raul, and a change of foreign minister.   Humberto Perez Gonzalez, who has headed the Central Planning Board for the last seven years, was replaced by the Construction Minister, Jose Lopez Moreno, who is described by Cuban sources as a young technocrat.

headline: Rainier Bank Selects Young & Rubicam
abstract: Young & Rubicam, San Francisco, has been appointed as the advertising agency for the Rainier Bancorporation, a Seattle-based bank holding company with assets of $7.6 billion.   The account, valued at $4 million, was previously handled by Cole & Webber of Seattle.

headline: Broadcasting Lures Founder of Essence
abstract: Since he founded it in 1969, Edward Lewis has built Essence Communications Inc. into one of the 50 largest black-owned companies in the nation, with estimated sales of $25 million this year. But for some time, Mr. Lewis recalled, he had been thinking of expanding the closely held concern - of which he is chairman and chief executive - into broadcasting.   Those thoughts came to fruition last week, when a group made up mainly of black investors, including Mr. Lewis's company - which publishes Essence, the monthly magazine for black women - agreed to buy television station WKBW in Buffalo from Capital Cities Communications Inc. for $65 million. The deal would result in the largest black-owned TV station in the country.

headline: The U.N. Today; Sept. 11, 1985
abstract: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Committee to Review International Development Strategy - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.   Committee for the 40th Anniversary of the U.N. - 3 P.M.   International Conference for Just Cause of Namibian People - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

headline: AUSTERITY IMPOSED ON ISRAEL IN PLAN TO CURB INFLATION
abstract: After a 20-hour Cabinet meeting, the Israeli Government declared an economic emergency today and imposed sweeping austerity measures intended to break the country's 260 percent inflation.   The Histadrut, Israel's labor union federation of 1.6 million members, immediately responded by calling a nationwide general strike for Tuesday. It said the Government ''has gone too far.''   With 90 percent of the labor force in the Histadrut, the entire country, including harbors and airports, is expected to be shut down by the strike. Services will operate on an emergency Sabbath schedule.

headline: Concerns Said To Avoid Tax
abstract: Forty major corporations - including American Telephone and Telegraph, Boeing and General Dynamics -paid no Federal income tax last year, according to a study of 275 large, profitable companies conducted by Citizens for Tax Justice, a labor-sponsored research and advocacy organization.   The study, which focused on the 1981-84 period, also found that 129 companies paid no taxes in at least one of those years; nine companies paid no tax in any of those years, and 50 companies had an overall effective tax rate during the four-year period of zero or less.

headline: Penney Is Buying Cableshare Stake
abstract: The J. C. Penney Company said it had agreed to acquire the 36 percent of Cableshare Inc. held by Rogers Cablesystems Inc. The purchase would give Penney, the New York-based retailing company, access to in-home shopping technology being developed by Cableshare, which is based in London, Ontario.   Under terms of the agreement, Penney would purchase a 25 percent stake in Cableshare from Rogers at 15 percent above the market price on the day of the transaction.

headline: U.S. OFFICIAL SAYS JORDAN ARMS SALE WILL PROCEED
abstract: A high-ranking State Department official told a sharply critical House subcommittee today that President Reagan would soon announce plans to sell advanced American fighter planes and antiaircraft missiles to Jordan.   Faced with opposition from virtually all of the dozen Congressmen at the hearing, Richard W. Murphy, Assistant Secretary of State for Near Eastern and South Asian Affairs, said, ''the United States must be prepared to respond to the defense needs of those willing to take risks for peace.''   ''A Jordan arms package would improve Jordan's military capability to deter potential aggression,'' he said. ''It would also demonstrate to those who want to block peace and question the seriousness of American staying power in the search for peace.''

headline: Gas Prices Dip Over 2 Weeks
abstract: Gasoline prices dropped slightly during the last two weeks, and the decrease, the first in more than five months, reflected dealer anticipation of a cut in oil prices by OPEC, an analyst said today.   But the analyst, Dan Lundberg, predicted that prices would rise again soon because the cut by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries turned out to be minimal.

headline: ICAHN CLOSES IN ON CONTROL OF T.W.A.
abstract: For the second time in as many days, Carl C. Icahn disclosed yesterday that he and his group of investors have increased their stake in Trans World Airlines, increasing the likelihood that he will be able to gain control of the airline.   In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Mr. Ichan said his group had raised its holding to 45.5 percent, or 15.6 million shares, from 40.6 percent reported Tuesday.   Analysts and sources close to T.W.A. predicted that it was now only a matter of time before Mr. Icahn and his investors won the fight for the carrier, the largest in the North Atlantic.   The airline has already accepted a $23-a-share bid from Frank A. Lorenzo, the president of the Texas Air Corporation. However, that offer is strongly opposed by T.W.A.'s unions, which have offered Mr. Icahn important concessions to help him counter it. T.W.A. had earlier rejected an $18-a-share offer from Mr. Icahn, but Monday he made a sweetened bid of $24 a share that analysts said T.W.A.'s board would have a hard time ignoring. T.W.A. stock closed yesterday at $21.75, down 37.5 cents, on the New York Stock Exchange.

headline: SIGNED JULY ACCORD WITH GANDHI
abstract: A leading Sikh political figure was shot and killed today by Sikh assailants in the Indian state of Punjab.   The slaying of the political leader, Harchand Singh Longowal, who was president of the mainstream Sikh party, Akali Dal, came less than a month after he had signed an accord with Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi to end a three-year separatist crisis in Punjab in which thousands died.   Only hours earlier, a Hindu politician of the governing Congress Party was slain in the Punjab city of Jullundur. Two other Congress members were wounded in the attack, which authorities said had been carried out by Sikhs.

headline: A MATURING STORER'S GAINS
abstract: There were nights in recent years when Peter Storer lay awake wondering whether the expensive push by Storer Communications Inc. into the cable television business was going to pay off.   ''I never had any lack of faith in cable,'' said Mr. Storer, chairman and chief executive of the company his father founded with one radio station in 1927. ''The question was whether we had gotten ourselves in a position where we were overcommitted. We were struggling there for a while.''

headline: Phoenix Is Selling $117 Million Issue
abstract: A $117 million issue of Phoenix general obligation bonds was offered with yields ranging from 4.50 percent for bonds due in 1986 to 6.60 percent in 1990, 7.75 percent in 1995, 8.30 percent in 2000 and 8.70 percent in 2006 through 2009. The underwriters were led by Salomon Brothers.   The bonds are rated Aa-1 by Moody's Investors Service and AA+ by the Standard & Poor's Corportion.

headline: Doremus Sets President Post
abstract: In order to create a new image for its public relations organizations, Doremus & Company, the largest of the Wall Street ad agencies, is bringing in Richard B. Truitt from Carl Byoir & Associates to assume the new title of president on Sept. 1.   The two components of his domain are the corporate and financial public-relations operation and, at a different location, Marketshare/Doremus, the newer unit that does consumer-oriented public relations and product publicity.

headline: INSOLVENCY FEARS GROW FOR JAPANESE SHIPPER
abstract: Japan's Sanko Steamship Company, one of the world's leading tanker companies, may be headed for insolvency.   Japan's major stock exchanges halted trading on Thursday in Sanko stock as rumors circulated that banks were about to stop lending to the company. Stock trading resumed today amid continuing rumors about the company's financial health.

headline: Market Place;   Public Wary About Stocks
abstract: STOCK prices are heading into uncharted territory, with the major indexes setting new highs. But stockbrokers say that, in contrast to past experience, the average investor has yet to succumb to the speculative itch.   Whether or not that changes with this week's surge in virtually all sectors of the equity market remains to be seen. The Dow Jones industrial average closed yesterday at a new high of 1,357.97. In the last two sessions it jumped a total of 22.51 points.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST: THURSDAY, SEPTEMBER 19, 1985
abstract: The Economy    Housing starts showed their best gain in five months with a rise of 6.2 percent in August. Analysts saw the report as a new sign of economic revival. Economists have been waiting for declines in mortgage rates to bring about a big increase in sales and building. Fixed-rate conventional mortgages are available for about 12.25 percent, down from 15.2 percent last summer. [Page D1.]    Congressional leaders said tax revision could not be enacted in the limited time left this year. That would mean that even if a tax measure is enacted early next year, many elements probably would not go into effect until 1987. [D17.]  President Reagan assailed the deductibility of state and local taxes as ''unjust.'' Speaking in New Hampshire, Mr. Reagan said the existing law ''rewards rich states with big budgets and high taxes.'' [D17.]  The I.R.S. is trying to improve its ability to identify and prosecute tax cheats. [D17.]

headline: Mid-July Car Sales Down 7.3%
abstract: Sales of new American-made cars declined 7.3 percent in the July 11-20 selling period from last year, the manufacturers reported today. It was the third consecutive period of declining sales.   Total vehicle sales, however, remained strong, increasing four-tenths of 1 percent, pulled up by a 20 percent increase in light-truck sales.

headline: Peak Grain Output Seen
abstract: World grain production this season should break records, despite a downward revision in forecasts for wheat harvests, the International Wheat Council said today. It estimated that grain output would rise 2.4 percent, to 1.35 billion metric tons, from last year's record of 1.32 billion.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST: MONDAY, SEPTEMBER 2, 1985
abstract: International    South Africa froze repayments of foreign-debt principal for four months. The move, prompted by the refusal of foreign banks to renew loans and by the sharp plunge in the value of the rand, underscored the deepening sense of crisis in South Africa. [Page 1.]  More than 60,000 of the country's 550,000 miners went on strike. [1.]

headline: EXCERPTS FROM U.N. SPEECHES BY SHULTZ AND SHEVARDNADZE
abstract: Following are excerpts from speeches at the General Assembly by Secretary of State George P. Shultz on Monday and Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze of the Soviet Union today. Mr. Shevardnadze's speech was translated by the Soviet Mission. Shultz Speech Much of the conflict in the world today stems from the refusal of some governments to accept the reality that the aspirations of people for democracy and freedom simply cannot be suppressed forever by force.   In South Africa, these aspirations on the part of the black majority have - as never before - drawn global attention and support. Change is inevitable. The issue is not whether apartheid is to be dismantled, but how and when. And then, what replaces it: Race war, blood bath, and new forms of injustice? Or political accommodation and racial coexistence in a just society? The outcome depends on whether and how quickly the South African Government can accept the new reality, and on whether men and women of peace on both sides can seize the opportunity before it is too late.   This much is clear: There must be negotiation among South Africans of all races on constitutional reform. True peace will come only when the Government negotiates with -rather than locks up - representative black leaders. The violence will end only when all parties begin a mutual search for a just system of governance.

headline: POST-PRANDIALS
abstract: Premium cigars and cognac are enjoying rising popularity as the baby-boom generation passes into middle age. ''Demographics have suddenly caused sales of cigars and cognac to explode,'' said Carol L. Colman, partner in Inferential Focus Inc., a market research organization.

headline: Jury Ruling On Asbestos
abstract: A Federal jury in South Carolina found yesterday that two former asbestos makers, the National Gypsum Company of Dallas and the United States Gypsum Company of Chicago, were not liable for the $284,000 cost of removing the product from five school buildings in Spartanburg, S.C., two years ago.      During the two-week trial in   Greenville, lawyers for the two companies argued that the levels of exposure were not high enough to constitute a health hazard.

headline: Japan Plans Space Shuttle
abstract: Japan plans to begin a research program aimed at developing its own space shuttle by the 21st century, the Yomiuri Shimbun reported today.   The Space Development Commission and the Science and Technology Agency will make a decision on the program on Thursday, the newspaper said.

headline: Apple Founder Cutting Stake
abstract: Steven Jobs, chairman of Apple Computer Inc. and one of its founders, intends to sell 500,000 Apple common shares, further lowering his stake in the personal computer company.   The sale, valued at $7.4 million, raises the number of Apple shares sold by Mr. Jobs since July to 1.3 million. Mr. Jobs disclosed his plans in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

headline: BEIRUT RADIO SAYS HIJACKERS ARE KNOWN
abstract: The state-run Beirut radio reported today that Lebanese authorities had identified the men who hijacked a Trans World Airlines jet last month and intended to prosecute them. The White House tentatively welcomed the report, which it called ''a step forward.''   But State Department officials could not confirm the details of the broadcast. The report was broadcast at 11 A.M. in Beirut (4 A.M., New York time) and was dropped in later newscasts.

headline: U.S. ASKS INCLUSION OF MANDELA GROUP IN PRETORIA TALKS
abstract: The United States has urged South Africa to allow the outlawed African National Congress to take part in any discussions between the Government and black leaders on the country's future, State Department officials said today.   It was the first time that the Administration had specifically said the congress should be included in negotiations. The South African Government, which banned the congress in 1960, has accused it of being a Communist organization dedicated to the forceful overthrow of the Government.   There is no indication that the Government of President P. W. Botha is willing to deal with the congress.

headline: Home Loan Laggards
abstract: The number of Americans two months late in making mortgage payments to savings institutions declined sharply in May, the United States League of Savings Institutions reported today. The trade group said 1.68 percent of residential loans held by 900 thrift units were 60 or more days overdue, compared with 1.99 percent in April and 2.22 percent in January. The rates are based on dollar amounts.

headline: Ohlmeyer Gets Another Entertainment Account
abstract: Ohlmeyer Advertising seems to be on a roll as far as winning accounts with entertainment orientations.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: American Motors Corp., Southfield, Mich., said it would offer 8.5 percent financing to buyers taking delivery of 1985 Renault passenger cars between Aug. 1 and Sept. 30.    * Chicago and North Western Transportation Co., a unit of CNW Corp., said it ordered 35 SD50 locomotives from General Motors Corp. for $45.5 million.    * Federal Express Corp. said that the Federal Communications Commission had authorized it to establish a satellite network, which the company said would give it enhanced telecommunications capabilities.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Previous   Year

headline: ICAHN RAISES T.W.A. STAKE TO 40.6%
abstract: Carl C. Icahn and his group of investors have increased their stake in Trans World Airlines to 40.6 percent, or 13.9 million shares, the financier disclosed yesterday in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission.   The higher stake, combined with the promise of major concessions from two of the carrier's three unions, gives the Icahn group a good chance to win control of the airline, analysts said. ''Icahn has got all the cards,'' Timothy Pettee, the airline analyst of L. F. Rothschild, Unterberg, Towbin, said.   Mr. Icahn is competing against a $23-a-share offer by the Texas Air Corporation that T.W.A. has already accepted.

headline: A.T.& T. IN VENTURE IN JAPAN
abstract: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company will announce today a venture with at least five leading Japanese companies, including Fujitsu and Hitachi, to offer sophisticated systems in Japan for transmitting computer data.   The introduction of the systems, known as ''value added networks,'' will mark A.T.&T.'s first big push into the burgeoning Japanese telecommunications market since it was opened to foreigners last spring.   According to telecommunications professionals, the venture could also help A.T.&T. sell computers and other business equipment in Japan.

headline: Accounts
abstract: Berkley Publishing Group to AC&R Advertising for its paperback books.    * Pinkerton Tobacco Company and Benton & Bowles have ended their relationship.    * Media Networks to TCI Advertising, Stamford, Conn.

headline: Halaby Renewing Dulles Airport Tie
abstract: Najeeb E. Halaby is 69 years old, but the man who stepped down in the early 1970's as chairman and chief executive officer of Pan American World Airways still has dreams.   Last week Mr. Halaby, who has run a management consulting firm since he left Pan Am, took a step toward realizing one of those goals when it was announced that he had been named chief executive officer of Dulles Access Rapid Transit Inc., a privately held concern that has proposed building a high-speed rail line linking the Washington Metro system with Dulles International Airport in suburban Virginia.   ''I got interested because it would complete a project or vision we had in the Kennedy Administration, to put up a high-speed monorail out to Dulles,'' said Mr. Halaby, who served as head of the Federal Aviation Administration during that period. As chief of the F.A.A., Mr. Halaby was in charge of construction of the airport, which is 20 miles outside Washington.

headline: PSYCHOLOGICAL EFFECTS SEEN FOR CURBS
abstract: By themselves, the sanctions that President Reagan adopted today will have a negligible impact on the economy of South Africa and on the American companies doing business with the country, according to trade experts.   But the analysts also said that the President's decision might have psychological effects, strengthening the resolve of other governments to expand their own sanctions. Such measures, combined with the American actions, could eventually hurt South Africa's economy, they added.   Some analysts speculated that South Africa could respond in a way that would work against President Reagan's commitment to the moment, as he put it today, ''when apartheid will be no more.'' The sanctions could encourage the country to redouble its effort to build a self-supporting economy, leaving it free to pursue its segregationist policies, these experts said.

headline: New Agency in Boston For John Hancock Life
abstract: In Boston the John Hancock Life Insurance Company - which, like so many other companies in its field, is broadening its financial services - is shifting its advertising account out of Arnold & Company and into Hill, Holliday, Connors, Cosmopolus.   The ad budget, only $1 million about six years ago, is now up to $18 million.

headline: CLOSE VOTE PUTS NORWAY'S COALITION IN DOUBT
abstract: Kaare Willoch was something less than jubilant on learning early today that he had been re-elected Prime Minister of Norway.   Exhaustion from the campaign and his own reserve had something to do with his demeanor. The main reason, however, was that the results of the voting had left no doubt that Norway had turned left, leaving the Government hanging by a thread.   The conservative wave led by Mr. Willoch has been broken by a resurgent Labor Party and its ally, the Socialist Left Party.

headline: Beecham Ex-Chairman To Take Over at Thorn
abstract: Sir Graham J. Wilkins, who retired last year as chairman and chief executive of the Beecham Group at the age of 60, was named to those posts at Thorn EMI yesterday after Thorn's board forced the resignation of Peter Laister, who ran the troubled electronics and entertainment conglomerate for just over a year.   During the 56-year-old Mr. Laister's ill-fated campaign to diversify, Sir Graham had been Thorn's deputy chairman, with no active role in management. He has been a director of Thorn since 1978.
