headline: Indonesian Mission in China
abstract: An Indonesian trade mission arrived here today in an effort to reopen commercial relations. Indonesia suspended them in 1967 on the ground that China had supported a Communist coup attempt in Indonesia two years earlier.

headline: Southland-McColl
abstract: The Southland Corporation, the Dallas-based retailer and gasoline company, said it would sell its Southland-McColl Ltd. subsidiary to Martin the Newsagent P.L.C., a unit of Guinness P.L.C. Southland-McColl has 371 confectionary, tobacco and news stores in Scotland and Northern England, which will continue to operate under the R.S. McColl trade name. Southland, parent of the 7-Eleven chain, did not disclose the price, but Guinness said it paid about $33 million.

headline: Chief at a Subsidiary To Head Mannesmann
abstract: Mannesmann A.G., the diversified West German steel products company, has named Werner Dieter, the head of a major subsidiary, to be chief executive.   Mr. Dieter, who is 56, succeeds Franz Josef Weisweiler, who died in July after a brief illness. Mr. Weisweiler, who was 57, had been chief executive since 1983.

headline: MCFARLANE BACKS AIDE ON CONTRA ROLE
abstract: President Reagan's national security adviser told the leaders of the Senate intelligence committee today that no one on the National Security Council had violated the law by assisting anti-Government rebels in Nicaragua.   But the chairman and deputy chairman of the committee said they still had serious concerns about the council's involvement and were not fully satisfied with the Administration explanation. The two Senators would not say, however, that the Administration had violated the law.   The chairman, Senator Dave Durenburger, Republican of Minnesota, said he saw no need now for hearings on the matter. The chairman of the House intelligence committee has scheduled hearings to begin Sept. 17.

headline: WHY THE DATA MAY BE OFF
abstract: Is the United States truly a debtor nation, as the Commerce Department reported last week? I think not. While there is no disputing that America's international investment position has fallen dramatically, the official figures give a highly misleading impression. The reason lies in a failure to properly allow for inflation.

headline: IN QUOTES
abstract: 'I'm not going to be bribed into shafting my shareholders.' Michel C. Bergerac Revlon's chairman, rejecting a Pantry Pride offer to let him keep his job if Revlon was taken over.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: American Bank Note Co., the 190-year-old security printing company, has appointed Calvin W. Aurand Jr. president, replacing Salvatore F. D'Amato, who becomes deputy chairman.    * The Cartier Collections, a new tableware company formed by Cartier International and the Reed & Barton Corp., has elected Richard R. Gillespie president.

headline: JUDGES TO RULE ON COSTA RICA PRESS LICENSING
abstract: A panel of human-rights advocates is considering whether Costa Rica's law requiring licensing of journalists violates the public's right to information.   The rights advocates of the Inter-American Court of Human Rights, which was established in 1979, have no power to enforce their findings, but Costa Rican authorities have indicated they will take the findings into serious consideration when deciding whether to maintain the licensing law.   The court's opinion was requested by Costa Rican authorities. A judgment is expected in November.

headline: Utility Backed On Plant Costs
abstract: Middle South Utilities Inc. said today that the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission has denied requests from states served by Middle South's operating units to stay an earlier order allocating nuclear power plant costs.   Separately, the company said, the Federal District Court in Baton Rouge, La., will consider a request from Middle South's Louisiana Power and Light subsidiary for a preliminary injunction compelling state regulators to recognize the Federal order.

headline: VIDEO DISKS CATCH ON AT THE OFFICE
abstract: THE MOST ubiquitous purveyor of information today is the video screen. While its most common form is the television, its influence extends far beyond entertainment and the evening news. Screens seem to be everywhere, displaying information above airline counters, in railroad and bus terminals and in hotels. Certainly, no one considers a television threatening.   But sit those same people down in front of a similar machine, call it a computer and give it a keyboard, and many of them will freeze in fear.

headline: Big Board Economist To Leave
abstract: As chief economist of the New York Stock Exchange for the last 17 years, William C. Freund has had one foot in academia and the other in the bustle of the world's largest securities exchange. This fall, he will join the academy full time when he takes an endowed chair at the Lubin Graduate School of Business at Pace University in Manhattan.   ''It seemed to me that this was a good time in my life to embark one more career before I finally retire,'' said Dr. Freund, who is 58. ''And I will have an office with a window, and at the university that's hard to come by.''

headline: Accounts
abstract: Chroma Copy International's U.S. advertising to David H. Block Advertising, Montclair, N.J.    * Matthew Bender & Company, a legal and tax publisher and a subsidiary of the Times Mirror Company, to E. B. Wilson.

headline: Dairy Group In Chapter 11
abstract: The financially troubled Northeast Dairy Cooperative Federation has filed for protection from its creditors under Chapter 11 of the Federal bankruptcy laws.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: * BankAmerica Realty Investors, San Francisco, has named as a trustee C. Preston Butcher, regional partner, president and chief executive of Lincoln Property Co. N.C. Inc.    * Chatham Manufacturing Co., Elkin, N.C., which makes blankets, auto and furniture upholstery and apparel, has elected Alan L. Payne president and chief executive, succeeding Powell W. Glidewell 3d, who resigned.    * Checkpoint Systems Inc., a Thorofare, N.J., company that makes electronic article surveillance tags, labels and detection equipment, has elected to its board Richard J. Censits, vice president of finance for Campbell Soup Co.

headline: USAir Buys 20 F-100 Aircraft
abstract: USAir, a major domestic carrier in the United States, today ordered 20 Fokker F-100 passenger planes, the Dutch aircraft manufacturer announced. The value of the contract, the biggest in Fokker's history, is $350 million, the company said, adding that the Washington-based airline took options on 20 additional aircraft of the same type.

headline: Washington Watch;   LATIN AMERICA DEBT AUSTERITY
abstract: ALTHOUGH President Fidel Castro of Cuba has urged his Latin American neighbors to declare a moratorium on their debts, most of the countries, including Nicaragua, are trying to stay on good terms with their bankers.   Despite Washington's efforts to squeeze it economically, the Sandinista Government has cleared up its arrears with the International Monetary Fund and has negotiated the refinancing of $295 million of payments to commercial banks due this year.

headline: MOVE SEEN AIDING COKE'S TOTAL SALES
abstract: When the Coca-Cola Company locked away its fabled formula 7X in an Atlanta bank vault in late April and introduced a new, sweeter version of the world's best-selling soft drink, it took one of the great marketing gambles of all time.   Yesterday the company conceded that perhaps it should not have bet all of its chips on reformulated Coke.   Analysts and marketing experts agreed yesterday that the company had lost considerable face because of its decision. Most analysts, however, felt that, with the reintroduction of the old formula of Coke, the company would come out of an embarrassing situation with a higher overall market share.

headline: Stock Plan Upheld By Refractories
abstract: The General Refractories Company said yesterday that it would continue with its stock-exchange offer and sale of its European operations, despite a shareholder vote Tuesday to replace the 11 board members with a slate headed by the Philadelphia investor Raymond G. Perelman. Mr. Perelman, who owns 40 percent of the company's stock and says he is now chairman, opposes both steps.   The board that was voted out by shareholders, however, is seeking to invalidate Mr. Perelman's election through court action, contending, among other reasons, that he gave insufficient notice to stockholders in calling the meeting.

headline: INDIA SAYS IT WILL GO AHEAD WITH VOTE IN PUNJAB SEPT. 25
abstract: The Indian Government announced tonight that it would proceed with elections in Punjab next month despite warnings that the balloting might prompt new assassinations and violence in the state.   Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi was reported to have decided against putting off the elections after consulting advisers and moderate Sikh leaders. The elections were scheduled for Sept. 25.

headline: STRIKE AT 7 MINES
abstract: MBlack workers at seven mines tonight began a strike over pay that is expected to involve 60,000 of the country's 550,000 black mine employees.   The leaders of their union, the National Union of Mine Workers, have said they fear employers will try to break the strike. The union has warned of a wider stoppage if that happens. #2 White Men Killed In another development, the police said two white men had been killed and two wounded when blacks returning from a funeral on Saturday night in a black township near East London attacked the men with knives and set their car ablaze.

headline: NEWS SUMMARY
abstract: SUNDAY, JULY 7, 1985     International     Robert G. Mugabe's party gained an overwhelming victory in Zimbabwe's first general election since independence. The Prime Minister's party won 63 of the 80 seats reserved for blacks in the 100-member Parliament. Mr. Mugabe indicated that he saw the victory as a mandate to dismantle Zimbabwe's British-drafted Constitution.[Page 1, Column 5.]    A Salvadoran rebel military leader vowed that the guerrillas would carry their attacks to the capital of San Salvador and spread the war to every area of the country. He said the attacks would make El Salvador ungovernable within the next year.[8:1-3.]

headline: People
abstract: Robert Starr has joined Backer & Spielvogel as a senior vice presient, associate creative director.

headline: Addendum
abstract: Rose & Brosse Advertising announced that it was no longer a merger partner with Edwin Bird Wilson. The agency said it was now on its own, with offices at 171 Madison Avenue.

headline: 'We Both Feel Secure'
abstract: FOR most of their working lives, John and Lucille Smaidris gave little thought to planning for retirement. He spent 37 years with the International Harvester Company; she worked 28 years as a secretary for Atlantic Richfield, and both participated in em-ployee stock and thrift plans at work.   Those plans, and some savings in certificates of deposit, were the extent of the couple's planning until the fall of 1981, a few months before Mr. Smaidris retired from his job as a stationary engineer at a Harvester research plant. At that point, they were jointly earning more than $50,000 a year and were worried about the size of their tax bite.

headline: Neiman's Ensemble Approach
abstract: NEIMAN-MARCUS department stores' first national media campaign has been coordinated so that its television advertising, store magazine and in-store promotion give shoppers a single impression of the Dallas-based chain.   One scene setting the mood reappears throughout the campaign. On the cover of the retailer's new NM magazine is a picture of a stylishly dressed woman viewing a Neiman-Marcus store window filled with video screens. The scene comes from the retailer's first national television commercial. In addition, Neiman-Marcus's in-store shoppers will find video screens in the store windows just like on the magazine cover. And on the screens will be the story of the making of the commercial.

headline: AIR FORCE G.E. MOVE
abstract: The Air Force announced today that it had further relaxed a ban on awarding new contracts to a major division of the General Electric Company that was imposed three months ago in connection with a fraud investigation.   Air Force Security Verne Orr, citing internal financial improvements, said he would allow most of G.E.'s Space Systems Division to resume bidding on Government contracts.

headline: Bid by MidAmerican
abstract: ''he MidAmerican Commodity Exchange, a 105-year-old futures market that trades small agricultural contracts, has asked its big brother, the Chicago Board of Trade, to consider reorganizing the exchange as an affiliate. The request comes at a time of extensive consolidation within the commodities industry.

headline: Chrysler Prices
abstract: The Chrysler Corporation said that tentative price increases for all its 1986-model passenger cars would average 2 percent to 3 percent. Firm prices would be announced when new cars are introduced in October, the auto maker said. On Tuesday, the General Motors Corporation announced price increases of slightly more than 3 percent on its two-door 1986 Grand Am Coupe, Oldsmobile Calais and Buick Somerset models.

headline: PERMANENT GLOBAL WATER SHORTAGE FORESEEN
abstract: Conservation and efficient use of existing supplies will be the only realistic answers to what is expected to be a permanent global water shortage, according to a new study issued today by the Worldwatch Institute.   The institute, an organization based in Washington that does research on issues involving resources, found that the world's existing sources of water for drinking, agriculture and industry are approaching their limits.   It also found that such traditional ways of expanding available water supplies as building dams, reservoirs and canals can no longer provide satisfactory solutions in much of the world.

headline: PROTECTIONISM
abstract: To the Editor:   Jeffrey E. Garten (''America's Retreat From Protectionism,'' Forum, June 16) asks whether anyone can doubt that the Smoot-Hawley Tariff Act of 1930 ''did contribute to the Great Depression'' and that any increase in protectionism today ''would be an act of gross stupidity?'' One answer: I hope so.   The arrival and persistence of high unemployment has coincided with the rise in imports. Mr. Garten and Senator John C. Danforth (the source of Mr. Garten's question) might usefully pay less heed to economists and re-examine the assessments of both Herbert Hoover and Franklin Roosevelt as to the causes of the Great Depression.

headline: SOUTH AFRICA ADMITS BREAKING MOZAMBIQUE PACT
abstract: Amid conflicting reports about its latest invasion of Angola, South Africa acknowledged today that its forces had also violated an nonaggression pact with neighboring Mozambique.   The agreement with Mozambique had been seen as a cornerstone of United States regional diplomacy.   Foreign Minister Roelof F. Botha, at a meeting with Mozambican officials at Komatipoort on their common border, was reported to have countered word of South African violations by accusing Mozambique of infringing on the agreement too.   The admission of South African violations was made shortly before President Samora M. Machel of Mozambique met in Washington today with President Reagan.

headline: FOR JAPANESE, A TIME TO REMEMBER: NOT WAR'S CONSEQUENCE, BUT NATUIRE'S
abstract: In a sturdy stone building across the street from the Imperial Palace moat, one must ride up five stories and then walk down a long corridor to find the office from which Gen. Douglas MacArthur once presided over Japan.   It is not an especially elegant room, nor one that speaks of power. But it does whisper money, as might be expected inside the head offices of a major insurance company, Dai-ichi Mutual Life.   The room has inlaid wood floors and soft pictures of fishing boats hanging from the paneled walls. In one corner is the general's old green chair, long faded. His desk, simple and scratched, sits in the center.

headline: ECONOMIC REPORTS SEND STOCKS LOWER
abstract: The stock market turned in its fourth consecutive decline yesterday, and the Dow Jones industrial average closed out its worst weekly performance in six months. Traders cited the latest economic figures coming out of Washington, which many experts said indicated that the economy might not rebound so much as expected in the second half.   The Dow, which tracks the activity of 30 blue-chip stocks, ended the day at 1,307.68, down 4.71 points. But the average had been down twice that much during the session. For the week, the Dow lost 28.01 points, its worst performance since the week ending March 8, when it fell 29.70 points.

headline: 'Invisible' Campaign For Bank
abstract: HOMER & DURHAM ADVERTISING has called on an invisible man to remind people how they frequently feel when doing business with modern New York area banks.   He will show up - or not show up, depending on your point of view - in a 30-second commercial that the agency has created for the American Savings Bank, a metropolitan New York institution with 37 offices. And to illustrate the point that American Savings is a bank that treats all customers with the warmth that other banks reserve for millionaires, the invisible man, up to then just another empty suit, will take form and substance once given American's humane treatment.   The commercial, shot in a deserted tobacco warehouse in Virginia, was a collaboration by Deborah Bannister, copywriter, and Scott Sorokin, art director, who did TV and all of the other advertising as well.

headline: MID-AUGUST AUTO SALES FELL
abstract: New-car sales for Aug. 11-20 were down 4.6 percent from the comparable period last year, the manufacturers reported here today. Sales of light trucks slipped 2.6 percent from last year.   Auto industry analysts said sales in the mid-August period suffered from the walkout by the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, whose 21,000 members haul cars from factories to dealerships. Most of those drivers went back to work on Monday, but the auto industry is still struggling to deliver the huge inventories of cars that piled up during the strike.

headline: US West Unit Rating Is Cut
abstract: About $1.3 billion of long-term debt issues of the Northwestern Bell Telephone Company, the Omaha-based subsidiary of the U S West Corporation, were reduced to AA, from AAA, S.&P. announced yesterday. The company's commercial paper rating was unchanged at the highest A-1+.   The rating agency said that the company faces increasing business risks but that any substantial strengthening in its capital and financial condition is unlikely.

headline: Advertising;   People
abstract: * William F. Rosenthal has joined Einson Freeman, a sales promotion agency, as senior vice president.    * Gerald Broderick, president of Arnold & Company, Boston, has been named to the additional post of president at Arnold Public Relations.

headline: Zimbabwe Extends Vote Because of Lines at Polls
abstract: The Zimbabwean Government announced today that it would extend by two days the voting period in the first elections since independence because of an unexpectedly large turnout.

headline: Advertising;   New Ratliff + Shanley To Specialize in Art
abstract: Paul Shanley, former publisher of Art in America magazine, has joined Morris Ratliff in the creation of Ratliff + Shanley, a new ad agency specializing in the advertising of art galleries and other art world institutions.

headline: Accounts
abstract: Wendy's International to Impact, the Promotion and Design Company, Chicago, for sales promotion.

headline: HOUSE APPROVES FOREIGN AID BILL OPPOSING MARXISTS AROUND WORLD
abstract: The House passed a $12.6 billion foreign aid bill today that appears to reflect a growing determination on Capitol Hill to confront Communist and other leftist governments around the world.   The legislation authorizes new aid for rebels battling the Marxist Governments in Cambodia and Afghanistan, and lifts a nine-year ban on American help to insurgent forces in Angola.   Last month, the House reversed earlier votes and supported renewed aid to forces seeking to topple the leftist Government of Nicaragua.      'Don't Want to Look Weak'   Vin Weber, a Minnesota Republican, summed up the mood by saying, ''Members of Congress don't want to look weak right now.'' Michael D. Barnes, a Maryland Democrat, added: ''It's sort of an angry mood around here. Who can we stick it to next?''

headline: Ft. Worth Airlines' Chapter 11 Filing
abstract: Fort Worth Airlines, which operated commuter flights in seven cities in Texas and Oklahoma, has canceled flights and filed for protection from creditors under Federal bankruptcy laws. John Y. Bonds, a lawyer for the nine-and-a-half-month-old airline, said the Chapter 11 petition for reorganization was filed Sunday morning.

headline: Caterpillar's Net Doubles
abstract: The Caterpillar Tractor Company reported today that net income in the second quarter more than doubled, to $50 million, or 51 cents a share, compared with $24 million, or 25 cents a share, in the quarter last year.

headline: Approval Sought For ABC Merger
abstract: Capital Cities Communications Inc. asked the Federal Communications Commission to approve its proposed merger with ABC Inc. and asked for a waiver to allow it to keep its lucrative Philadelphia TV station. The F.C.C. has never granted such a waiver.

headline: U.S. TO PROPOSE NEW EFFORT TO EASE DEBT CRISIS
abstract: The United States, in a major change of strategy, will propose that the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund undertake an unusual joint effort to ease the debt crisis and improve economic performance of poor countries in Africa and elsewhere.   Treasury officials said that Treasury Secretary James A. Baker 3d will make the proposal - which could involve loans of as much as $5 billion over a five-year period - at the annual meeting of the two institutions in Seoul, South Korea, early next month.   The new strategy is intended to help countries that have failed to repay their borrowings from the fund and seem to have little prospect of being able to do so soon. The mechanism is to create a new joint fund-bank agency that would substitute new loans for what the fund has lent. The fund would be paid off and the borrowers would have more time to pay the new creditor.

headline: PARADYNE AND S.E.C. SETTLEMENT
abstract: The Paradyne Corporation and the Securities and Exchange Commission announced today that they had reached a settlement that avoids trial of a civil complaint charging that Paradyne had violated Federal securities laws to obtain a $100 million computer contract from the Government.   In the settlement, the company, based in Largo, Fla., did not admit or deny wrongdoing. The settlement was approved just two days before the trial was scheduled to begin before Federal District Judge William Terrell Hodges in Tampa, Fla.

headline: Great Western Suit
abstract: The Great Western Financial Corporation, parent of the nation's third-largest savings and loan organization, has filed suit against the Citadel Holding Corporation over an apparently aborted $109 million takeover of Citadel. The suit also names Alfred Roven, who headed a group of dissident shareholders opposed to the merger and eventually got Citadel to name him and two associates to Citadel's board.

headline: Peat Marwick Named in Suit
abstract: The Justice Department has filed a suit on behalf of the National Credit Union Administration seeking as much as $6.1 million from Peat Marwick over its role as outside auditor of the Penn Square Bank, which failed in July 1982.      The suit, which was filed in   Federal District Court in Oklahoma City, where Penn Square was located, also names 12 Peat Marwick employees and Penn Square's directors.

headline: Ads Curtailed By Japan Air
abstract: Japan Air Lines has stopped advertising in Japan and abroad for ''a period of mourning'' for the 520 passengers of a J.A.L. flight who died in a Boeing 747 crash on Aug.12.      Young & Rubicam Inc. in   New York said yesterday that it had suspended its J.A.L. advertising schedule until at least Sept. 30.

headline: WAR, PEACE AND ANGOLA
abstract: With its raid today into southern Angola, South Africa seems to have revived an issue that has lately been lost in the welter of its own domestic turmoil: the continued presence of Cuban troops in Angola.   At the same time, the attack seems to have reinforced the feeling among many commentators here that a resolution of the issue, which once absorbed much of Washington's attention, is as remote as ever.   The Cubans first went to Angola during the civil war of 1975-76 to support and insure the victory of the Popular Movement for the Liberation of Angola against two other Angolan factions, supported variously by China, the Central Intelligence Agency and South Africa. Only one of those rival groups, the National Union for the Total Independence of Angola, led by Jonas Savimbi, survives, sustained by South Africa in a ''liberated area'' in southeast Angola.

headline: SHULTZ, IN HONOLULU, DENOUNCES NEW ZEALAND
abstract: Secretary of State George P. Shultz renewed criticism of New Zealand today, accusing it of undermining the United States nuclear deterrent and weakening its own security.   He referred to New Zealand's refusal in February to allow an American warship to make a port call on the ground that the vessel might be carrying nuclear weapons.   ''If New Zealand's objective was to enhance specific security and reduce the nuclear danger, it has acted against its own interests,'' Mr. Shultz said in a speech at the East-West Center on the campus of the University of Hawaii.   He spoke at the end of a two-week tour that took him to Southeast Asia, Australia and the South Pacific.

headline: 10 Boeing 737's Ordered by KLM
abstract: KLM, the Dutch national airline, has ordered 10 of the Boeing Company's 737 passenger planes to replace part of its medium-range fleet, the airline said. The value of the order, KLM's first ever for Boeing medium-range planes, is estimated at $344 million, an airline spokesman said.   The 737-300 airplanes, which carry 124 passengers, will use 25 percent less fuel than the Douglas DC-9 planes they will be replacing, the spokesman said.

headline: U.S. Petroleum Data
abstract: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

headline: BIG DEVELOPMENT PLAN ANNOUNCED IN TORONTO
abstract: The Toronto City Council approved a $1.5 billion development plan today for an area now covered by railway tracks.   The project, to be built over 20 years by Canadian Pacific and Canadian National Railways, includes a 60,000-seat domed stadium, 12 million square feet of high-rise offices, 5,800 housing units and 30 acres of parks.

headline: Bell Helicopter Furloughs Set
abstract: Bell Helicopter, a unit of Textron Inc., said yesterday that it would temporarily lay off about 1,800 of its 2,700 production employees to conduct a ''wall-to-wall'' inventory to meet Army accounting standards.   The furloughs, which begin tomorrow, will affect 1,000 workers for eight working days and another 800 employees for three days, the company said.

headline: SALVADORANS FIND A HAVEN IN CANADA
abstract: A half-dozen refugees from El Salvador sit around a living room here, sipping coffee and watching their children playing on the floor.   One man, now a dishwasher but 18 months ago a law student, tells of being captured by the National Guard, thrown over a cliff and left for dead. A freelance photographer tells of being blindfolded and imprisoned with no explanation. A former university student says she found her house sacked, grabbed her baby and ran until she reached Canada.

headline: ADVERTISING;Students' Real-Life Challenges
abstract: JAN H. REMAK and Naranaswamy Sivakumar, graduate students at Rice University  in Houston, undertook a challenge in advertising and marketing. Suppose they worked for Philip Morris Inc., the producer of Marlboro cigarettes, 7-Up soft drinks and Miller beers. Could they create a new product that would fit into the company's existing businesses and add sales, but not cannibalize the market share of any of the existing products?         Their answer: a British drink called shandy. The students felt their version, made with Miller beer, 7-Up and lime juice, would provide product compatibility, while taking advantage of consumer trends that favor more fruit juices and less  alcohol in drinks.

headline: Saturn's Pay Pattern
abstract: White-collar workers in the General Motors Corporation's Saturn subsidiary will receive smaller salaries but more incentive pay than elsewhere in G.M., a company spokesman said today. The new car is to be built in Tennessee.

headline: A.T.&T. Center
abstract: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company said that it plans to establish a credit and collections center in Charleston, W. Va., to handle $1 billion to $3 billion worth of accounts. Officials said the center will create 400 jobs and is expected to open by the end of 1987. John Landers, vice president of A.T.& T. West Virginia, said Charleston was selected because it is the site of a major switching center.

headline: A.T.& T.'S RIVALS GO ABROAD
abstract: ''Save on calls down under,'' says GTE Sprint in advertisements promoting Sprint's recently inaugurated long-distance phone service to Australia. An MCI ad showing a family of penguins in the Antarctic says, ''This is the only continent you can't call right now with MCI International.'' An A.T.&T. television ad filmed in Italy shows a doleful, American teen-ager bidding farewell to her Italian boyfriend. A voice in the background offers a cheerful note: ''Saying goodbye is never easy, but saying hello is, with A.T.&T.''   So goes the marketing in the latest push in telecommunications competition: international long distance. Having broken the monopoly on domestic intercity calling, A.T.&T.'s cut-rate rivals are trying to repeat their success in the business of calling abroad. While the American Telephone and Telegraph Company still controls roughly 97 percent of that $5 billion market, most industry analysts say the percentage could shrink quickly as A.T.&T.'s rivals intensify their efforts in a rapidly developing marketing war.   ''The U.S. business customer is used to thinking about competitive carriers,'' said Mary A. Johnston, a long-distance industry analyst at the Yankee Group, a Boston-based research firm. ''If they can get reasonable quality service for calls abroad, there is no reason they should not go for the low-priced carrier.''

headline: Massey-Ferguson
abstract: Massey-Ferguson Ltd., the Toronto-based manufacturer of farm and construction machinery, said that it had agreed to purchase the axial-flow combine harvester technology and related holdings of White Farm Manufacturing Canada Ltd., which has been in receivership and under the control of Peat Marwick Ltd. since April. Terms were not disclosed.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Previous   Year

headline: STOCK PRICES EASE AS DOW FALLS 7.62
abstract: Stock prices sagged yesterday in surprisingly brisk pre-holiday trading. Wall Street's attention remained riveted on potential takeovers, especially those in the entertainment industry.   CBS and MCA, Nos. 1 and 2 on the consolidated active list, provided the most excitement. CBS announced a stock repurchase program designed to hinder an acquisition attempt by Ted Turner, the Atlanta business executive. MCA made no announcement, but its stock continued to climb on buyout rumors.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Previous   Year

headline: Fleet Will Acquire First Connecticut
abstract: Fleet Financial Group Inc. said that it had reached a definitive agreement to acquire First Connecticut Bancorp in a stock transaction valued at $193 million. The terms of the agreement call for each share of First Connecticut to be exchanged for $62 of Fleet Financial common stock, or a minimum of 1.55 Fleet shares and a maximum of 1.77 shares.   Fleet was also granted an option to buy one million First Connecticut shares, or about 25 percent of the shares outstanding, for $55 a share.

headline: D'AUBUISSON, SALVADOR RIGHTIST, QUITS PARTY POST
abstract: Roberto d'Aubuisson, the standard-bearer of El Salvador's militant and often violent right, stepped down today as the head of his party, the National Republican Alliance.   His resignation is widely believed by diplomats and politicians to be a tacit recognition that he has outlived his usefulness as party leader. They also feel he has become a liability to his backers, important sectors of the country's military, businessmen and landowners.   The party has been weakened by internal squabbling, desertions, loss of funds and a crushing defeat in the March legislative elections.

headline: Afghan Rebel Attacks On Convoys Reported
abstract: Western diplomats said today that Afghan rebels attacked two Soviet-Afghan military convoys last month, killing hundreds of soldiers, and mounted their heaviest rocket assault in months on the suburbs of the capital of Kabul.   The rocket attacks on Kabul's eastern suburbs, which killed up to six people, prompted a ''massive'' artillery shelling of rebel strongholds by Afghan forces and Soviet units in Afghanistan supporting the Soviet-installed Government, the diplomats said.

headline: TV Spots Start Tonight For Commodore Amiga
abstract: A spare, gray-haired man in a gray jumpsuit is seen walking purposefully up and down a series of shadowy staircases and then emerging in what can best be described as a temple-like hall, at once ancient and modern. At the end of it is a platform that can best be described as an altar. Something tabernacle-like glows from its center. As he nears, we see the object is a personal computer. A simple press of the button and he is bathed in its glow. He smiles, eyes closed as he soaks up the artificial light. Then, as our TV screen is filled with the computer screen on which appears a wide-eyed fetus, the voiceover delivers practically its only line in the 60-second commercial: ''Re-experience the mind unbounded.''

headline: YEN'S RISE NOW SEEMS KEY GOAL
abstract: It is becoming increasingly clear that last Sunday's five-nation accord to work together to lower the dollar was largely aimed at putting pressure on Japan to follow through on past pledges to strengthen the value of the yen. A stronger yen would help cut the United States trade deficit, by making Japanese imports more expensive for Americans to purchase and by making United States goods less expensive in Japan.   Japan left the Group of Five meeting with the ''understanding that the major issue is the exchange rate between the dollar and the yen,'' said a senior official at the Bank of Japan. [Monetary officials familiar with the talks also said the strengthening of the yen was a major focus of the meeting. Page D6.]  In the past, Japan has pledged certain economic steps that would have the effect of improving America's balance of trade. Japan is believed to have reiterated those pledges at the Group of Five meeting. Also, judging from action in the foreign currency markets over the past four days, Japan apparently said it would intervene heavily by purchasing yen for its central bank.

headline: BUSINESS GROUPS RESIST CHANGES IN TAX PLAN
abstract: Business backers of President Reagan's tax revision plan are warning that their support will collapse if Congressional tax writers bargain away the reductions in corporate and individual tax rates contained in the plan.   While support from the business community is not viewed as critical to move a bill out of the House tax-writing committee, whose members are now generally committed to turning out a comprehensive tax overhaul bill, their lobbying organizations are being counted on to help win passage on the House and Senate floors, where support is uncertain.   The business groups backing the Reagan plan represent a relatively small segment of the business community and their influence has been weakened by division within their ranks. Nonetheless, they have emerged as the strongest base of support thus far amid a sea of dissent from most segments of the business community and lackluster support from the general public.

headline: SOVIET LIQUOR PRICES UP IN DRIVE ON ALCOHOLISM
abstract: The Soviet Union sharply raised prices today on liquor, beer and champagne, bringing the price of the cheapest brand of vodka to 6.20 rubles a half-liter, or $8 a pint.   The increases, announced on the evening television news show as part of Mikhail S. Gorbachev's campaign against drinking, came as no surprise to the thousands of men who have been standing in line outside liquor stores for up to three hours as rumors of impending price increases spread.   Today's announcement did not specify prices, which will become known at 2 P.M. on Tuesday when the liquor stores open.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST: THURSDAY, JULY 11, 1985
abstract: Companies    Coca-Cola will bring back the original Coke it scrapped three months ago, calling it Coca-Cola Classic. It will keep the new Coke, which it introduced with great fanfare. The company acknowledged the outpouring of consumer protests in making the stunning about-face. [Page A1.]  Industry analysts said despite the loss of face Coke suffered, it may have stumbled into a position of new dominance in the industry by catering to more segments of the market. [D4.]    Hutton's chairman said the brokerage house mishandled its guilty plea on charges of defrauding banks. The executive, Robert Fomon, said he should have ''pleaded guilty on behalf of the company'' and ''the individuals involved would have stood by themselves.'' [D1.]  If Hutton is found to have withheld documents during the Federal investigation, the Justice Department will reopen its investigation, Attorney General Meese said. [D5.]

headline: New Zealand Air Sells Eight Planes
abstract: New Zealand Air Ltd., a state-owned airline, said it had sold eight older aircraft - six Boeing 737's and two McDonnell Douglas DC10-30's - to the International Lease Finance Corporation, a United States concern that owns and leases jets, for $106 million.   The company's managing director, Norman Geary, said that the airline had received more than the average market price. ''The funds from this deal will provide part of the financing for our total fleet replacement and expansion program,'' he said.

headline: Debt Ratings Cut for Five
abstract: The Standard & Poor's Corporation lowered the debt ratings yesterday of five forest products companies, affecting some $4.4 billion of outstanding debt.   The rating service cited the earnings outlook of the paper industry as significantly lower than previous expectations, mentioning the specter of increasing worldwide competition.   The senior debt ratings of the five companies were cut as follows: the Weyerhaeuser Company rating was reduced to A+, from AA-; the Georgia Pacific Corporation dropped to BBB+, from A-; the Union Camp Corporation to A-, from AA; the Great Northern Nekoosa Corporation to A, from A+, and the Boise Cascade Corporation to BBB, from BBB+.September 27, 1985, Friday, Late City Final EditionSeptember 27, 1985, Friday, Late City Final Edition

headline: WINSTON LORD IS NAMED AS ENVOY
abstract: President Reagan intends to nominate Winston Lord as Ambassador to China, the White House said today.   If confirmed by the Senate, Mr. Lord, who is 47 years old, will succeed Arthur W. Hummel Jr.

headline: INTERGROUP, LEUCADIA IN ACCORD
abstract: National Intergroup Inc., pulling a thorn out of its corporate side, said yesterday that it had reached an agreement with the Leucadia National Corporation to buy 75 percent of the National Intergroup stock held by Leucadia.   Unlike many such deals, however, the company did not have to pay a premium to get its stock back. In fact, National Intergroup will pay Leucadia $24 a share in cash - $3.50 below the stock's closing price yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange and about the same price that Leucadia had paid for its holding of 1,823,300 shares of common, or 7.8 percent. The stock was down $1 on the day.  Leucadia, which had tried to buy National Intergroup, will receive a warrant to purchase 1,367,475 National Intergroup shares at $30.75 a share. The warrant expires in September 1988. Leucadia also entered into a standstill agreement that removes any threat of a takeover by Leucadia for 10 years.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST: FRIDAY, SEPTEMBER 13, 1985
abstract: The Economy    Dan Rostenkowski said his House Ways and Means Committee will write protectionist trade bills, including one that would curb textile imports, despite White House plans to draft new trade legislation and the President's pledge to veto protectionist measures. The Illinois Democrat said the President's ''strategy of slowing the push for tougher trade policy isn't working.'' [Page D1.]    Two Congressmen gave some of their constituents a chance to see how their 1984 Federal returns would have fared if the Administration's tax plan had been in effect. An accounting firm did the calculations, which apparently showed that a big majority would have wound up with lower tax bills. [D1.]

headline: Peking Finance Talks
abstract: Twenty senior executives from London's financial district, led by the Earl of Limerick, opened a two-day seminar here today to instruct Chinese officials about international finance.

headline: PAPAL 'COLUMN' WILL CONTINUE, WITH CHANGES
abstract: A new newspaper column fashioned from the writings and speeches of Pope John Paul II that was strongly criticized by Vatican officials on Tuesday will proceed with Vatican cooperation, an official of the syndicates distributing the column said yesterday.   The syndicates agreed to make several changes, including the column's name, to win Vatican support, according to Richard S. Newcombe, president of News America Syndicate and The Times of London Syndicate. Both are owned by the publisher Rupert Murdoch.   On Tuesday, the Vatican press office denounced the first column, which appeared in newspapers throughout the world last weekend, for attempting to use the Pope's ''byline'' for ''commercial operations.'' The Vatican statement expressed ''astonishment and disapproval'' and said that reprinting the Pope's words required placing them in the proper context so their ''exact meaning'' could be understood.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: Automatic Data Processing Inc., Roseland, N.J., said it acquired the brokerage transaction services division of Control Data Corp. for an undisclosed amount of cash and contingent payments based on business results for the next year.    * Chesebrough-Pond's Inc., Greenwich, Conn., said it had sold the headquarters office complex of its recently acquired Stauffer Group in Westport, Conn., to Interim Funding Corp. for $85 million in a sale-and-leaseback arrangement.    * Eastman Kodak, Rochester, said it introduced a 16-millimeter high-speed color negative film that features improved image sharpness and grain structure.

headline: IN FEAST OF FAMINE, THERE IS BREAD IN RUSSIA
abstract: The collective farm chairman lost his job and his Communist Party membership and now faces trial on criminal charges. Three of his subordinates also lost their jobs. Their crime: feeding bread to pigs.   The very notion has an almost sacrilegious ring to Russian ears. Pigs, after all, are pigs, and bread is not only scarce, but a national symbol.   In the phrases of songs and poems often heard here, bread is gold, it is the motherland, it is the hard work of the masses, it is life itself. Bread is credited with saving the starving people of Leningrad during the blockade in World War II. One poet put it this way: Bread, that pure, that sacred word. Bread, our very lives.  In a village cafeteria in Siberia hangs a poster that reads: ''Bread is the warmest, kindest of words. Write it always with a capital letter, like your own name.''

headline: JOB OUTPUT RATE POSTS 0.5% GAIN
abstract: Business productivity in this year's second quarter rose at an annual rate of five-tenths of 1 percent, a turnaround from a decline in the first quarter, the Labor Department reported today.   Meanwhile, unit labor costs, which reflect changes in productivity and hourly compensation, moderated in the second quarter. A big increase in unit labor costs in the first three months of 1985 had caused some economists to worry about a possible acceleration of inflation.

headline: India Rightists Want Bomb
abstract: India's major right-wing opposition group urged Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi today to develop nuclear weapons to counter what it described as a threat from Pakistan. The Press Trust of India news agency quoted the Bharatiya Janata Party as saying that Mr. Gandhi's Government should take ''immediate steps to develop our own nuclear bomb in view of reports that the threat of a Pakistani nuclear bomb is real.'' Mr. Gandhi said two weeks ago that Pakistan was fairly close to manufacturing a nuclear weapon.

headline: Olin Elects New President
abstract: John W. Johnstone Jr. has been elected president of the Olin Corporation, assuming the title and position held for the last two years by John M. Henske, chairman and chief executive officer.   Mr. Johnstone, 52 years old, was formerly executive vice president of the corporation.

headline: EXCERPTS FROM GRIFFIN BELL'S REPORT ON HUTTON
abstract: Following are excerpts from the report of former Attorney General Griffin B. Bell on his investigation into the overdrafting practices of E. F. Hutton Inc.:   Our investigation of Hutton's New York management focused on the Hutton overdraft problem and those areas of management at headquarters which may have had some responsibility for the problem. Over 30 officers and employees were interviewed in the departments or areas of Hutton that we determined to have responsibility for Hutton's cash management practices.   Amongst this group, there was a great deal of overlapping of functions, with vague lines separating the division of responsibilities, some dual reporting, much grey area in function as well as responsibility, and generally, a loose management structure.      Money Mobilizer    Most of the Hutton problems giving rise to the investigation by the Department of Justice arose in money management and centered around [Thomas]  Morley, who was in charge of money management and carried the title of first vice president and money mobilizer.

headline: Rooney, Pace Loss Estimate
abstract: Rooney, Pace Group Inc. said yesterday that it expected a $16.4 million loss for its fiscal fourth quarter, ended May 31, which would push its loss for the fiscal year to $31 million.   Reflecting the seriousness of the losses, the brokerage holding company also announced an exchange offer for its $25.7 million in outstanding floating rate notes to help it avoid defaulting on interest payments.

headline: AGCA SAYS HE ALTERED STORY OVER GIRL'S ABDUCTION
abstract: Mehmet Ali Agca said today that he had altered his testimony against Bulgarians accused of helping him in a plot to kill Pope John Paul II after he was convinced that they had engineered the kidnapping of an Italian schoolgirl to obtain his release from prison.   Mr. Agca repeatedly altered his version of events during the 23-month investigation leading to the trial, in which eight people are accused of conspiring to kill the Pope.   Mr. Agca's explanation of how the kidnapping relates to his case contrasted with earlier testimony in which he said the abduction was engineered by the spurious Masonic lodge known as Propaganda 2, which he said knew he was Jesus Christ and sought to put him in the Vatican.

headline: THE BIG MARKET IN LITTLE READERS
abstract: CURIOUS GEORGE, a monkey who made his first mischievous appearance in 1941, caught Jake Ames's eye at a recent booksellers' convention in New York. ''I like him,'' the four-year-old boy told his father. ''He's very silly.''   And indeed, several generations of young readers have felt the same way. The Curious George books have sold more than four million copies over the years, according to the publisher, Houghton Mifflin. They have been so successful, in fact, that a new crop of Curious George books is coming on the market.   But the new books reflect the changing dynamics of children's book publishing as much as the popularity of the whimsical monkey. A generation of parents that prizes book-learning is now trying to expose its children to books at an earlier age. And as a result, publishers are rushing to turn out volumes geared to youngersters aged 2 to 6 - and even younger. The new Curious George books, for example, are intended for a somewhat younger readership - including children as young as 2 years - than the original books.

headline: THE SPLASHY RETURNS IN SECTOR FUNDS
abstract: THE recent showy performance of some sector funds has caught the attention of many individual investors. Sector funds, also known as specialty funds, limit their portfolios to specific market groups ranging from utilities and financial services to health care and high tech.   In recent years, specialty funds have been firmly lodged in the top spots in mutual fund rankings. For example, of the 860 mutual funds whose performances are monitored by Lipper Analytical Services, sector funds filled the top four spots for the 12-month period ending Aug. 22. The No. 1 performer was Prudential-Bache Utilities, with a rise of 50.8 percent. Next were Fidelity Select Financial (up 45.4 percent), Fidelity Select Leisure (42.7 percent) and Century Shares Trust, which specializes in insurance companies (39.6 percent). In fact, of the top 10 performers, 7 were sector funds.

headline: Economic Scene;   Banks' Impact On Apartheid
abstract: PRESIDENT P.W. BOTHA of South Africa has proposed to restore citizenship to millions of blacks who lost it when the Government set up its ''homelands'' policy, which was intended to make South Africa ultimately a white state. The pass laws controlling the movement of black labor appear likely to go next. If, as it now seems, apartheid is crumbling, what cracked it at last is the threat of economic collapse, brought on not by political pressures or sanctions but by the actions of bankers and business executives - and by the economic blunders of the South African Government.   The economic crisis has been a long time in coming. The central piece of legislation to remove blacks and control the influx of blacks into urban areas was a 1951 version of a 1936 pass law. For the first time, women as well as men were required to carry passes. Under section 10 of the bill, an African was permitted in a city for more than three days only if (a) he or she was born in that city, (b) had lived there for 15 years or worked for one employer continuously for 10 years, (c) was under 16 years of age, or (d) received special Government dispensation. A person's status could not change through marriage.

headline: Olin Restructuring To Cut 3,500 Jobs
abstract: The Olin Corporation yesterday announced a major restructuring that will cut employment by 3,500 and result in a $330 million pretax charge against earnings in the third quarter.   The company, based in Stamford, Conn., said it would sell or liquidate certain businesses, decommission chemical facilities that are currently on standby status and write down the value of certain facilities and assets hurt by changing economic conditions.   The company said the move, which is expected to result in a loss for the year, was a further step in its recent actions to reposition itself. Olin said it was closing and writing down the value of some chemical facilities in response to overcapacity in basic chemicals as overseas plants multiply and seek markets here.

headline: Top Two Officers Resign From AMF
abstract: AMF Inc., recently acquired by Irwin L. Jacobs's Minstar Inc. in a hostile takeover battle, said yesterday that its top two executives had resigned.   In a four-sentence news release, the company said that W. Thomas York, chairman and chief executive, and William P. Sovey, president, had stepped down.   Kenneth J. Severinson, who has worked with Minstar and Mr. Jacobs in various capacities for the last eight years, was named to succeed Mr. York in both jobs.

headline: Freddie Mac Sets Rate On New Certificates
abstract: The Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation, known as Freddie Mac, yesterday announced interest rates on $700.9 million of pass-through certificates, which are backed by mortgages of multifamily loans.   It is the first issue of a recently announced new program whereby Freddie Mac buys mortgages on multifamily units and repackages them into mortgage pass-through securities, which are then sold to investors.

headline: C.D.'s, Money Funds Off
abstract: Rates on certificates of deposit and money market mutual funds fell again in the week ended yesterday. Money market accounts, on the other hand, continued to hold firm.   The Bank Rate Monitor's national index this week showed that the average yield on a bank money market account was unchanged for the sixth consecutive week at 6.90 percent. The average yield on a six-month certificate of deposit slid two-hundredths of a percentage point, to 7.64 percent. Yield figures in the index are based on rates available at institutions for the lowest minimum deposits.

headline: Combustion Selling 3 Oil and Gas Units
abstract: Combustion Engineering Inc., a major supplier of electric power equipment, said yesterday that it would sell most of its oil and gas business and take a $200 million charge against third-quarter earnings, resulting in a loss for the year.   The company, which is based in Stamford, Conn., cited weakness in the oil and gas markets and the need to redirect its resources to other areas, such as the rising business in garbage-burning plants and new demand for computer technology in industrial plant processes. The company said it was not yet in talks with potential buyers of the three oil and gas units scheduled to be sold.

headline: AFTER A BRIEF WARMING, U.S.-CUBAN TIES COOL ANEW
abstract: American and Cuban officials agree on one thing these days: that relations between the United States and Cuba have reached one of the lowest points in years. .   A modest improvement in the long-chilly relationship - marked by the signing of an immigration agreement in December and indications that some Cuban troops might be withdrawn from Angola - has been stalled, and the officials say there appears to be no hope for improvement in the near future.   The warming in the relationship, which United States officials had publicly denied, came to an abrupt halt in late May when the United States inaugurated a broadcast service to Cuba called Radio Marti. Officials in Washington said the station would provide Cubans with news about their Government that was being withheld by their leaders.   Fidel Castro, the Cuban leader, denounced Radio Marti as a cynical and provocative attempt at subversion and suspended a five-month-old immigration agreement with the United States, which had been the first major accord between the two countries in seven years.
