headline: AIR FORCE OFFICER'S MEMO SUGGESTS U.S. PLANS LONG STAY IN HONDURAS
abstract: An internal memorandum written by an Air Force civil engineer in Honduras suggests that the United States is planning to maintain a major military presence in that country for at least three to five years.   Reagan Administration and Pentagon officials have repeatedly said that the United States presence in the Central American country is maintained only on an annual basis and is designed to support military exercises.   The Defense Department and the State Department repeated those assertions today. They said the memorandum, written by Lieut. Col. Philip G. Stowell, involved ''contingency planning'' and only represented ''his perceived needs and his interpretation of assumptions and planning factors.''

headline: BROKEN HILL OUTGROWS AUSTRALIA
abstract: THEY call the Broken Hill Proprietary Company the Big Australian - with good reason. This steel, mining, and oil monolith accounts for 3 percent of Australia's gross domestic product, 5 percent of exports and 10 percent of the value of all shares listed on the nation's stock exchanges. On an Australian scale, that's rather like being U.S. Steel, Asarco and Exxon rolled into one.   Even more impressive, B.H.P. boasts remarkable profitability for a company in such distressed industries. It reported record net income of $546 million on sales of $5 billion for the fiscal year that ended May 31. Those earnings, two-thirds of which stem from highly profitable Australian oil operations, received an added lift because almost half its sales were made in strong American dollars, while most costs are paid in the much weaker Australian currency.   But the Big Australian has grown too big for Australia. Not only does it monopolize the steel industry there, but it also produces, in a joint venture with Exxon, most of the oil pumped in Australia and it is a major miner of iron ore, coal and manganese. To grow faster than the nation's economy, the century-old company has decided that it must go multinational.

headline: No Currency Action by U.S.
abstract: The United States did not intervene on currency markets in May, June or July, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday in a quarterly report.

headline: Jefferson County
abstract: Jefferson County, Ky., yesterday tentatively priced at par, $65 million of pollution control revenue bonds, 1985 series A, through underwriters led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets.

headline: JAPANESE TRUST BANK SET FOR U.S.
abstract: Daiwa Securities said today that it would open a trust bank in the United States. Daiwa will be the first Japanese securities company allowed to enter the trust business overseas, and its entry is expected to trigger a rush among its competitors to the United States market.   The move reflects the gradual financial deregulation now under way in Japan. As in the United States, the line between banking and securities businesses is beginning to erode in Japan, although at a much slower pace.

headline: Financial Officer Named by Disney
abstract: Gary L. Wilson, the Marriott Corporation's chief financial officer and a pioneer in sale-and-leaseback financing, was named executive vice president and chief financial officer yesterday of Walt Disney Productions Inc.   Mr. Wilson, who also was elected to Disney's board of directors, is likely to use the expertise he developed at Marriott to explore the possibility of raising millions in cash through the sale and leaseback of Disney's major theme parks, according to David Londoner, an analyst at Wertheim & Company in New York.   Under its new chairman, Michael D. Eisner, and president, Frank G. Wells, Disney has announced several new motion picture productions, as well as other major projects to increase theme-park attendance. The projects include a $300 million production studio and tour at Disney World, near Orlando, Fla., and a 12-minute, three-dimensional film for the Disney parks starring Michael Jackson and directed by George Lucas.

headline: People
abstract: Donald Blauweiss has joined Saatchi & Saatchi Compton as senior vice president, creative director.

headline: Japan Reportedly Found Tracks of Soviet Subs
abstract: Japanese intelligence experts have identified tracks of Soviet midget submarines on the bottom of the Sea of Japan, along the straits a Soviet fleet must use to reach the Pacific, The Los Angeles Times reported today.   The newspaper said the tracks were a sign that Soviet special forces are making contingency plans for amphibious landings to take control of the key waterways in time of crisis.

headline: AN ENDURING RUSSIAN FACE
abstract: A Western diplomat, trying to break the ice with a poker-faced Andrei A. Gromyko at the start of a round of talks, once asked whether he had had a good breakfast. Pausing just long enough to make his questioner feel a bit uncomfortable, Mr. Gromyko answered, ''Perhaps.''   When Mr. Gromyko was transferred today from the post of Foreign Minister, which he had held for 28 years, to that of President, there was nothing in his demeanor to indicate whether the move was a promotion or a demotion.   In brief acceptance remarks before the Supreme Soviet, the Parliament, he stated what might have been his credo as the survivor of six Soviet administrations: ''I will make every effort to fulfill with honor my duty toward the party and the country.''

headline: U-Haul Complaint
abstract: The Federal Trade Commission's complaint against U-Haul International, the nation's largest renter of trucks and trailers, is a ''gross injustice,'' a company official said.   Paul J. Kelley, director of public relations for the Phoenix-based company, said on Friday that U-Haul had exercised its constitutional right to collect a debt when it filed the suit against Jartran and received a $40 million award from Federal court.

headline: BUSINESS ETHICS
abstract: To the Editor:   The arguments that Lester Crown sets forth (''Lester Crown Blames the System,'' June 16) are refutations of his assertion, ''there isn't a cultural, ethical change required'' in general Dynamics. Admitting his company's ''foolishness and stupidity,';' he said, ''we didn't do anything wrong but it wasn't right either.'' Mr. Crown's criteria for ethics seems to be, as he stated, ''What could this look like on the front pages?''

headline: Chinese Get Credit Cards
abstract: China entered the plastic money age today when two leading bankers became the first Chinese citizens to own credit cards. The chairman of the Bank of China, Bu Ming, and its president, Wang Deyan, were presented with two Mastercards bearing a picture of the Great Wall.

headline: 3 BIG COMPANIES PLAN TO RESTRUCTURE
abstract: A wave of restructurings hit the corporate world as big companies tried to respond more quickly to market conditions. Union Carbide, facing severe financial problems because of a series of chemical leaks and trying to cope with overtures by GAF, said it would take about a $1 billion charge against earnings as it cuts its white-collar work force by 15 percent, shuts unprofitable plants and takes other write-offs. Carbide is consolidating 12 chemical divisions into 7, and reassigned some top executives.   Mesa Petroleum will shift to a limited partnership, which the chairman, T. Boone Pickens, says will take Mesa out of the takeover business, at least ''in the near term.'' Mr. Pickens said the switch will funnel most of the cash flow, after debt payments, to the partners. Analysts said the move is a good response to reduced opportunities in oil and gas.

headline: CHASE OFFICER LEAVING IN WAKE OF RESHUFFLING
abstract: Having lost out in a reshuffling of senior management, James H. Carey has resigned, effective July 31, as an executive vice president of the Chase Manhattan Bank. He will continue as a consultant to Chase until the end of the year.   The 53-year-old Mr. Carey has been in charge of the corporate industries group, which caters to large corporations. He was immediately replaced by Richard J. Boyle, 41, another executive vice president, who has been in charge of Chase's commercial lending group, which deals primarily with medium-size companies.

headline: New Coke vs. Classic: The Verdict Is Still Out
abstract: Coca-Cola Classic, the revived original version of the world's best-selling soft drink, is now available in more than 80 percent of the nation's retail outlets. But retailers and fountain operators say it is still too soon to tell how well the latest incarnation of the old product will sell, and what effect it will have on sales of ''new'' Coke. And while consumer tastes will have a large say in the ultimate success or failure of a two-Coke strategy, the Coca-Cola Company seems determined not to let Classic usurp new Coke's role as its flagship brand.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: Debt Issues    * Cardinal Distribution Inc. is offering $40 million of 8 1/4 percent convertible subordinated debentures due 2010 through underwriters led by Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Co. The debentures may be converted at any time into Cardinal Distribution common stock at a price of $21 a share.    * Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corp. plans to sell next week up to $160 million of collateralized mortgage obligations with average lives of 2.4 years, 5.4 years and 8.5 years, through various securities dealers.

headline: BUILDING OF HOUSES UP BY 6.2%
abstract: Housing construction in August posted its best gain in five months, the Commerce Department reported today. Analysts said that the 6.2 percent increase provided further evidence that the economy was showing signs of a revival.   Construction of new homes and apartments rose to an annual rate of 1.75 million units, adjusted for seasonal variation, the report said. That reversed a 3.2 percent decline in July and was the best performance since a 14.7 percent advance in housing activity in March.

headline: DOLLAR FALLS BROADLY TO '85 LOW
abstract: The dollar tumbled yesterday to its lowest level in almost eight months, amid widespread sentiment that a weak economy is likely to push it significantly lower in the coming weeks and months.   The value of the dollar, as calculated by the Federal Reserve Board against 10 leading currencies, dropped to 143.50, its lowest point since Nov. 15. It closed Friday at 144.45.   By late in the day in New York, the dollar traded for 2.97 West German marks, down from 3.00 on Friday evening. This was the first time since April 18 that it had closed below that level in New York.

headline: STATE DEPT. ASSISTANCE QUAKE IN MEXICO: FEARS AND WORRY NORTH OF THE BORDER
abstract: The State Department has established a task force on the Mexican earthquake to answer the questions of Americans concerned about United States citizens in that country, officials said today. The telephone number, which will operate around the clock, is (202) 653-7959.

headline: Cooke's New Offer For Multimedia Set
abstract: Jack Kent Cooke, less than a week after the Federal Communications Commission allowed him to go ahead with his hostile takeover bid for Multimedia Inc., said  today that he would make a tender offer of $70.01 a share for 6.73 million shares of Multimedia's outstanding stock.         Mr. Cooke's purchase of the stock, 40.3 percent of the outstanding shares, plus the 1.6 million shares he and his affiliates already own, would give him a  majority of Multimedia's 16.7 million in outstanding stock.

headline: Lebanese Swimmer Slain
abstract: A 14-year-old Lebanese boy was killed today when teen-agers swimming in the Litani River on the edge of what Israel calls its ''security zone'' in southern Lebanon came under fire, sources said. The sources, who refused to be identified, said they believed the firing came from positions of the Israeli-backed militia known as the South Lebanon Army. A seriously wounded teen-ager and three others with minor injuries were hospitalized in Sidon.

headline: MARCOS SAID TO PLAN TO QUIT AND HOLD A SPECIAL ELECTION
abstract: Pentagon and State Department officials said tonight that they had been told by the Philippine Embassy here that President Ferdinand E. Marcos planned to resign in September in order to call a special election this fall as a test of his popular support.   The officials said the United States Embassy in Manila had been unable to get confirmation of such plans from the Philippine Government. A White House spokesman said there had been no official notification to the Reagan Administration of a planned election.

headline: COMPANIES TURN TO INCENTIVES
abstract: A year ago, the suggestion that Douglas W. Moul would aggressively push his division to generate more cash so that another division could build a new plant would probably have made him laugh. But today, rather than laughing, that is exactly what Mr. Moul, the general manager of one of the American Can Company's packaging divisions, is doing.   The reason: This year, American Can introduced an incentive program that enables the 40 top managers in its packaging sector to profit from the success of the group as a whole. Mr. Moul, who now talks about acting like ''an entrepreneur'' and being ''an owner'' of the $2 billion sector, stands to share in the riches if the new plant's product, a semi-rigid bottle, is a big seller.   In industries ranging from financial services and telecommunications to food processing and high technology, more and more companies are pushing incentive pay farther and farther down their white-collar ranks in a bid to tie compensation more closely to individual and divisional performance.   Indeed, more than 100 of some 500 medium and large companies surveyed by the Hay Group, a consulting firm, said they either had begun to spread incentives to lower levels in their organizations, or planned to do so. The goal: to make the fixed salary a smaller and smaller portion of total compensation.

headline: TOP U.S. AIDE SEES ABYSS OF VIOLENCE FOR SOUTH AFRICA
abstract: Robert C. McFarlane, the President's national security adviser, said today that both blacks and whites in South Africa are ''looking into an abyss of massive violence,'' and he urged black leaders to challenge the Pretoria Government to produce specific changes to match what he termed vague promises.   Mr. McFarlane said he was disappointed by the speech given on Thursday by the South African President, P. W. Botha. Despite a buildup of expectations both in the United States and South Africa, Mr. Botha pointedly did not detail any specific actions for change in South Africa.      Growing Questions on Speech    Mr. McFarlane's comments today came against a background of growing questions in the United States and South Africa as to why expectations were so high that President Botha's speech would contain major concessions to the country's black majority, and whether South African officials suggested that the speech would point in that direction.   The week before Mr. Botha's address in Durban, Mr. McFarlane and a high-level American delegation met in Vienna with South African officials to discuss Pretoria's intentions.

headline: RETRENCHMENTS SET AT STEEL COMPANIES
abstract: Three steel companies reported further retrenchments yesterday as the difficult times in the industry continue.   The LTV Corporation, seeking to conserve cash, said that it had suspended payment of dividends on its preferred stock. Armco Inc. said it planned to close permanently its seamless tubular plant at Ambridge, Pa. And the Bethlehem Steel Corporation announced further cuts in pay and benefits for 10,000 salaried employees.

headline: GUATEMALAN PROTESTS BROKEN UP
abstract: The police fired tear gas to disperse hundreds of students, workers and housewives today as demonstrators rampaged through the Guatemalan capital, stoning shops and vehicles.   The military Government closed all public schools and universities in the capital and said the order would remain in effect as long as protests over a 50 percent increase in public transport fares continued.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST: SATURDAY, JULY 13, 1985
abstract: The Economy    Retail sales fell 0.8 percent in June, the third drop in four months and the steepest since July 1984, the Government said. Consumer spending has been the mainstay of the economic recovery. But economists said the June decline showed how tenuous the recovery has become. [Page 29.]

headline: U.S. ENVOYS MEET IN PANAMA TODAY TO DISCUSS LATIN PEACE EFFORTS
abstract: Elliott Abrams, the Assistant Secretary of State for Inter-American Affairs, said today that he would meet with American ambassadors to Central America on Monday to explore ways to give new impetus to the search for peace in the region and support elections in Guatemala and Honduras.   A four-page working paper that circulated in the State Department last week in preparation for the meeting said that the so-called Contadora peace process ''remains central to our policy'' in Central America but that ''collapse would be better than a bad agreement.''   ''A good agreement remains the goal,'' it said.   Mr. Abrams, interviewed by telephone today from Key West, where he stopped en route to Panama for the one-day gathering, said the paper did not reflect precisely what he planned to say to the ambassadors on the subject, but other State Department officials said it fit within established policy guidelines.

headline: Oil Price Cut By Egypt Seen
abstract: Egypt has decided to cut oil prices but has yet to decide how big the reductions will be, a senior Oil Ministry official said today.   The official, who said ministry policy allowed him to discuss price deliberations only if he was not identified, said the cut probably would be around $1.50 a barrel and that a final decision might be reached Thursday.

headline: Indians Buy Katy Unit
abstract: A group of Wisconsin-based Indians has bought the Simpson Electric Company from Katy Industries for $22.9 million. Katy's chairman, Wallace Carroll, said the new owners, the Lac du Flambeau band of the Lake Superior Chippewa Indian tribe, told him the sale was the largest purchase of a manufacturing company by an Indian tribe in the United States. Simpson, which makes electrical meters, has a plant on the tribe's Wisconsin reservation that employs 400 people.

headline: INVESTING TO RETIRE: 3 CASE STUDIES
abstract: JOSEPH E. BIBEN, the owner and founder of the Joseph E. Biben Sales Corporation, of Philadelphia, hasn't fixed a date for retirement. Nevertheless, he is prepared.   ''Twenty-four hours after I stop having fun, I'll be gone'' from the company, the 59-year-old said. In 1966, three years after he had formed his business, Mr. Biben was advised, by a friend whose job is pension planning, to look into formal retirement, pension and estate plans. The options he selected, for his corporation and himself, are re-evaluated every two years.

headline: Bond Offering By Minnesota
abstract: Minnesota is offering almost $52 million of general obligation bonds through underwriters led by the Bankers Trust Company.   The financing consists of serial bonds with yields ranging from 7 1/2 percent for bonds due in 1994 to 8 percent in 1996, 8.20 percent in 1998 and 8.35 percent in 2000.   The bonds, backed by the full faith, credit and taxing power of Minnesota, are rated Aa by Moody's Investors Service and rated AA+ by the Standard & Poor's Corporation.

headline: LOEWS HOLDS 9.9% OF CBS
abstract: The Loews Corporation reported yesterday that it had bought 9.9 percent of the common stock of CBS Inc.   In its filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Loews said the purchase was for investment purposes only. But it also disclosed that during informal talks with CBS, Laurence A. Tisch, the chairman of Loews, had indicated an interest in acquiring the broadcasting company. These talks were held after Ted Turner, through his Turner Broadcasting System, announced his bid for CBS.

headline: SIGNAL AND ALLIED ADVISER FEES SET
abstract: The First Boston Corporation and Lazard Freres & Company will share a $20 million fee for advising, respectively, the Allied Corporation and the Signal Companies in the nearly $5 billion merger of the two concerns, according to documents released yesterday. Copies of the 324-page proxy describing the merger are being sent to nearly 330,000 shareholders in one of the largest mass mailings in business history.

headline: U.S. Clears Practice of Exclusives
abstract: AFTER nearly two years of review, the United States Justice Department has decided that the practice of granting advertising exclusivities does not violate antitrust laws, according to Justice Department officials.   The officials said that an investigation begun in late 1983 after a complaint from the Stroh Brewing Company would be closed and that no further action was expected on the case.   Exclusivity is the practice of a television network granting an advertiser the right to be the only product in its category to have its commercials air in a given program. For example, on NBC-TV's major league baseball ''Game of the Week'' tomorrow afternoon, all beer commercials will be from the Miller Brewing Company.

headline: JAPANESE CITY WHERE GANGSTERS SHOW CIVIC PRIDE
abstract: The residents like this old port city so much that even the criminals worry about hurting its reputation.   In the middle of a shooting war that had been going on since January, two rival clans of yakuza gangsters, Japan's underworld, declared a late-summer cease-fire while Kobe was holding an Olympics-style event known as the Universiade. It would make the city look bad, they said, if they continued firing away while thousands of foreign athletes were in town.   Their civic-minded gesture did not impress the police.

headline: Merck Stock In Sharp Drop
abstract: Concern that an anti-hypertension drug produced by Merck & Company might have harmful side-effects sent the company's stock sharply lower yesterday in heavy trading.   Merck fell $2.875 a share, to $107.875, on a volume of 1.1 million shares.

headline: CAPACITY USE AT 80.8% FOR 4TH MONTH
abstract: The nation's factories, mines and utilities operated at 80.8 percent of capacity in July, a level that has been unchanged since April, the Federal Reserve Board said today.   The July results were 1.2 percentage points below the level of last August, indicating how weak the manufacturing sector has been. Manufacturers have been hurt by the import wave brought in by the strong dollar.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: * American Express Travel Related Services Co., a subsidiary of the American Express Co., has named G. Richard Thoman president of its international division.    * American Security Corp., Washington, has named Clement Geitner and Junius S. Morgan senior vice presidents.

headline: THREAT TO INTERVENE CAN BE EFFECTIVE
abstract: Nowhere in the statement that the United States and four other nations published Sunday did they explicitly invoke the use of intervention to drive the dollar down. Nevertheless, there was only one message in the single-spaced, nine-page statement: a threat to intervene.   In its simplest form, the process of intervention is just what tourists do on a small scale when going abroad. They exchange, or sell, some dollars and get German marks or British pounds. Governments do the same thing, but with the specific intention of altering the basic exchange rate of their currency.

headline: A SHIFT AWAY FROM THE WEST IS SENSED IN SUDAN
abstract: A Sudanese-Libyan military agreement, the signing of which was reported Monday, is being widely viewed here as a symbol that relations between the two countries are warming while the Sudan's ties with both Egypt and the United States are weakening.   The still unpublished ''military protocols,'' signed in Libya last week and announced in Sudanese newspapers on Monday, are ''the most significant in a series of moves aimed at easing tension between Khartoum and Tripoli,'' a senior Western diplomat. ''At the very least, it shows that the new Government here is determined to adopt a more neutral, less pro-Western stance.''   That new Government, led by Gen. Abdel Rahman Siwar el-Dahab and other military officers, came to power after the overthrow of President Gaafar al-Nimeiry three months ago. The general promptly re-established diplomatic links with Libya, in exchange for which Libya shut down an anti-Sudanese radio station and promised to stop supporting rebels in the southern Sudan.

headline: RESHAPING LABOR TO WOO THE YOUNG
abstract: LIKE many workers in the fast-growing health care, high-tech and government sectors here, Paula McLain Mixson was solidly anti-union when she moved to this Texas boomtown. During her childhood in East Texas, her father often told her not to take a job ''where some union goes around telling you what to do.''   But in her five years at the Texas Department of Human Services, Mrs. Mixson has become a convert to labor's cause. A program analyst in her 30's, Mrs. Mixson switched allegiances after management repeatedly ordered sweeping job changes for her and her co-workers without consulting them. ''Unions are the only way that the little people can have an effective say over rules that govern them on the job,'' she now says.   For the labor movement, signing up Mrs. Mixson was a small, but important, victory after a decade of declining union membership and particular difficulty in enlisting young people. Increasingly, union leaders are recognizing that if labor is to reverse its decline, it must woo more young workers. And to that end, American labor has embarked on a host of new strategies to attract the 52 million American workers under the age of 35, who represent half of the nation's labor force.

headline: RETAIL SALES ROSE IN JULY A SLIM 0.4%
abstract: Retail sales posted only a modest rebound in July, the Government said today, and analysts contended the report was another blow to the Reagan Administration's hopes for a healthy economic upturn in the second half of 1985.   The Commerce Department said sales at department stores, restaurants and other retail establishments edged up four-tenths of a percent last month to a seasonally adjusted total of $113.7 billion.   The modest rise followed two months of declines, including a sharp 1.4 percent drop in June that originally had been reported last month as a less severe fall of eight-tenths of 1 percent.   Private economists gave as much weight to the downward revision for June as they did to the modest July increase.

headline: EX-GENERAL TELLS OF NICARAGUA ROLE
abstract: A retired United States Army general who is active in assisting and advising Nicaraguan rebels said today that he was in contact with a member of the National Security Council in the White House to keep him informed of his work, including fund raising for the rebels.   Administration officials and members of Congress have said in recent days that a National Security Council staff member is the United States official primarily responsible for coordinating contacts with the rebels.   In an interview, the retired general, John K. Singlaub, said he called the National Security Council official from time to time. The topics, he said, have included the general's work with Adolfo Calero, political head of the Nicaraguan Democratic Force, the largest rebel group.

headline: LTV PLANS TO SELL SPECIALTY STEEL UNIT
abstract: The LTV Corporation, acting to strengthen its balance sheet, said yesterday that it planned to sell its specialty steel products unit, the nation's second-largest producer of stainless steel, after Allegheny Ludlum.   LTV had announced in May that it planned to sell or seek joint-venture partners for several units in its steel and energy operations in an attempt to produce $500 million over 18 months.

headline: Anti-Takeover Plan at Cluett
abstract: Cluett, Peabody & Company, which recently rejected a $336 million takeover bid, said its board had adopted a rights distribution plan aimed at preventing takeovers financed through Cluett's borrowing capacity or the sale of its assets. Paul Bilzerian and William Brodovsky, two California investors, hold 9.9 percent of Cluett, a New York apparel maker, and offered to buy it last month for $40 a share.

headline: U.S. FINANCING FOCUSES ON BILL SALE
abstract: Treasury financing this week is confined to the bill market, where the Government has scheduled a regular weekly sale today of three- and six-month issues totaling $14.4 billion. About midweek, the Treasury is expected to announce plans for a two-year note auction on Sept. 18.   In advance of today's bill sales, the outstanding three-month issue was bid late Friday at 7.27 percent, while the six-month bill was at 7.44 percent. The 8 7/8 percent two-year notes were yielding about 9 1/8 percent.

headline: 6 ACCUSED BY F.B.I. IN IRAN ARMS PLOT
abstract: Six people, including an Iranian and an Army lieutenant colonel who had top-secret clearances, have been arrested in what the Government said was a plot to smuggle more than $75 million in advanced missiles and weapons to Iran.   The first shipment of weapons, more than $9 million in antitank TOW missiles, was scheduled to be flown out of the country on Wednesday. The weapons were never sent because of the work of an undercover agent. But the Federal Bureau of Investigation said that one of those arrested had told the agent that over the last two years he sold more than $10 million in arms to Iran in deals involving a top Iranian official.

headline: Ally & Gargano Income
abstract: Ally & Gargano reported gross agency income of approximately $7 million for its 1985 fourth quarter, an increase of about 23 percent over the same period last year.

headline: REAGAN SAYS TAX CODE NOW AIDS 'RICH STATES'
abstract: President Reagan today assailed as ''unfair'' and ''unjust'' the Federal income tax provision that allows deductions for payments of state and local taxes.   In New Hampshire, where residents pay no general state income tax and thus cannot take full advantage of the deduction, Mr. Reagan said the existing Federal income tax ''rewards rich states with big budgets and high taxes.''   Mr. Reagan's remarks, delivered at an outdoor rally at the Statehouse here, were part of his campaign for Congressional adoption of his tax-revision plan. It calls for a sweeping overhaul of the Federal income tax code that would eliminate many deductions and would lower tax rates.

headline: Manville's Plan Is Said to Gain
abstract: Attorneys for the Manville Corporation and its creditors reported progress yesterday in trying to fashion a settlement based on a company plan of reorganization that includes an offer to pay $2.5 billion to asbestos victims. Federal Bankruptcy Judge Burton Lifland adjourned the proceedings until Sept. 4 to give the attorneys more time to negotiate.

headline: S.E.C. MAY BAR EXCLUSIONARY BIDS
abstract: The Securities and Exchange Commission proposed yesterday barring any tender offer that does not apply equally to all shareholders. This action would prevent corporations from discriminating against certain shareholders - as Unocal Corporation did in its defense against T. Boone Pickens. It would also prevent raiders from adopting the same practice.

headline: Philippine Mayor Slain At a Beauty Pageant
abstract: A gunman shot the mayor of a northern Philippine town, in the back before hundreds of people watching a beauty pageant in the plaza, the Philippine News Agency reported today.   The news agency said Mayor Westrimundo Tabayoyong of Laoac, 105 miles northwest of Manila, was dead on arrival at a hospital shortly after the shooting, which occurred late Friday night.

headline: INVESTING;  A HEADY TIME FOR COMMUTER AIR STOCKS
abstract: THE rapid growth in the number of pasengers flying on commuter airlines in recent years has sent the profits of many of these companies zooming. And investors have bid up the prices of many of their stocks: Over the past year some have quintupled.  An index of the publicly traded commuter airlines stocks published by Commuter/Regional Airlines News, a newsletter based in Arlington, Va., has doubled since January. Among the high-performance issues of the past year are Atlantic Southeast Airlines, an Atlanta-based carrier, which has rocketed to more than $15 a share from $3; Wings West Airlines of California, which has jumped from $2 to more than $10, and Metro Airlines of Houston, which trades at $17, up from $5 a year ago.

headline: COPING WITH THE COST OF A NURSING HOME
abstract: AS technology helps more Americans live into their 80's, the problem of their rising health- care costs assumes increasing urgency. ''Lawyers have done a good job arranging people's financial affairs after death,'' but they have to start thinking about lifetime planning, says Peter J. Strauss, a partner with Strauss & Wolf, a law firm that specializes in problems of the elderly.   Although public and private insurance plans offer relatively good protection against the cost of hospitalization for acute illnesses, both types of insurance leave the elderly virtually unprotected if they Last in a series of articles on helping the elderly manage their money. develop a chronic illness, such as Alzheimer's disease, and wind up needing long-term care.   True, only about 5 percent of the elderly are institutionalized. But for that small percentage, the expense can be devastating. Nationwide, nursing homes cost about $25,000 annually, but in New York the price can soar to $60,000. Thus, the institutionalization of one spouse can rapidly destroy a nest egg that took a couple decades to accumulate.

headline: BEAR, STEARNS PLANNING TO GO PUBLIC
abstract: Bear, Stearns & Company, a Wall Street maverick that is one of the few remaining large brokerage partnerships, has decided to make its first public offering of stock and debt securities, Alan C. Greenberg, its chief executive, said yesterday.   ''Our intention now, unless there are unforeseen circumstances, is to make the offering,'' Mr. Greenberg said in a telephone interview. The executive committee of Bear, Stearns - known as one of Wall Street's scrappiest, high-stakes traders - formally made its decision on Aug. 5, Mr. Greenberg said. It was reported in late July that the firm was considering options for raising capital.

headline: Article 092907 -- No Title
abstract: Scoa Industries, a general merchandise and footwear retailer based in Columbus, Ohio, said that its board had received a leveraged buyout offer valued at $35 a share, or a total of $574 million, from a group including management.   The company said that its board considered the price acceptable, subject to successful negotiation of other terms.

headline: Rubbermaid-Gott
abstract: Rubbermaid Inc. said it had signed a definitive agreement to acquire the Gott Corporation in an exchange of stock valued at $23 a share, or a total of about $66 million. Both are rubber and plastic products companies. Gott employs 1,500, and Rubbermaid, which is based in Wooster, Ohio, employs 3,800.

headline: STEELMAKERS LISTEN TO DETROIT
abstract: Three years ago, the Ford Motor Company was rejecting and returning nearly 9 percent of the steel it purchased from suppliers because of surface defects or faulty chemistry. Now, the rate has been reduced to less than 2 percent.   Ford has also forced its suppliers to reduce delinquent deliveries of steel to less than 3 percent today, from 20 percent in August 1983.   On a crash program to close the ''quality gap'' with their foreign counterparts, particularly the Japanese, Ford and other domestic automobile manufacturers have been pressuring American steel manufacturers to improve their performance.

headline: Emmerling Shop Wins Italian Leather Account
abstract: John Emmerling Inc. has just won a five-agency competition for a $1 million assignment from the Italian Trade Commission to promote leather goods. And that competition, Mr. Emmerling reported yesterday, was conducted without meeting the prospective client.

headline: ADVERTISERS TEST AN UNCHARTED MEDIUM
abstract: LAST year when the Red Lobster restaurant chain was approached by Backer & Spielvogel, its advertising agency, to sponsor a home video of the health and diet book ''Eat to Win,'' executives decided to gamble.   They produced it. Since seafood plays a large role in the book's diet plan, the tape seemed an excellent vehicle to carry the national chain's name and advertising, said Dick Monroe, a Red Lobster spokesman. The company was one of the first and most prominent concerns to undertake such a venture, so many people have been watching the ''Eat to Win'' project with intense interest.

headline: NEW QUESTIONS ON HUTTON'S SCHEME
abstract: Congressional investigators have obtained internal E. F. Hutton documents that are said to raise the possibility that senior management knew of an elaborate Hutton scheme to overdraw its bank accounts by hundreds of millions of dollars to earn extra interest.   According to Washington officials, the new documents came to light in recent days - nearly two months after Hutton pleaded guilty, by arrangement with the Justice Department, to 2,000 counts of mail and wire fraud and agreed to pay a fine of $2.75 million. Hutton also consented to reimburse banks for unearned interest lost by the banks.   The papers were apparently produced by officials from Hutton regional offices following hearings held by the House Judiciary's crime subcommittee last month, at which Hutton's chairman, Robert Foman; its vice chairman, Thomas Lynch, and two other senior officers testified. According to the Washington officials, several Hutton officials at the regional level were upset that blame for the overdraft scheme was laid at the feet of the regional offices and that top management denied all culpability.

headline: PROTESTS AND LOOTING SPREAD IN GUADELOUPE
abstract: Looting spread today and protesters' barricades kept this French Caribbean commercial center isolated from the rest of the island.

headline: VIDEOTEX
abstract: To the Editor:   With over 200,000 subscribers to CompuServe, 100,000 or more to Dow Jones, and nearly that many using The Source, I'd hardly call Videotex and electronic mail a failure. In addition, numerous private electronic mail and computer teleconferencing services have been operating for years within government and the private sector.

headline: Guatemala Candidates Expecting Fair Election
abstract: Six candidates for vice president in Guatemala's first civilian Government in 31 years said today that they believed the November election would proceed as planned and be fair and free from electoral fraud.   ''I think we're going to have a clean event'' on Nov. 3, Jaime Caceres, a member of the right-wing Movement of National Liberation-Institutional Democratic Party, said at a news conference.

headline: NEW TURNER TARGET REPORTED
abstract: Rebuffed in his attempt to take over CBS Inc., Ted Turner is now focusing on the possible acquisition of a part of the MGM/UA Entertainment Company, according to a well-placed industry source.   Kirk Kerkorian, the reclusive financier who owns 50.1 percent of MGM/UA through his wholly owned Tracinda Corporation, has said he wants to sell the United Artists Corporation to MGM/UA shareholders for $500 million.   It was not clear yesterday whether Mr. Turner was interested in bidding for United Artists or for other parts of MGM/UA, but he is apparently one of several interested buyers, and he was at the MGM/UA lot last week. Executives at MGM/UA could not be reached for comment late yesterday. Alex Swan, a spokesman for Turner, said he had no knowledge of Mr. Turner's interest in the company.

headline: I.M.F. Sees Slow Growth
abstract: Economic growth in the industrial world will expand by only 3.1 percent next year, according to an International Monetary Fund forecast to be published next month, Western monetary officials said today.   The gloomy prediction is contained in the I.M.F.'s World Economic Outlook, which the global lending agency is to release early in October at its annual meeting in Seoul, South Korea.

headline: OPEC Price Report Denied
abstract: As OPEC leaders began arriving today for their midsummer conference, a report by the Government-supported Kuwait News Agency said a majority of the 13 ministers had reached tentative agreement to lower the price of OPEC's top-grade crudes by $1 to $1.50 a barrel.   The report, citing unidentified Persian Gulf oil sources, said that in addition to lowering the price of Saudi Arabian Light crude oil from $28 a barrel, the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries also should cut its production ceiling by as much as one million barrels a day.

headline: I.R.A. SAYS IT KILLED CATHOLIC POLICE INSPECTOR
abstract: Two Irish Republican Army gunmen shot and killed a police inspector in an ambush outside his home in Northern Ireland early today, the police said.   Hours later, the outlawed Irish Republican Army issued a brief statement through its political wing, Sinn Fein, taking responsibility for killing the Roman Catholic officer.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST: FRIDAY, AUGUST 16, 1985
abstract: The Economy    Industrial production rose a slight 0.2 percent in July, providing little evidence of the second-half economic rebound predicted by the Reagan Administration and most private analysts. But economists found some consolation in the Federal Reserve report, since it showed at least some growth for the seventh straight month. [Page A1.]  Americans took on $6.79 billion more in installment debt than they paid off in June, the smallest rise since November. [D2.]    Defense Secretary Weinberger said he would support changes in the way the Pentagon buys weapons in order to restore public confidence in the military. Officials said that at a closed meeting he advocated a stricter review of new weapons before they are approved for full-scale development and tighter limits on specifications that make weapons more complex and expensive. [B4.]

headline: PROSPECTS
abstract: The P.P.I. Stays Put On Friday, the Government's report on the Producer Price Index - which measures changes in the prices of finished goods as they leave the factory -will show a rise of two-tenths of 1 percent for August, says John D. Paulus, chief economist at Morgan Stanley & Company. That is a slightly lower rate increase than the three-tenths of 1 percent for July, when there was a burst in food prices.   The P.P.I. is being held down in part by the still-strong dollar, which keeps a damper on the prices of commodities that go into the products measured by the index, Mr. Paulus said. Looking ahead, he said that producer prices would rise by only 1 percent to 1.5 percent for the entire year.

headline: BELL RESOURCES IS SUED
abstract: The Justice Department today filed a civil suit charging Bell Resources Ltd. and Weeks Petroleum Ltd. with violating Federal premerger notification requirements in the acquisition of about $61 million of Asarco Inc. common stock. The suit was filed in the Federal District Court in New York at the request of the Federal Trade Commission.

headline: Leftists Cause Blackout In Much of Chile
abstract: A bomb for which leftist guerrillas took responsibility plunged much of Chile into darkness Wednesday night. It was the 12th anniversary of the military coup in which President Augusto Pinochet took power, and church sources said nine people were hurt in anti-Government protests.

headline: Wang Posts Big Loss
abstract: Wang Laboratories Inc., the maker of office automation equipment, yesterday reported an unexpectedly large $109 million loss for its fourth quarter ended June 30.

headline: THE TELEPHONE LOBBY: NO LONGER A ONE-COMPANY SHOP
abstract: THE nation's telephone lobby used to operate much like a dictatorship.   The powerful American Telephone and Telegraph Company, which once controlled all of the nation's long-distance business and 80 percent of its local telephone service, would decide its position on an issue, marshal the needed troops from its nationwide ranks, then make its point with policy makers. As far as Washington and the telephone behemoth were concerned, differences voiced by the independent telephone companies were little more than static on the line.   But now, thanks to deregulation of the telephone business and last year's breakup of A.T.&T., rampant democracy - and more than a modicum of chaos - has set in.   A.T.&T., with a Washington staff of 14 people as well as a ''field force'' of 70 people across the country, remains a potent lobbying presence. But now each of the seven regional phone companies has a Washington office of its own, with staffs ranging from 6 people to more than 30. The former Bell companies, the old line independents, the long-distance companies, and a host of other contenders for the lawmaker's ear all are making their own spirited efforts to influence telecommunications policy.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Previous   Year

headline: Houston Offering Sewer Bond Issue
abstract: A $270 million issue of Houston sewer revenue refunding bonds was tentatively offered yesterday with a maximum yield of 9.42 percent for bonds due in 2014. Underwriters are led by Goldman, Sachs & Company.

headline: SENATE APPROVES 29 APPOINTMENTS
abstract: By overwhelming margins, the Senate today confirmed three key diplomatic appointments, ending a monthlong battle with Senator Jesse Helms over nominations to State Department positions.   Richard R. Burt, now Assistant Secretary of State for European Affairs, was approved as ambassador to West Germany by a vote of 88 to 10. Rozanne L. Ridgway, now envoy to East Germany, was confirmed to succeed Mr. Burt by 88 to 9. Edwin G. Corr was endorsed, 89 to 8, as envoy to El Salvador.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Previous   Year

headline: European TV Deal
abstract: Compagnie Luxembourgeoise de Telediffusion S.A. and News International P.L.C. plan to form a venture involved in television broadcasting, the principal stockholder in Compagnie Luxembourgeoise, Bruxelles Lambert S.A., said. The projects would include direct broadcasting from satellites and program production, the company said.

headline: Market Place;   Falling-Dollar Stock Plays
abstract: THE ''foreign currency play'' - buying stocks of companies that benefit from the declining value of the dollar - is enjoying a renewed burst of popularity and adding sparkle to the equity market.   In particular, investors have snapped up shares of major drug manufacturers, whose foreign sales account for an estimated 35 to 40 percent of their total business. The Upjohn Company jumped 4 3/4 points Wednesday, and yesterday its stock hit record highs, finishing at 121 1/8, up 3/8.   ''A decline in the dollar is a positive development that adds to the appeal of drug stocks,'' said David F. Saks, an analyst for Morgan, Olmstead, Kennedy & Gardner Inc. ''However, these issues already were benefiting from their recession-resistant nature and the promise of new products. My 'buy' recommendations are Pfizer and Warner-Lambert.''

headline: Textron Unit Sold To Ingersoll-Rand
abstract: Textron Inc. said that it had sold its Fafnir Bearing division to the Ingersoll-Rand Company for an undisclosed price.

headline: FINANCIAL CLOSINGS SPREAD RAPIDLY
abstract: Bowing to nature, not only did Wall Street shut down yesterday but its silence stilled nearly all activity in most of the nation's other financial markets as well.   As Hurricane Gloria roared up the Eastern Seaboard and through the metropolitan area, the New York markets in stocks, government securities, commodities and other financial instruments either never opened or closed by midmorning.   Faced with high absenteeism and concern among those already on the job, banks, investment houses and securities firms concluded in rapid-fire fashion to batten down the hatches and send employees home.   The government securities market opened for about an hour but closed at 10 A.M. after major securities dealers decided that absenteeism was too high. Trading in foreign currencies, which has been a major focus of the financial community this past week, suddenly was reduced in the United States. [Pages 38 and 40.]  Wall Street's shuttering, in turn, quickly rippled across the land, closing the over-the-counter market, the nation's regional stock exchanges, and the two largest futures markets in Chicago, leaving many brokerage firms elsewhere with little choice but to close for the day.

headline: FOR '45 INVASION FORCE ON GUAM, A JOYOUS REPRIEVE
abstract: The writer of this dispatch was a correspondent in Guam for The New York Times at the time of the Japanese surrender in 1945.    The news of Japan's surrender reached Guam, then the heart of the American war effort, just before lunch time on the western side of the International Date Line 40 years ago today. As the realization sank in that the war was really over, the island went wild.   Guam was jammed with marines preparing for the assault on Kyushu on Nov. 1, which was to be the start of the invasion of the Japanese homeland. Military authorities estimated the operation would cost between 500,000 and a million casualties.

headline: ECUADOR TROOPS TRAP KIDNAPPERS OF BANKER
abstract: Special police and army units engaged left-wing guerrillas in a brief gunfight today and then surrounded the house near Guayaquil where the rebels are holding a kidnapped banker, Nahim Isaias, the governor of the state of Guayas said.   Gov. Jaime Nebot said that the guerrillas belonged to Colombia's April 19 Movement, and Alfaro Vive, an Ecuadoran rebel group.

headline: P.& G. Proposals On Takeover Bids
abstract: The Procter & Gamble Company will ask its shareholders to approve various anti-takeover amendments. The company said the steps were intended ''to encourage any person seeking to obtain control of the company to deal directly with the board,'' adding that it ''is not aware that any party has plans of any nature to acquire or seek control of the company.''

headline: Searle Head To Quit Post
abstract: G.D. Searle & Company said yesterday that its chairman and chief executive, Donald H. Rumsfeld, will leave those posts after Aug. 31, in anticipation of Searle's $2.7 billion merger with the Monsanto Company. The company said Mr. Rumsfeld, a former Secretary of Defense, whose departure had been expected, will ''continue to assist in the transition'' for a period after he steps down.   The company said its president and chief operating officer, John E. Robson, will assume the additional post of chief executive Sept. 1, also ''for a period during the transition,'' until Searle becomes a subsidiary of Monsanto after the merger.

headline: Uganda Military Chief Is Made Head of State
abstract: The Chief of Staff of Uganda's armed forces, who has been a soldier since 1940, was sworn in today as interim head of state.

headline: Penn Central
abstract: The Penn Central Corporation said it had ended negotiations on the possible acquisition of the Empire Gas Corporation.

headline: Nepal Frees 1,649 of 1,750
abstract: Nepal today announced the release of 1,649 people detained for questioning about bomb blasts in June that killed seven people. It said 101 people were still in custody and announced the start of legal proceedings against extremists accused of involvement in the blasts.

headline: THAI LEADER STRESSES STABILITY
abstract: Prime Minister Prem Tinsulandonda, who recently survived the second attempted coup against his administration in less than five years, is going to the United States to convince investors that Thailand is economically and politically stable.   Economic grievances rank high among the reasons that dissident officers gave for trying to oust the Prem Government on Sept. 9. The coup was put down within 10 hours.   On the eve of his Tuesday departure for Honolulu, the first stop on his trip, Prime Minister Prem made a rare television address, warning Thais that there is no easy way out of recession. His tour will take him to New York, where he will meet American officials and address the United Nations General Assembly.

headline: China Assays 5-Year Plan
abstract: China today declared its current five-year economic plan to be a success, setting the scene for the introduction of the next five-year plan sometime over the next two weeks.   The official Economic Daily said most of the targets in the current plan, drawn up to guide economic development from 1981 through 1985, were surpassed one or two years ago.

headline: SHOPPING FOR A MORTGAGE
abstract: GREGORY P. HICKEY, a 35-year-old tax partner with Price Waterhouse, in Los Angeles, went mortgage shopping a few months ago to finance the $350,000 home he wanted to buy in the Hancock Park section of Los Angeles.   Mr. Hickey, who makes about $115,000 a year, had $83,750 to put down, and needed a mortgage for $266,250. ''It was confusing and time-consuming to reach a decision,'' he said after picking a 30-year adjustable-rate mortgage with an initial interest rate of 10 percent. ''Even for a C.P.A., it's difficult to do the analysis.''   Mr. Hickey currently lives in a condominium he owns that he intends to rent after he moves into his new home. If he sold it, he said, he would have to take a loss. ''I'm so conscious about my cash because I'm not selling the condo,'' he said, ''that I needed to get the lowest monthly payment possible'' on the new mortgage.

headline: Stanley S. Kresge
abstract: By most accounts, Stanley Sebastian Kresge, who died June 30 at the age of 85, was a man of strong principles. In 1977, the S. S. Kresge Company, founded by his father, was voting on changing its name to the K Mart Corporation.

headline: ICAHN SAID TO SEEK TEXAS AIR PULLOUT
abstract: Advisers representing Carl C. Icahn and the Texas Air Corporation are involved in talks to get Texas Air to withdraw its offer for Trans World Airlines, and thus speed Mr. Icahn's ability to buy out the remaining shareholders and name his own directors, sources involved in the negotiations said yesterday.   Mr. Icahn and his partners, in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission yesterday, said they had increased their holdings to 47 percent, from 45.54 percent, by buying two blocks of shares on Wednesday, totaling 742,000 shares.   T.W.A. shares closed at $22.375 yesterday, unchanged, in trading on the New York Stock Exchange.      Bitter Struggle    Mr. Icahn confirmed in an interview that the talks with Texas Air were going on. ''We would rather do it peacefully,'' he said, referring to the bitter takeover struggle that the two companies have been involved in since last June 13, when the T.W.A. board agreed to merge with Texas Air for $23 a share. Mr. Icahn later offered $24 a share, and Texas Air came back with a $26-a-share bid, but then lost the support of T.W.A.'s board.

headline: Reagan Says He Hopes To End 'Nuclear Threat'
abstract: President Reagan, in a message to a nuclear nonproliferation conference, said today that he wanted to build a more cooperative relationship with the Soviet Union and ''rid the world of the nuclear threat.''

headline: A BRITISH INVASION OF CAPITAL MARKETS
abstract: The British are coming to Wall Street. Aiming to emulate American brokerages and commercial banks that are firmly entrenched in the London financial market, merchant banks from Britain are scrambling to expand into the New York capital market.   Robert Fleming Holdings Ltd., one of the largest merchant banks in London, announced two weeks ago, for instance, that it had agreed to purchase F. Eberstadt & Company, a small, specialized Wall Street research firm. Last month, S. G. Warburg, the venerable London firm, reorganized and widened its American securities business. And over the last few years other large British financial institutions - such as Kleinwort, Benson Ltd.; Mercantile House Holdings P.L.C., and J. Rothschild Holdings P.L.C. - have begun building American bases of operation.

headline: Treasury Yields Off Modestly
abstract: Interest rates on short- and long-term Treasury issues declined modestly yesterday.   By late in the day, rates for outstanding Treasury bills were lower by a few hundredths of a percentage point, though rates at the auction of new bills were up from last week's levels. While outstanding three-month bills were bid at 7.12 percent, down from 7.15 percent on Friday, the new three-month issue sold at an average rate of 7.12 percent, up from 7.07 percent a week ago. The new six-month bill averaged 7.30 percent, up from 7.21 percent.

headline: MERRILL UNIT APPEARS TO WIN SCM
abstract: Merrill Lynch Capital Markets appeared yesterday to have made the winning bid to buy the SCM Corporation, but may yet have a major battle on its hands for the giant typewriter, food and chemical company.   Joining forces with the Prudential Insurance Company and SCM executives, Merrill Lynch Capital, the investment banking arm of Merrill Lynch & Company, yesterday offered stockholders $74 a share, or $906.5 million, prompting Hanson Trust P.L.C., the British conglomerate and SCM's only other suitor, to withdraw its competing offer of $72 a share.   By late yesterday, however, enormously heavy buying of SCM stock hit the New York Stock Exchange, with sources friendly to SCM contending that Hanson was the buyer.   These sources estimated that Hanson had purchased between 1.5 million and 2 million SCM shares before the 4 P.M. trading halt, and may have continued buying in other markets after the Big Board closed.

headline: Ralston Purina Up 56%
abstract: The Ralston Purina Company said yesterday that it earned $57.1 million, or 71 cents a share, in its third fiscal quarter, up 56 percent, from $36.6 million, or 42 cents a share, in the same period of 1984. Sales rose to $1.39 billion, from $1.17 billion. William P. Stiritz, the company's chairman and chief executive, said the earnings of the grocery products and pet food businesses continued to be favorable.

headline: UGANDA REGAINING UNEASY NORMALCY
abstract: A semblance of calm rested uneasily on this East African country today, a week after a military coup brought a wave of looting and a plague of uncertainty.   Soldiers, many of them very young, are stationed throughout this tattered capital city, carrying automatic weapons and positioning themselves around antiaircraft guns on grassy knolls. Mounds of empty shells suggest that some of the artillery has been put to heavy use in recent days.   The soliders' ubiquitous and makeshift checkpoints are represented by lines of beer bottles in the streets or rows of tires and garbage cans, some decorated with slashes of colorful flowers.

headline: Fitch Suspends Ratings Of 4 Middle South Units
abstract: Fitch Investors Service Inc. announced yesterday that it had suspended the debt and stock ratings of all four operating companies of Middle South Utilities Inc.   The action affects a total of $3.7 billion of debt securities of the four companies: the Arkansas Power and Light Company, the Louisiana Power and Light Company, the Mississippi Power and Light Company and New Orleans Public Service Company.

headline: Wheeling Labor Ruling
abstract: A Federal District Court judge in Pittsburgh today upheld last month's decision by a bankruptcy court allowing the Wheeling-Pittsburgh Steel Corporation to void its labor contracts.   Wheeling-Pittsburgh, the nation's seventh-largest steel company, filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection in April after a breakdown in efforts to negotiate additional wage concessions with the United Steelworkers of America.

headline: 2 Former Amin Officers Join Uganda Council
abstract: Two army officers who served under President Idi Amin in the 1970's were among four guerrilla leaders named to Uganda's ruling Military Council after agreeing to cooperate with the new Government, Radio Uganda announced.

headline: Grey to Handle Special Coins
abstract: Grey Advertising has been named to handle advertising and promotion for the Treasury Department's Statue of Liberty/Ellis Island Commemorative Coins.

headline: Virginia Bank Head Quits
abstract: Douglas H. Ludeman has resigned as president of United Virginia Bankshares Inc., in the wake of a finding by the company's audit committee that he violated company rules by buying stock in three other bank holding companies at the same time United Virginia was buying shares in two of the companies.   The company named Richard G. Tilghman, 44 years old, formerly vice chairman, to succeed Mr. Ludeman, 54, as president. Mr. Tilghman will also become chief executive, succeeding Joseph A. Jennings, 65, who will retire from that post Sept. 1, but will remain chairman.

headline: PATENTS;  X-ray Scan For Space Shuttles
abstract: X-RAY equipment to check the alignment of metal parts in space shuttles was patented this week for the National Aeronautics and Space Administration.

headline: JOHN KERANS, BRITISH SKIPPER WHO LED '49 YANGTZE EXCAPE
abstract: Comdr. John S. Kerans, the British naval officer who was hailed as a hero after he stealthily guided the frigate Amethyst down the Yangtze River out of a Chinese blockade in 1949, died Wednesday, his family said.

headline: Free Trade Talks Set To Begin
abstract: President Reagan's demand that United States banks, insurance companies and other service industries get better access to foreign markets will be the major point of controversy at talks opening here Monday to discuss beginning a new round of international trade-freeing negotiations, according to trade officials.   Representatives from 90 nations will be trying again to agree to begin a new trade round, the ninth since the end of World War II, during a special three-day meeting of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, the body overseeing world trade. This week's talks are critical, because they may decide whether a new trade round starts in a atmosphere of global consensus, or after a split between industrialized and developing nations.   A new international trade negotiation, which would be the first since the five-year ''Tokyo Round'' ended in 1979, is seen by the Reagan Administration and many other governments as a means of defusing explosive protectionist pressures building in the United States and elsewhere.

headline: WHY VICKS IS SUCH A HOT PROPERTY
abstract: Richardson-Vicks Inc. may not be on the leading edge of technology or the keeper of vast undervalued assets, but in the corporate takeover market its basic business - catering to the whims of the consumer market - is what is hot these days.   Last weekend Unilever, the world's largest consumer company, showed that it was so eager to find even more ways way to tap the consumer's wallet that it offered to buy Richardson-Vicks for what Wall Street feels is an exceptionally attractive price of $54 a share, or $1.24 billion in cash.   Richardson-Vicks, a company that prides itself on products that attack the common cold, acne, dirty hair and rough skin, rejected the offer as inadequate, even though last Friday its stock was trading for barely $36.   By yesterday, Richardson-Vicks's stock stood at $48, up $1.875 for the day on a volume of 2.9 million shares.

headline: Uganda's Talks With Guerrillas Stall
abstract: Peace talks between Uganda's month-old military Government and members of the nation's main guerrilla group broke off today with no apparent progress made, officials said.   The talks were the first between the National Resistance Army and the Government since the military toppled President Milton Obote in a coup July 27.

headline: Utility Bonds In California
abstract: M-S-R Public Power Agency, a consortium of municipally owned utilities in Modesto, Santa Clara, and Redding, Calif., is offering $242 million of electric revenue bonds with a maximum yield of 9.323 percent for bonds due 2021, through underwriters led by E. F. Hutton & Company. The bonds are rated single A by both Moody's and S.& P. The financing includes other bonds yielding from 6 percent in 1987 to 7 1/4 percent in 1990, 8.60 percent in 1996 and 9.178 percent in 2005. Proceeds will be used to retire bond anticipation notes issued by M-S-R to purchase an interest in a coal-fired power plant.

headline: Israel Suffers Inflation Rise
abstract: Israel, which began a three-month austerity program in July aimed at restoring the country's ailing economy, suffered its worst monthly inflation ever last month, officials said today.   The Central Bureau of Statistics said July's record 27.5 percent surge in inflation was predicted when the Government announced its economic emergency program in July.

headline: RESURGENCE IN CANADA GOLD
abstract: In the early 1980's the high price of gold caused Canada's Government and mining industry to make some decisions that seemed imprudent when bullion's price fell by nearly two-thirds. Now, with the world's most productive gold fields caught in the turmoil of South Africa, the Canadian moves are starting to seem shrewd.   Gold is ''the one sector in the mining area in Canada which is cooking,'' Christopher Bryan, vice president of Levesque Beaubien Inc., a Montreal securities firm, said. ''There are no long faces. Piles and piles of money are flowing into gold exploration.''   Sizable profits have also flowed into the pockets of investors in Canadian gold stocks. The Toronto Stock Exchange's index of gold shares has posted a 59 percent gain this year.

headline: INQUIRY IS SOUGHT ON AID TO REBELS
abstract: Common Cause, the Washington-based lobbying group, called today for Congressional investigations of the National Security Council's involvement with the Nicaraguan rebels over the last year.   Last week the White House confirmed reports, first published in The New York Times, that the National Security Council had been helping several Nicaraguan rebel groups plan some operations and raise private funds. The rebels have been fighting to overthrow the Nicaraguan Government.

headline: BISHOP TUTU SAVES MAN FROM CROWD
abstract: Against the backdrop of a blazing automobile, Bishop Desmond M. Tutu, winner of the 1984 Nobel Peace Prize, argued and wrestled with a crowd of angry blacks today to rescue a man the crowd called a collaborator with the white authorities.   Activists in the crowd said they wanted to incinerate their victim alive on the burning car for his purported crimes, but he escaped to safety after the Bishop's intervention.   The incident was one of many during a funeral on an African winter's day in this township 30 miles east of Johannesburg that brought into sharp focus the hatreds that township dwellers reserve for both the white-led police and those blacks deemed to be collaborating with the authorities.   Members of the crowd accused the black man of being a police undercover operative. The man's ''sentence'' was passed by an impromptu gathering of blacks who did not believed the man's story - that he was the son of a butcher from nearby Daveyton. His car was set on fire, an activist said, ''to provide his funeral pyre.''

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: * AEL Industries, Montgomeryville, Pa., which designs and manufactures radar and other electronic equipment, promoted Mark Ronald and George King to senior vice presidents.    * Batus Retail Group appointed Hugh V. Cochrane executive vice president of its Gimbels East Division, with responsibility for finance and loss prevention.

headline: MEXICO'S ELECTION: NATION'S IMAGE MAY HAVE LOST
abstract: The official results of Mexico's national elections were announced today, and they showed the governing Institutional Revolutionary Party winning all seven governorships that were at stake, all but five of the 300 elected seats in the Chamber of Deputies, and all but a handful of dozens of local and state offices.         But the major damage, some politicians and foreign diplomats here say, was not done to the opposition. There was more than a reasonable chance that most of its candidates would have lost in any case.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Previous   Year

headline: Bell's Stockholders Back Guinness Bid
abstract: Arthur Guinness & Sons P.L.C. claimed victory today in its battle to acquire the Scotch whisky producer Arthur Bell & Sons P.L.C. for $518 million.   Guinness's 10-week campaign to add Bell's whisky brands and its Gleneagles Hotels group to its stable of businesses had been bitterly resisted by Bell.

headline: RELIEF AGENCY DEFENDS MOVES
abstract: Catholic Relief Services, the largest private charity distributing United States Government food in Ethiopia, yesterday defended its handling of funds collected for famine victims.   Lawrence A. Pezzullo, the agency's executive director, said complaints from former employees that the charity had misled donors by failing to properly spend money collected since October did not take into consideration the agency's long-term efforts in the drought-stricken country.   Mr. Pezzullo made his remarks at a news conference at the agency's Manhattan offices.

headline: KOHLBERG'S STORER BID IS ACCEPTED
abstract: Storer Communications Inc. yesterday accepted an improved $2.03 billion acquisition offer from Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company, while turning down a new bid made by the Comcast Corporation valued at $2.1 billion.   Julian Brodsky, chief financial officer of Comcast, a cable company based in Bala-Cynwyd, Pa., said he was ''amazed and disappointed'' with Storer's decision to accept the lower bid.   Under the Kohlberg, Kravis offer, shareholders would receive $91 a share in cash as well as a warrant to buy shares of stock in the company estimated to be worth an additional $3 a share, while Comcast's package of cash and stock was valued at $98 a share.      Offer Worth More    Paul Tierney, a member of the Storer board, conceded that the Comcast offer appeared to be worth about $4 a share more than Kohlberg, Kravis's new bid. But, he said, it would have been less favorable to Storer's shareholders on an after-tax basis. ''This was a good offer,'' Mr. Tierney said of the new Kohlberg, Kravis bid, but he agreed that the Comcast offer was also a good one.

headline: Accounts
abstract: Coachmen Recreational Vehicles, a division of Coachmen Industries of Elkhart, Ind., to BBDM Cunningham & Walsh, Chicago.

headline: Paine Webber in Black
abstract: Paine Webber Group Inc. said yesterday that it earned $12.5 million, or 63 cents a share, in the quarter ended June 30, in contrast to a $4 million loss a year earlier. Revenues increased 30.9 percent, to $493.8 million, from $377.3 million. Elsewhere, earnings at Jefferies Group Inc. were off 12 percent, to $2.2 million, or 27 cents a share, from $2.5 million, or 31 cents.

headline: Vietnam Reports Clashes
abstract: Vietnam said today that its armed forces killed or wounded 50 Chinese soldiers in repelling attacks along its northern border this week. A Vietnamese radio broadcast monitored in Bangkok said Chinese troops fired nearly 20,000 artillery rounds into Vi Xuyen district of Ha Tuyen province Monday and Tuesday.

headline: PAULSON TAKES CONTROL AT WHEELING
abstract: The embattled Wheeling-Pittsburgh Steel Corporation today named Allen E. Paulson, its largest shareholder and a leading businessman, as chairman.   He replaces Dennis J. Carney, who resigned today. Mr. Carney said he hoped his departure would help resolve ''the current labor impasse'' and ''accommodate the desires of Mr. Paulson.''   Mr. Carney led Wheeling into an expensive modernization program, costing hundreds of millions of dollars, but he failed to restore its profitability, and in April the company filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection. Analysts said that what doomed him was his failure to win further concessions from the company's union. Instead, he embittered the union, which struck in July.

headline: RUN ON MARYLAND THRIFT UNIT
abstract: Depositors of Community Savings and Loan Inc. of Bethesda, Md., waited in line to make withdrawals over the weekend after the disclosure that a real estate investment subsidiary affiliated with the thrift unit had missed some debt payments.   But Community Savings said the financial problems at the subsidiary, the Equity Programs Investment Corporation, would have ''no effect on Community Savings and Loan.'' Community Savings has assets of about $400 million.   Community Savings said Friday that Equity Programs had failed to make some payments to holders of about $1 billion in mortgage-backed securities it issued to finance real estate deals, and that it could be in technical default by the end of this month.

headline: Security for Balloting High in New Caledonia
abstract: More than 3,000 paramilitary gendarmes and policemen took up positions across this French Pacific territory today ahead of crucial elections Sunday pitting French loyalists against Melanesian separatists.   Despite high tension on both sides, the last week of the campaign passed with little violence.

headline: INDIA'S 'TEJI' (BULL) MARKET
abstract: A typical day on the floor of the Bombay stock exchange: About 2,000 frantic, sweating brokers are packed into an immense, sweltering room. They are pushing and shoving each other and everyone seems to be screaming.   This exuberant roar can be heard blocks away. It is the sound of India's latest flirtation with capitalism, and while most financial people are delighted by it, some are worried.   Prompted by the biggest burst of optimism ever to hit the Indian business community, the Bombay stock exchange is having a boom unlike anything since the country's independence in 1947. The ''teji,'' or bull, has completely vanquished the ''mandi,'' or bear.

headline: AMAX Posts Big Loss
abstract: AMAX Inc. said yesterday that it lost $394.9 million in the second quarter, in contrast to earnings of $9.8 million, or 6 cents a share, a year ago. Sales were down 19.7 percent, to $523 million, from $651 million in the 1984 period. The loss partly reflects a $350 million write-down of properties and investments, including $175 million in termination costs for copper facilities in Arizona and Carteret, N.J.

headline: SOVIET CALLS ITS RIGHTS FOES IN WEST SLAVE TRADERS WHO DEBAUCH GIRLS
abstract: A Soviet spokesman accused human rights advocates in the West today of being slave traders who run networks of houses of prostitution where they debauch young girls.   The emotional accusation by the chief of the Foreign Ministry's press department, Vladimir B. Lomeiko, appeared to add a new dimension to the often repeated Soviet charges of hypocrisy in the West over human rights.   At a news conference devoted to the human rights provisions of the 1975 Helsinki accords, Mr. Lomeiko also suggested that Jews had difficulty in leaving the United States, while asserting that such problems do not exist in the Soviet Union.   In answer to a question, he said Andrei D. Sakharov, the physicist and dissident, was exiled to the city of Gorky in 1980 to prevent him from divulging state secrets to foreigners. He said such safeguards on state secrets were common in the West as well.

headline: Retirements Raise Arco's Write-Off
abstract: The Atlantic Richfield Company said today that about 6,000 employees, or nearly 16 percent of its work force, have taken part in the company's early-retirement plan designed to pare the company's payroll as part of its broad restructuring announced in April.   The unexpected response from its employees will cause a $200 million increase in Arco's one-time after-tax charge, to $1.5 billion.

headline: Mississippi Refinancing $205 Million Road Issue
abstract: Mississippi is offering $205 million of highway revenue refunding bonds through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers Inc.   The financing includes serial bonds tentatively priced yesterday to yield from 5 1/4 percent for bonds due in 1986 to 7.40 percent in 1990, 8.60 percent in 1995 and 9 percent in 1999.

headline: WHERE KRISHNA FROLICKED, JOY MARKS HIS BIRTHDAY
abstract: The first shadows of dusk seem to bring this sacred old city to life with prayer. From countless corners in its narrow, winding streets comes an eery tinkling of cymbals, the buzz of chanting and the peal of bells.   The soft night air soon becomes fragrant with incense and sweets to be offered to Lord Krishna, one of the most popular gods of the Hindu pantheon. Thousands of years ago, Krishna's sensuous adolescent adventures are said to have taken place here on the banks of the Jumna River.

headline: Advertising;   Vogue's 'Essential Woman'
abstract: THE Cosmo Girl holds a special place in advertising circles. She is intended to embody the readership of Cosmopolitan, allowing advertising decision makers the freedom to discard all those readership demographic data and just think of her as the personification of the magazine.   In the belief that this is a beneficial ploy, Vogue and its agency, Chalk, Nissan, Hanft, have created the ''Essential Woman.''   It appears that her most endearing quality is that she spends money easily and frequently for the kind of high-ticket items that advertise in the Conde Nast fashion magazine.

headline: Zimbabwe M.P.'s Renew Emergency Decree
abstract: Zimbabwe's new Parliament, meeting for the first time since elections this month, renewed the country's state of emergency today.   The emergency powers provide for indefinite detention without trial, a provision Government ministers say is needed to combat anti-Government rebels but which opposition politicians say are being used unfairly against minority parties.   The opposition leader, Joshua Nkomo, said that six legally registered weapons were confiscated from his home in Bulawayo on Tuesday and that 11 unarmed guards were taken into custody by authorities from his home in Harare today.

headline: NICARAGUA CALLS REBELS A THREAT IN HBONDURAS
abstract: Nicaragua's Embassy in Honduras has requested protection from the Honduran Foreign Ministry after threats from right-wing Nicaraguan rebels.   An embassy communique published today in local newspapers said Ambassador Danilo Abud Vivas had put the request to the Honduran Foreign Minister, Edgardo Paz Barnica, after learning of ''terrorist plans by the counterrevolution.''

headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE;Economist at Chemical Loses His Department
abstract: Following similar steps taken by a number of money center banks in recent years, the Chemical Bank has disbanded its economics department and is seeking to place its staff of 40 -a figure that includes 20 economists - in other areas  of the bank.         ''All of the banks feel acute pressures on costs, and are looking at anything and everything in order to reduce them,'' said Frederick Deming, a senior vice president and economist at Chemical who headed the unit.

headline: Farm Credit System Sets Rates for Bond Sale
abstract: The Farm Credit System announced details yesterday of its first bond sale since its senior officials warned that it might need Federal assistance to cope with mounting losses on loans to farmers.   The agency set an interest rate of 8.30 percent for $1.366 billion of new six-month bonds, which are offered at a price of 100.

headline: Storer Meeting
abstract: Storer Communications Inc.'s board met yesterday to decide which of two takeover offers to accept, amid indications that a decision would be announced soon.

headline: 16 Turks Die in Bus Plunge
abstract: Sixteen Turks were killed today when the minibus they were traveling in plunged 300 feet down a cliff near the southern town of Adana, the Anatolian News Agency reported. One passenger survived.
