headline: GROUPS OF KOREANS CROSS BORDER, ENDING KIN VISIT
abstract: Groups of North and South Korean visitors recrossed the border today and returned home after historic reunions with separated families they had not seen since before the Korean War.   Red Cross officials on both sides called the highly unusual exchange of families a success, and said they hoped that more would follow.   But it was evident, too, that the two Koreas had not forgotten their mutual distrust, and they issued complaints and protests even as their citizens were boarding buses for home.

headline: MAKING INVESTMENT CHOICES IN THE FACE OF THE DEFICIT
abstract: INFLATION has fallen two-thirds from its level of five years ago, and financial assets are back in style. It's happy days again for stocks and bonds and bye-bye to gold bars and other physical assets.   But what happens now that interest rates have fallen so much that Treasury bills and money market funds yield only a couple of percentage points more than passbook savings accounts, and the stock market averages have hit record highs? How much more good news awaits, when the Federal Government still spends 24 percent of the nation's gross national product, about $200 billion a year more than the 19 percent of G.N.P. it collects in taxes?   Although many still think that stocks, bonds, and - for the most conservative - certificates of deposit are the best places for their money, Washington's lack of commitment to budget-cutting has cast a definite pall on things.

headline: House Passes a Ban On Rebel Arms Aid
abstract: The House of Representatives today approved by a voice vote an authorization bill for intelligence agencies which would ban ''material assistance including arms, ammunition, equipment or other material which could be used to inflict serious bodily harm or death'' for the Nicaraguan rebels fighting the Sandinista Government.

headline: I.B.M.'s 30-Year Bonds Set to Yield 10.572%
abstract: The International Business Machines Corporation, like hundreds of companies that have jumped into the bond market in recent weeks for relatively low-cost financing, is offering $500 million of 30-year bonds through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers.   The bonds carry a 10 1/2 percent coupon and are offered at a price of 99.35, to yield 10.572 percent.

headline: Baxter Pact Is Canceled
abstract: In a retaliatory move, the Hospital Corporation of America canceled a $100 million contract with Baxter Travenol Laboratories Inc., a company that so far has successfully blocked Hospital Corporation's planned merger with the American Hospital Supply Corporation.   The contract for intravenous solutions was to have run through 1987.

headline: COMPUTER TASK GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: The Slowdown At Restaurants
abstract: RESTAURANT sales, a discretionary spending item that analysts sometimes focus on to divine shifts in the economy, have been sagging lately. The downturn, which has occurred during the normally strong summer months, has had an impact on restaurant stocks and caused some analysts to revise their investment strategy toward the group.   The slump has come after a six-month period when restaurant stocks performed significantly better than the overall market, as measured by the Standard & Poor's 500 index. And it has hit Church's Fried Chicken Inc., the nation's No. 2 fried chicken chain, after Reynolds Industries' Kentucky Fried Chicken, especially hard.

headline: Marsh Picks Consultant
abstract: Marsh & McLennan Inc., the big insurance brokerage, said it had retained John R. Cox, a former executive vice president of the Cigna Corporation, as special consultant to a new liability insurance company being organized by Marsh. Marsh said the new company, the American Casualty Excess Insurance Company, would provide catastrophe liability insurance as well as liability insurance for directors and officers of industrial companies. Marsh said it had received commitments from 15 companies for capital investments totaling $140 million in the new company, which plans to be in operation by the end of the summer.

headline: A POIGNANT TIME FOR RUMANIA'S DWINDLING JEWS
abstract: ''No conversions to Judaism are accepted,'' announces a handwritten sign at the door to the office of Rumania's Chief Rabbi. ''It is useless to insist.'' A sign that might have been the height of sarcasm some years ago in a country that has known as much anti-Semitism as the rest of Eastern Europe reflects today's reality. Jews enjoy the privilege of being allowed to emigrate more or less freely, and many Rumanians are ready to pay the price of adopting an unpopular faith for that opportunity.   In the past some Rumanians, to gain greater acceptance, hid the fact that even part of their ancestry was Jewish. But today many come to Jewish offices to claim fictitious Jews in their family trees or to confess infidelities they may have never committed to try to offer their children a chance to emigrate.

headline: UNITED NATIONS: 40 YEARS OF GROWTH AND CONFLICT
abstract: xhrrJune 26, 1945 United Nations Charter signed in San Francisco. Oct. 24, 1945 United Nations is created as Charter comes into force. Jan. 10, 1946 First General Assembly, with 51 nationsrepresented, opens in Central Hall, Westminster, London. Feb. 1, 1946 Trygve Lie, a Norwegian, appointed first Secretary General. Dec. 11, 1946 Assembly meets in New York. Nov. 29, 1947 General Assembly adopts plan to end British mandate in Palestine, and partition it into Arab and Jewish states with Jerusalem under U.N. administration. Dec. 10, 1948 General Assembly adopts Universal Declaration on Human Rights. Jan. 7, 1949 Dr. Ralph Bunche secures cease-fire between new state of Israel and Arabs. Dec. 3, 1949 General Assembly establishes office of High Commissioner for Refugees. Jan. 10, 1950 Soviet Union, after Security Council fails to act on its proposal to oust representative of Nationalist China, boycotts Council. June 27, 1950 When North Korea invades South Korea, Security Council - acting in the absence of the Soviet Union -votes military sanctions and calls on members to help repel invasion. In July, establishes unified force under United States command. Jan. 5, 1952 Overriding South African objections, General Assembly takes up question of apartheid. April 7, 1953 Dag Hammarskjold, Swedish diplomat and economist, elected Secretary General after Trygve Lie's resignation. July 27, 1953 U.N. and North Korea sign truce agreement. Nov. 3, 1956 Prime Minister Nagy of Hungary appeals to Security Council to counter Soviet invasion. A day later, Assembly approves resolution, 50 to 8, but it remains unenforced. Nov. 6, 1956 First Emergency Special Session of General Assembly meets over Suez Canal crisis.

headline: AN ICE CREAM WINS JAPANESE
abstract: To be young and fashionable in Tokyo this summer is to be seen with a Haagen-Dazs ice cream cone.   In the swank neighborhoods of Harajuku and Aoyama, where teen-agers flock on weekends to parade their designer clothes, lines stretch outside the red-and-white ice cream shops. Outside one of them, young men in oversized linen jackets or black leather pants strut about, their tough look undermined by the ice cream cones in their hands.   ''I guess people who chase after fashion like this ice cream,'' said Masanobu Endo, a 26-year-old computer games designer who hastened to say he was only eating Haagen-Dazs because he liked it.

headline: HOUSE APPROVES A MEASURE TO AID CAMBODAIN REBELS
abstract: The House voted today to approve $5 million in military and economic aid to the non-Communist rebels in Cambodia. The vote was 288 to 122.  On the same vote, the House rejected an amendment that would have limited the $5 million to humanitarian aid, including food and medicine.   The action, on an amendment to the foreign aid authorization bill for 1986 and 1987, marks the first time that the House has approved aid to forces fighting Vietnam's occupation of Cambodia.

headline: EAST GERMAN ACTION SAID TO HAVE FOILED JUNE PLOT ON U.S. JET
abstract: Sources in the West Berlin Senate said today that the East German authorities had foiled a plot to hijack an American airliner in West Berlin by two people carrying diplomatic passports from a Middle Eastern country.   The sources said security agents in East Germany, acting on a tip, arrested the two about four weeks ago at East Berlin's Schonefeld Airport and found explosives in their bags.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Previous   Year

headline: Freddie Mac Issue
abstract: The Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation, known as Freddie Mac, sold $150 million of 15-year mortgage participation certificatese at an average price of 99 21/32, to yield 10.78 percent. The certificatse are offered at various prices through securities firms. The certificates, which are a kind of mortgage pass-through security, are backed by a pool of 15-year fixed-rate home mortgages.

headline: FARM BANK SYSTEM AT ISSUE
abstract: The recent problems involving the Federal Intermediate Credit Bank of Omaha and other members of the Federal Farm Credit System are shedding light on a little-known network of cooperative lending institutions that is the largest source of loans for the nation's farmers.   Directors of the Federal Farm Credit System are expected to approve a $340 million rescue plan for the ailing Omaha Credit Bank, a plan that has already been endorsed by the presidents of the 37-bank system.   But even if approved, it has come too late to prevent growing concerns among farm state Congressmen and Agriculture Department officials over evidence of wider problems in the system that provides credit supporting $75 billion of the more than $200 billion in national farm debt.   ''The system was at least six months late in getting anything done in Omaha,'' said Representative Cooper Evans, Republican of Iowa, noting that troubles suffered there had imposed a heavy penalty on farmers in its four-state district of Iowa, Nebraska, Wyoming and South Dakota. ''And what happens if you get a couple of other Omaha's?''

headline: Doctors' Income
abstract: To the Editor:   In ''A Squeeze on Doctors' Profits'' (June 2), Dr. Rudkin vents his hostility about the earning power of athletes and other entertainment types. It seems to me that the good doctor is ''out of bounds.''

headline: SANDINISTA ASSERTS WAR HAS TAKEN 12,000 LIVES
abstract: President Daniel Ortega Saavedra said this week that the war against United States-backed rebels had cost the lives of 12,000 Nicaraguans in the last four years.   It was by far the highest estimate of war dead the Government has given. Mr. Ortega said the toll included civilians as well as fighters for both sides.   Mr. Ortega said the war ''could be interminable'' because the Reagan Administration seems determined to continue its support of the rebels. He said the Sandinistas planned no new diplomatic overture to Washington.

headline: MISPLACED CREDIT
abstract: To the Editor:   I would like to call your attention to some misinformation in ''The TV Commercial Tries On Some Disguises'' (Sept. 1). I was the producer of the Chanel commercial ''Share the Fantasy.'' The director was Ridley Scott, who also directed Chanel's ''Garden'' spot.      EVALYN FRUMKIN   Senior TV Producer Young & Rubicam New York, Sept. 3

headline: RUSSIANS SAID TO RETURN 'BOAT PEOPLE' TO VIETNAM
abstract: Thirty-seven Vietnamese, believed to be ''boat people'' fleeing their homeland, have been returned to Vietnam by a Soviet freighter that plucked them from the South China Sea, the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees said today.   Officials of the United Nations commission said it was the first time to their knowledge that Vietnamese refugees had been returned home in all the years since the end of the Vietnam War 10 years ago began a mass exodus from the Southeast Asian nation.   More than 555,000 Vietnamese have fled since the fall of Saigon, many of them in rickety, often unseaworthy craft or private boats. Thousands have died in the South China Sea of starvation, dehydration, accidents and pirate attacks.

headline: New York Fed Hires Financial Consultant
abstract: In another twist in his varied career, Edwin H. Yeo 3d yesterday left Morgan Stanley & Company, where he was a managing director, to become a consultant to the Federal Reserve Bank of New York and a counselor to E. Gerald Corrigan, its president.   Mr. Yeo, who is 51, has a close acquaintance with Paul A. Volcker, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, as well as with Mr. Corrigan.

headline: Morgan Executive Is Moving to Drexel
abstract: Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., the investment banking firm that pioneered the use of high-yield ''junk'' bonds for corporate clients, is rapidly building a staff to expand a similar business internationally.   The most recent addition to Drexel's international trading and capital development unit, part of its corporate finance department, is Antonio Gebauer, who last week resigned from the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company as senior vice president in charge of North American and South American banking operations.   Mr. Gebauer, who is 45 years old, headed Morgan's Latin American division from 1981 until early 1984.

headline: Coke Cuts TV Tie to Rock Show
abstract: COCA-COLA, which was to have been the major advertiser on the ABC-TV Network's three hour prime-time coverage of the highly publicized Live Aid telethon of rock stars Saturday, withdrew its involvement yesterday.   The event, being called the electronic Woodstock, is intended to raise funds to aid the starving in Africa.   It is understood that the reason for Coke's withdrawal is the existence of signs for competitive products in the Wembley Stadium in London, which with John F. Kennedy Stadium in Philadelphia are the two locations for the fund-raiser.   Competitive signs will have no effect on the radio coverage so the embattled Atlanta soft drink giant can continue to be the only network sponsor of the ABC Radio's 6 A.M. to midnight coverage for which it is paying $360,000.

headline: The U.N. Today: Aug. 26, 1985
abstract: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Council for Namibia - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

headline: WHERE IACOCCA AND COMMON SENSE ERR
abstract: THERE IS usually a simple common-sense solution to any economic problem. And usually it is wrong.   America's trade deficit is a perfect example. Here is the common-sense understanding of it - by Lee Iacocca of Chrysler, Lane Kirkland of the A.F.L.-C.I.O., your brother-in-law at the Kiwanis club and your state's Democratic and Republican senators.

headline: People
abstract: Thomas Mabley has been named executive vice president and creative director-U.S. at Henderson Friedlich Graf & Doyle.    * Robert Richards has been appointed general manager of Grey Canada's Toronto office.

headline: Sovran Financial
abstract: The Sovran Financial Corporation, a bank holding company based in Norfolk, Va., said that it had agreed to acquire the D.C. National Bank Corporation in a stock swap valued at $64.5 million. D.C. National is the holding company of D.C. National Bank, the sixth-largest bank in Washington. The merger is contingent on the passage of an interstate banking bill by Washington's City Council and approval of shareholders and regulators. Under the agreement, D.C. National will operate as a separate unit of Sovran under the name Sovran Bank/D.C. National.

headline: Swiss Consumer Prices
abstract: Consumer prices in Switzerland fell two-tenths of 1 percent in July from June but were up 3.4 percent from July 1984, the Government reported today.

headline: DURABLES GOODS ORDERS INCREASED BY A STRONG 3.4% IN AUGUST
abstract: Orders to United States factories for so-called big-ticket durable goods rose a strong 3.4 percent last month, the latest in a string of business barometers showing a moderate rebound in August.   The Commerce Department said today that orders rose to a record $107.9 billion in August. The $3.5 billion rise was propelled by strong demand for autos and military equipment. Strength in the auto sector, reflecting sales incentive programs, has been a factor in a number of the August indicators.

headline: Australian Raises Bid for Brewery
abstract: Alan Bond, the Australian investor, today announced the largest takeover bid in the country's corporate history by raising a previous offer for Castlemaine Tooheys, the brewing giant. Mr. Bond, chief of the brewing and trading conglomerate the Bond Corporation, lifted last week's bid for 50 percent of the Brisbane-based company to $780 million.   The new bid was promptly rejected as inadequate by Castlemaine, which is one of Australia's three leading brewery groups. Mr. Bond, who has a Western Australia brewing monopoly with the Swan Lager brand as well as global business interests, held about 14 percent of Castlemaine as of last Friday. He would secure about 40 percent of the Australian beer market if the takeover was successful.

headline: Hospital Offering From Michigan
abstract: The Michigan State Hospital Finance Authority is offering $90 million of refunding bonds with a maximum yield of 9 1/2 percent for bonds due in 2015 through underwriters led by Kidder, Peabody & Company. For shorter maturities, yields range from 5 percent for bonds due in 1986 to 8.20 percent in 1995 and 9 1/8 percent in 2004.   The bonds are issued for the Sisters of Mercy Health Corporation. Because they are insured by the Municipal Bond Insurance Association, they are rated Aaa by Moody's and AAA by S.& P.

headline: Gorbachev on Vacation
abstract: Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader, left Moscow today on vacation, the press agency Tass said. It did not say how long he would be gone or where he would spend his vacation, but Kremlin leaders traditionally have a two-month summer break in the Crimea.

headline: LEBANON BAST WORRIES RED CROSS
abstract: Officials of the International Committee of the Red Cross said today that the use of a stolen Red Cross vehicle in a car bombing in southern Lebanon this week had seriously hampered the agency's work in Lebanon.   Officials said the attack, which occurred Monday, was the first incident in years of work in Lebanon in which a Red Cross vehicle had been used in an attack.

headline: Ratings Reviewed For ATT Entities
abstract: Debt and preferred stock ratings of ATT Technologies Inc. and the ATT Credit Corporation are under review for possible downgrading, Moody's Investors Service said yesterday.

headline: U.S. Priest Held for 3 Days By the Honduran Authorities
abstract: A Roman Catholic priest from the United States was detained Sunday for investigation of possible ''crimes against the security of the state'' and then released late Tuesday.   A church spokesman said the priest, The Rev. John Donald, a native of Albuquerque, N.M., had been turned over to the custody of Msgr. Oscar Andrew Rodriguez, auxiliary bishop of Tegucigalpa, who promised to vouch for his behavior.

headline: The U.N. Today: Aug. 8, 1985
abstract: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Decolonization Committee - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

headline: Mobil Withdrawal
abstract: The Mobil Corporation, citing ''intense competitive pressure,'' has announced that it has withdrawn from selling gasoline and diesel fuel in New Mexico, Oklahoma, most of Arkansas, western Texas and the southern part of Nevada. Mobil said it would continue to market aviation fuel and lubricants in all the areas affected. It also said it would continue other business interests in those areas.

headline: First Fiber-Optic Product for Kodak
abstract: The Eastman Kodak Company will enter the fiber-optics market with a connector for single-mode optical fibers produced by its newly formed division, Lamdek Fiber Optics, the company announced.

headline: Takeover Bill Seen Needless
abstract: The staff of the Federal Trade Commission said today that a New York State bill to restrict corporate takeovers was unnecessary and would damage stockholders and the economy.   The F.T.C., responding to a request for comments by Governor Cuomo, said there was ''no need'' for further regulation of corporate takeovers, which it said are generally beneficial, whether friendly or hostile.

headline: MODERATE LIST OF NEW ISSUES SEEN
abstract: In the corporate market this week a moderate number of issues are expected to be offered, with a large number of shelf registrations still poised to come to market should interest rates move lower.   Except for large offerings from I.B.M., Atlantic Richfield and Pantry Pride, as well as one by Canada, activity last week was lighter than normal.   Some securities dealers said Friday that many domestic borrowers are holding back because they believe lower interest rates lie ahead, while foreign investors, particularly the Japanese and West Germans, stayed on the sidelines because of the continuing decline of the dollar.   Treasury financing this week is confined to the bill market. Proceeds from the new issues will be used to refund maturing bills and raise new cash to reduce the Federal deficit.

headline: GUNMAN IN CYPRUS SAID TO BE BRITON
abstract: One of three gunmen who killed three Israelis aboard a yacht off Cyprus Wednesday was identified today as a Briton.   Two years ago journalists interviewed the Briton after he had fought alongside supporters of Yasir Arafat, the chairman of the Palestine Liberation Organization.   A Cypriot Government spokesman identified the man as Ian Michael Davison of South Shields in northern England. The gunman had said he was a Palestinian named George Hannah.

headline: Import Duty On Ethanol
abstract: William von Raab, the Commissioner of Customs, said today that, in response to complaints from domestic producers, he was reversing an earlier ruling and imposing a duty of 60 cents a gallon on imports of blended ethanol, effective today.   Ethanol, or ethyl alcohol, is mixed with gasoline to make gasohol.

headline: IN CAPE TOWN, APERITIFS AMID THE ANGER
abstract: Images of a day in South Africa:   At the Athlone sports stadium, during the first charge of the day against demonstrators, many run, weaving their way through parked cars, past fruit stores and supermarkets, pursued by policemen. One man, tired of fleeing, raises his arms in surrender, but is not permitted to give up. He is thrashed with heavy whips.

headline: SOVIET FOUND AHEAD IN ARMS
abstract: A new appraisal of the military balance between the superpowers says the United States still lags behind the Soviet Union after having spent $1 trillion since President Reagan took office in 1981.   ''We are not doing well in narrowing the gaps between U.S. and Soviet capabilities that existed in 1980,'' according to a study by John Collins of the Congressional Research Service.

headline: Service Merchandise Assigns Creative Job
abstract: The Service Merchandise Company of Nashville, a showroom catalogue merchandiser with 270 stores in 37 states, has turned to Lois Pitts Gershon Pon/GGK for a television image advertising campaign.   The creative-only assignment for the showrooms division has a budget of $1.5 million.

headline: OLDEST LONG BEACH HOTEL TO UNDERGO CONVERSION
abstract: The history of this resort city by the sea - its rise, its decline, and its rebirth in the 1980's - has been intimately tied up with its hotels. The Paradise, the Nassau, the Royale, Waldman's Miami - they stood like surfside icons through the early part of the century, attracting the monied classes from New York, and capturing the spirit of an age of parasols, white tuxedos and jazz.   Later, amid the blight that crept through this and other shore cities from the late 1950's on, the hotels came to symbolize faded glory -hulking reminders of a world that was gone. In the 1960's and 1970's, most of the old hotels became adult care facilities for the elderly and former mental patients. Long Beach was the only city in Nassau County with plenty of vacant and inexpensive rooms.

headline: REAGAN HOPING FOR ARMS PROPOSAL BY SOVIET
abstract: President Reagan is hoping that a ''concrete proposal'' to limit nuclear arms will be offered by the Soviet Foreign Minister in their meeting Friday, the White House national security adviser, Robert C. McFarlane, said today.   But Mr. McFarlane made it plain that the White House remained uncertain whether the Foreign Minister, Eduard A. Shevardnadze, would propose an arms reduction plan in the meeting.   Asked if Mr. Reagan would be disappointed if a plan was not presented, a senior Administration official replied: ''Yes.''   The Soviet Foreign Minister spent more than four hours with Secretary of State George P. Shultz in New York on Wednesday. Aides said no arms proposals were offered then, and the gap between the nations did not narrow.

headline: U.S. NUCLEAR ARMS WERE KEPT IN JAPAN IN 50'S, ARTICLE SAYS
abstract: An article to appear in next week's issue of The Nation magazine says the United States stored nuclear weapons in Japan from 1955 to 1957.   Citing a newly declassified operations manual for nuclear warfare in the Far East, which was issued by Gen. Maxwell D. Taylor in 1955, the article maintains that Japan was part of a network of weapons storage bases that included Okinawa, Iwo Jima and Guam.

headline: FOOD CRISIS SAID TO END IN 8 AFRICAN COUNTRIES
abstract: A United Nations agency dealing with Africa's famine said Friday that the crisis was over in 8 of the 21 nations that faced exceptional food supply problems in 1984-85. But it said the emergency remained acute in five countries.

headline: $195 Million in Bonds Offered by Honolulu
abstract: Honolulu is offering $195 million of general obligation bonds through underwriters led by Citibank with yields ranging from 6.90 percent for those due in 1989 to 8.40 percent in 1995, 9.10 percent in 2000 and 9.40 percent in 2006 through 2008.   The bonds, which will be used to finance a solid-waste energy and resource recovery plant, are backed by Honolulu's full faith and credit and were assigned high-grade ratings of Aa by Moody's Investors Service and AA by the Standard & Poor's Corporation.

headline: CREDIT MARKETS;A 'HOLDING PATTERN' FOR RATES
abstract: Paul A. Volcker, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, does not predict interest rates. When he comments on monetary policy and the outlook for the economy, however, credit market participants are quick to make their own rate predictions.         Last week, after digesting the Fed's mid-year report to Congress on monetary  policy published late Wednesday and a host of fresh economic data issued Thursday, the credit markets concluded that the outlook for lower interest rates is not as bright as a few weeks ago. Consequently, rates rose, with Treasury note and bond yields up about a tenth of a percentage point and short-term rates up by a slightly greater amount. Most of the rate increases occurred Thursday.

headline: GENERATION GAP ADDS TENSION AMONG SOUTH AFRICAN BLACKS
abstract: It's a Saturday in Soweto and conflict seems inevitable.   The word has spread among teen-agers who call each other ''comrade'' - and who do not tolerate those who reject the label - that there is to be a funeral rally, across town, in Avalon cemetery. Cars and minibuses are hijacked, and scores of white troops armed with automatic rifles take up positions along the route.   At the cemetery gates, a blue-painted bus drives by, packed with ''comrades.'' A white soldier whips rifle to shoulder in the firing position, instinctive and menacing as the mock charge of an elephant.

headline: CITY RETAIL SALES FELL IN MONTH
abstract: New York City retail sales in June fell slightly under the year-earlier level, continuing a yearlong slump that has dismayed merchants. Seven of the city's largest retailers had an average decline of three-tenths of 1 percent compared with their sales of June 1984, according to a spot-check over the weekend.   Sales of the metropolitan area stores, including those in the city and in their suburban branches, rose 2 percent in June over the same month in 1984, the spot-check found.

headline: VIOLENCE AND APARTHEID
abstract: The images this weekend linger. Black South Africans tear down the former home of Mohandas K. Gandhi outside Durban systematically, seeing a shrine of peace as no more than a source of free building material. A day later, a black crowd incinerates a fellow black depicted as a sellout.   There is to it all a harsh logic and a kind of explanation. But the beneficiaries include those who seek evidence of black violence with which to counter black political demands.   The damage seems to go deeper than points scored in a propaganda battle. Within less than a week, in which bloodshed has spilled far beyond the areas affected by the state of emergency, blacks have shown themselves sharply divided.

headline: ADVERTISING;  New Agency Is Sought For Gaines Pet Foods
abstract: Gaines Foods Inc., the pet food division of Anderson, Clayton & Company, said it would select one of five advertising agencies to handle its Gravy Train, Cycle, Gaines-Burgers and Top Choice dog foods. The account, estimated at $20 million, had been handled by Benton & Bowles.

headline: People
abstract: Joseph M. Barrett has been named executive vice president and elected to the board at B.B.D.O.    * Spencer Plavoukos and Frank DeVito have been named to board of SSC&B: Lintas Worldwide.    * Jane Newman was named senior vice president/director of account services at Chiat/Day.

headline: Summit Talks Started in War
abstract: The session planned for Geneva would be the latest in a long series of Soviet-American meetings.   The first were held during World War II as part of Big Three allied meetings, when President Roosevelt met with Stalin and Churchill at Teheran and at Yalta.

headline: U.S. Adding to U.N. Agency
abstract: The United States Government is adding $8 million to its 1985 contribution to the United Nations Relief and Works Agency for Palestinian refugees, the organization said today. The increase brings the total American donation this year to $75 million, according to a statement by the agency. The agency said it had cut more than $43 million from its budget in the last six months but still needed an additional $8 million for this year and was approaching other governments for voluntary contributions.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: * Associated Dry Goods Corp. has appointed Herbert A. Abbott Jr. to the new position of vice chairman of its L. S. Ayres & Co. division, which operates department stores in the Cincinnati area throughout Indiana.    * Bausch & Lomb Inc., Rochester, has promoted Thomas C. McDermott to executive vice president of the company and president of U.S. operations, both new positions. It also said that W. Terry Smith, senior vice president of the company and president of its professional eye care products group, has resigned as an officer and director.

headline: LATEST EPISODE IN GUCCI FAMILY FUED
abstract: The fierce family feud over control of the Gucci leather empire took a new turn last week as an Italian court sequestered the 50 percent share of the company controlled by Maurizio Gucci, its chairman.   The action came after Maurizio's uncle, Aldo, and two of Aldo's sons, Roberto and Giorgio, brought suit charging that Maurizio had arranged to have his father's signature forged to gain control of the company. Maurizio Gucci, 37 years old, angrily denied the charge.   On Thursday, a magistrate postponed a showdown by ordering that a shareholders' meeting - essentially a meeting of family members - be put off, pending the appointment of a legal custodian for Maurizio's shares.

headline: New Steps In Athens
abstract: Steps taken to improve security at the Athens airport may result in some delays but increased security, Greek officials said today.   The steps include the construction of a fence around the perimeter of the airport and the guarding of the perimeter by the armed forces, who are equipped with tanks and supported by police cruisers.

headline: Top Yield 9.424% For Texas Agency
abstract: The Texas Housing Agency yesterday tentatively priced $200 million of single-family mortgage revenue bonds with a maximum yield of 9.424 percent for bonds maturing in 2016, through underwriters led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets.

headline: Missing Rebel's Body Is Found in Costa Rica
abstract: The mutilated body of Dr. Hugo Spadafora, a colorful guerrilla fighter, was found this week in southern Costa Rica, according to reports from San Jose, the capital.

headline: CATALOGUES WITH A DIFFERENCE
abstract: If Macy's doesn't tell Gimbels, does Bloomies tell Neiman's?   Perhaps not, but the conclusion that Dallas-based Neiman-Marcus and other specialty stores reach about trendy Bloomingdale's latest ploy will determine whether Bloomies has indeed started a new trend or elected to march alone.   In its latest catalogue, alongside the Bloomingdale winter fashion promotions, are advertisements for cigarettes, cars, liquor and a range of other products - many of which cannot be ordered or bought in any of the Manhattan-based department store's locations.

headline: REVLON PLANS BUYBACK WORTH $57.50 A SHARE
abstract: Directors of Revlon Inc., fighting a takeover bid by Pantry Pride Inc., yesterday approved an offer to repurchase up to 10 million shares of its common stock for new notes and preferred stock valued at $57.50 a share.   The Revlon board noted that this exchange offer would represent ''a substantial premium over recent share prices.'' The announcement came after the close of trading and following a two-hour meeting of directors. Revlon's stock rose 12.5 cents, to $46.375, yesterday.

headline: Advanced Micro Realigns Units
abstract: Advanced Micro Devices, a semiconductor company, said it had realigned its operating units, except the advanced-technology division, into three major business groups -the memory group, the general logic group and the special logic group.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: Bayly, Martin & Fay, an insurance brokerage firm with headquarters in Fort Worth, has named Andrew H. Marks chief executive officer of its New York and northern New Jersey offices.    * Data Architects Inc., Waltham, Mass., which provides computer software and consulting services for the banking, life insurance and telecommunications industries, has elected R. Benanto senior vice president in charge of finance and administration.    * Flow Systems Inc., Kent, Wash., a maker of cutting systems for industrial automation, has appointed its president, Henry C. Massenburg, chief executive officer.

headline: Conoco-Tenneco Plant Being Built
abstract: The E.I. du Pont de Nemours & Company's Conoco Inc. subsidiary said that it and the Tenneco Oil Company were proceeding with construction of a previously proposed natural gas processing plant at a cost of $60 million.

headline: GANDHI ANNOUNCES MAJOR SETTLEMENT WITH SIKH LEADERS
abstract: Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi and Sikh leaders agreed today on steps that the two sides said would ease Sikh hostility toward the Government and hasten an end to turmoil in Punjab.   A key agreement calls for a change in the boundaries of Punjab to increase the Sikh population within the state and give it more of a chance to exercise political influence. Sikhs have long sought greater control, and the more militant groups have been agitating for independence.   In a dramatic announcement in Parliament, Prime Minister Gandhi said the Government had also yielded to demands for more lenient treatment of thousands of Sikhs arrested in riots over the last three years.   In addition, he agreed to greater compensation for those hurt in anti-Sikh rioting last year.

headline: Esso A.G. Closings
abstract: The West German subsidiary of the Exxon Corporation said that it would close refineries in Hamburg and Cologne, putting 800 employees out of work.

headline: SHULTZ PLAYS HOST TO SOVIET MINISTER
abstract: Secretary of State George P. Shultz and the new Soviet Foreign Minister, Eduard A. Shevardnadze, met today in what the American called ''a good first step'' in preparing a summit meeting in November.   ''The talks were serious and good,'' Mr. Shevardnadze told reporters after the three-hour meeting. ''The most important thing is the summit. The first step has been taken.''

headline: Stocks Rise Again; Dow Adds 5.83
abstract: Stock prices, aided by strength from secondary issues, ended moderately higher yesterday after Tuesday's strong advance.   The Dow Jones industrial average, ahead only fractionally in early trading, finished the day up 5.83 points; on Tuesday it gained 11.20. Advancing stocks outnumbered losers by 989 to 566. Volume on the New York Stock Exchange expanded to 94.9 million shares, up from 91.2 million on Tuesday.

headline: Insider Reports
abstract: The New York Stock Exchange yesterday issued its latest report of changes in the shareholdings of officers, directors and large stockholders in companies whose shares are listed on the exchange. The reports of changes follow: NEW YORK EXCHANGE ANALOG DEVICES, INC- Joseph M. Hinchey, Senior Vice President-Finance, sold 34,000 shares leaving him directly with a balance of 8,718.

headline: Coffee Plan Rejected
abstract: Coffee-producing countries rejected an export incentives proposal today that was presented by coffee-consuming nations at International Coffee Organization negotiations. ''We cannot accept any mechanism that leads to penalties on undershipment,'' said a spokesman for the producers, Jorio Dauster. The meeting was called to draw up market-stabilization arrangements for the new crop year beginning Oct. 1.

headline: U.S. WARY OF SEIZING T.W.A. KILLERS
abstract: United States officials have now identified the three men suspected of having killed a young Navy diver aboard a hijacked Trans World Airlines plane in Beirut last June, but they say they are reluctant to take steps to bring them to trial.   The three are wanted not only for the hijacking, but for the killing of the Navy man, Robert Dean Stethem, who was a passenger on the flight. Thirty-nine Americans were held hostage for 17 days in the incident.   Among the reasons the United States has been constrained from trying to gain custody of the suspects, the officials said, is the fear that such an attempt might complicate efforts to obtain the release of six Americans still in Lebanon.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: * Audi of America Inc., Troy, Mich., said increases on its 1986 models average three-tenths of 1 percent, or $45, from comparably equipped 1985 models.    * Bankers Life Co., Des Moines, said it was scrapping its 106-year-old name and symbol because consumers could not distinguish the company from other similar-sounding concerns. The company will be known as the Principal Financial Group.

headline: Article 143280 -- No Title
abstract: Pepsico Inc. reported yesterday that it earned $256.3 million, or $2.68 a share, in the second quarter of 1985, contrasted to a loss of $42.5 million a year earlier, which included a pretax charge of $156 million for restructuring.   Sales in the latest quarter rose to $1.94 billion from $1.82 billion.   Second-quarter results included a $1.45-a-share gain from the sale of North American Van Lines to the Norfolk Southern Corporation during the quarter.

headline: Control Data To Sell Ticketron
abstract: The Control Data Corporation, which has been battered by the weak market for computers and peripherals, said that itwas offering its Ticketron unit for sale. Ticketron operates a nationwide computerized ticketing service for athletic and entertainment events.

headline: 325 AMAX Jobs Cut in Colorado
abstract: AMAX Inc. said today that 325 employees would not be returning to work at two Colorado molybdenum mines that are scheduled to resume production on Sept. 3.

headline: Decision Seen On Merrill Post
abstract: Merrill Lynch & Company board members said yesterday they expected that Daniel P. Tully would be named president on Monday, after a regular monthly board meeting.

headline: Hitachi Plans
abstract: Hitachi Ltd. said that it would increase its investments in the United States and would buy an additional $120 million in American products as part of a program aimed at easing trade tensions between the United States and Japan.

headline: People
abstract: Anthony Bucci and Norbert Sieber have been elected senior vice presidents at Marc & Co., Pittsburgh.    * Michael Perlis has been named publisher of Runner's World magazine, which is owned by Rodale Press.

headline: A Plan to Help Deposit Fund
abstract: The Federal Home Loan Bank Board said today that it was considering establishing a quasi-govermental unit to help the Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corporation by buying and managing its nonproductive assets.

headline: Piedmont Air
abstract: Piedmont Airlines announced that it had ordered 19 additional Boeing 737-300 airplanes.

headline: Litton Contract
abstract: Litton Industries said that its precision gear division had received a $109 million contract from the Boeing Vertol unit of the Boeing Company to supply new transmission components for 240 Army Chinook helicopters, built by Boeing, which are being modernized.

headline: JAPAN 40 YEARS AFTER WAR: RICH, POWERFUL, UNEASY
abstract: Forty years after abject wartime defeat, Japan is grappling with its peacetime role as a world power.   It is amply proud - detractors would say smug - about its economic might, but it also knows that its success has made others edgy or outright angry.   It is almost obsessed with the thought of itself as unique. Yet self-consciously, it measures virtually every accomplishment against those of other countries, from the size of its gross national product to the prowess of its home run hitters.   Its people boast in more expansive moments that the next century will belong to them. Then in the next breath they retreat to the safety of the tattered cliche that theirs is a ''resource-poor island country,'' hardly carved out for such a grand role.

headline: NEW ZEALAND ASKS FOR AGENTS' NAME
abstract: Prime Minister David Lange condemned France today for having ordered its agents to sabotage the Greenpeace protest ship Rainbow Warrior in Auckland Harbor.   He demanded that France name those responsible for the attack.   Mr. Lange told reporters that New Zealand had been vindicated by France's admission that its agents had carried out the July 10 attack. He called the attack ''a sordid act of international state-backed terrorism.''

headline: Zellerbach To Renew Suit
abstract: The Crown Zellerbach Corporation said yesterday that it would resume its litigation against Sir James Goldsmith, the British financier who has been fighting for control of the forest and paper products company.   The company's suit, originally filed in April, charged Sir James with manipulating the market to win control of the company in violation of Federal securities laws.

headline: AMERICAN ENVOY BACK IN RETORIA
abstract: The United States Ambassador, Herman W. Nickel, returned to his post in South Africa tonight, carrying a personal message from President Reagan to President P. W. Botha.   The Ambassador said that South Africa faced ''momentous choices'' that would inevitably have an effect on relations between the two countries.   Mr. Nickel said he was not ''at liberty'' to disclose the exact contents of the ''important message,'' except to say that, as President Reagan said Monday in his address on economic sanctions, ''It underlines our grave view of the current crisis and our assessment of what is needed to move from confrontation to negotiation here in South Africa and to restore confidence abroad.''   He said that he would deliver the message ''very soon,'' although not tonight.

headline: Andre Obrecht Dies in France; Longtime Chief Executioner
abstract: Andre Obrecht, France's chief executioner for a quarter of a century, died Wednesday in a hospital here after a career in which he beheaded hundreds of criminals.

headline: RAISING SECURITY CONSCIOUSNESS
abstract: THERE are still a few red marks on my posterior left from a chance encounter with some flying particles of rock salt in my youth. These were added to my collection of childhood scars as a couple of fellow mischief makers and I were busy scaling the exterior of some four- and five-story factory buildings. Our objective was the flat, skylit roof of a bread factory, from which one could watch neatly wrapped baked goods trundling along a line of moving belts toward the waiting packing boxes.   Having ventured into this territory before, we had come bearing fishing lines ending in treble hooks and lead weights. With a little skill, it was posssible to lower one's line and snag a loaf of raisin bread as it passed below. This particular day, however, the guard was onto us and our levitating bread trick. As we were looking down, he was coming up, a rock-salt-loaded shotgun in hand.

headline: U.S. STRATEGY OF TOUGHNESS: A COUNTER TO THE RUSSIANS
abstract: In the maneuvering in advance of President Reagan's meeting with Mikhail S. Gorbachev in November, the United States is taking a tough line on arms and other issues in response to what it sees as a Soviet public relations campaign.   Critics of the Administration say that Mr. Gorbachev, with announcements of moratoriums on nuclear testing and missile deployments in Europe, has thrown the United States onto the defensive.   With a series of hard-hitting statements and policy moves this week, the Administration has tried to regain the upper hand. American officials say that President Reagan, by giving the go-ahead on Tuesday for an anti-satellite weapon test, wanted to show that the Russians cannot slow down American weapon development.

headline: Parallels to U.S. View
abstract: The Soviet statements today on research into space-based defense systems appear to parallel some points that the United States has been making in the Geneva talks, according to American accounts.   Although officials said that Mr. Kvitsinsky's statement would be carefully studied, a White House spokesman was skeptical that there had been a basic shift in the Soviet position.

headline: Price Corporation
abstract: The Price Communication Corporation is offering a total of $145 million of speculative-grade debt securities in two parts through underwriters led by Morgan Stanley & Company. A $125 million issue of 14 5/8 percent subordinated debentures due 2000 was offered at a price of 98 1/4, to yield 14.92 percent.

headline: PAPAL LETTER ASKS RELIGIOUS LIBERTY IN EASTERN EUROPE
abstract: Pope John Paul II issued an encyclical today calling for ''solidarity'' with his fellow Slavs, religious tolerance in Eastern Europe and closer ties between Roman Catholicism and Eastern Orthodoxy.   The encyclical, the fourth in John Paul's six and a half years as Pope, also emphasized ''the common Christian roots of Europe'' and said Christianity was ''one of the most solid points of reference'' for those who would reunite Eastern and Western Europe.   ''Not even today,'' the Pope declared, ''does there exist any other way of overcoming tensions and repairing the divisions and antagonisms, both in Europe and the world, which threaten to cause a frightful destruction of lives and values.''      Anniversary of Saint's Death    Titled ''Slavorum Apostoli'' (''The Apostles of the Slavs''), the encyclical was issued in honor of the 1,100th anniversary of the death of St. Methodius. With St. Cyril, his brother, St. Methodius brought Christianity to the Slavs in the ninth century and devised the Cyrillic alphabet.

headline: PENTAGON BACKING PROPOSAL TO DROP A FAIRCHILD PLANE
abstract: The Defense Department has proposed canceling a new Air Force training plane that is the mainstay of the Fairchild Republic Company's aircraft plant on Long Island, Pentagon and industry sources said today.   The sources said the Air Force proposed the cancellation of the $3.5 billion program in Pentagon budget documents, as part of a budget-trimming exercise, and the move had been approved by Deputy Secretary of Defense William H. Taft 4th. His endorsement came two weeks ago in a classified ''program decision memorandum,'' the sources added.   Officials said management deficiencies at the Farmingdale plant, which the Air Force had previously made public, figured in the decision to eliminate the plane, the T-46A. #3,600 Employees at Plant Aerospace industry analysts said its cancellation could be fatal to the Republic plant in Farmingdale, which employs 3,600 people.

headline: Note and Bond Prices Up a Bit
abstract: Treasury note and bond prices rose modestly yesterday, reversing most of the declines of the previous two days, as traders were encouraged by fresh statistics showing a weak economy.   Many analysts said that June's data for total business sales and inventories portrayed an economy that is weak, and not poised for a strong second-half rebound as was predicted a month ago. A month ago, predictions of 4 percent growth this quarter were widespread, and caused investors to worry about rising rates. Now, however, growth forecasts are being reduced to less than 4 percent and hopes for lower interest rates have been revived.

headline: CHANNELING ENERGY - AND CASH - INTO THE COMMUNITY
abstract: ON a recent summery afternoon, William S. Woodside, chairman and chief executive of the American Can Company, sat in his West 57th Street office overlooking Central Park, and spoke with some emotion about matters he considers important.   He did not seem concerned, at that moment, about his company's investment in the Ticor Mortgage Insurance Company, which has been caught up in the crisis surrounding the troubled Equity Programs Investment Corporation. Nor was he at his most animated when discussing American Can's dramatic and successful asset-restructuring.   Rather, Mr. Woodside, a stockily built man of medium height, was visibly upset about the death of Westway, the proposed superhighway and waterfront development along Manhattan's West Side, a project that had been abandoned by New York officials earlier that day. He was concerned about a flap over a proposed new wing for the Whitney Museum of American Art. And he was ''appalled,'' as he put it, that a would-be corporate co-sponsor had backed out of a hunger project.

headline: TEXAS AIR DEAL WITH ICAHN SEEN
abstract: The Texas Air Corporation has agreed to withdraw from its merger pact with Trans World Airlines, sources close to the two airlines said yesterday. The agreement, if signed, would pave the way for Carl C. Icahn, the New York financier who has acquired 52 percent of T.W.A.'s shares, to officially take control of the nation's fourth-largest airline.   The agreement, reportedly reached over the weekend, would end the months-long battle for T.W.A. between Mr. Icahn and Frank Lorenzo, the chairman of Texas Air whose control of the carrier seemed all but certain two months ago. An investment group headed by Mr. Icahn had secured a majority of T.W.A.'s stock, but the airline's previous agreement to be acquired by Texas Air remained a stumbling block for Mr. Icahn.

headline: EMPIRE AIRLINES GETS TWO OFFERS
abstract: Empire Airlines, a fast-growing regional carrier that has its hub in Syracuse, said yesterday that it had received two proposals to be acquired at a premium of the current market price.   The airline, which declined to name the two companies, said that it had retained the firm of L. F. Rothschild, Unterberg, Towbin to assist its board in considering the proposals and other available alternatives.

headline: Yields at Banks Steady
abstract: Interest rates on certificates of deposit and bank money market accounts were mostly unchanged for the week ended yesterday, following three months of steady declines, while yields on money market mutual funds showed a slight downturn for the week.   Robert K. Heady, publisher of The Bank Rate Monitor, said that there had been no movement in yields on bank money market accounts or on C.D.'s with maturities of six months to two and a- alf years. Yields on five-year C.D.'s were down by four one-hundredths of a percentage point, he added.

headline: From Iranian Delegate, A Bouquet and a Message
abstract: The corps of journalists covering the United Nations expands dramatically as various heads of state arrive to address the Assembly. More than 200 reporters from Latin America are expected here this week to cover the appearances of the leaders of Brazil, Panama, Peru, Uruguay and Venezuela.

headline: U.S. FINDS POISON IN 12 BRANDS OF WINE IMPORTED FROM AUSTRIA
abstract: The Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms said today that 12 brands of wines imported from Austria to the United States had been found to be contaminated with diethylene glycol, and that it was advising consumers to drink no Austrian wines until the tests are completed.   A spokesman for the agency, Dot Koester, said the testing for the presence of the poisonous substance would probably not be completed for two weeks. She said laboratory analyses had found from traces to four grams per liter of the contaminant in the tested wines.

headline: San Diego Selling Bonds for Utility
abstract: San Diego is offering $100 million of industrial development revenue bonds on behalf of the San Diego Gas and Electric Company, through undrwriters led by Salomon Brothers.

headline: MIGUEL OTERO SILVA
abstract: Miguel Otero Silva, a Venezuelan author and journalist, died of a heart ailment here Wednesday.

headline: American Ticket Change
abstract: American Airlines said yesterday that it would match most of the fares announced Wednesday by United Airlines, which said it would begin basing its ticket prices on mileage traveled. Both airlines will offer reductions of 45 percent below coach fares on tickets bought 14 days in advance.

headline: PRATT & WHITNEY'S WORKHORSE
abstract: In the 21 years since the debut of Pratt & Whitney's JT8D jet engine, it has made its mark in aviation history. This engine powers nearly half of all commercial planes flying today, and it has compiled a record of having flown more hours than all other commercial jet engines combined.   It has ''paid the rent'' for the Pratt & Whitney Group, a part of the United Technologies Corporation. The JT8D remains the biggest Pratt & Whitney product and still accounts for a substantial share of the group's revenues and earnings. The engine sells for $1.6 million to $2.2 million each, depending on the power of the model.   The reach of this single product makes recent accidents involving the engine a matter of great concern to both the industry and the company.

headline: Moody's Posts Rating Shifts
abstract: Moody's Investors Service yesterday lowered the debt rating of the International Paper Company and raised the rating of the Illinois Bell Telephone Company. The companies have a total of $2.4 billion of debt outstanding.

headline: Minnesota Bonds
abstract: A $150 million issue of Minnesota general obligation bonds was offered yesterday through underwriters led by Chase Manhattan Bank.

headline: TWO ABANDONED BLACKS ARE RENEWED IN HARLEM
abstract: There is a bittersweet tone in Wilfred George Gooden's remarks as he walks along Amsterdam Avenue to the corner of 144th Street in Harlem. In the rich cadences of his Jamaican accent, still strong after 40 years in New York City, he speaks with pride about this block and how it has been transformed over the last decade from a row of abandoned and burned-out shells to a vibrant residential strip with stores at street level.   But as Mr. Gooden approaches 144th Street, which marks the beginning of a long row of abandoned buildings on Amsterdam, his talk is tempered by a recognition of the realities: that the Federal funds that made the improvements possible are gone, and that however much is done to create affordable new housing in Harlem, the numbers are still tiny compared with the demand.   Mr. Gooden, a 59-year-old developer and Harlem resident, began in 1977 to work his way along 145th Street from Broadway east to Amsterdam, then south along Amsterdam toward 144th Street, rehabilitating city-owned abandoned apartment houses under the Federal Government's Section 8 housing subsidy program.

headline: BEHIND REED'S CITICORP SHUFFLE
abstract: In his announcement yesterday of a reorganization of top management, John S. Reed, Citicorp's chairman of one year, indicated that he was trying to make the world's largest, and possibly most powerful, banking organization a considerably more harmonious and conciliatory institution.   Mr. Reed's new appointments themselves presented few surprises, since most of the shifts had been predicted as early as last week. But the logic behind them, which Mr. Reed laid out at a news conference yesterday, provided the first real glimpse of Mr. Reed's management philosophy, which seems to be in sharp contrast to Walter B. Wriston, Citicorp's iconoclastic chairman for 17 years, whom Mr. Reed succeeded last September.   James H. Wooden, bank-stock analyst for Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith Inc., called the changes ''non-revolutionary.'' He added, ''They reflect Reed's fairly conservative character.''

headline: REAGAN'S HIDDEN 'INDUSTRIAL POLICY'
abstract: THE 1984 Presidential campaign buried the idea of ''industrial policy.'' Or did it?   Not long ago, several Democratic Presidential aspirants were talking about industrial policy. Although the precise meaning of the term remained elusive, the general idea was that the Government should be more purposeful in easing the transition of our economy out of basic industries like steel and textiles into high-tech businesses.

headline: Ad Pages Off, Spending Up Through July
abstract: The magazines that belong to the Publishers Information Bureau were collectively down 10.3 percent in advertising pages in July from the same month last year, to 9,467 pages. Monthly revenue was off by 8.6 percent, down to $308.9 million.

headline: Norway's Saga Loses Benin Deal
abstract: The West African state of Benin has canceled a deal with Norway's Saga Petroleum Group and handed control of the country's oilfields to a Swiss-based concern, the Norwegian company said. Saga, which was responsible for production and expansion of the country's Seme oilfield, does not know why it was thrown out, a company spokesman said.

headline: Frenchman Sought by Police In Greenpeace Ship Bombing
abstract: The police said today that they were looking for a Frenchman who was seen near the Greenpeace ship Rainbow Warrior before a bomb sank it.   They said they had asked the international police organization Interpol to help track him.

headline: Iraq Reports Air Attack On Iran Military Camp
abstract: Iraq said its aircraft had attacked a military camp in western Iran today.

headline: Textron to Sell Stock, 3 Units
abstract: Textron Inc. said it planned to offer 4 million shares of common stock and sell three divisions to further trim the $1.4 billion debt incurred by its purchase of the Avco Corporation of Connecticut.

headline: Attorney General In Shift on Hutton
abstract: The Connecticut Attorney General said yesterday that he had reversed his earlier decision to reopen an investigation into whether E. F. Hutton & Company should be allowed to remain a broker in the state. The state has already held hearings, investigating Hutton in the wake of its guilty plea to Federal charges that it defrauded banks in a check overdraft scheme.

headline: PANEL AND TREASURY CONFER ON TAX PLAN
abstract: After a private weekend retreat in the Virginia countryside, Treasury Department officials and leaders of the House Ways and Means Committee said today they were optimistic they could work together to write legislation restructuring the Federal income tax system.   At a joint news conference, Treasury Secretary James A. Baker 3d said that President Reagan's commitment to tax revision was ''total'' and ''unswerving'' and that ''at the very least, there's a fair shot'' of accomplishing the goal this year.   The committee chairman, Representative Dan Rostenkowski, said the weekend session indicated that all sides had the ''patience and flexibility and bipartisanship'' to work together.

headline: CAMBODIA ON BRINK OF REBIRTH, OR DECAY
abstract: Nearly seven years after Vietnamese soldiers replaced the brutal Pol Pot regime with a Government friendly to Vietnam, Cambodia is an exhausted and isolated nation, struggling to develop - and still haunted by the threat of Pol Pot's troops.   Residents say those soldiers, known as the Khmer Rouge, are able to strike within 10 to 15 miles of the capital, although such attacks seem to be infrequent. The Khmer Rouge is based near the Thai border, as are two non-Communist insurgent groups.   More guerrilla activity is reported in the distant provinces of the north and northwest. Trains and buses from the Battambang area arrive in Phnom Penh with armed guards aboard.

headline: U.N. AGENCY ANNOUNCES STEPS TO COORDINATE FIGHT AGAINST AIDS
abstract: The World Health Organization has announced a series of measures to combat acquired immune deficiency syndrome, or AIDS.   Officials at the organization's headquarters in Geneva said Friday that the number of cases of the fatal disease reported worldwide had surpassed 15,000 by mid-September, showing an increase in the United States alone to 13,074, from 12,612 cases reported Aug. 30.   Figures issued by officials of the World Health Organization, which is an agency of the United Nations, included 1,284 cases in Europe, 103 in Australia, 15 in Asia and 723 in Latin America. No cases were reported from Africa, although several hundred are suspected there, the officials said, adding that many countries, including New Zealand and those in the Soviet bloc, also reported no cases.

headline: G.M. to Lift Prices On Compact Line
abstract: The General Motors Corporation today announced price increases that it said totaled 3.1 percent to 3.3 percent on a line of 1986 model cars. The action could signal G.M.'s pricing strategy for the 1986 models, one that has traditionally set a pattern for the rest of the industry.   The increases, on the sporty compact models known internally as the N-bodies and sold as the Pontiac Grand Am, Oldsmobile Calais and Buick Somerset, are substantially above G.M.'s price moves of recent model years. It raised the price of 1985 models 2.3 percent and the 1984's by 2 percent over the previous years.

headline: FED PANEL BACKED REIN IN JULY
abstract: The Federal Reserve Board's senior policy committee decided in July that it would clamp down on the growth in the nation's money supply if it kept growing at the extremely rapid pace of May and June, according to the minutes of the meeting released today.   But the panel, in what some analysts saw was a significant change, decided that, if the supply of money began to decline, it would do nothing to keep it from falling.   The minutes indicated that the members were concerned about the continued rapid growth in M-1, the basic money supply measurement, which had expanded at a 13 3/4 percent rate in the second quarter of the year.   At the same time, as announced by Paul A. Volcker, the Fed's chairman, in his semiannual Congressional testimony on monetary policy last month, the members of the Federal Open Market Committee decided to set a new base for the growth of M-1. The committee voted to set a 3 to 8 percent growth range with a base starting in the second quarter, rather than in the first. In February, the Fed had set growth targets for M-1 between 4 and 7 percent for 1985.

headline: Texas Bank Cuts Payout
abstract: The First City Bankcorporation of Texas said it slashed its quarterly dividend to 15 cents, from 32 1/2 cents, because of the deterioration of principal lending markets.   The bank holding company, with assets of $17 billion, said that its total earnings over the past four quarters have not covered its cash payout.

headline: FOUR ARAB YOUTHS ARE WOUNDED BY ISRAELI SOLDIERS IN WEST BANK
abstract: Israeli soldiers shot and wounded three Arab youths in Hebron today after they started to run away from an army patrol approaching to check their identification, the Israeli Army spokesman announced.   A 12-year-old Arab boy, who was standing nearby, was also accidentally wounded by the gunfire, the spokesman said. He described the boy's condition as serious.   The shooting was the latest in a series of violent confrontations between Arabs and Israelis in the occupied West Bank that has led some Israeli newspaper columnists to talk of an incipient ''civil war'' in the territories.

headline: CHILE BOMB KILLS ONE NEAR A U.S. CONSULATE
abstract: A car packed with explosives blew up tonight across the street from the United States Consulate here, killing a man in a passing car and wounding two policemen who had been standing guard outside the consulate, the police reported.   The explosion, which took place shortly after 9 P.M., caused extensive damage to several nearby buildings and broke most of the windows in the consulate building, which is across the street from a public park.

headline: Market Place;   Foreign Stocks Draw Attention
abstract: INSTITUTIONAL investors own an estimated $15.7 billion worth of foreign stocks, compared with $3 billion just five years ago. And investments overseas, according to money managers, promise to grow as pension funds and other institutions diversify their portfolios.   ''We are convinced that investing is becoming increasingly global and that the rate of change in this direction will accelerate,'' Barton M. Biggs said in January. ''For many years, European investors have been international in their perspective. Now American institutions are expanding their horizons.'' He is chief investment strategist for Morgan Stanley & Company and chairman of Morgan Stanley Asset Management Inc., the company's investment management subsidiary, which supervises assets of more than $5 billion.

headline: U.S. CONCERNED ON ATOM PERIL IN SUBCONTINENT
abstract: The Reagan Administration is sending two high-level officials to India and Pakistan to express concern about the possible development of a nuclear weapon by Pakistan and about overall tensions in the region, officials said today.   The two officials - Michael H. Armacost, Under Secretary of State for Political Affairs, and Donald R. Fortier, the third-ranking aide in the White House National Security Council - are to visit New Delhi and Islamabad from Sunday to Thursday, White House officials said.   Aides said Mr. Armacost and Mr. Fortier would discuss the Soviet occupation of Afghanistan and other ''matters of mutual concern'' with Indian and Pakistani leaders.      Concern About Retaliation    But other Administration officials said a key reason for the visit to both countries was to express anxiety about the possible development of a nuclear weapon by Pakistan and concern that India would seek to retaliate, in a way similar to the Israeli strike against an Iraqi nuclear reactor in 1981.

headline: A RAIDER TAKES COMMAND AT AMF
abstract: IRWIN JACOBS'S ten-year ascendency on the takeover ladder is filled with tales of triumph, miscues and setbacks. But one incident sticks out firmly in his mind.   Back in 1981, during what turned out to be an unsuccessful but highly profitable 14-month pursuit of Pabst Brewing, a stockholder angrily confronted Mr. Jacobs. Why, the stockholder wanted to know, should he side with Mr. Jacobs's group of insurgents when Arctic Enterprises, which Mr. Jacobs had taken over a few years prior, had entered Chapter 11 proceedings? The embarrassed Minneapolis investor said he had no adequate answer.   Four years later, as he tries to integrate AMF Inc. into his other operations, that question still nags at Mr. Jacobs. Although he has made tens of millions of dollars in stock transactions as a result of takeover runs against Disney, RCA, Kaiser Steel, Avco, Holly Sugar, Phillips Petroleum and others, he has no track record for managing companies larger than Bekins, a small company he acquired for $90 million in 1983.

headline: CONSUMER RATES
abstract: In percent

headline: PROSPECTS
abstract: Bears Begin To Prowl For more than a year, investors had bet that declining interest rates, low inflation and dozens of undervalued stocks would have the market soaring in the second half. But, said Robert S. Salomon Jr., managing director of equities research at Salomon Brothers, most bets were off as of last week. On Friday, the Dow Jones industrial average closed at 1,320.79, down 32.76 points from the week before.   ''Investors no longer believe the market is as undervalued as it was in the past year or so,'' said Mr. Salomon. ''What they see today is a continuing flow of poor corporate earnings in a sluggish economy.'' As a result, Mr. Salomon says that ''like us, many investors have largely written off the third quarter as a repeat of the lackluster second quarter.''

headline: THE DANGERS OF IRREGULAR VOLTAGE
abstract: IT was during the muggy heat spell of last week, at a moment when my thoughts were far from my computer, that the machine simply lost its mind.   The screen flickered, the document on which I had been working left the land of retrievability, and I had to re-edit a column from scratch. Electric power had failed or dropped low enough to make the computer's internal voltage regulator incapable of dealing with the fluctuation.   Voltage drops seem to be more and more common in this country. The power company in my area announced recently that it soon expects to reduce the electricity it makes available by five or six volts for several hours a day, until further notice. The company says that most of the cutback will occur in the evening, so it should not greatly affect business computers. But for those dedicated individuals who take floppies home in their briefcases, and for businesses that continually run their computers, the decrease certainly could cause problems.

headline: JAPAN JET WAS CARRYING RADIOACTIVE MATERIAL
abstract: The Japan Air Lines airliner that crashed on Aug. 12 was carrying 61 packages of radioactive materials manufactured in the United States for medical research and diagnosis in Japan, according to the New England Nuclear Corporation, a subsidiary of Du Pont based here.   A spokesman for New England Nuclear, Charles B. Killian, said it was unlikely that the radiation levels were high enough to affect the four survivors or rescue workers. He said Japanese authorities had been told before rescue workers reached the site that the materials were on board.

headline: Data Retrieval Improvements
abstract: Text written on paper must be in a specific order. This article, for instance, has a particular order of paragraphs, and the reader will normally follow it from beginning to end in sequential fashion.   But computer-based information need not be bound by such restrictions imposed by paper. With computers it is possible to have individual small packets of information that can be called up in any order the reader desires. The concept has been called nonsequential text, or ''hypertext,'' and it is slowly gaining adherents in computer science.

headline: S.E.C. CITES 3 BANKERS IN TEXAS
abstract: The Securities and Exchange Commission charged today that the three top officials of a major Texas bank holding company illegally propped up reported earnings by failing to make sufficient provision for bad loans.   This resulted, the commission said, in the $7.6 billion Southwest Bancshares Inc. publishing several false and misleading financial statements, including proxy material related to its 1984 merger with the Mercantile Texas Corporation to form Mcorp, a $21 billion banking organization.   The complaint was filed in Federal District Court here along with a settlement in which the defendants consented to court orders permanently barring them from such violations but without admitting or denying any of the S.E.C.'s allegations. The company was not charged.

headline: Farmers Sue Bank
abstract: Nine southwestern Iowa farm families today sued their local bank for $100 million, saying they were being wrongfully forced off their land.

headline: New Talks For Wheeling
abstract: The stalled talks between the Wheeling-Pittsburgh Steel Corporation and its striking employees will soon be reopened, according to representatives of the United Steelworkers of America.   Paul D. Rusen, chairman of the Wheeling workers' negotiating committee, termed a two-hour meeting today with George A. Ferris, Wheeling's new chief executive, ''a breath of fresh air.'' Mr. Rusen said talks would resume Monday.

headline: ISRAEL, WOOING UNIONS, DELAYS PART OF AUSTERITY
abstract: The Israeli Government, in an effort to win the support of labor for its sweeping austerity plan, has agreed to postpone some of its tougher elements pending discussions on how to cushion the impact on wage earners.   Prime Minister Shimon Peres said Tuesday night that emergency regulations cutting cost-of-living increments due in July, freezing wages from July to September and dismissing 10,000 public sector workers in two months would be postponed.

headline: Market Place;   Atlantic City: A Full House?
abstract: AT first glance, the gambling industry in Atlantic City appears to be doing well, with gross revenues at record levels last month and the prospects for improvement bright. But to Wall Street, it is down on its luck, the victim of overexpansion that could cause a shakeout of less sturdy competitors.   ''Over the next 15 to 18 months, I expect to see a number of casino/hotels have to change hands,'' said Marvin Roffman, who tracks the industry for Janney Montgomery Scott Inc., a Philadelphia brokerage firm.   While others are not so pessimistic, all agree that the building of new casinos and the expansion of old ones is likely to continue to give smaller slices of the gambling pie to each participant.

headline: 4 MORE U.S. VICTIMS ARE FOUND
abstract: The United States Embassy today identified four more American victims of Mexico's two earthquakes, and officials reported no damage or injuries from a third temblor that sent thousands of people fleeing into the streets Friday night.   The new identifications by the embassy brings to 10 the number of confirmed American dead.

headline: Schwab Cut Bank Stake
abstract: Charles R. Schwab, a director of the BankAmerica Corporation and chairman of its discount brokerage unit, sold about 350,000 shares of BankAmerica stock in June. BankAmerica reported Wednesday a $338 million quarterly loss. Hugo Quackenbush, a senior vice president at Charles Schwab & Company, said Mr. Schwab had used the money to repay debts.

headline: GAF Raises Stake In Carbide to 7.1%
abstract: The GAF Corporation, in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, said yesterday that it had raised its stake in the Union Carbide Corporation to 7.1 percent. GAF said two weeks ago that it had acquired 5.6 percent in Union Carbide as an ''attractive investment opportunity'' and that it was considering a number of options, ''including the possibility of a business combination'' between the two chemical companies.

headline: People
abstract: Bob Fudge, Peter Kellogg, Deborah Kushnick, Laurie Ellen Murphy and Ralph Palamidessi have been promoted to senior vice presidents at SSC&B:Lintas USA, where John Lerch, a senior vice president, has added the title of group creative director.

headline: SAATCHI & SAATCHI'S BUYING BINGE
abstract: ITS no-holds-barred advertising campaign for Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher created a national furor in 1979. Its 90-second sci-fi spot for British Airways - showing the entire island of Manhattan coming in for a landing at Heathrow Airport -was one of the most talked-about commercials of 1983.   But in the past year, probably nothing that the Saatchi & Saatchi Company has done for its clients is as provocative as what it is doing on its own behalf. The huge advertising agency has been on a trans-Atlantic shopping spree, buying up not only advertising and public relations agencies, but even a management consulting firm.   ''They're collectors,'' said Jeremy Bullmore, chairman of J. Walter Thompson's London agency, which Saatchi & Saatchi overtook in billings in 1979. ''They collect companies, clients, money, pictures, everything. They vastly enjoy growth and acquisition.''

headline: ABC to Lay Off About 3% of Staff
abstract: The American Broadcasting Companies said that it planned to lay off between 300 and 350 people, or about 3 percent of its work force, by the end of August. The broadcasting and publishing company, which is in the process of being acquired by Capital Cities Communications Inc., said that the layoffs would come from all levels of employees.

headline: Phone Rate Cut Ordered
abstract: The New York State Public Service Commission has directed the New York Telephone Company to lower its toll rates by up to 30 percent. The move is intended to discourage corporate customers, which make many toll calls, from setting up their own phone networks.

headline: SECOND 'BLACK BOX' IS RECOVERED FROM ATLANTIC IN AIR-INDIA CRASH
abstract: A robot submarine retrieved the remaining ''black box'' from the sunken wreckage of an Air-India jumbo jet off Ireland today, giving investigators an improved chance of discovering why the plane crashed with the loss of 329 lives last month.   Comdr. Sunil Kulknari, the leader of the Indian investigating team, said that both the flight recorder recovered this morning, which contains information on the aircraft's speed, altitude and heading, and the cockpit voice recorder, brought up on Wednesday, were undamaged.

headline: Hospital Corp. Shifts Officers
abstract: The Hospital Corporation of America said today that Thomas F. Frist Jr., 47 years old, the company's president and chief executive, would assume the title of chairman, effective Sept. 1.   R. Clayton McWhorter, 52, the company's executive vice president for operations, will succeed Mr. Frist as president and assume the post of chief operating officer.

headline: FEES FOR USING TELLER MACHINE
abstract: WITH the expansion of automated teller machines and switching networks linking the machines at different financial institutions around the country, some banks and savings and loan associations are instituting special service charges for customers who use teller machines.   The institutions that have imposed these fees say that the additional expense involved in hooking up to and maintaining a link with a network mandates a charge. But others believe that such switching or interchange levies, which typically range between 25 cents and $1 a transaction, are self-defeating since they tend to diminish the usage of these machines at a time when many bankers are trying to encourage more customers to restrict their personal dealings with tellers.   Automated machines - which automatically provide major banking services such as deposits, withdrawals and account status information on a 24-hour-a-day, seven-day-a-week basis - first went into operation in 1967, according to the American Bankers Association. Today about 65,000 of these devices are in operation at more than 7,000 institutions, with a large percentage connected to one of the more than a hundred statewide, regional, national or international networks that allow account holders to use machines at other banks as though they were at their own.

headline: State Names Director Of Cash Management
