abstract: Maryanne Gridley, former senior legislative budget analyst for the New York State Senate Finance Committee, has been named director of cash and debt management, State Comptroller Edward V. Regan announced.   Miss Gridley, who is 36, fills a post that has been vacant since April, when John Hull was named Deputy Comptroller for Investments and Cash Management.   In her new job, which carries an annual salary of $60,000, Miss Gridley will be responsible for the state's banking and cash-management program as well as the marketing of all New York State bond and note issues. The state, whose fiscal year begins on April 1, has sold more than $4 billion in notes and bonds so far this year.

headline: New York Policemen March With the I.R.A.
abstract: Members of a New York City police band ignored appeals by the Government and Irish police and marched Saturday in a parade with I.R.A. supporters.   The 22 members of New York's Emerald Society Pipe Band joined a 1,000-strong procession at Bundoran in County Donegal, less than 10 miles from where I.R.A. guerrillas assassinated Earl Mountbatten six years ago.

headline: GORBACHEV INVOKES DIETY
abstract: To Western ears, the invocation of the deity by the head of an atheist nation may seem somewhat akin to a citation of Lenin by an American President.   So it was when Mikhail S. Gorbachev, in an interview with Time magazine journalists, said, according to their account: ''Surely God on high has not refused to give us enough wisdom to find ways to bring us an improvement in our relations, an improvement in relations between the two great nations on earth. . . .''   The comment recalled Leonid I. Brezhnev's much-quoted remark to President Carter at their summit meeting in Vienna in June 1979 that ''God will not forgive us if we fail.''

headline: SOVIET TV GIVES ITS VIEWERS RARE GLIMPSE OF AFGHAN WAR
abstract: For the first time in more than five years of undeclared war, the fighting in Afghanistan has come into Soviet living rooms on the television evening news.   A two-and-a-half-minute report earlier this month, including what appeared to be battlefield footage and heroic words from a group of Soviet soldiers, was a far cry from the daily, detailed and often negative reports from Vietnam that filled American television screens.   But the fact that the officially controlled television program was showing burning trucks, explosions and Soviet troops assaulting an unseen enemy raised eyebrows among Western diplomats here.   A Soviet journalist said he believed that the footage had been filmed in Afghanistan but that the battle scenes themselves were likely to have been at least partly staged for the camera.

headline: Economic Scene;  Agriculture's Bleak Outlook
abstract: THE performance of agriculture has continued to decline throughout the current strong business expansion. Farm export sales have slumped. Farm asset values have continued to fall. And farm income has stagnated at levels that are unacceptably low for many farmers. As a result, farm business failures have increased sharply from the very low levels of the past two decades. Problems on the farm have spilled over into rural communities, and financial pressures on agribusinesses and farm lenders have increased markedly.  The main symptom of agriculture's problems is the financial stress on farms and ranches. In the nation's midsection, failures of farm businesses were running nearly four times the normal rate this spring, while partial farm liquidations were more than five times normal.

headline: Advertising;   Magazine Tries New Campaigns
abstract: AN ''Under New Management'' sign is hardly necessary at The New Yorker magazine. Not when there are so many little happenings that say it quite clearly without a sign.   For example, tomorrow the publication will be running its first 30-second TV commercials since 1971 and running advertising for the first time ever in prime time.   The other signs of change include the appearance of the first advertising insert card in the magazine (placed by L.L. Bean on Sept. 2), the availability of half-page advertising units for the first time, a two-million-piece subscription-solicitation mail drop and the first such drive by the magazine in 14 years.

headline: EXECUTIVES
abstract: * Bank of New Zealand has appointed Robert F. Hirten executive vice president and manager of its New York branch.

headline: PRAGUE CLOSES BORDER: TERRORIST ATTACK CITED
abstract: Czechoslovakia closed a major crossing at the Austrian border today, saying a terrorist attack had taken place at the post near Bratislava, the Interior Ministry said.   A person near the scene said defectors trying to leave the country had taken hostages.

headline: Pilots Back Frontier Plan
abstract: Members of the Air Line Pilots Association have joined flight attendants and transport workers in ratifying Frontier Airlines' proposed $400 million employee stock ownership plan entailing undisclosed wage and benefit concessions.

headline: ANTIMISSILE SHIELD HELD TO RAISE RISK OF A NUCLEAR WAR
abstract: The development of a defense against intercontinental missiles might make nuclear war between the United States and the Soviet Union more likely, analysts for Congress's Office of Technology Assessment concluded in a report made public today.   This might not be true, the analysts said, if the United States could devise an ''extremely capable'' shield that would protect many cities and much of America's arsenal of nuclear weapons.   But the report expressed doubt that a nearly leakproof shield was technologically feasible and argued that a highly effective defense would require that the Soviet Union agree to significant limits on its offensive nuclear force.      Threat to Arms Control Seen    The nonpartisan agency's 324-page report, commissioned by the House Armed Services Committee and the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, said the current ''urgent'' effort to develop a high-technology missile defense would probably encourage the Soviet Union to increase its nuclear attack forces and could threaten both ''the entire arms control process'' and the 1972 treaty that limits defenses against intercontinental missiles.   A companion report on antisatellite weapons said that the best course for the United States would be to seek a treaty limiting the testing of such space weapons and, at the same time, to devise ways to defend American satellites from attack.

headline: Ex-Cell-O Acquisition
abstract: The Ex-Cell-O Corporation said today that it would buy Babco Industries, a maker of precision jet engine components, for an unspecified amount. Babco, a closely held company based in Danvers, Mass., has annual sales of about $20 million and employs 200 people, Ex-Cell-O said.

headline: Intergroup Talks On Sale of Unit
abstract: National Intergroup Inc. said yesterday that it had entered into talks for the sale of the First Nationwide Financial Corporation, a savings and loan subsidiary.

headline: Nicaraguan Rebel Aide Says He'll Abandon Armed Efforts
abstract: A leading official of a Nicaraguan rebel group said today that he was abandoning armed efforts to overthrow the Nicaraguan Government.

headline: U.S. IS SAID TO TELL SOUTH AFRICA THAT POLICIES COULD HARDEN
abstract: The Reagan Administration has told South African officials that an ''emotional climate'' exists in the United States that could harden American policies toward that country, a senior Administration official said today.   The official said that that view was presented during a meeting Thursday in Vienna between high officials from the United States and South Africa. The senior official said he had presented the assessment to South African officials to acquaint them with what he called the realities within the United States. He said the assessment was his personal view.

headline: FALWELL DENOUNCES TUTU AS A 'PHONY'
abstract: The Rev. Jerry Falwell called Bishop Desmond M. Tutu a phony today and began a campaign to block imposition of economic sanctions against South Africa. The step came amid growing evidence that American conservatives were deeply divided on the issue.   Mr. Falwell, just back from a five-and-a-half-day visit to South Africa, denounced the Anglican Bishop who is South Africa's most prominent clergyman, saying, ''If Bishop Tutu maintains that he speaks for the black people of South Africa, he's a phony.''   Bishop Tutu, a leading critic of the Pretoria Government's racial policies who won the 1984 Nobel Peace Prize, has offered theological as well as social arguments against apartheid.

headline: FOES AND FRIENDS OF PRETORIA CRITICIZE REAGAN'S SANCTIONS
abstract: Leaders of the American movement protesting South African policies said today that President Reagan's sanctions were riddled with loopholes and had been crafted to spare him a rebuke in Congress rather than help black Africans.   Critics urged the Senate to move ahead with proposed legislation despite the Presidential measure and to approve the sanctions already voted by the House of Representatives.   As demonstrations continued outside the South African Embassy, Randall Robinson, co-chairman of the Free South Africa Movement, said of Mr. Reagan: ''The executive order and speech were designed to help him reconcile his reflexive sympathy for the white minority government of South Africa with the building opposition to his program of constructive engagement in the United States.''

headline: REAGAN REJECTS SHOE IMPORT CURB
abstract: President Reagan, calling protectionist measures ''ineffective and extremely expensive,'' today rejected pleas from the ailing domestic shoe industry for a curb on imports.   ''Placing quotas on shoe imports would be detrimental to the national economic interest,'' he said in a statement.   ''I am notifying Congress today of my decision not to impose quotas on nonrubber footwear imports,'' Mr. Reagan said. ''As President, it is my responsibility to take into account not only the effect of quotas on the shoe industry but also their broader impact on the overall economy.''

headline: VATICAN CONDEMNS A PAPAL 'COLUMN'
abstract: The Vatican press office yesterday issued a strong condemnation of a new newspaper column based on the writings of Pope John Paul II. The column has been sold to over 200 newspapers worldwide by news syndicates owned by the publisher Rupert Murdoch.   A statement issued by Msgr. Guilio Nicolini, deputy director of the press office of the Holy See, criticized the column because it used the Pope's name as a ''journalistic byline'' for ''commercial operations.''

headline: 2 BRAZILIAN FINANCE AIDES QUIT
abstract: Two of Brazil's senior finance officials resigned today in the first Government shake-up since civilian rule returned to the country last March.   The Finance Minister and the central bank president both stepped down after their repeated calls for tighter economic austerity had gone unheeded by President Jose Sarney.   Finance Minister Francisco Dornelles quit just three days after his deputy, Sebastiao Marcos Vital, was abruptly dismissed by Mr. Sarney for criticizing the Government's current expansionist economic policy.

headline: Interest Rates Rise Modestly
abstract: Short- and long-term interest rates rose modestly yesterday, with traders concerned that a spate of stronger economic statistics, combined with weak investor demand for notes and bonds, could point toward higher interest rates in the future.   The late afternoon announcement of a $2.4 billion rise in the nation's basic money supply had little impact on interest rates. Although the gain was slightly less than the $3 billion or so that was expected, analysts noted that money supply continues to expand far more rapidly than the Federal Reserve's targets.   Until the central bank's actions prove otherwise, many analysts expect Fed officials to guide monetary policy according to the behavior of the economy, not money supply.

headline: ADVERTISING;Checking on Running Of TV Commercials
abstract: Last week the Federal Communications Commission gave the O.K. to two companies that have already begun to set up electronic systems for verifying that television commercials have run as ordered, a service that has become more  important as the result of the F.C.C. decision not to require that stations keep logs of commercial performance.         The companies are Ad Audit of Alexandria, Va., and Telescan, founded by Burton Greenberg, a director of commercials. Both have systems that will use line 22 on the 525-line TV screen to carry codes that will be picked up by computerized monitors in individual markets.

headline: Net Triples At Texas Air
abstract: The Texas Air Corporation, which owns 81 percent of Continental Airlines and 70 percent of New York Air, reported yesterday that its second-quarter earnings tripled, to $41 million, or $2.69 a share, from $13.4 million, or 77 cents a share, a year ago. Revenues rose 49.8 percent, to $495.1 million, from $330.6 million, in the period.

headline: Messerschmitt, Aerospatiale Pact
abstract: Aerospatiale, the French state-owned aerospace company, said it had concluded a research agreement with Messerschmitt-Bolkow-Blohm of West Germany as part of the European Eureka research program.

headline: Shearson Lehman Sets New Floating-Rate Note
abstract: Shearson Lehman Brothers yesterday introduced a new kind of floating-rate note, which it expects to underwrite soon for the American Express Credit Corporation. The American Express unit filed a shelf registration with the Securities and Exhange Commission for up to $200 million of the notes.   The new security, called money market notes, is similar in concept to the money market preferred stock introduced by Shearson last August.

headline: U.S. CONCERNS FACE ADDED OBSTACLES
abstract: South Africa's suspension of currency and stock trading threatens to make conditions even tougher for American corporations with operations there, business consultants and academic experts said yesterday. But a number of companies took a wait-and-see attitude about the effect on their operations there.   This week's run on the rand further reduced the value of American assets in South Africa, which had been diminished greatly in the last two years by earlier currency weakness. In addition, a three-year recession and the weak rand had already taken a toll on earnings, which now stand to suffer even more.

headline: SOVIET MAY DEPLOY SATELLITE WEAPON IF U.S. HOLDS TEST
abstract: The Soviet Union served notice today that if the United States went ahead with a planned test of an anti-satellite weapon, Moscow would no longer consider itself bound by its two-year-old commitment not to deploy such weapons.   The announcement was couched in a ''Tass statement,'' a format that signifies an official Government position. Tass, the Soviet press agency, had made a similar threat last month, though in a less authoritative form.   The White House last month announced a decision to proceed with the first American test of an anti-satelllite weapon against an object in space. Officials argued that the test was needed to maintain a military balance with the Soviet Union.

headline: COUNSELING STIRS SOME CHARGES
abstract: CAREER counseling has fallen on difficult times. In fact two of the country's biggest and best-known job advisers are the subject of state legal actions and several small firms have gone out of business.   In Boston, Job and Career Counselors Inc., an affiliate of Bernard Haldane Associates, long a leading franchiser of counseling services, has gone into bankruptcy proceedings. In New York City, there is a court action against both Bernard Haldane Associates and its affiliate on behalf of clients by the office of the New York State Attorney General.

headline: Pantry Pride's Plan for Revlon
abstract: Pantry Pride Inc. told the Securities and Exchange Commission yesterday that if it succeeded in its $1.8 billion takeover of Revlon Inc., it would sell everything except the cosmetics business. It said it thought it could raise between $1.7 billion and $1.9 billion in the sales and might also sell Revlon's foreign operations.

headline: HEBRON SQUATTERS EVICTED BY ARMY
abstract: The Israeli Army today evicted a group of members of Parliament from an apartment in Hebron that they had occupied since Thursday. The legislators said they were there to establish the right of Jews to settle wherever they wanted in the West Bank.   Shortly before dawn, a team of soldiers arrived at the three-room apartment in the heart of the Hebron covered market, called the casbah. The soldiers told the seven legislators that the area had been declared ''a closed military zone'' and that their parliamentary immunity did not apply there, an Israeli Defense Ministry spokesman said.

headline: People
abstract: * Thomas J. Mullins has been appointed senior vice president at Eisaman, Johns & Laws, New York.    * Roger Van Remmen has been promoted to senior vice president at Dailey & Associates, Los Angeles.    * John F. Nephew has joined Mediamark Research as vice president, marketing.

headline: CAMBODIAN WAR BY RADIO
abstract: Journalists, usually denied the opportunity for first-hand reporting from inside Cambodia - or Kampuchea, as it is known in Southeast Asia - rely for information at least in part on the radio broadcasts of two opposing sides in the Cambodian civil war.   The Cambodian Government radio, called the Voice of the Kampuchean People in Phnom Penh, and the Khmer Rouge radio, called the Voice of Democratic Kampuchea, which is believed to transmit from southern China, try daily to portray their enemies in disarray. Here are samples of two recent broadcasts, as monitored and translated by Reuters in Bangkok:   'Misled People' Return Voice of the Kampuchean People, Aug. 23 - During the first six months of this year, 154 misled people surrendered to revolutionary state authorities in Santuk district of Kampong Thom Province.

headline: INVESTMENT BANKER FOR UNIONS
abstract: When Brian M. Freeman, an investment banker, is negotiating a deal, he bluffs, he demands and, very calculatingly, he sometimes insults his adversary to gain the upper hand.         The clients he so tenaciously represents, however, are neither deep-pocket takeover artists nor multimillion-dollar corporations. Instead, they are labor unions whose members may be willing to make wage concessions in return for profit-sharing and stock ownership.

headline: BULGARIA'S AMBITIOUS HIGH-TECH GOALS
abstract: This small Balkan nation is moving ambitiously on several fronts to develop capabilities in the manufacture of computers and other advanced-technology products.   It is a gigantic task, engineers and scientists here agree, the more so because Bulgaria until very recently was largely a rural, agricultural society. But the engineers and scientists have begun the effort with what one of them, Zhivko Zhelezov, called ''a mountain of optimism.''   Dr. Zhelezov is director of the Central Institute of Computing Technique, a facility that oversees 15 enterprises that manufacture personal computers, memory tape systems, disks, word processing terminals and other computer hardware. ''All research and development is done here,'' he said of his 2,000-member institute, with headquarters in a large building on the eastern edge of Sofia.

headline: INDIA IS SAID TO URGE SRI LANKA TO GIVE IN ON TAMIL AUTONOMY
abstract: The Sri Lanka Government and leaders of Tamil guerrilla groups are to resume their talks Monday amid indications that India has been pressing Sri Lanka officials to make more concessions to the insurgents.   The two sides were described as far apart this week in negotiations that are intended to end three years of spreading warfare in Sri Lanka. An Indian official close to the talks said he was not optimistic about the chances of a successful outcome.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: Debt Issues    * Anheuser-Busch Cos. is issuing 11.5 billion yen of 8 percent dual currency Euronotes due in 1995 at a price of 101 through underwriters led by IBJ International Ltd. The bonds are redeemed in U.S. dollars at an exchange rate of 208 yen to the dollar.    * Burroughs Corp. has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for up to $300 million of debt securities.

headline: COOKE SELLS STAKE TO MULTIMEDIA
abstract: Multimedia Inc. agreed yesterday to buy Jack Kent Cooke's 10 percent stake for a large premium over what the newspaper, cable-TV and broadcast company is offering shareholders in its recapitalization plan.   Mr. Cooke will receive $70 a share, or a total of about $114 million. Multimedia is offering other shareholders cash and securities that Wall Street values at $55 to $61 a share.

headline: Chairman Sees Growth For Fleet Financial
abstract: J. Terrance Murray has been acting more like a shopper on a spending spree than a New England banker.   In the past two weeks, Mr. Murray, who is chairman, president and chief executive of the Fleet Financial Group in Providence, R.I., has spent a total of $325 million through stock transactions to acquire the First Connecticut Bancorp of Hartford and, more recently, the Merrill Bankshares Company of Bangor, Me.

headline: Eastern Air Official Is Named President
abstract: Eastern Air Lines Inc. yesterday named Joseph B. Leonard, a 42-year-old engineer who has run the carrier's daily operations as executive vice president since May, to be president and chief operating officer.   As president, Mr. Leonard succeeds Frank Borman, the 57-year-old former astronaut who remains chairman and chief executive of the Miami-based airline. The chief operating officer's post is a new one.

headline: JAPAN COURT AGAIN DEPLORES INEQUITABLE ELECTION SYSTEM
abstract: Japan's Supreme Court ruled today that the most recent parliamentary elections, held in 1983, were unconstitutional because of procedural inequities that made some votes worth far more than others.   The court, however, declined to declare the election results invalid, arguing that to do so would run against the public interest.   It was the third time in the last nine years that Japan's highest court has denounced the country's election procedures, either in whole or in part.   Like the previous rulings, the decision today lacked teeth. But in both tone and substance it was regarded as stronger and thus more likely to have an effect on an electoral system that is widely deplored but rarely altered.

headline: HERO OF PORTUGAL REVOLUTION FACES TERRORISM TRIAL TODAY
abstract: What many here are calling one of the biggest political trials ever held in Portugal is scheduled to begin Monday in a courthouse specially built for it atop a steep hill overlooking this capital city.         Lieut. Col. Otelo Saraiva de Carvalho, organizer of the army-led revolution in 1974 that ended nearly 50 years of dictatorship, will be in the dock, charged with secretly leading an extreme leftist terrorist band in an attempt to undermine the democracy he once championed.

headline: PATENTS;  Tightener For Wire In Surgery
abstract: DR. HARVEY A. KLEIN of Brooklyn, who describes himself as a mechanical engineer turned orthopedic surgeon, received a patent this week for what he calls a wire tightener and twister.

headline: THE BOOT CAMP FOR TOP M.B.A.'S
abstract: ''YOU just walk into the trading room and it hits you between the eyes,'' said Christopher Charron. ''This is great, this is where it happens.'' Mr. Charron, Harvard '85, is one of 127 trainees in corporate finance, sales and trading who started at Salomon Brothers this summer and, if he sounds more like a religious convert than an investment banker, there are 126 others just like him.   Each year hundreds of M.B.A.'s and B.A.'s descend on Wall Street like recruits at Marine boot camp, uniformly armored in gray worsted and a determination to excel. In its hours and rigors, Salomon's training program may resemble Camp Lejeune, but these recruits' enthusiasm surpasses their instructors'. ''They don't need to give us a pep talk,'' said Craig Calle, a Harvard M.B.A. who expects to work in corporate finance at Salomon. ''We're pumped up.''

headline: ITS STEEL-ONLY STRATEGY HAS YET TO YIELD A PROFIT
abstract: STEEL. Once the country seemed to provide unlimited markets for the industry to build cities, create industrial empires, win wars. The steelmakers grew comfortable and complacent, and so, after a time, did their union workers.   But Big Steel fell into distress at the end of the last decade. As it lagged in technology and as cheaper imports grew, some of the behemoths began to diversify. The United States Steel Corporation, the industry leader, bought a huge petroleum company, Marathon, and now only one-third of its revenues come from steel. Earlier, National Steel had changed its name to National Intergroup, to reflect its move into financial services and other areas. But the Bethlehem Steel Corporation, long the nation's second-largest steelmaker until the recent merger of the LTV Corporation with Republic Steel, stubbornly stayed with its core business.   The stick-with-steel strategy was all the more noticeable because it was not executed by entrenched executives but by Donald H. Trautlein, 58 years old, an accountant who spent 25 years with Price Waterhouse before joining Bethlehem as controller in 1977. He took over as chairman five years ago.

headline: SUCCESSOR IS SWORN IN
abstract: Linden Forbes Sampson Burnham, who ruled the South American country of Guyana since 1964, died today in a Guyanese hospital after a throat operation. He was 62 years old.   Desmond Hoyte, the country's Prime Minister, was sworn in to succeed him under the Guyanese Constitution. Mr. Hoyte has served as a senior minister in the Guyanese Cabinet for more than a decade, mostly in economic posts, and had been named Prime Minister by Mr. Burnham last year.   The new President is viewed as a political and philosophical protege of Mr. Burnham. ''I don't think you're going to see much of a change,'' said John Galinas, an American consultant who represents Guyana.

headline: Consumer Debt Up In July
abstract: Americans took on $6.25 billion more in installment debt than they paid off in July, up by more than $1 billion from June, the Government said today.   The Federal Reserve Board said the July increase was above the June debt gain of $5.23 billion but well below the May increase of $9.04 billion.

headline: ISRAELIS DETAIN 14 MORE ARABS IN NEW WEST BANK CRACKDOWN
abstract: Israel detained 14 more Arabs in the occupied West Bank today and ordered them held without trial.   The arrests brought to 46 the number of Arabs detained since Wednesday on what authorities said was suspicion of involvement in subversive activities. They offered no further details.  Under administrative detention, Israeli security forces can hold people for six months without trial.

headline: S.&S. Compton Adds Renault
abstract: The American Motors Corporation, with two agencies -Grey Advertising and Saatchi & Saatchi Compton - for two vehicle lines - Renault and Jeep - decided to put all of its eggs in one basket. On Friday A.M.C. announced it would be S.&S. Compton, which has been working on Jeep since 1964.

headline: The U.N. Today: July 11, 1985
abstract: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Symposium on Palestinian issue -10 A.M. and 3 P.M.   Ad Hoc Committee on Indian Ocean - 3 P.M.

headline: WEIR SAYS CAPTORS WANT 17 RELEASED
abstract: An American clergyman, freed by kidnappers in Lebanon after 16 months, said today that he had told President Reagan that Shiite militants continue to insist that they will not release the remaining American captives until the United States obtains the release of 17 terrorists held in Kuwait.   Mr. Weir, a 61-year-old Presbyterian minister whose release over the weekend was announced on Wednesday, said his captors had asked him to convey the message to the President. He said Mr. Reagan did not respond directly to him.   Mr. Weir said he had told the President that the militants, who are believed to be holding six other Americans, warned that the remaining hostages might be executed if Kuwait did not release the 17, who were convicted of terrorist assaults on Western diplomatic installations.

headline: 'JAPANESE' NOVA'S SALES ARE DELIGHTFUL TO G.M.
abstract: To Hector Lima, the only American characteristics about the new Chevrolet Nova he purchased recently were the nameplate on its grill and the fact that it was manufactured in the United States. There, he contended, its Yankee traits ended.   ''It's got the feel of a Japanese car, it rides like a Japanese car and everything about it seems Japanese,'' said Mr. Lima, a 24-year-old Houston technician. ''When our friends saw it they said they liked it a lot, but that it looked just like a Toyota.'' Indeed, in marketing the Nova, the General Motors Corporation is straightforward about the part-Japanese heritage of the first fruit of its joint venture with Japan's Toyota Motor Corporation. ''We make no bones about the fact that it's a heavily Toyota-engineered product,'' said Ed Lechtzin, a G.M. spokesman. The model offers ''the best of both worlds,'' he said, repeating the advertising slogan adopted for the Nova.

headline: SNAG SEEN OVER LOAN IN EQUITY RESCUE TALKS
abstract: Negotiators trying to rescue the Equity Programs Investment Corporation have begun to fight over who will get $100 million that the big real estate company borrowed from its parent, the Community Savings and Loan Association, investment banking sources said yesterday.   Although a compromise seemed possible, the sources agreed that how to account for the $100 million loan had emerged as a major hurdle in the broader effort to prevent Equity Programs, one of the nation's largest real estate syndicators, from defaulting on its obligations.   The company, which is based in Falls Church, Va., has already missed some payments on nearly $1.4 billion in mortgage obligations and its problems touched off a run on deposits earlier this month at Community Savings, based in Bethesda, Md.

headline: Accounts
abstract: Alpwater (U.S.A.) Inc. of Beverly Hills to Dancer Fitzgerald Sample/ Southern California.

headline: MONEY SUPPLY UP $2.8 BILLION
abstract: The Federal Reserve late yesterday announced a larger than expected $2.8 billion increase in the nation's basic money supply, but the news had a very limited impact in the credit markets, where interest rates were little changed on the day.   After a day of listless, pre-holiday trading, the money supply increase led to a rise of only a few hundredths of a percentage point in Treasury bill rates while prices of Treasury notes and bonds fell only a few 32ds of a point. Three-month Treasury bills, for example, were bid at 7.05 percent, down from 7.08 percent, while 10 5/8 percent Treasury bonds due in 2015 were offered at 102 3/8, down 3/32 on the day, to yield 10.37 percent.   ''The market has grown callused to money supply growth,'' said one trader. ''It's like beating a dead horse,'' said another trader when asked if the Fed ought to reassure the financial markets with some special explanation of rapid money supply growth.

headline: Libya and Morocco Move Toward Union
abstract: Libya and Morocco took a step closer to formal union today by setting up a joint legislature.   Formation of the assembly, done in Morocco's Chamber of Representatives, was a provision of the Arab-African Union Treaty signed by the two countries last August.

headline: SHULTZ MEETS HUSSEIN ON ARMS SALE AND PEACE TALKS
abstract: Secretary of State George P. Shultz held an unpublicized dinner with King Hussein in New York this week to discuss the Reagan Administration's problems with the imminent announcement of the sale of advanced American aircraft and other military equipment to Jordan, Government officials said today.   They said that in the dinner, which was held Tuesday at the United Nations Plaza Hotel, Mr. Shultz sought to gain further assurances from King Hussein about his readiness to negotiate with Israel. They said such assurances would make it easier to defuse the Congressional opposition to the arms sale, which is expected to be heavy.

headline: KEEP MAIL ORDER OUT OF TAX COLLECTION
abstract: NOT MANY people have a clear idea of what a use tax is, and yet this tax may shortly enter the lives of most Americans.  Use-tax laws have been on the books of 45 states for more than two decades, giving states the power to tax (at the same rate as their sales tax) items purchased through the mail and to tax other property brought into the state by residents.  This broad taxing authority has been exercised within reasonable limits only because methods of collecting the tax have proved to be either impractical or unconstitutional. However, state tax administrators now have a plan to circumvent constitutional barriers and shift the practical burdens to out-of-state companies, which would be forced to serve involuntarily as tax collectors.

headline: Investment Group Head At Home in SCOA Bid
abstract: For Thomas H. Lee, a leveraged buyout specialist, Monday's announcement that an investment group he heads is near an agreement to purchase SCOA Industries for $637 million represented more than a sound business decision. In a sense, the deal sent Mr. Lee back to his roots.   ''My grandfather, Robert W. Schiff, founded SCOA in 1905,'' Mr. Lee said in a telephone interview. ''It feels wonderful to be able to do this.''

headline: 42 SLAIN IN BEIRUT IN HEAVY SHELLING
abstract: At least 42 more people were reported killed over the last 24 hours today as Christian and Moslem gunners bombarded Beirut's residential districts and the airport with artillery, rocket and tank fire.   The police said most of those killed and wounded were civilians. The fighting that has raged for the last 10 days is the worst outbreak in six months, and the police said at least 280 people have been killed and 876 wounded by shelling and car bombs.

headline: Washington Watch;   Freer Trade In High Tech
abstract: DESPITE the big buildup of protectionist pressures in Washington, the United States and Japan are rapidly abolishing tariffs in high technology products.   Canada may match some of the cuts. Even the European Economic Community, which has long protected high technology behind high tariff walls, is considering reductions. The Common Market's Council of Ministers is weighing a cut from 17 percent to 14 percent in its semiconductor tariff.

headline: DETAILED DEFENSE OF TAX PLAN
abstract: Richard G. Darman, Deputy Secretary of the Treasury, said today that accusations that the Reagan Administration's tax proposals would be unfavorable to middle-income Americans were ''not sustainable'' and came from ''partisans'' trying to derail the plan for other reasons.   In the Administration's first public point-by-point rebuttal to critics of its tax plan, Mr. Darman said the proposals would benefit most taxpayers at every income level.   Modest changes may have to be made in the proposals, he said, to assure that two-income families would not be penalized and that very wealthy taxpayers would not gain a much larger proportional tax cut than others. But he insisted that ''the problem is manageable.''

headline: Salvador Rebels Report Anti-Transport Raids
abstract: Leftist rebels said today that they had inflicted 109 casualties on Government soldiers during a three-day campaign to paralyze national transportaion.   A spokesman for the United States-backed military, however, said the number of army casualties was ''not higher than 12'' during the three days, and that the guerrillas had suffered between 15 and 20 casualties.   The rebel-run Radio Venceremos said the transportation stoppage campaign, which began Monday, was ''95 percent effective.''

headline: ATTRACTIONS SEEN FOR U.S. INVESTORS
abstract: Investors in the United States reacted calmly yesterday to the shutdown of the South African stock and currency markets. Shares of that country's companies, which continued to trade in the United States and elsewhere, declined only moderately.   Analysts say the South African situation may have pushed the shares of some gold mining companies low enough to represent a good investment opportunity.

headline: 2 COAST CARRIERS BATTLE OVER BUSIEST AIR ROUTE
abstract: In the ''California Corridor,'' the 350-mile stretch between Los Angeles and San Francisco that forms the nation's busiest air route, Aircal Inc. is waging a slick, multimillion-dollar marketing war against Pacific Southwest Airlines Inc. for the No. 1 position.   Aircal Inc., a regional airline that draws about 70 percent of its revenue from the Los Angeles-San Francisco market, hopes to win over a majority of the 6.6 million travelers who each year fly between the four Los Angeles-area airports and the San Francisco Bay area's three airports.   After three strained years, aggravated by fare cutting, that threatened to bankrupt the Newport Beach-based carrier, Aircal returned to stable prices and profitability last year. Since then it has poured millions into new Boeing 737-300 jets and a barrage of advertising aimed at unseating its rival. The company has signed a contract to lease 12 jets valued at $300 million, and it has options for 11 more.

headline: U.S. Petroleum Data
abstract: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

headline: Dividend Meetings
abstract: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of July 15, 1985:

headline: THAIS MAY BAR VIETNAMESE BOAT PEOPLE
abstract: A Thai official said today that Vietnamese boat people might lose their right to asylum in Thailand because resettlement in third countries was proceeding too slowly.   The official, Prasong Soonsiri, who is secretary general of the National Security Council, said in a speech to a conference of international refugee agencies marking 10 years of Indochinese refugee arrivals that Thailand ''may be unable to cooperate in allowing their illegal entry any further.''   Mr. Prasong was particularly critical of Western European nations that, he said, tended to leave the refugee burden to poorer countries of first asylum. He said the Europeans wanted to settle refugees in developing countries ''as a durable way to keep them from entering Europe.''

headline: ZIMBABWE LEADER FURIOUS AT WHITES
abstract: Prime Minister Robert G. Mugabe today criticized white voters in this black-governed African nation as ''racists of the past'' for the impressive political victory they gave former Prime Minister Ian D. Smith last week.   Mr. Mugabe said the outcome of the voting showed that the whites had rebuffed his Government's attempt at reconciliation and his effort to build a united nation.   ''What came out is that the enemy of yesterday is still today's enemy,'' he said at a rally on the eve of voting for blacks Monday and Tuesday, the second stage of Zimbabwe's first general election since independence in 1980.   Mr. Mugabe said there could never be an alliance between Mr. Smith's supporters and Zimbabwe's black majority. He told up to 200,000 supporters that it would now be ''very hard going for the racists of this country.'' Mr. Smith was Prime Minister of the country when it was known as Rhodesia.

headline: New York State
abstract: A $100 million issue of New York State Electric and Gas Corporation first-mortgage bonds was tentatively price yesterday through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers Inc. The bonds, due in 2015, are offered at a price of par, to yield 12 percent. They are rated Baa-2 by Moody's and BBB-plus by S.& P. Proceeds will be used for retirement of debt and capital expenditures.

headline: New Product Ads Up
abstract: New product introductions in August were once again well ahead of the same month last year, with 168 compared with 145, according to the Dancer Fitzgerald Sample New Product News. That means that, with the exception of June, every month of the year has topped 1984 monthly totals. For the eight months, the figure was 1,415, compared with 1,292.

headline: Wheeling Backed on Wage Cuts
abstract: A Federal bankruptcy judge yesterday granted a request by the Wheeling-Pittsburgh Steel Corporation to void its labor contract with the United Steelworkers union.   The decision means that the company, which filed for court protection from creditors under Chapter 11 of the Federal bankruptcy laws on April 16, is free to impose its own wages, benefits and working conditions.   It was the first major decision on voiding a labor contract of a company in bankruptcy proceedings since the Federal bankruptcy law was revised in 1984. Continental Airlines, which voided its labor contracts, has operated under the bankruptcy law since September 1983, before the revision, and has reduced its labor costs from about 35 percent of total operating expenses to about 22 percent now.

headline: CONSUMER RATES
abstract: In percent

headline: ETHICS
abstract: To the Editor:   I read with interest Edwin McDowell's review of Solomon's and Hanson's book on business ethics (''What's New on the Executive Bookshelf,'' Sept. 1). Many successful companies indeed incorporate codes of ethics within their culture.

headline: Nigeria
abstract: Geography With an area of 356,700 square miles, Nigeria is about the size of California, Nevada and Arizona combined. Its name derives from that of the Niger River, the third-longest river in Africa, and its territory ranges from southern coastal swamps to tropical forests, from open woodlands, grass and savannas to semidesert in the far north. Nigeria, which is relatively flat, has rich oil and mineral deposits. Population Nigeria's population, estimated to range from 80 million to 95 million, includes some 250 tribal groups. About half the people are Moslems, primarily in the north. There are many Christians in the south. English is the official language but major African languages, such as Hausa, Yoruba and Ibo, are widely used. About 70 percent of the population is illiterate. Economy Nigeria is one of the largest suppliers of oil to the United States. It must import 70 percent of its food and raw materials. In addition to oil, which accounts for more than 90 percent of its foreign exchange, Nigeria also exports cocoa and rubber.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: Amerifederal Savings Bank, Lawrenceville, N.J., has appointed R. Scott Twigg senior vice president.    * Binswanger Co., Philadelphia, a real estate concern, has named Peter B. Maroney senior vice president, communications.

headline: Petro-Lewis S.E.C. Case
abstract: The Securities and Exchange Commission charged today that the Petro-Lewis Corporation defrauded its shareholders and investors in limited oil and gas partnerships by issuing false statements. The S.E.C. also said the company failed to file proper reports with the Government.

headline: NAVY ENDS BAN ON CONTRACTING WITH DYNAMICS
abstract: The Navy announced today that it had lifted a ban on signing new contracts with the General Dynamics Corporation, bringing five months of penalties against the company to a close.   By ending the moratorium on new work at the company's Electric Boat division in Groton, Conn., and Pomona arms factory in Los Angeles, the Navy signaled a return to normal business after one of the most tumultuous disputes over weapon costs in the Pentagon's history.   ''There was no pattern of corruption - they were simply doing what our regulations allowed them to do,'' said Everett Pyatt, Assistant Secretary of the Navy for Shipbuilding and Logistics, of General Dynamics' disputed contract charges. The charges were determined to be improper by Congressional investigators and Pentagon auditors.

headline: INDIA AND PAKISTAN DIFFER OVER U.S. MISSION
abstract: A United States mission to India and Pakistan this week was praised in Pakistan but criticized in India for suggesting the two nations undertake ''regional initiatives'' to avert a nuclear arms race on the subcontinent.   A United States official called the four-day visit a success and said it signaled further involvement by Washington in encouraging discussions between India and Pakistan, particularly on each country's fears of the other's nuclear program.   The official said the next step in reducing tensions could come at a possible meeting between Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi of India and President Mohammad Zia ul-Haq of Pakistan at the United Nations in October.

headline: G.M. Hughes Accounting
abstract: The General Motors Corporation, at the insistence of the Securities and Exchange Commission, will report two earnings figures for its new G.M. Hughes subsidiary, company officials said today.   The auto company, which is in the process of acquiring the Hughes Aircraft Company for $5 billion, is establishing a new category of stock, G.M. H shares, that will be backed by the earnings of the new subsidiary.

headline: Alcoa Debentures Due Date Is 2015
abstract: Aluminum Company of America is offering $150 million of 12 percent sinking fund debentures due 2015 at a price of 99.6, to yield 12.05 percent, through underwriters led by the First Boston Corporation.   The debentures, rated A-3 by Moody's and BBB+ by Standard & Poor's, were priced with a yield that was 1 1/4 percentage points greater than the 10 3/8 percent Treasury bonds due in 2012. Because of sinking fund payments, the debentures have an average life of about 21 years.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST: TUESDAY, JULY 30, 1985
abstract: Markets    Stock prices fell sharply as weakness last week broadened to hurt the overall market. The Dow Jones industrial average dropped 13.22 points, to 1,343.86, its biggest decline in more than six weeks. Shares that fell outnumbered those that rose by nearly 4 to 1. Volume was moderate, however. Sectors that were hit hard included food, technology, transportation and utilities. [Page D1.]    Treasury note and bond prices continued to slide as government securities dealers searched for levels that would attract investors to next week's heavy supply of new Treasury issues. [D19.]

headline: New Deputy Named For Burmese Leader
abstract: Burma's only legal political party elected a deputy today to the country's longtime military leader, Brig. Gen. Ne Win.   The move was widely seen in the region as a clue to who might succeed the 74-year-old general, who has ruled Burma unchallenged for nearly a quarter of a century.

headline: General Mills in the Red
abstract: General Mills Inc., which has been divesting itself of many of its consumer goods operations, yesterday reported large losses in the fourth quarter and the full year ended May 26.

headline: MOSCOW QUESTIONS PRESS REPORTS ON 'STAR WARS' CONCESSION
abstract: Soviet arms negotiators said here today that reports indicating that Moscow was now willing to accept an arms treaty permitting American research on a space-based missile defense were incorrect.   The statement, issued by Valery Artemyev, an adviser to the Soviet delegation, was corroborated by a United States delegation official, although neither side would issue an outright denial of the reports.   Mr. Artemyev, speaking with reporters, singled out a Washington dispatch in The New York Times on Tuesday that quoted Reagan Administration officials as having said that Soviet officials would be willing for the first time to accept an arms treaty allowing research on the space-based defense system popularly known as ''Star Wars.''   ''The article by Leslie Gelb,'' Mr. Artemyev said, referring to the writer of dispatch in The Times, ''as well as articles and reports of a similar content which appeared in other newspapers, do not reflect the actual state of affairs at the negotiations.'' Objections Not Specified When asked to explain what the Russians found objectionable, Mr. Artemyev invoked the confidentiality agreement between the two sides and said: ''It means the thing I referred to is incorrect.''

headline: PATENTS;  Method and Instrument For Figuring Fertility
abstract: Two physicians have invented a method and instrument to enable women to calculate their own fertility timing.

headline: Stop and Shop
abstract: Stop and Shop Companies, a Boston-based retailer, is offering $125 million of 10-year notes through underwriters led by Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc. The notes carry a 10 3/4 percent coupon and are offered at a price of 99 3/4, to yield 10.79 percent. They are rated Baa-2 by Moody's Investors Service and BBB by the Standard & Poor's Corporation.

headline: PAIN RELIEF
abstract: To the Editor:   It is astonishing that ''Arthritis: Building an Industry on Pain'' (Aug. 18) failed to mention electronic pain management. There are some 40 companies that manufacture and distribute a small electronic battery-operated unit that eliminates or greatly reduces the need for pain medication. ELIZABETH L. GILLMAN Scarsdale, N.Y., Aug. 19

headline: Firestone Net Declines 73%
abstract: The Firestone Tire and Rubber Company said today that it earned $13 million, or 31 cents a share, in its fiscal third quarter, a 73 percent drop from $48 million, or $1.06 a share, a year earlier. Sales fell to $994 million from $1.03 billion.

headline: Iraq Tells of New Raid On Kharg Island
abstract: Iraqi warplanes dropped more than four tons of explosives in a raid on Kharg Island today and shot down an Iranian jet in a dogfight over Iran's main oil terminal, the Baghdad command said.   An Iraqi military spokesman said the raid was designed to hinder Iranian efforts to repair damaged installations and extinguish fires caused by previous attacks on the island.

headline: Accounts
abstract: * Abbott Diagnostics of North Chicago has assigned several of its business groups to Sutton Communications.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST: FRIDAY, SEPTEMBER 27, 1985
abstract: International    Canada's Government asked to open talks to liberalize trade with the U.S. From the Reagan Administration's perspective, a Canadian trade deal could be an important move against the rising tide of protectionism in Congress. But actual negotiations are expected to be difficult, officials in Washington said. [Page A1.]    Pressure on Japan to strengthen the yen appears to be the main intent of the weekend accord to lower the dollar. Japan left the meeting of five nations with the ''understanding that the major issue is the exchange rate between the dollar and the yen,'' said a senior official at the Bank of Japan. [D1.]  Monetary officials from Britain, France and West Germany concurred that the most decisive action is expected to come from Japan and the U.S. [D6.]

headline: DELTAUS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Dole Warns Taipei on Curb
abstract: The Senate majority leader, Bob Dole, urged Taiwan today to take drastic measures to cut its large trade surplus with the United States.

headline: JUDGE WON'T BAR TEST FIRING AT SATELLITE, EXPECTED TODAY
abstract: A Federal judge today denied a request by four members of Congress and an organization of scientists to forbid a test of the United States anti-satellite weapon, which is expected to take place on Friday.   District Court Judge Norma Johnson denied the motion, partly on the grounds that she viewed the issue as a ''political question'' between the legislative and executive branches of Government in which the court should not intervene.   Judge Johnson also said that she did not believe the plaintiffs had legal standing to bring the suit and that she had found no evidence that the test would do ''irreparable harm.''

headline: Baldwin Plan Reviewed
abstract: A proposal that would increase the projected payment to policyholders of the Baldwin-United Corporation is being reviewed by Arkansas and Indiana insurance commissioners, insurance industry sources said today.   The proposal was presented last week by the Sun Life Group, an insurance subsidiary of Kaufman & Broad Inc. of Los Angeles. The commissioners had requested the proposal as an alternative to a plan organized last year by the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company and the American Council of Life Insurance.

headline: Free Shoppers' Magazine Set
abstract: A free magazine for supermarket shoppers is in the works at Family Media, already the publisher of The Ladies' Home Journal, Health, 1,001 Home Ideas, The Homeowner, Savvy, World Tennis and Golf Illustrated.   The new monthly publication will be called The Shopper along with the distributing chain's name, such as The Safeway Shopper.

headline: Freddie Mac to Package Multifamily Mortgages
abstract: The Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation, known as Freddie Mac, announced a new program yesterday to buy mortgages on multifamily properties and repackage the loans into a mortgage pass-through security to be sold to investors.   Leland C. Brendsel, an executive vice president at Freddie Mac, said that ''this security will produce a larger pool of capital for multifamily mortgages'' because the ability to quickly sell mortgages will encourage more lenders to enter the field. Greater lending activity would put downward pressure on interest rates and rents for multifamily projects, he said.

headline: DOLLAR FALLS A BIT AMID INTERVENTION
abstract: The dollar fell moderately yesterday as a consensus formed that central banks are serious about intervening in the currency markets to force down the dollar.   The Federal Reserve Bank of New York sold modest amounts of dollars yesterday, traders said, but cast a long shadow in New York trading rooms by frequently telephoning banks for quotes. Most of the time the Fed did not make a transaction, but the calls reminded traders of their vulnerability to sudden intervention.   ''They let us know they're looking over our shoulder,'' said James Bacci, a trader at the Swiss Bank Corporation in New York. ''Each time the Fed calls there's a moment of tension.''

headline: FLAT 3D QUARTER FOR STOCKS
abstract: The stellar stock price gains posted on many of the world's major exchanges in the first half of 1985 jerked to a stop in the third quarter, as the sluggish American economy forced companies and investors around the globe to reassess their strategies.   Despite gyrations that periodically sent prices sharply higher on several exchanges - and even set a record in New York, the world's largest exchange - the indexes of share prices at many exchanges finished the quarter almost unchanged from where they began.   ''It was really a long, hot, lackluster summer,'' Hugh A. Johnson, a senior vice president at the First Albany Corporation in Albany, said. ''It was trendless but volatile. And that might be telling us something more important. The lack of much market growth in the third quarter may indicate really that we have seen the peak in this cycle.''

headline: Tunisia Said to Expel 253 Libyans for Spying
abstract: Tunisia has expelled 253 Libyans, including diplomats, for spying, the official press agency reported today.

headline: PATENTS;  A Legume Compound Used as Leukemia Curb
abstract: A substance has been found that is useful in the treatment of leukemia tumors.

headline: A FIGHT TO ACQUIRE REVLON IS EXPECTED
abstract: Pantry Pride Inc. may be waging a losing battle in its multibillion-dollar campaign to take over Revlon Inc., even though Revlon is showing considerable interest in a Pantry Pride takeover, Wall Street investment bankers said yesterday.   Michel C. Bergerac, chairman of the big cosmetics company, is known to have met yesterday with Ronald O. Perelman, head of MacAndrews & Forbes, a little-known company that controls Pantry Pride.   The merger talks were one of a series of secret meetings between the two men, and additional meetings are expected shortly - thus giving Wall Street the first serious indication in more than a year that Revlon might consider selling the company.

headline: Old Court Owners Sued
abstract: The conservator of the Old Court Savings and Loan Association has filed a civil suit against the Maryland thrift institution's owners and directors charging that they misappropriated funds and failed to meet their responsibility to depositors. The suit charged that their actions ''may have constituted the largest financial fraud in the history of the state of Maryland'' and asked for punitive damages of $200 million.

headline: Consumer Credit Report
abstract: The Federal Reserve Board said that the consumer installment credit report for June, scheduled for Tuesday, was now tentatively scheduled to be released on Wednesday.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST: WEDNESDAY, SEPTEMBER 11, 1985
abstract: Companies    Top management changes at Citicorp are imminent, according to banking sources. John S. Reed, who was named chief executive a year ago, is expected to ask the board Tuesday to appoint new top officers for each of the company's three major divisions. Thomas C. Theobald, once Mr. Reed's main competitor, would be shifted from head of Citicorp's huge commercial banking business to take charge of its key investment banking activities. [Page D1.]    A unit of GTE was accused of misuse of classified documents. The Justice Department charged that the company, a leading maker of electronic warfare devices, obtained Pentagon documents and then used them to make plans for marketing equipment to the services. The company said it would plead guilty. [A22.]

headline: Market Place;   Tax-Exempt Trusts Flourish
abstract: WHATEVER uncertainties may exist in the securities markets, many people continue to buy tax-exempt unit investment trusts at a record clip. ''Tax-exempt trust volume totaled $9 billion for the first seven months of 1985,'' according to John Nuveen & Company. ''This compared with $8.8 billion in the same period last year.''   These trusts are fixed, diversified portfolios of long-term municipal bonds being packaged by an increasing number of sponsor firms for distribution to retail customers. Chicago-based Nuveen is the largest sole sponsor and, according to industry sources, accounts for about 24 percent of all new offerings.

headline: U.S.-CANADIAN RIFT ON WOOD EXPORTS
abstract: A serious confrontation over Canada's growing lumber exports to the United States appears to be looming, with a flurry of legislation before Congress to limit shipments through duties or quotas.         The main issue is contentions by members of Congress and the American lumber  industry that Canadian companies are buying standing timber from provincial governments at unfairly subsidized prices.

headline: Southern Pacific
abstract: The Southern Pacific Transportation Company is offering cash payments to all of its 3,000 nonunion workers if they quit their jobs, a spokesman for the railroad company said. The offer, which takes effect Aug. 16, covers about 10 percent of the company's employees. A spokesman, Andrew Anderson, said the offer had been made because of a slump.

headline: 7 CHILEAN POLICEMEN ORDERED HELD IN 3 SLAYINGS
abstract: Seven paramilitary policemen, including two colonels, have been arrested in connection with the slayings of three Communist Party opponents of the Government, the police said today.   Judge Jose Canovas Robles ordered the arrests in a ruling published Friday. Judge Robles sparked a political shake-up when he ruled earlier this month that he had evidence that 14 policemen were involved in the murders, which occurred in March.

headline: Verbatim Shows Optical Disk Drive
abstract: The Verbatim Corporation has introduced a prototype of an optical disk drive  that can erase and write information on a disk rather than just read it. The product was shown at the National Computer Conference here.         For years, experts have predicted that optical disks would become standard equipment on computers because they can store far more data than standard magnetic disks. Optical disks use beams of light to record and read data. All of the optical disk drives now on the market, however, have a major drawback: While they can pluck data off the disk, they cannot change it and put it back on.

headline: HOT MARKET FOR RADIO STATIONS
abstract: They may not have the cachet of television stations. And in the merger market, they do not command the same multimillion-dollar price tags. But radio stations are quietly changing hands these days at a record-breaking pace.   The auction tomorrow of eight radio stations that Capital Cities Communications Inc. and the American Broadcasting Companies are selling to accomplish their merger is likely to generate even more interest in the field. Among the properties to be sold by sealed bid are WPAT-AM and WPAT-FM in the New York area, which boast operating profit margins of nearly 53 percent.

headline: Filling Energy Agency Job
abstract: A confirmation battle looms in the Senate over the nomination of Charles Trabandt to the five-member Federal Energy Regulatory Commission, which oversees the natural gas industry and wholesale transactions in electricity. The main supporter of Mr. Trabandt, formerly chief counsel of the Senate Energy Committee and currently a lawyer at the Interior Department, is said to be William Clark, former Secretary of the Interior, who has left the Government. Mr. Trabandt hopes to succeed Georgiana Sheldon, whose second term expired in October.   Meanwhile, a group of 10 Senators has sent a letter of ''strong recommendation'' to the White House that Michael Naeve, a lawyer with Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom, be named to replace Oliver Richard 3d for a Democratic slot on the commission. Mr. Oliver recently announced his resignation.

headline: CITY RETAIL SALES ROSE 0.1% IN JULY
abstract: New York City retail sales in July rose only one-tenth of 1 percent over the same 1984 month, remaining in the plateau that has been evident for more than a year, according to a spot-check.   Total area sales of seven of the largest stores in the city and in the suburbs also were disappointing, rising only eight-tenths of 1 percent over the year before.   Since June 1984, city sales have been in the doldrums, rising 5 percent or more above the year earlier only in three months but running flat or behind the previous year's levels in nine months. Suburban stores, while performing slightly better than those in the city, generally have also shown an erratic, mostly downward sales pattern.

headline: SHULTZ TELLS U.N. HE SEES A CHANCE TO AVERT WAR RISK
abstract: Secretary of State George P. Shultz said today that the United States and the Soviet Union now had a ''historic opportunity'' to reduce the risk of war. But he accused Moscow of making ''blatantly one-sided'' statements that were holding up progress in the arms talks in Geneva.   ''So let's get down to real business, with the seriousness the subject deserves,'' he said.   Setting the stage for this week's high-level discussions here and in Washington with Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze of the Soviet Union, Mr. Shultz said at the start of the 40th meeting of the United Nations General Assembly session that signs of Soviet good faith ''will be more than matched on the American side.''

headline: AFGHAN REBELS DENY KABUL REPORT THAT THEY DOWNED CIVIL AIRLINES
abstract: Afghan exiles today challenged Afghanistan's assertion that guerrillas shot down one of its airliners with an American-made missile. They said that the plane might have crashed or that it was a military transport.   Afghan guerrilla groups based in Pakistan said today that they had no independent reports of the incident. No guerrilla organization asserted responsibility for shooting down such a plane.

headline: TURMOIL CONTINUES TO BESET NIGERIA
abstract: By the sheer number of its people and the size of its economy, Nigeria looms as the giant of Africa. Another upheaval in sub-Saharan Africa's largest military establishment augurs uncertainty and political unrest in an entire region.   With a population estimated at about 85 million, Nigeria is the most populous and one of the most crowded African countries. Its people make up a quarter of the population of sub-Saharan Africa and the state of their affairs cannot help but influence events, especially in such English-speaking countries as Ghana and Liberia.

headline: F.D.I.C. Wins Court Case
abstract: Seven partners who bought the First National Bank building downtown in late 1982 for $75 million - 10 months before the bank was declared insolvent - have been ordered to begin paying $31.8 million plus interest to the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation by United States District Judge Lucius Bunton. The ruling was issued Wednesday in a lawsuit that contended payments on the property were overdue.   In a non-jury trial last March, the partners said they believed the purchase was a short-term venture to keep the bank from reporting a loss.

headline: MARWICK,HURDMAN SAID TO HOLD TALKS
abstract: Peat Marwick, the nation's second-largest accounting firm, and KMG Main Hurdman, the ninth-largest, are holding preliminary merger discussions, sources at both firms said yesterday.   Officials at both firms, however, cautioned that the talks were at a preliminary stage and that each firm had had preliminary talks with other firms in recent months that had not lead to formal merger negotiations.   ''We have basically had communications with lots of firms in the past year and we are not positioning ourselves to get into formal merger talks,'' a partner at Main Hurdman said. ''We have been approached by six or seven of the Big Eight firms wanting to enter into exploratory talks. We're exploring lots of people and no firm decisions have been made.'' However, a source at Main Hurdman described the Peat Marwick talks as the most serious.

headline: Baldwin Deal With S.E.C.
abstract: The Baldwin United Corporation has settled with the Securities and Exchange Commission on charges it violated antifraud, proxy-solicitation, reporting and accounting provisions of the Federal securities laws in its sales of annuities in the early 1980s. The information was contained in a suit filed in United States District Court in Cincinnati yesterday.

headline: 9.57% Yield Set In Alaska Housing
abstract: The Alaska Housing Finance Corporation is offering $100 million of collateralized home mortgage bonds through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers.   The financing consists of 9 1/2 percent bonds due in 2020 and tentatively offered at a price of 99 1/4, to yield approximately 9.57 percent.   Because the bonds are secured primarily by program obligations, consisting of mortgage-backed certificates guaranteed by the Government National Mortgage Association or guaranteed mortgage pass-through certiticates issued by the Federal National Mortgage Association, they are expected to be rated triple-A by both Moody's and Standard & Poor's.

headline: FARM LOAN AID PLAN IS ASKED
abstract: Saying that the nation's system of more than 800 cooperative farm banks faces ''the most severe crisis since the Depression days,'' the system's top regulator today asked Congress and the Reagan Administration to begin laying plans for a Federal rescue that he said could run to ''multibillions of dollars.''   If the deterioration of the farm economy persists, Donald E. Wilkinson, governor of the Farm Credit Administration, said at a news conference, parts of the Farm Credit System - as the loosely connected network of farmer-owned lending institutions is known - would face liquidation in 18 to 24 months without Federal aid. The nonfarm economy would suffer as well, he added.   Mr. Wilkinson said the system was the farmers' biggest creditor, holding more than a third of all farm loans, or $$77 billion of a total of $213 billion.

headline: VIETNAM PROMISES TO RETURN BODIES OF 26 AMERICANS
abstract: Vietnam has promised to return the remains of 26 more American servicemen who died in the Vietnam War, the largest such turnover since the fighting ended, Americans officials said today.   Officials traveling with Secretary of State George P. Shultz on a tour of Southeast Asia and Australia appeared surprised and delighted at the commitment, which was made to a United States military casualty research group that just ended a three-day mission to Hanoi.      Visit With Cambodia Rebels   On Monday, Mr. Shultz will meet with Thai officials in Bangkok, and on Tuesday he will visit a Cambodian refugee camp inside Thailand on the border with Cambodia. United States officials said Mr. Shultz would meet with two leaders of Cambodia's non-Communist resistance movement in Bangkok.

headline: MARINE RISES 8%
abstract: The Chemical New York Corporation, parent of Chemical Bank, the nation's sixth largest, yesterday reported a 39.7 percent jump in second-quarter net income, to $107.3 million.   Analysts described the strong showing as the start of what is expected to be a string of good earnings reports for the industry.   Interest rates fell sharply throughout the quarter. For most banks, this meant that their cost of funds, what they pay for borrowings, generally fell more quickly than what they charged their customers for loans, which increased their spread on the loans, analysts explained.

headline: HELD BY KUWAIT: 17 SHIITES
abstract: On Dec. 12, 1983, bombings took place in several places in Kuwait, including the American and French Embassies, the international airport, a petrochemical plant and an American residential area.   Five people were killed, including a suicide truck-bomber, and 66 others were injured.

headline: Ethiopian Rebels Win Clash
abstract: Eritrean rebels said today that they had killed or wounded more than 1,500 Ethiopian Government soldiers and shot down a MIG fighter plane in heavy fighting last week.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: Debt Issues    * Bankers Trust Co. is offering $150 million, up from $100 million, of 9 1/4 percent, three-year notes at a price of 99.87 to yield 9.30 percent through underwriters led by Merrill Lynch.    * Citicorp sold $50 million of 91-day commercial paper at an average rate of 7.463 percent, down from 7.58 percent last week. A $50 million issue of 182-day commercial paper sold at an average 7.435 percent, down from 7.718 percent.    * Crane Co. filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for a shelf offering of up to $125 million of subordinated debentures.

headline: TRW Co-Founder Heads Venture Group
abstract: The Aetna Casualty and Surety Company, a division of the Aetna Life and Casualty Company, has announced the formation of a new joint venture to pursue venture capital opportunities in high technology, and has named Dr. Simon Ramo, a co-founder of TRW Inc., its chairman.   Dr. Ramo's is not the only familiar name involved in the new operation, called the Aetna, Peterson, Jacobs & Ramo Technology Venture Group. Indeed, the group was formed as a result of wide-ranging contacts in government and business made by Peter G. Peterson, a Commerce Secretary under President Nixon who also has been chief executive of Bell & Howell and chairman of Lehman Brothers.

headline: THE 'REAL' G.N.P.
abstract: All economic statistics can be deceptive, but few more so than the gross national product. Last Thursday, for instance, the Commerce Department said second-quarter G.N.P. rose 1.7 percent, compared with a gain of just three-tenths of a percent in the first three months of 1985.

headline: BEIRUT CHRISTIAN GOES TO DAMASCUS
abstract: The commander of Lebanon's Christian militia traveled to Syria today for talks with Government officials there about Lebanon's continuing political crisis.   It was the first visit to Damascus in a decade by a Christian militia activist, and appeared to underline a shift in policy by the militia, the Lebanese Forces, in recent months.   Last March, the militia commander, Elie Hobeika, led what was called an uprising against the senior politicians in the Phalangist Party, the country's principal Christian organization, which fielded the largest number of the militia forces. Mr. Hobeika, 28 years old, heads the 12-member executive committee that controls the 6,000-strong Lebanese Forces.   Until the revolt, the Lebanese Forces had strongly opposed Syria and cooperated closely with Israel. But in a reversal of policy, Mr. Hobeika and his colleagues announced that they were renouncing the link with Israel and choosing instead a Syrian and Arab role in ending the 10-year-old civil war.

headline: A BANNER YEAR FOR AUTO SALES
abstract: Even though car and truck sales will hit record levels for the 1985 model year, the chairman of General Motors Corporation warned today that the American auto industry, and others as well, would have to move swiftly to computerize their operations to meet threats from abroad.   Roger B. Smith predicted that total American sales of cars and trucks -domestically made or imported -would reach 15.4 million by the end of the month, which is the end of the 1985 model year. The previous record was 15.3 million in the boom year of 1978.   And he said he expected 1986 to be strong as well, though perhaps not reaching a record. ''We have a real shot at surpassing 15 million units again,'' he said at a news conference.

headline: Economic Scene;   The Explosion Of Private Debt
abstract: THE rapid growth of the Federal Government's debt has been the focus of a great deal of public concern in recent years. But much less attention has been paid than is due to the even greater explosion of private debt.   Total outstanding debt in the United States has more than doubled in the past seven years, increasing from $3.3 trillion at the end of 1977 to $7.1 trillion at the end of 1984. While the Federal debt was rising by $754 billion during that period, private debt was climbing by $2.3 trillion.

headline: Control Data Sets New Plant Closings
abstract: The Control Data Corporation, conceding that its troubles have spread to another of its divisions, said yesterday that it would close six of its minicomputer manufacturing operations for 11 days later this year because inventories are piling up.   Last month the Minneapolis-based company announced layoffs and temporary plant closings in its computer peripherals operations.

headline: RESCUE EFFORTS, AND BURIALS, CONTINUE IN MEXICO
abstract: Mexico's earthquake-battered capital began returning to normal today, but that effort created new problems.   While rescue teams continued their search for survivors of the earthquakes that struck the city Thursday and Friday, and while burials continued, other people began to return to work.   The additional cars on the streets -combined with the many blockades in damaged areas around the city -snarled traffic into impenetrable knots. The additional volume of telephone calls resulting from renewed business activity brought the city's crippled telephone system to near collapse, with waits of 15 minutes for a dial tone not uncommon.

headline: Better Outlook Seen by Apple
abstract: Apple Computer Inc. expects Christmas sales to be strong this year and has increased its advertising budget somewhat, the company said today.   The remarks appeared to be more optimistic than predictions made in late July by the company.   Apple officials also indicated that the company expects to be profitable in the current quarter, which ends Sept. 30.

headline: Bemused By Coincidence
abstract: David W. Schropfer is a regular churchgoer, and is therefore only bemused by a coincidence of numbers in his life.   The keystone to the tale is his training ground, Procter & Gamble, whose well-publicized logotype problems rested on the rumor that woven into the curlicued beard on the old man in its logo was the number 666 written backward.

headline: Ex-Diplomat Will Head The Americas Society
abstract: The Americas Society has appointed George W. Landau, a former diplomat, as its president, effective yesterday.

headline: AT LEAST 80 KILLED IN A DAM COLLAPSE IN NORTHERN ITALY
abstract: An earthen dam in the northern Italian mountains burst today, sending forth what one survivor called ''a wall of mud and water'' and killing at least 80 people. Officials said they expected the death toll to rise to 200 or more.   The dam collapsed at about 12:20 P.M. (6:20 A.M., New York time) and sent water sweeping through the mountain village of Stava, washing away everything in its path.   The 150-foot-wide wave of mud and water destroyed three hotels, part of a fourth and two dozen houses in one of Italy's greenest and most popular mountain resort areas.

headline: U.N. PENSION FUND SPEEDS DIVESTMENT
abstract: The United Nations pension fund of $4 billion has accelerated its 11-year-old policy of selling holdings in companies that do business in South Africa.   At the end of May, 6 percent of the holdings, worth $250 million, were in 30 companies with operations in South Africa, according to a statement issued today by J. Richard Foran, the United Nations controller. By Aug. 6, the holdings were down to 14 companies with a market value of under $100 million.

headline: Zero-Coupon Securities Introduced in London
abstract: Quadrex Securities Ltd. yesterday introduced zero-coupon securities to the British Government bond market, with an offering of $:309.3 million face amount of zero-coupon issues, known informally as ''stags.''   The new securities, which had the approval of the Bank of England, were created by separating interest payments from the principal on $:100 million of 15 1/2 percent Treasury bonds, or gilts, due in 1998 Together with Charterhouse Japhet P.L.C., Quadrex is offering zero-coupon bonds due between 1985 and 1998 at prices ranging from 98.90, to yield 10.55 percent, and 26.875, to yield 11.11 percent.

headline: Lebanese Are Barred From Kuwait's Airline
abstract: Kuwait has barred all Lebanese citizens from traveling on its national airline, aviation sources said today.   Earlier this month, the United States barred Lebanon's national carrier, Middle East Airlines, from American airports and banned sales in the United States of airline tickets to Lebanon after a Trans World Airlines plane was hijacked by Lebanese Shiite Moslems.

headline: Resignation At Genrad
abstract: Genrad Inc., which has been experiencing financial difficulties of late, said that W. Douglas Hajjar has resigned as executive vice president, chief operating officer and chief financial officer.   The company, which is based in Concord, Mass., said William R. Thurston, 64 years old, president and chief executive, would add the responsibilities of chief operating officer.

headline: Ex-Solidarity Aide Released After 2 Days of Questioning
abstract: A longtime official of the banned labor union Solidarity said he was detained by the police Thursday in the northern port of Szczecin and questioned for 48 hours before being released today.   Marian Jurczyk, a shipyard worker, said the police had ordered him to report to the prosecutor's office on Monday for further questioning.

headline: Manville Sued By Holder
abstract: In the first protest on the Manville Corporation's recently released proposed plan of reorganization, a shareholder has filed suit in Delaware Chancery Court to force the company to hold an annual meeting.   The reorganization proposal, which has been accepted in principle by a lawyer for any potential future asbestos health claimants, was negotiated and announced without shareholder participation, the committee representing shareholders in bankruptcy proceedings noted in a related motion filed Monday in Federal Bankruptcy Court in Manhattan.
